editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

div.p:
CHARLES the Second, by the Grace of God, King of England, Scotland, France and Ireland, Defender of the Faith, &c. To all Our Loving Subjects of what Degree, Condition or Quality oever within this Our Kingdom of England, Greeting. Whereas We have been given to undertand, That Our Truty and Well-beloved John Browne Eq One of Our Chirurgeons in Ordinary, ha ‚Ä¢ not only with great Art,
but at the Expence of much Time and Charge, Compiled a Book, Entituled, The Anatomy of the Glandules, with a General Treatie of Strumaes, or Kings-Evil-Swellings, and the Royal Gift of Healing; Which Performance of his is to Our great Liking and Satisfaction. That We may expres Our Approbation thereof, and give him all due and ample Encouragement for the future, We do hereby ignifie Our Royal Pleaure, granting unto the aid John Browne the ole Priviledge of Printing the aforeaid Treatie;
and trictly charging, prohibiting and forbidding all Our Subjects to Copy or Import, Buy, Vend, Utter or Ditribute any Copies or Examplars of the ame, Reprinted beyond the Seas within the pace of Fifteen Years next enuing the date hereof, without the Conent and Approbation of the aid John Browne, his Heirs, Executors, and Aigns, as they and every of them o offending will anwer the contrary at their utmot Perils: Whereof the Company of Stationers of Our City of London, the Commiioners and Officers
of Our Cutoms, and all other Our Officers and Miniters whom it may concern, are to take particular Notice, that due Obedience be given to this Our Royal Command.

closer.dateline: Given at Our Court at Whitehal, this 28th day of February 1682/3. in the Five and Thirtieth Year of Our Reign.

div.head: To the Mot Sacred Majety, CHARLES II. By the Grace and Providence of GOD, KING Of Great Britain, France and Ireland, Defender of the Faith, &c.
div.p:
THee Anatomical Exercitations of the Glandules, and Treatie of
Strumaes, or Kings-Evil-Swellings, lie protrate at Your Majeties Feet, humbly imploring Your Majeties Sacred Touch; Dedicated and Preented with all Obeyance to Your Royal Hand by

closer.signed: Your Majeties Mot Loyal Subject, and Mot Obedient Servant, J. Browne.

div.head: To the mot Noble and mot Illutrious Prince, JAMES, Duke, Marques and Earl of Ormond; Earl of Oory and Brecknock; Vicount Thurley; Lord Baron of Arclo and Lanthong; Lord of the Regalities and Liberties of the County of Tiperary; Chancellor of the Univerities of Oxon and Dublin; Lord Lieutenant General, and General Governour of His Majeties Kingdom of Ireland; One of the Lords of His Majeties mot Honourable Privy Council of His Majeties Kingdoms of England, Scotland and Ireland; Gentleman of His Majeties Bed-Chamber; Lord Steward of His Majeties Houhold; Lord Lieutenant of the County of Someret; Lord Lieutenant and Lord High Steward of the City of Britol; Lord Steward of the City of Wetminter; And Knight of the mot Noble Order of the Garter.
div.p:
AS nothing confirms a Noble-Man more Illutrious than Learning, o
this makes his Conjectures little les than Oracles: for that which comes nearet to ene, does trike our Minds fullet, and leaves the mot lating Impreions in our Memories; whereas bear Speculations, like thin and ubtile Air, do mot eaily lide from our ndertandings, and leave but imperfect Impreions of their Appearances.

And ince Solomon's Concluion is very Excellent, That it is a Miery to live, if it were to live for nothing ele, I preume to
think it my Duty as well as my Zeal to atisfie the World with the Phaenomena of Providence, in hewing the Admirable Compoure and Contexture both of the Conglomerate and Conglobate Glandules in Humane Body; wherein are illutrated their proper es and Variety of Secretory and Excretory Offices.

A ubject of very great Moment, collected from the Indutrious Sweats of the mot Learned Men of our Profeion in all the
World: The which although it may be pincht by the traitnes and meannes of my Capacity, the Author wanting Art to recommend it to Your Grace.

Yet herein he preumes the Tryal will with eae ecure the Deign of its common paage, Your Lordhip affording it Your Honourable Paport; Whoe Soul is as Great as Your Name, and Your Illutrious Nature as Generous, as Your Peron is Eminent; You evermore being allowed the Father of our Nobility,
the Venerable Example of our Gentry, and the niveral Prayer of our Commonalty.
And as Your Graces Name does carry the Golden World in it, o Your Puiant Nature does bear the Rich Pearl of Inetimable Value.

From Your Noble and Princely Loyns have iued uch Heroick and High-born Branches, of whom may be aid, Virtutem ex te, fortunam ex aliis habuerint. Their Early Titles of Fame
came into the World with them, and will continue without cratch or checquer o long as Time hall be allowed being therein.

body.p: Although I have preumed to Indulge my Pen to a coniderable length in this Addres, being too free with Your Sacred Minutes; yet give me leave to ay, The nivere hath not the like Subject for Age, Prowes, Loyalty, Learning, Honety and Goodnes.
As Truth therefore does always play above-board, and echews every Appearance of Equivocation; o that which is really Excellent needs no farther popular Etimation.

Pardon therefore my Imperfections in this my Addres, and be pleaed to reckon me in the number of thoe who pay all Reverence to Your Virtues, and Obeyance to Your Illutrious Name, the which will highly Encourage me to aume
the Liberty of ubcribing my elf,

closer.signed: Your Graces Mot Humble and Devoted Servant, JOHN BROWNE.

div.head: AN Introductional PREFACE To the Studious READER.
div.p:
THat great is the Indutry of the Bee, and rare its Oeconomy, excellent the Contexture; and very fine the thread of the Spider, wonderful the Spinning; and curious the labour of the Silkworm, every coniderate Man mut acknowledge. But when thee are compared to the Fabrick of MAN, or conidred in the hour of his wonderful Make, they mut look but as Atoms in the
Air, Rays to the Sun, or Shadows to a Subtance; for admirable is his Frame, excellent the ymmetry of his Proportion, and miraculous his Compoure, made by the Almighty as the Corollary, Navil, and Compendium of this great World, the Image of his Maker, and the Prince of all Animals. Matter and Form being his two firt Principles; His innate Heat, by Philoophers, being compared to Fire; His Spiritual parts to Air, his Solid parts to Earth, and his Moit parts to Water: The firt called Natures principal Agent in the World, carrying in it the two Engines of natural Motion and Life; the econd poeing the Animals Spirits, rare and fluxile Bodies evermore allowed boundles as to Limits, pending themelves into Liquefaction; The
third bearing in it the Bais of the four Elements, and therefore call'd by the Philoophers Primum Frigidum; Heat and Cold being as Natures right and left Hands, under whoe commands are Life and Death, Generation and Corruption.

The firt being nothing ele but an Harmonical act begot out of Matter and Form, making an individual Perfection lengthned into Continuance by a placid motion of Spirits operating in the Nutritive Juyce of the body; Death concluding both the Actor and Act, by making a Divorce between the former: Generation confirming a pecifique Form inherent in the pecifique Seed and Matter, and Corruption only dicovering the diolution of corruptible Elements already lapt into ruine.

The fourth being as Natures Mentruum, a Volatile and Spirituous Body evaporating in Humour by a mean heat, and well enough call'd Humour its elf: This Diaphanous Body of Man being much like a Looking-glas heat by the rays of the Sun, and drawn up by its likenes.

In Natures Elaboratory we may alo find three everal Offices provided for variety of ues, as in the firt, her Intruments, Veels, and Conitences, of Bodies kept and reerved in their proper places. Where we may ee Percolation made, which is a kind of eparation of ubtil Natures, the finer pirits being eparated from the groer, and this maintained by the weight of unequal Bodies.

Clarification hewn by an equal ditribution of Liquor with
the tangible parts, and by refining the Spirits themelves.
Impulion or Percuion made good by a ponderous Body put into motion.

Fermentation in its Original Particles ariing in our Bodies out of Sulphure and Salt, Sulphure being the exitence, and Salt the mater of its Acrimony; nothing entring our Bodies which do not bear a aline quality in it, and Sulphure being herewith intermixt, diolves this Salt and runs it into Fuion, the which being looned and attenuated by its Acrimony, doth diolve the ame, and o enters all the parts of the nutriments which we take into us.
A aimilation being made by many paages, Percolations, long continuance of gentle heats, and circuits of Time.
Liquefactions alo oft-times occaioned by detention of Spirits playing in the Body, and opening the ame.
Attraction acting in us like pongy bodies ending forth Air, and ucking in Liquor or moiture thereinto.
Dilatation opening every compact Body, and cauing a free paage therein.

Digetion taking its notion from living Creatures, and thence extended to Liquors or Juyces, the highet notion thereof being fetcht from the degrees of alteration of one Body into another, as from Crudities to a more perfect Concoction, which is the ultimity of the action and proces.

Maturation of Liquors being wrought up by the congregation of Spirits, whereby they are
een to gain and receive a better digetion.
Sublimation being nothing ele than the eparation of ubtil and thin Particles from thoe which are thick and feculent, making that which was once impure, to appear more clear and pure.

Calcination making for a more apt Solution abating the Acrimony, its end being twofold, as making that which was inflamable, impure, and crude; much abated, altered, and better calcined, running the ame into a more generous Liquor, and changing its corporeous nature for a more pirituous.
Fixation being the equal preading of tangible parts, and their cloe coacervation which makes them les willing to iue forth.
Concretion of Bodies commonly olv'd by its contrary, thus Ice which was congealed by cold, is diolv'd by heat, thee operations rather being the returns towards their former nature, than alterations.

Coagulation made from the reduction of thin and fluid Bodies to a olid ubtance, and this may be made good either by eparation, egregation, or comprehenion, as when the whole is run into an uniform ubtanc, by Cold or Vicidity, ariing from a aline principle, Coction or Elixation.

Condenation made good in the Jejunes of the Spirits and their impurity with the Tangible parts: Thee, or mot, if not all of them being nearly concern'd in us, I have preumed to
give a light touch upon them by way of Introduction.

In the next Office we find Natures varieties of Fermentative Mentruums, Salts, and eparating Juices, daily ued in our Bodies, and thee do bear the names of Acids, Subacids, Salines, Acreds, Auteers, Vicids, Bitters, Acerbs or Sowers, Oleaginous or oily Juices, Dulcorate, Inipids, and thoe other Juices of the Glandules, &c.

We begin with Acids, where we find that every Acidity is a very great Ingredient in Fermentation, all Acids being appointed for promoting and etting forward its journey and progres; Thus an Acid humour prepar'd in the Stomach out of the Nutriment and therein for ome eaon reerv'd, does both promote Digetion, and the ubaction of
the ame, for all Acids which are reduced to a fluidnes having their Salts advanc'd, do both promote and ait Fermentations and diolutions of the ame in our bodies, in which action both the Salt and the Sulphure with which our Nutriments were repleniht, are hereby confringed in the Ventricle and reduced into minute Particles; and hence is it that Chyle it elf thus being fermented, does get a Creamy colour by its ulphureous Particles being diolv'd with the Salts, and mixt with an acid Ferment: But then how thee Acidities do get into our Bodies, we no ways making ue of acid things, may thus be made good. We cannot live without Acidity in Turgent occaions, for there is an acidity in the Air, in which we breath, made good by a
Caput Mortuum, or Vitriol, being thereto expoed, which is een to fetch out hence an Acidity.

Gaandus and others do declare, That the Air is fill'd with Nitrous Particles, and Niter every one knows does maintain an acidity in it; in Meats and Drinks are acidities made good, and hence we need not run far to hew how Acidity happens in Man, we apparently eeing that by continual Fermentations in our Bodies, many things which were formerly weet and pleaant, or at leat temperate, have afterwards turn'd mot acid, the which may either happen by diipation of the Animal Spirits, or ome other internal caue; and this amongt Animals is not eaily found out, unles it be by a melancholy Juice, ferments of
the Stomach, or Spleen, or Pancreatick Juice, or Morning Saliva, or Spatttle; and as all Animals have their conitence from Fermentative principles, o the whole World is fill'd with Fermentative Particles; and it's the general opinion of Phyicians, that whoever wants an acid Juice, can never be allowed to diget well: We hall much enlarge upon thee acid Juices, when we hall treat of the Blood and Lympha.

Subacids take their names from their leer quantity of Acidity, and thus the Pancreatick Juice is call'd Subacid, made by the Blood and Spirits like it, paing out of the maller into the larger Ductus; and as a general remarque hereof, as too much Acidity is een a great procurer of Intermitting Fevers, o Subacids
do make a ready way for the dicharge of the ame, for o long as Choler is predominant in our Bodies, Flegm is les vicous, and the Pancreatick Juice being leened in its acrednes, this makes the more ready way for the dipatch of Dieaes.

Salines, experience teacheth us, do congregate into divere Figures and Angles, and all Bodies being naturally Saline, carce perceivable in the family of Vegetables; for Herbs have their fixt Salts from their Incinerations, and Volatil Salts are een extracted from the Blood of Animals by Sublimations; and Lixivial Salts being either fixt or volatile, do infring Acidity, attenuate Flegm, correct acid and auteer Effects, hinder concretion of Bile, correct ill Humours,
and cleane the Blood; and Volatile Salts do concenter and enervate the Subacid Liquors of the Glandules; and although an acid Spirit is not eaily ecern'd from a Lixivial fixt Salt, yet it is eaily made good from a volatile Salt; which volatile Salt may be contained in a legitimate Serum of the Blood made out of laudable Bile, in which Serum whereof I uppoe may be made an acid Spirit apt enough for framing a Matter for the Lympha; as therefore there is in the body of the Blood a laudable Serum, which may well enough be variouly changed either by outward caues, as Air, or Nutriments, or inward, by the motion of the Mind, or Body, or the like, o may thee beget and imprint a trange quality in the Lympha, by making it either
more acid, more ubaline, more diluted or aqueous, or more thick and vicid. But we hall have more occaion hereof in the Blood; all Natural Salts therefore, if they be urged by repeated Ditillations, do pas into lucid Liquors; Volatile Salts are always een white, and if they be expoed to humid air, they peedily run into a reddih Liquor, not very alt, the volatile aline parts herein vanihing, and the ulphureous parts only remaining which gives the colour; the aline parts of the Blood therefore lodge between Fixation and Volatization, then properly call'd Fixt, when it adhears to the Sulphure and terene parts, and then Volatiliz'd, leaving them both and ticking to the pirituous Particles thereof and marching therewith, as is
made good in ditill'd Spirit of Urine after a long digetion: Thus in ome meaure the aline parts in our Bodies are een to mix with the Chyle, and run the ame into digetion in the Bowels, they acting orderly in us; and then are volatiliz'd into a Nervous Juice, and planted in the middle contitution of the anguine Mas, and then being exalted by a long circulation and digetion they hereby become Volatile, and are partly joyned with the Spirituous Particles and extill'd into the Brain with them, and there become Animal Spirits, and at length turn into a Nutrimentitious Juice fit for nourihing the ulphureous and olid parts of the Body through which they pas. Salt therefore as it is allowed three tates of Fuion, Volatization, and Fluidnes, o
it acts accordingly in our Bodies, for when its aline Corpucles be mixt with the ret and made ready for diolution, then it hews it elf in the firt conception of Animals, beginnings of Fermentations, and indigeted Formations of things, and this bears the name of Fuion.
When from the firt rudiments of Motion the Saline Particles are een to acend with ome Spirit having Sulphure thereto added, this invigorates the ame and gives it a volatization.

That properly called Fluor Salis when the aline parts which were formerly collected with the Earth and Sulphure, are now aociated to the Spirit, and this knot of mixture being looned, it thereby gets its freedom, and being thus clear'd and freed whilt the major part of the Spirit
and Sulphure leaves it, it takes chief place it elf, and o is rendred inipid and free from all altnes whatever.

Acreds do hew their dependance from a Volatile Salt in concrete things, the which being diolv'd from their mixtures, do peedily loe themelves; and hence is it that ome Herbs although abounding with an acred Juice whilt green, when they grow dry they are perfectly een to loe their Acredity, as is made good in Scurvey-gras, Watercrees, and the like. Again, the volatile acred Salt being mixt with the Air in the Lungs and received into the Blood by Inpiration, or taken into the Stomach with our Nutriments, or uckt into the Body by its pores, or mixing it elf with the Liquors of the Glandules or the
Blood, doth both infect, enervate and vitiate the ame. Acreds alo in the time of Fermentation do contract the Ventricle and promote an expulive faculty therein, moving the heat with more frequent contractions, making the Pule bear a part with it, and the Blood being tagnated, does hereby grow more acred, and this runs it into Inflammation, and oft-times converts it into purulent or corrupt Matter.

Autere Acids do generally arie in thoe bodies which are readiet inclinable to Atringency, whoe Particles are fill'd with many mall prickings cloing upon the Fibres, and as it were contracting the ame: Thus we ee autere Acids do breed and produce Glutinoities of fluid things by atriction, retore both
the Tone and trength of the parts, correct and temper volatization, amend the fluidnes of Choler, hardning the Excrements of the Intetines, oft-times the mother of Suffocation, and whatever we take into our Mouths of Vitriol or Tobacco, they are een to leave an auteer gut upon our pallates.

Vicid Juices do variouly bring Dieaes upon our humane Bodies; Thus we ee that both Saliva, Pancreatick Juice, and Lympha, do err, and prove injurious by their vicidities in Hecticks, and the beginnings of Catarrhs are allowed to arie from vicid Nutriments and cold Air. Coagulation of Humours alo are een to arie from a vicid Chyle, and an Intetinal Flegm marching along in the milky veels, and its vicidity that makes
flations, keeps o cloe to the Stomach and in it, and which makes their exits thence o uneaie, and its vicous and coagulate Blood that both tagnates the motion of the Blood, and hinders the ecretion of the Chyle, &c.

Bitter Juices carry in them both Sulphure and Salt, wherein they are een very equally concern'd, and do operate in the Blood as they do in compound Liquors, where contracting a new bitternes by being either burnt in their Concoctions, or too much pent by evaporation; they do hence occaion a kind of bitter moakines which they eem to purchae hereby, and bear the ame in their whole progres.

Acerbs or tart and owre Juices generally are in their proper
nature very near in kin to autere or atringent Juices, and do hurt our Bodies by obtructing our Pores, wherein having once got entrance, they are not very readily or eaily to be thence dicharged; they bear up their tart and owre nature, and are not to be overcome with uch which are of a more weet contitution.

Unctuous or oily Juices are then allowed to be produced when the Particles of any Body are een phaerical and globular, neither bringing much diturbance, or pricking, or tickling therewith. Sulphure being herein mater in chief, and Oyl being apt to take fire, if it once aumes it, it keeps the ame up and maintains it; and the Lixivial Salt once joyn'd with Oyl as often as it is digeted with any acid, it produceth a notable heat;
and thus the Blood o long as Choler is cheif mater in it, is een to turn aline and oily, Oyl and Fat being accounted the two chief ingredients of Bile.

Dulcorate Juices do declare themelves by their pleaant tat which they carry in them, and when the aline Particles do grow equally together with the ulphureous Particles giving the later another nature, they are both een to run into obtue treaks; and this alchalizated Spirit and fixt Salt, of what body oever it be mixt and circulated by long digetion, does there produce and beget a dulcorated weetnes.

Under Inipid Juices, if they may o be called, may be reckoned Water, Rain, the White of an Egg, and thoe may then mot properly be o termed
when the Particles of any Bodies are not always rendred with an aperate, but with levigated Superficials, in which the principles of Earth and Water are predominant above the ret; and although indeed there's nothing in the world can really be allowed Inipid, yet thoe are generally een to carry that name which are altogether deprived of Sapour and Gut.

Thee Juices are thus een to bear concord and agreement in our Bodies, where we commonly ee Sweets and Acids very well agreeing together, and Sweets and Auteers, the firt hewn in Syrup of Citrons, Conerve of Wood Sorrel, Barberies, and the like; the later in Marmalade of Quinces, tewed Prunes, &c.
Sweets and Unctious may alo well enough agree in the Palate but not in the Stomach, they being very ubject to occaion a vomiting and naueounes.
Sweets never agree with Acred, Bitters or Salines.
Bitter Juices never are pleaant to the Palate.
Salines always agree bet with acred things.

Chyle therefore is a milky Juice like to that of Cream, prepared and excocted out of Nutriments taken into the Ventricle, and thee Nutriments are digeted in the Stomach after the manner of Fermentation and o become moit, and Chyle thence extracted. What Fermentation is we have already in brief et down, we therefore next do proceed to the caue of Chilification, and this is taken from
its propriety of ubtance, in repect of which, heat is otherwie operated in the Stomach than it is in the Heart; it takes its creamy colour from its ulphureous parts, being diolv'd with its aline, and thoe mixt with the acid ferment of the Stomach; for whatever Liquor is impregnated with Sulphure and volatile Salt, it gets hence a milky whitenes if any acid humour be poured to it. Blood is the Royal liquid Balam, and the chief Fermentative liquor of the Body; the carlet Juice whereof is made in the Heart out of Chyle for the nutrition thereof, raied out of two Juices having a Serum intermixt; Sulphure and Salt being its primary Particles, thee alo being allowed Juices when they are produced into Fuion for the Sanguinary mas;
and hence the Chymit gives the name of the Third Mercury, when he writes that there's no Body framed by Nature, but carrieth in it Mercury or Liquor, Sulphure or Oyl, Sal or Salt; Salt by Coagulation giving olidity to Bodies, Colour and Gut; Sulphure tempering the coagulation of Salt with a benign mixture, and this allows the ame trength and tranmutation; and Mercury, like an Elixir, yielding vertue, vigour, and ecrets to the irrigation of the Vital and Vegetative Liquor. Again the uperfluities of Salt are eparated by the Urine, Sulpure ecern'd by the Intetines, and Mercury the liquor of Nutriment ent into the Body; and if any uperfluous part thereof happens to keep behind, this is thrown out by Sweat through the Pores, and the Blood
it elf having its conitence from thee three principles is hence made good; for Sulphure evidently explains it elf in it by our Nutriments which we aume, which are fat, oily, weet, and ulphureous, for we ee many ulphureous and fatty parts of the Body generated out of the Blood, the which do gain their oftnes, oilynes, and tenuity from Sulphure; Salt we have from the ue of alt Meats, which we do eat, and Serum does as evidently demontrate it elf as any of the former; Vital Spirit is the mot ubtile and efficaceous part of the Blood conflated out of the ulphureous and aline parts thereof dilated by fermentation of the Heart and there united together; the colour which it is een to bear it takes from its digetions and dilatations which
are made in the Heart, for out of the permixture of the Salt, acid Particles with the ulphureous a red colour is raied, as is evidently made good in Chymitry by ditillation of Sal Niter, which contains many ulphureous Particles in it. Thus we ee Pale Conerves and Syrups, by having a few drops of Oyl of Vitriol added to them, thus runs them into a reddih colour, and if any thing of Sulphur be thereto added, it gives them a more deep ruddy tain. Thus if you mix any acid pirit with Blood, you'll find the Blood hereby becomes more or les coagulate; and this is thus made good, for if we take Oyl of Vitriol, or Sulphure per Campanum, Aqua Fortis. Regis, or the like, beides the Blood's being herewith coagulated, you'll find it changed
into a Chenut colour; if we alo take weet Spirit of Salt, Juice of Lemons, ditill'd Vinegar, and the like, whoe acid Spirits are more temperate, thee will give the Blood the thicknes and conitence of a Syrup, its colour remaining altogether unalterable and no ways injured. And hence is it that the ue of Acids does keep Man from the Plague, not becaue according to the opinion of ill Authours, they are Inciive and attenuant, but becaue they do keep up the natural conitence of the Blood, and hinder the ame, by how much it is les affected with an acid volatile Salt, or in an air in which we breath; and this was one caue which made Sylvius, in the great Sicknes-time at Amterdam, before he ever viited his people which were troubled
with the Infection, to eat white Bread dipt in Marygold Vinegar, with which Alexipharmick he o well preerv'd himelf that no Infection ever reacht him. Acids alo according to diverity of things wherewith they are mixt, are een to yield variety of colours. (And herein I mut make a little tay, the knowledge whereof being of great concern in our humane Pile, as to its Health and its Dieaes:) Thus pour an acid Spirit upon Vulgar Sulphur diolv'd in Lixivium, and you'll find its Red colour turn'd White. Antimony calcin'd with Niter or Chalk, and boil'd in Water, its limpid colature being eparated from its acid effuion will look yellow. Infuion of Galls mixt to a olution of Vitriol, makes a black Ink, and adding hereto a little acid
Spirit of Vitriol, all its blacknes will oon leave it, and it turns as clear as Water. Tincture of Violets by adding a few drops of Oyl of Vitriol or Spirit of Sulphure, turns into an excellent Purple colour. A Knife after cutting of a Citron in the middle, unles preently wiped and purged from the acid Juice of the Citron, will make it turn black. Thee verions of Liquors are alo very proper to be undertood, by which we may make ome probable conjectures compared herewith, with the Juices and Liquors in our Bodies. Admirable alo is it to ee the variety of Coagulums made by diverity of Acids everally plac'd in everal Liquors; As by adding Lemons, Verjuice, Vinegar, Vitriol, Sulphure, Niter, Sloes, Barberies, and the like, in everal
Veels wherein Milk has been put, and ee their wonderful diverity and Coagulums; all which are of near concern in us and with us, being compared to the variety of Acid, Acerb, Autere, Acred, Subacid, and the like Juices, mixing themelves both with the Chyle, Blood, Lympha, Nervous Juice, Animal Spirits, and the like, in our Bodies; and whoever examines Nature, in betowing her variety of Nourihments convenient for our diverity of Nutriment of parts, hall find that they are not all fed alike; for ome do receive greater and more ubtile digetion, others les and more incraate concoctions. And thus we ee ome parts are made aimilated out of ulphureous and aline parts equally mixt; And this is made good in the
flehy parts; other parts are rendred more Oleaginous and ulphureous as is een in the fatty parts of our Bodies; others more alt and tartareous proved in the Nervous parts and Bones.

Animal Spirits are allowed thin, ubtile and volatile viible exhalations made in the Brain, out of a few ulphureous and aline parts, and many volatile parts of the Blood erving partly for the Natural and partly for the Animal actions; and the Matter out of which they are generated, is the Arterial Blood, whoe conitence is from a alt ulphureous Juice and Serum, not of every one alike, for the Saline parts by a peculiar quality of the Brain, are in a great meaure both diolv'd and eparated from the Sulphureous; their Seroity being wet out, and o hence
becoming volatile, and o thin and ubtile, as to pas the mot minute and inviible Pores of the Nerves themelves, and are deign'd for two ubtantial ues, as the performance of all Animal actions and motions thee commonly known by all; The other is, that natural ue which is aigned them, whereby they are allowed to help forward nutrition of the Spermatick parts. And this is thus made good, for as we ee the Blood continually does flow from the Heart and by its Arteries, o the Animal Spirits do continually pas from the Brain by the Nerves, and that naturally, without any determination of thoughts or wills of ours; Nay when our wills are lockt up by leep, as is evident in leepy dieaes, wherein thee are not idle.

Lympha is a fermentatious Liquor eparated out of the erous parts of the Blood in the conglobated Glandules, not imply perfued with much fue and volatile Salt, and impregnated with omewhat ulphureous Particles, ent partly to the Chyliferous Veels, and partly to the Veins, making the one thinner by its mixture, and giving it a larger dilatation perfected in the Heart; and preparing the ame for the Venous Blood les attenuated for their dilatation in the Heart. And becaue I deign to decribe this and its ues more fully in the Conglobate Glandules, when I hall offer at the Lymphatick Juice, I hall leave it to that place. Salival Flegm or Spattle, is allowed a light fermentaceous Liquor both Serous and Lymphid, eparated out of the
arterious Blood, in the Parotides, or thoe of the Auricular Glandules, or thoe of the Fauces, Mouth and Throat, and ent thence into the Mouth by their proper and common Ductus. What it is, is hence made good, for it is no Simple Body, but a Compound Sublucid Liquor, les fluid than Water, and more vicid; It readily mixing it elf with any or all our Nutriments, and requires no great courthip to bring it into an acquaintance with whatoever we take into our Stomachs: Its ue is een of great concern in us and with us, for it readily makes an eaie Deglutition, extracts all apours and tate from dry Meats, quenceth Thirt, keeps all paages moit, promotes Fermentation when it enters the Stomach, and gives it a further Ferment
in its progres; and when it marcheth in its true order, as I have hewn in its proper place, it arieth from the erous part of the Blood, which makes the Lympha's more glutinous paage through the Arteries, and partly out of the Animal Spirits ent by the Nerves to the aforementioned conglomorated Glandules. Now a Vitious Saliva may hence be made good as well by proper as common enible qualities, and this proved by its tate which ometimes is een alt, ometimes acid, ometimes weet, and ometimes bitter; the alt part being given to the Salt Serum in the Blood, the acid to the plenty of acid humours in the Body, both as touching the Blood, as alo the defect of the Animal Spirits; the weet ariing like Saccharum Saturni in
the like Serum, it being no eaie task exactly to explain all the innumerable qualities of the Humours in our Bodies, not well undertanding the common Diet made ue of, by which thee Sapours may o readily take their variable alterations; The bitter arieth either from Choler uckt upwards, leaving ome of its reliques in the Mouth, or having ome of the ame mixt with the Serum, and o ent into the Glandules: The glutinous part hereof arieth from the flegmatick part of the Blood, or from its more fluid or aqueous defect.

Flegm is reckoned the crude part of the Blood newly made out of the Chyle, not much circulated or dilated in the Heart; and the truth is, if we will give this humour its true merit, it ought not to be reckoned amongt
excrementitious humours; it by all indeed is allowed Inipid, and < in non-Latin alphabet > , may be granted a crude humour, by reaon of its undue digetion in the Ventricle, which is both tedious and no ways anwering the others in its Concoction. The Blood alo is preternaturally concervated in the Conglobated Glandules, by reaon of its impediment of refluxion, and its firt obtruction in the capillary Veels, frequently occaioned by Flegm in the Arterial Channels, or in the Venoe interpoition, for the Blood being coagulate, is eldom een contingent; Now Blood and Flegm are een to be coagulate in the Conglobated Glandules as well as in the other parts, which makes them both unapt for motion being inherent in the Veels or their intermediate
Channels, and here topt in their progres, and dipert into the neighbouring ubtance of the Glandules, raiing the ame into greater bulk, and ditending them into Strumous Dieaes; and wherever any humour is cloely pinn'd up in the ubtance of the Glandules, making the ame more olid and compact, this breeds a hardnes therein; and this may erve as one reaon of its Coagulation concreted there, and its being a proper Nure and Matron of Strumous Effects. Choler is a fermentaceous Juice or Liquor pret out of Venous Blood and Splenetick Juice, by a pecifique digetion in the Liver it's bred out of the ulphureous and oleaginous Particles of the Venous Blood; for the Sulphureous Juice, although of its own nature
it is Subdulcid, yet being for a while Excocted with a ubaline Ferment, it becomes bitter, and is een to change its colour; and this part of Bile thus excocted in the Liver, any thin part of it remaining unmixt with the Blood, and o carried to the Vena Cava, does bear in it a fermentative quality which it gives to the Blood, the other parts thereof it ends by the Bilious Pore to the Guts; ome part thereof ent into the Veicula Fellis, where it is made both more acred and bitter, and therein requires a more trong fermentative quality: The natural colour of Choler is yellow, its tate bitter and ubacred, and its ubtance fluid, but all thee are een to take their changes and chances in us according to the temper and contitution of the Body, the
chief ue hereof being acribed to Fermentation, of which we have already writ.

Pancreatick Juice, o called when it attains the Pancreas and paeth through its Ductus, is Sublimpid, and as it were, a Salival Juice omewhat autere, bearing in it alo ome rellih of a Subacid nature; It's een as well moderate in quantity, as it appears ueful and neceary in repect of the pecifique or rather Subacid quality it carries in it; for the etting forward and promoting of the fluxion of Bile, mixing it elf therewith by its new efferveceny of the digeted Aliments, lapt from the Stomach into the Guts, and therein making an ueful eparation from that which is Excrementitious, and this efferveceny is made from the Volatile Salt
of Bile and Sulphureous Oyl, getting acquaintance with the acidity of this Pancreatick Juice. And hence hath our Health its great dependance, we having a ound Pancreas, the which being dieaed, is the only mother of many Dieaes which former Ages attributed to the vitiounes of the Spleen, Liver, Meentery, and the like parts; and whoever deires more hereof, let him perue Regnerus de Graaf, who hath a whole Book of the ame ubject already communicated to the World.

Serum, by all Anatomits, is allowed the waterih parts of our Nutriments excocted with the ulphureous and aline Juice of the ame in the Ventricle and other Bowels, plentifully betowed on the Blood, giving it its tenuity and flexibility, the
which mediating herewith makes it run through its narrow paages, wahing away its Impurities and Crudities, and dicharging it elf by Spattles, Sweats, and Urine. Urine is a great action of the Kidneys, eparating and dicharging a redundant erous humidity from the Blood, ending the ame onwards in its journey by the Emulgent Arteries, and o thence into the Renal Glandules, Urinary Fibrilla's, and Papillary Caruncles, a great part of the Serum whereof is ditill'd and eparated into the Pelvis, and thence dipatcht from the Kidneys by the Uriters into the Bladder, and what remaining of the Blood is left behind and mixt with that part of the Serum (the whole Serum not being eparated from the Blood) is thence ent out by
the Emulgent Veins to the Cava. And this is thus made good, For as the bet and mot ueful part (but fluid and endewed with a milky colour) and call'd Chyle, ent by the milky Veels to the Heart, is ecerned by the Nutriments taken into the Stomach and there fermented, and the thick and more feculent parts thereof dicharged per Anum, or the greater Guts; So out of the Chyle converted into Blood, is eparated a uperfluous part of the Serum in the Kidneys, the which may variouly be obtructed in its long journey, as by ill affections of the Caruncles, or Vicid Flegm, or Glutinous Matter, the Caruncles herewith being prejudiced, and uffer oft-times Coagulations, a common calamity uual with them.

Sweat is een ever more alt in tate, and hence this may be allowed the caue thereof, whereas that part of the Nutriment which was freh and weet being converted into Blood and Fleh, leaving this, and Sweat granted nothing ele than the part eparated and ecern'd from the former. This is een to arie more in the upper parts of our Bodies than in the lower parts of the ame, they being more plentifully tockt with Spirits. And hence may we allow the difference between heat and cold, the Pores being both opened by the one, and hut by the other, the one being but as Flame incent into Air, the other nothing more than Air condens'd.

We next come to the Juices of the Glandules, and whereas they are various, o their ues
are alo accounted divers; and here therefore are we to enquire of what uefulnes they may be accounted after their ecretion from the Blood, and of what ervice they may be to the Oeconomy of the Body; and he who examines them with a careful Eye will find it no eaie buines to make out, epecially if we look into their motions; for when the Liquor of the Conglobated Glandules is ent into the Thoracick Ducts, and mixt there with the Chyle, and to the chief parts of Nutriment, it marcheth along with the ame into the Jugular Vein, or left Subclavian, whence necearily with the decendent Blood it marcheth thus confue through the right ear of the Heart into its right Ventricle; and hence by no means allowed either
unueful or excrementitious, becaue the excrementitious humors thus excreted from the Blood, having no further concern therewith, are dipatcht from the Body; the which is clearly manifet by the Urine in the Kidneys ecreted from the Sanguinary mas, and ent thence by the Ureters into the Bladder, whence by the laws of Nature it is thence dimit from having any further concern with the Body. Thus the Juice of the Conglomerated Glandules effued through peculiar Ductus, into divers Cavities of the Body, where they are allowed neceary for nourihing ome parts thereof, is no ways to be thought excrementitious. Thus the Spattle in the Maxillary Glands ecreted from the Blood and ent forth into the Mouth and thence
dipatcht into the Stomach, is no ways to be allowed excrementitious but very ueful; as is that of the Pancreas, and the like, already made good: Now there is a great ditinction between the Liquors of the Conglobate and the Conglomerate Glandules, as I have hewn in their proper place; for Experience hews us, that out of the Conglobated Glandules, Lymphatick Veels do arie, and Lympha it elf is prepared therein; and this partly bred from the acid part of the Blood ecreted from the other part thereof in the ound Glandules, and partly from the Animal Spirits ent through the Nerves thither, and therein permixt; and as thee Conglobate Glandules in the Body are either entire or ill affected, o this ill affection
may either arie from the fault of Spirits, or the acidity of the Blood; or its ecretion from the Serum, wherein and whereby is made a permixture hereof with the Volatile or Animal Spirits: How many ways therefore this Lympha may be vitiated, no Man yet hath undertaken to hew, it being a matter not only of great difficulty, but very near in kin to impoibility; for this preparation of Glandulous Lympha, may be vitiated by being either more paring or more plentiful in quantity or quality, being more or les acid, alt or glutinous, and the like: And although I may not have followed the exact contitution of the Conglobated Glandules, yet I have demontrated ome of its mot common Maladies, made good by
Tumour, Induration and Inflammation, all which are hewn in living Bodies, for dead Bodies loe both their heat and bulk. And hence it may be granted by how many ways thee Glandules are injured, the Lympha therein receeds from its pritine tate and natural quality, and becomes both alt and acid; and out of this Lympha thus ditributed and ent through the Veels in the habit of the Body, thee being lacerated by Effuion into the neighbouring parts, do there produce Pains and Tumors, the lat being the uual product of Strumous effects. And as a Lympha in all the Conglobated Glandules is generated, o alo in the Conglomerated Glandules is another peculiar Liquor begot, carried through every of their
Cavities. Thus in the Mouth two Ductus do apparently hew themelves, called Salivales, throwing their plentiful Liquor into the Mouth, whoe ues I have already decribed. Out of the Bile, Pancreatick Juice, and Salivary Flegm, arieth that Triumviral humour which hatneth the Liquor to the Heart, and gives it its natural conitence and coagulation to the Blood, and according as the Blood it elf is vitiated, this is co-partner with it, joyns in its vitiation, and where thee or any of them are exalted, they are een to create intetine wars in us.

Now if the Glandules thus dicoured of, might be allowed Spinning or Unraveling, as it is the opinion of ome few of our late and bet Anatomits, this may very well make a Platform
for Conjecture, that any or all of either of thee Acids, Subacids, Salines, Subalines, Auteres, Acreds, and the like Liquors or Juices, may run by or between thee looe fibrous Contextures, as through o many Trunks or Channels; wherein Nature may evince and declare her times and tides of ebbs and flowes of Sicknees and Dieaes, and the better circulations of Liquors and eparation of Juices, as well traced by the Lympheducts into thee two orts of Glandules, as that of the Blood by the Heart and its Arteries, into the Veins. And from hence for ought I know, may more proper Conjectures arie how in Plenilunaries, the Brain hould be overtockt with Rheumatimes, Catarrhs, and
Cephalick Defluctions, how Apoplexies, Epilepies, and Convulive Motions hall more readily declare themelves then, and make their confident Attempts upon the Sons and Daughters of Man; how the Tydes become the preages of Sicknes as well as of Health, of Recovery or Death. If herein I may but raie a park fetcht by the colliion of conjectural Arguments, which may be invigorated and impregnated by a better and more refined Alchymit, as to their eparatory Offices, or may have hereby made any likely Eay towards the more clearing out the new tream and current of the everal paages in our Bodies: I hall think my elf extream fortunate in picking forth a tone which may be of any ue towards this great
Building. But I fear I have been too tedious in my entrance; If I find any new thing worth the Readers entertainment, that may abide the common Tet and Tryal for advance, I hall as readily promote it for publick good, and think my time well pent,

closer.dateline: From my Houe at Charing-Cros, Dec. 13. 1683/4.

div.head: To the AUTHOUR Mr. JOHN BROWNE.
div.l: WHilt your Great Galen cans each Human part,
(Galen, the Learnedt of the Noblet Art)
Its fine Contexture, Motion, Ue, Surveys,
With clearer Demontration he diplays
The Godhead; than the wrangling Schools can boat,
Whoe Reaon in the maze of Terms is lot:
Such is thy Art, Fam'd Browne, whoe Skilful Pen
Can Lym the Great Creator's pow'r in Men:
The Purple Liquor in the mallet Vein,
Which runs, like Arethua to the Main
In ecret Channels, cant ecape thine Eye,
Which does new Tracts i'th' leer World decry:
Ev'n Death begins to fear thy earching Art,
Let thou houldt find a Balm againt his Dart.
The Healing Vertue of the Royal Hand,
(Next to our King, the Glory of our Land)
Which Heaven on our Monarchs does betow,
To make the Vain, Conceited Rabble know
That Pow'r and Government, from Heaven flow;
And that there's ome Divinity in Gods below,
Is now dicover'd by thy piercing Brain,
As far as Man can Miracles explain.

div.p: ADENOGRAPHIA, Or, An Exact Anatomical Treatie OF THE GLANDULES; Illutrated with Variety of New Obervations.
WHEREIN Are Dicoured their different Ues and Offices, with their proper Names and Natures according to their Situations and Inertions.
Written by JOHN BROWNE, One of His Majety's Chirurgeons in Ordinary, and Chirurgeon of His Majety's Hopital.

q.p: Rerum iparum cognitio vera √® rebus ipis et.

div.p: LONDON: Printed by Tho. Newcomb for Sam. Lowndes, over againt Exeter-Exchange in the Strand. 1684.

div.head: The Firt Book.
CHAP. I. Of the Glandules in general, and their ues allowed by the Ancients.
div.p:
SInce Diection of man had its firt teps, as to its birth and origination from our fore-fathers, it never arrived at that perfection which it is now een to wear. Prudent Nature giving former ages her light touches barely, leaving them in their dead colour. But by breathing whiles of time he hath been both more kind and liberal;
and ome ages have more generouly received a finer draught thereof than others, fetcht by the weat and tudy of its Indutrious Sons, and not purchat but by their utmot Ingenuity. And as former ages found it no eaie task to break way for ucceeding generations, for their better arriving at this Art; o in our times we have een both the park and the flame much invigorated, appearing more bright and clear, and freed from many thick obcurities which it enjoyed in its early days.The tudy of Anatomy. This tudy of Anatomy is now viible enough to ocular inpection, whereby we may view the fabrick of Bodies both of Birds, and Bruits, and Men. But of thee we hall find a great difference between their being alive and dead. The one giving the poition, frame, ight, figure, and connexion of all the parts thereof; whilt the living mans Obervation mut adjut the account of their motions, communications, circulations, congruity or diagreement; and declare how his humours do eparate, divide, attenuate, and diget his nutriment; as likewie demontrate the everal
excretions of the various Organs thereof, as to their proper functions, both as to the advancing the Spirits, as likewie touching their eparation. Where we may alo premie, as touching things only accommodate to this preent life, That in man there are ome parts of greater ue than others, and deigned for more noble ends; others thereof being framed for more inferiour ervices; and o according to their greater or leer degrees of uefulnes, their Knowledge ought to be more or les eligible. This tudy carrying recompence in its front, is thus made good, in conidering both its excellency and uefulnes; in relation it is concern'd with the mot noble of all creatures, Man; as to his tation in this World, namely, a tate of regulated ociety and government; as alo for the better knowing of our elves, being not only ueful to us for the preent life in vi√¢, but alo proportioned to that tate which is in Patri√¢. And although in the knowledge of this Art, there are many Phaenomena of Nature which have taken up the hours, thoughts and tudy of many
learned men, who have more than with an ordinary heat exercied the ame; and as well charg'd their paions, as forc'd many diputes about it: And although its Knowledge is pleaant, curious and delightful, yet it does not yield that fertile crop of atisfaction which may reward the tudious mind. Our Fore-fathers, and Indutrious Indagators, ought to have our thankful acknowledgements, for our firt rules which we gain'd from them in this Art of Anatomy. And ince our preent dicoure tyes us wholly up to the Anatomy of the Glandules, or glandulous parts of the Body, which came into the World with the firt man, and have from his infancy, been found as o many Scavingers, to uck up all excrementitious humours, which might otherwe diorder the humane Pile, and thereby diturb the oeconomy of its parts.The nature of Glandules in general. I hall preume firt to demontrate their nature in general; they being by the mot learned ever allowed Spongy Bodies, having in them a rarenes, a fatty ubtance, not framed like other flehes, being more friable,
attaining many veels deigned in them, appearing to touch like Wool, but upon trict compreion, yielding an Oleagenous humour thence extilling. They do eldome leave the body either in icknes or in health, but do keep it company the whole age of man. When they are affected, they are generally ditempered with this trumous or crophulous malady, a dieae being mot familiar with them, whoe trumous Tumours do gain their increment from a large repletion of Humidity, collected from all the parts of the Body, paing thence hither by the Arteries, and whatoever humour is thence dipatcht and ent hither, it no ooner makes its appearance here, but is readily uckt up by thee glandulous Bodies. And this fluxion being much and morbifique (the Glandules in the other parts of the Body diffuing the ame hereinto) doth very oft occaion a Fever, and alo both enlarges and inflames them: being much like a Channel of a River, which being over-charged with Water, more than it conveniently can deliver out, it necearily breaks
over the banks, to make its elf room, and way for its dicharge.

The Glandules are more large, and do appear in greater quantity in the concave parts of the Body, than in the exteriour parts of the ame: And here (as Natures general Maxim is) we hall find that the moit parts of the Body do declare their chief abode.The chief place of their abode. And where thee Glandules alo are, and in what places thereof they are reident, the hairy parts do alo dicover. For kind Nature framed both of them for one and the ame ue, which is, to uck up the excrements they receive, and to dicharge the ame; for we hall find the hairs of the Body as readily taking up the moiture which is ent into the Glandules, and dicharging it which arrives at the exteriour parts thereof, as the glandules do take the ame into them, when it once do arrive at them. And as a certain concluion, we may affirm, that we hall eldom or never meet with either glandules or hair, in any dry part of the Body, they being here out of their proper element as well as place. And as a further confirmation
hereof, whenever you ee the Parotides, or glandules, placed behind the Ears, you will meet with hairs as their outward guard. Under the Arm-pits where are planted the Axillary glandules, you will meet the ame; in the groins, where the Inguinel glandules are planted, you will find them covered with hairs; about the privities, where are many glandules, you will find them well tored with ociety of hairs, the glandulous parts being by Nature appointed as her Scavengers,Thee parts appointed as Scavengers. and thee hairs as her Beeomes, by which he weeps and wipes up all the excrements which he ends to thee emunctuous parts, by weats and the like; all thee wholly belonging to the exteriour and uperficial parts of the Body, this dicoure in general only touching thereupon, and keeping within the outward guard thereof. Again, there are variety of glandules ordered and planted in divere parts of the Body, appointed for everal ues; as thoe which are placed in the groins,Their everal offices. arm-pits, behind the ears, neck, face, eyes, and teticles, and the like;
ome of thee being deigned for commutation of the Blood, others given to the Breats for generation of milk; ome bequeathed to the Teticles for generation of perm, and others appointed for defence of the veels, and keeping them warm, as thoe in the neck, and for the diviion of the jugular veins and arteries, and for filling up everal empty paces in the Body, as the face, neck, and mucles of the throat; ome deigned for ucking up all uperfluous humidities; as thoe of the Parotis, Axillaries, Inguens, the which are properly called Emunctories, milking and training as it were the humidities which hall happen to fall therein, for Nature hath placed the Parotides, as its Sponges, for ucking up all uperfluous moyture which hall be ent from the Brain, and hath given the axillary glandules for the ame ervice of the Heart; the Inguens performing the like office to the Liver, and he having appointed a Scavenger to every noble part, they erve to clear in their proper places, thee parts from all impurities and uperfluous humidities, which
may arie from the Lymphaducts, for thee being tagnated, according to Dr. Willis's opinion, there is very oft-times een to follow Convulive motions in the head; and in his Book De Cerebro, he further writes, where any nervous humour meets with obtruction in its paage, not only Spamodical Symptomes have thence ucceeded, but trumous affects have alo apparently hew'd themelves. But to return to the glandules: I hope there is no man thinks me o ignorant, (that is either honet to himelf, or a friend to the Indutrious) as to give this our former dicoure as a general aertion to all the interiour glandules of the Body, every Anatomit knowing they are deigned for better ues; and becaue I would not be mitaken, I hall preume to touch upon them in a general order, being reolved to expatiate more largely thereon, when I hall come to treat thereof in a more particular manner.

I begin with the glandules of the Neck,Of the Glandules of the Neck. where we hall find them very frequently eated; others there
are as neighbours to thee, and thee are the Tonillae, by ome called the Almonds, they in ome meaure anwering the hape of Almonds; but thee are there placed for their proper ues. The Head being eated above all the other parts of the body, hollowed and rounded, and gathering a large quantity of humidity from the other parts of the body, this tranmitting the ame, and ending its fumes ariing thence upwards in form of a Lymbick, the which are ent back again, by and through everal parts deigned for this purpoe, the body being all this while in a good temper, and habit, and void of all icknes, after it hath remitted this retraction, this fluxion marches to the glandules and glandulous parts no ways moleting them, unles by coming lowly and moderately; the which were this humour either much, and that harp and inflamed, it would peedily run the glandules into Inflamation and Tumour, and o ditend the Neck, and by its puruit, paing or arriving at each ear, would peedily breed diorders therein; if therefore the Fluxion
thus happening, be either Pituitous, and much, this will make an inflamation like it, and when this humour is grown familiar and common in the glandules, it doth readily form thee Struma's, or Scrophulous wellings, the wort dieae belonging to them. But where a plentiful tock of thee acrid and erous humours do appear, they do always produce Tumours, and the Inguinal glandules being herewith diturb'd by the overplus thereof, it enters them, welling and running them into inflamation, and o forcing them towards uppuration, as do thoe of the arm-pits and neck. The Intetines have alo their due health given them by meats and drinks ent thither from the tomach, after digeted, and do receive a moyture under the Cuticula, by which it is alo thence uckt up by the glandules there planted. The Head it elf is not without its glandules,The Brain by ome improperly called a glandule. and the Brain by ome (although improperly) is allowed a glandule, and by former ages was accounted nothing ele but a friable glandule; and for its ake were the ret made which it keeps about it: And
according to its large ituation, framing greater or maller dieaes than any of the other glandules whatoever of the body, they allowing that all fluxions do arie hence, as from their chief fountain; the which it doth diffue and tranmit through everal channels, which by nature are deigned for the ame purpoe. Some of which are adjoyned to the Eyes, others thereof to the Ears, and Notrils, and ome ent down by the Palate and Throat, and o forwards into the Gulet; others by the veins paing into the Spinal marrow, and into the blood it elf: All which performing their parts alike, and in good order, they do cleane and dicharge all excrements from the brain, and do tranmit every decending fume and vapour, which being topt in their current, do mot readily create a dieae, and bring the ame into the body, into which having once got footing, and thee fluxions being as it were pinn'd up, where-ever they pas not in their right order, they do give trouble to the parts wherein they enter, and pain; and pain being the common mother of inflamation,
this does peedily produce a Fever to it, commanding an attraction on the parts, and ending thee acrid influxions back again to the Brain, and there cauing exulcerations, and having arrived there, and this fluxion being plentiful, does not top here till its major parts be exhauted, and ending this collected fluxion towards the extreme parts, and they as readily receiving the ame, bringing with them an unacquainted ditemperiety, do both encreae this attraction, and o frame dieaes; both which do poil Nature in her due coure, and put her out of order, bringing much trouble upon her by breaking her intentions, and violently aaulting her quiet, by the iue of painful affliction and dieae. Thus the Brain being ditempered, and made infirm, by being robb'd of its former oundnes, doth receive many unexpected perturbations: the mind hereby becoming diordred, and the body of the Brain it elf convult, and the whole man put into a trange frame, hence producing either uffocation, or a udden change in him by Apoplexy,
Lethargy, Epilepy, and the like. And ince it is time to leave the grand Centre, and to come to its fair and trong walls, which keeps and environs it in afety, that none of its channels or paages may by any overflow caue a deluge, or diquiet any of its Rivulets in their true coure, Nature hath afely prepared many fair channels for the dicharge of the ame; amongt the which, we do firt arrive at the Eye, the delicate Intrument which gives us the difference between light and darknes: But ince in hath checquered our bet appearances, and put a dark hadow upon our whole compoition, there is found another fluxion which attends this bet friend of ours, our ight, and this by the Greeks is called Opthalmia; which hews its igns as evidently as the Sun, by its tumefying quality; and if this borrows an acquaintance with the Nares, it as readily tamps in them an Ozaena, or an Ulcer which comes not without pain, neither will it leave it without trouble; if it arrives at the Palate, and from thence creeps into the tomach (the
natural houe of Digetion) it does mot frequently occaion Dropies, and Scurvies, and other dieaes, bred from its unhappy ociety. Beides, if much fluxion doth pas by the Palate into the Throat, as it's een very oft-times happening in Conumptive perons, their Lungs are een overcharged therewith, and by getting time and abode therein, they are exulcerated thereby, rotting and poyling thoe bellows which gave the poor man liberty to breath by. Neither is this humour o kind as to work the end of humanity by one particular method, but according to its variety of places on which it enters, it acts in diverity of hapes, according to the parts on which it takes cognizance. Thus if it greets the Spinal marrow, by ending a defluxion of humours from the head thither, hereby its impetuoity entring the Os acrum, or getting about it, and its adjacent parts, it commonly brings that pain which we commonly call the Sciatica; whereby it makes all its circumjacent parts take notice of its appearance therein; and by its cloe twitches, bordring
upon the nervous and tendinous parts thereof, makes the poor patient perfectly weary of its tyranny, and by its continuance therein, unles thence dipatcht by Phyick and other proper means, it doth by degrees hrivel him that endures it, into a Conumption, by pending his vital Spirits, and making him truckle to its direful and painful cruciations. Sometimes we ee fluxions playing their parts on man, as true Gameters, working by advantage, and winning by degrees, giving time for the exercie of their diguied and deigned end, whilt at other times, like people in a paion, do hower down as a torrent, their ready wihes to their preent humour. Hence fetching upon poor mortals, as their peedy Votaries, either Delirium, Madnes, Convulions, Epilepies, Apoplexies, and the like other dangerous Cephalick Dieaes; the which once taking fire, do inflame the whole Body, and make it ready to receive any ditemper whatoever, and when any part thereof doth feel of its cruel uage, like Indian Poyon,
it takes not this alone, but calls all its neighbouring parts in to hare therewith. And nature being thus royl'd, and the glandules thus dieaed, what art and skill mut be ued for the bringing thee into their right order again, epecially in womankind, who haring in this ditemper, any dicreet man may judge; ince we hall find their glandulous parts ometimes affording Milk,The difference between men and women, as touching their temper and contitution. and denying the ame at others. Man indeed may be wrought upon in a tronger method, Courage being his Buckler; he being formed of a robut mas, his paages being more narrow than thoe of Women, his growth and bulk giving him much more trength and advantage, both as to all the parts of his body, and to his glandules amongt the ret, he being born a full and thick creature, both for ight, ervice and touch, who by his hard labour, trouble and weats, can more readily dicharge thee uperfluous excrements ent into his glandules and glandulous parts; whilt Woman by nature being made of a more delicate mas, and better temper, and o gaining a more
excellent compoition; Beauty and a fair make being her bet dowry given by her Mother Nature, thee being her bet upporters, and being made of a finer mould than man, and of a more delightful tamp, of a more rare body, and o more fluid, and ubject to the reception of humidities, living a edentary life, and deigned as an idle creature by the Almighty, and o etranged to labours and hard exercies, in her contitution as well as in her temper, being both more looe and more rare than him: yet we find although he is thus finely framed, and thus curiouly fahioned, he alo is made a partaker of this ditemper, and a great harer in her youth with mankind: Sin making both kinds as well ufferers as doers thereof. For being in their humours ometimes very harp, and thee falling in earnet upon or into their glandules, near their throats, we hall find them much addicted to alivation or pitting, accompanied with Scorbutick pains, and other Rheumatims falling from their heads, with defluxions falling in and about their teeth and other parts; and divere
other ymptomes going along therewith, which their calm nature is carce able to reit, or capable to uffer. Let this erve as a general touch upon ome parts of the body as to its glandules, we arrive now at a more particular treaty of the ame, beginning our dicoure thereof with thoe belonging to the Head, and its parts adjoined thereto.

div.head: CHAP. II. Of the Brain, and its glandulous parts.
div.p:
WE began this dicoure with thoe glandulous parts which are aid to belong to the Brain:The Brain accounted a glandule by the Ancients. And here we hall firt ee Hippoc. lib. de Glandulis numbring the Brain it elf amongt the glandules; where he writes, that the Brain is the larget of all the glandules, it being white, oft, moit, and as it were ubpingued; but they err much who conent to this opinion of his, whereas any judicious man may ee that both in its tructure and ubtance it declares the contrary; beides the dignity and ue thereof ought to gain a better opinion thereof, and the principalnes of its operation hewing better things thereof, declaring it a perfect bowel, as well as the Heart
and Liver; and hath in it, and doth enjoy its proper faculties as well as any of the other two. And in treating the Brain according to the Rules of Anatomy, we hall find the Plexus Choroides, The Plexus Choroides pun out of minute glandules. which is mot noble, and bred from the fine and thin membrane of the Pia mater, pun and wove out of the mot minute glandules and ramifications of veels complicated together, which ramifications are upplied by the urcules of the Carotydal Arteries: This Plexus ariing from the lower poteriour parts of thoe ventricles, which the branch of the Carotid Arteries do eitherways enter, the which do contitute the Rete mirabile for the Glandula Pituitaria; by this Plexus is carried the arterial blood for making of the arterial pirits, from whence by the mall glandules, and carce viible in ome, the more erous part thereof being unueful for the preparation of any animal pirits, is eparated, emulged, and collected in the ventricles, not as an unprofitable excrement, as conjectured by ome of the Ancients, but as a neceary humour prepared there for
ome ueful liquor,A threefold ue of this liquor. of which there is found a threefold ue; as by its coldnes firt, cooling and better tempering the blood paing this Plexus, and o better preparing it for a more ueful confection of animal Spirits. Next, that this flowing to the glandules of the Tonils and mouth, it there doth keep the Larynx, Mouth and Oeophagus generally moit. And a third may be this, That mixing it elf with the Liquor which paeth through the Salival Ductus, it makes up the Saliva; and hence further moving it elf with the meat chewed in the mouth, fit to be ent into the tomach, it helps forward its digetion, by its peculiarly fermentative quality, in the ame way and method as the Lympha, flowing out of the liver and glandules, by the Lymphatick Veels to the Chylifique Ductus, doth prepare the Chyle by a pecifique manner, to which it mixeth it elf. We next come to dicoure of the Glandula Pituitaria, Of the Glandula Pituitaria. and this by all Anatomits is allowed a perfect glandule, both from its ue and compoition; for it ucketh up the pituitous humours collected
in the third or middle ventricle, it is called by the Greeks
< in non-Latin alphabet > , √† coni figura; and by ome it's termed Cerebri penis: in man it's very mall, but much larger in Bruits, and whatoever pituitous matter it ucketh up, it ends down to the Fauces and Palate, by propinque cavities or orifices; or, as our Phyicians and Anatomits do write, by the venous Veels, or Lymphaeducts; and not only to the Fauces and Palate, but into all other veins, and mixeth it elf with the venous blood, as hath already been proved, by other glandules of the body. And whether this be the proper ue of this glandule, let us further examine:Its ubtance. Its ubtance being harder than thoe of other glandules, and covered with a thin membrane, brought to it from the Pia mater, proceeding from the Infundibulum: And both Man and Beat are not without it; but in a dead Corpe it's een flagging; and in dead bodies not readily opened, it is carce dicernable, as I have oft-times found in uch dead bodies whoe brains I have examined very accurately. Silvius de le Boe gives nerves to this
glandule,Nerves given to this glandule. and Wharton allows it two nerves, one on either ide, ariing from the upper part of the Spinal marrow, being very mall, and he that to view will demontrate thee nerves, I am ure will find no eaie task to make good. But to enquire omewhat further as to its ue;Its ue. it's allowed to take, and continually to receive that flegm by the Infundibulum, which comes from the third ventricle of the brain, the which ought by ome way or other to be dimit and dicharg'd thence, but there are no ways yet found out for its dicharge, or parts appointed for the reception thereof; beides, this glandule by ome is aid to be exactly covered with the Dura Mater, and firmly fixed to the Sella equina, the which membrane is never open; how therefore can this happen, when it comes by the Infundibulum to this glandule, that it can make no further progres; and hould this flow further, whether hould it tend, for there is no part near it to receive it with afety; neither can it without prejudice borrow any further acquaintance with any part. Experience
it elf doth convince, that a Serum and excrementitious humours have been found in the brain, I mean in its ventricles; and ince it is o, it will be worth time to find out by what excretory paage thee do dicharge themelves: And for proof hereof it's allowed as a general opinion amongt the bet of Anatomits, that this erous humour ent from the glandules of the Plexus Choroides, is thence extill'd into the ventricles, and this made apparent by Hydropical perons, who have thee ventricles generally fill'd with liquor; the caue of which can only be attributed to the more aqueous part of the blood, the which doth depoe the greater Colluvies of the Serum, between the Circulation, the which is till retained in the glandules, or reduced to the vein. Whereby we may atisfie our elves, that in thoe who have a more aqueous part in their Cerebrum, or Cerebellum, and o les apt for production of Spirits, this filling the veels, if herein a greater quantity of Serum be found, than can either be uckt up or contained in them, all the overplus doth
fall into the ubjacent cavity, and this declares whence and how this Colluvies is carried between the ventricles thereof; and nature here hews her care as well as her curioity, by providing everal pipes and channels for the dimiing and dicharging them, as we have already made good; planting in the front of it the Proceus Mamillares, and what he ends by them is dipatcht by the Nares, or Notrils; at each ide thereof he hath in readines the Parotides, and thee he makes ue of by the Salival Ductus. But as a confirmation of this Glandula Pituitaria, whoe Ductus is inerted to its Infandibulum, Willis does offer, that it doth uck up the erous humours, and do dipatch them outwards, which he thus does ignifie, becaue, as he ays, not only thoe falling from the brains, but thoe alo ecreted or eparated from the blood ent into the brain, it admits between the pores; being thus made good, by injecting Ink into one trunk of an artery, you will find the Rete mirabile, and very oft the inward texture of this glandule covered with a black colour;
whence he aerts, that this glandule may and can uck up into it the erous humours, the which it not only receives from the brain, but alo from the erous blood in its acent thither,A double ue hewn thereof. here being a double ue made thereof; the firt taking into it the erous humours from the brain, which is but the leat; the other which comes from the blood, being of greater exitence in its paage thither. And although we find in man no Rete mirabile, yet we cannot deny Lymphaeducts in the brain, or the like veels, which are apparently viible; and this humour thus lodged in them, is uckt up by the glandules: In this glandule, Silvius writes he hath found many mall fibres pun out of a very fine texture;Stones found in this glandule proved. and he affirms, he once found therein a mall round tone, much in bignes to a fourth part of a Pea. Vanhorn, the mot accurate Anatomit, writes, he found a tone therein in the company of many of his Scholars, which took up the better part of this glandule, the which he kept as a rarity in his Cloet. Various are the ues of this glandule, according to the
diverity of mens opinions,Various ues deigned this glandule by Authors. ome of which I have already hewn you; ome being alo very trong in opinion, that this was made for the confirming and trengthening the ue of Plexus Choroides; others, with Galen, acribing its ue to that of a Valve, hutting up and keeping in the animal Spirits; others are as ready to allow this the place of the Soul, holding all principal faculties to arie thence, and from thence to emit and dipatch its commands to the nerves, for their working its effects throughout the whole body; ome as highly declaring this ue thereof, whilt others as manifetly do vindicate other ues deigned for it: And amongt thee, Carteius aith, that the Soul is joined to the whole Body, but its chief exercitations by which it performs all its functions, he affirms do primarily and principally dwell here more than in any other part thereof. Regius Med. lib. 1. cap. 12. writes this for the Common Senory, and doth alo declare that the Soul hath no other ubitance in any other part of the Body but in this. But our Worthy Dr. Wharton
doth much doubt of this high eteem which is given to this glandule, and thinks that its proper ue may be to uck up the excrementitious humidities which may arie from the upper part of the Spinal marrow. And thus according to the various Opinions of men, diverity of ues are put upon this glandule: I hope that as they have their Opinions free, I may bring mine with as much afety,Ob. where I hall carce joyn in the Hypotheis with thoe who call this the place of the Soul, and that from thence all animal faculties do flow as from their Origination, when as we ee all Animals, let them want imagination, memory, and other animal powers and faculties, yet this glandule they have in them; and till I be better confirm'd as to the other ues given hereof, I hall preume to believe that its ue as yet is lockt up from humane knowledge, and nothing hitherto but a pure conjectural Opinion hereof has given it breath amongt men, which is tetimony enough to confirm the aertion, ince as hitherto no man hath as yet poitively affirmed its particular ue.

div.head: CHAP. III. Of the Glandulous Caruncle of the Eye.
div.p:
Why this was framed.THat tears might not always flow from the Eye, the wie Creator hath given to either Eye a glandulous Caruncle, one that is both oft, and furnihed with many mall anguinary Veels, with ome almot inviible nerves; with two others, conveying the Lympha (they being more perpicuous in Beats than in Men) ariing from the interiour part of the glandulous fleh; this covering the cavity (and by ome is called Glandula Lachrimalis) prohibiting the continual efflux of the internal liquor, the which by us is called Tears, upon their coming forth. This Caruncle being by cold air overmuch contracted, or o occaioned by any harp corroive humour,
or ulcerated, the cavity not being exactly and cloe hut up, doth not hinder the eruption of Tears thence ditilling, or their continual and involuntary efflux.Ob. Floretus lib. 2. Ob. 10. writes of a Girl of nine years old, which had tears dropt generally from one of her Eyes, which were cold, and no ways corroding the ame: this Child being of a pituitous contitution, was alo accompanied with a continual Catarrh.Ob. A econd obervation of his is alo very remarkable, where he writes, that it's uual for tears to guh from the Eyes, but for drops of blood to come thence is a matter of greater moment; where he alo tells us of a thin and lean Woman, from whoe Eyes did generally ditil bloody drops, yea, Blood it elf; her Urine being much in colour to that tincture which is made of Saffron, ave only omewhat blacker, much reembling that of thoe who are troubled with the Jaundice.
