She being askt, How long he had been in that condition? She anwered, That for about three weeks he had this bloody flux of Tears ditilling from her Eyes, and
her Body was from that time coloured with this yellowih tincture, her Eyes not being very painful to her in this condition, unles in the mornings, by reaon of this continual flux, he not opening the ame without ome difficulty, he finding ome itching alo going along with the ame, he being cotive in her Body for about fourteen days together, by the ue of Catharticks, and other remedies proper for her dieae being precribed by him, and other Topicks outwardly applied, he recovered of all her dieaes.

div.head: CHAP. IV. Of the Palpebrae, or Eye-lids, and both the Canthi, or corners of the Eyes.
div.p:
AMongt the external enes, that mot excellent faculty which produceth light to the globular orbs of our Eye is firt to be had in eteem, thee being as the windows of the mind, and meengers thereof tranmitting a great and viible part thereinto, and by the Ancients called the face of Love. In thee trong Orbits are the Eyes contained as in an encloure, or in a globular oft pillow, kept up by the afety of the eye-lids, as its coverings, keeping both dut and vapours, and every thing that might otherwie be injurious to them, and defending them from too much light, and keeping them more pure and bright. Julius Caerius hath this Obervation taken from the Palpebrae, that
they who have their upper Palpebrae elated,Ob. are commonly proud and fierce, whereas uch as have the ame depret, as keeping the Eye about half hut, to be of an humble and mild contitution and nature. Thee Palpebrae being open, they do frame two angles, called by the Latines Canthi; the outward being maller, near which Orbit of the Eye is planted a large glandule,Here is planted Glandula innominata. which ome do call Glandula innominata placed in the upper Region of this angle, thicker upwards, and thinner downwards, divided into ome lobes, and ending forth many mall Lymphatick veels, which thence paing between the interiour coat of the Palpebrae, they do break through the ame with mall Formula's, omewhat ditant from the Cilia: Nicolaus Steno being the firt which hewed the ame to the World in the diection of Sheeps and Calves heads, and the like. The inward Canthus is greater and larger, in which the aforeaid glandule (which indeed is the true glandule, and by ome aid to be more thick,) cloing the Lachrymal Foramen or cavity, either of
thee glandules do erve for the powring out the Lymphatick liquor eparated from the Blood through the mot thin Lymphatick pipes to to the Eyes,Its ue both for their continual humectation, abtertion of the horney coat, and more eaie motion of the Palpebrae. At this very day many have acribed the production of Tears to arie from the Lymphatick veels belonging to the Eyes, but they do neither demontrate the way of lachrymation, nor the veels themelves that hould tranmit thee tears to the Eyes, till Steno had given a view thereof; and in his Book de Glandul. Oculorum, he doth not badly appoint the erous humour, eparated from the arterious blood, to be the chief agent of thee Tears;The chief agent of Tears. but as to the manner and place of Separation, none before him hath given a peculiar judgement. Where alo he thinks the Blood carried through the arteries into the glandules of the Eye, its uperfluous part thereof being uckt up by the veins, the veins being truly anywie contracted or contringed (no ways permitting this) and therefore by reaon
of a more tedious delay of this plenty of Blood in the glandules, the Serum more plentifully being thence eparated doth iue forth: Now the veins may be contringed by the glandules being tumefied, produced by a more plentiful influx of animal Spirits, the which being inerted in the glandules by mall nerves, according to the pleaure or will of the Patient, more or les, as in pain, anger, joy or adnes, may dicharge the ame out of the glandules, and o move them either more or les, according to the greater or leer contriction of them. This new Hypotheis doth eem to carry in it a kind of pecious acceptance, but hath no great matter of truth in it, not being able to maintain the fountain of Tears; for if we compare the great plenty thereof uddenly flowing out, with the mall anguiferous veels of thee glandules, we mut allow it a little trange that they thence hould have their Origination, whereas the Arteries are both mall, and for the mot part inviible, which are carried to the glandules of the Eye. Again, if it might
be allowed, that in the time of adnes the Blood hould more plentifully arrive at the Eyes, and that the glandules themelves hould herewith become more tumefied, and hence alo both pres and narrow the veins, Reaon it elf mut needs contradict this aertion, for in adnes the pule of the Heart and Arteries is both mall and contractive, the outward parts growing cold, the Heart calling from thence the Blood into its own Centre, and therefore doth not o freely end it to the exteriour parts; and o alo into the Arteries of the Head, neither is there any reaon to be given, why in adnes a greater plenty of Tears or of eroity hould be thus carried to the glandules, than to other parts.Ob. Luitanus Centur. 7. Curat. 63. writes of a young Child, who to all appearance being in very good health, and yet in the interiour part of her Eye, called the greater angle, the head of a Worm began to hew it elf, not eldome occupying and troubling the Eye it elf; which ight much troubling her friends and pectators, this Worm being drawn out thence, did
equal the length of a pan, being of a whitih colour, and having a moderate thicknes; the Child received no great hurt thereby all the while it was lodged in her, nor left any evident ign of its abode, when it was drawn out. A cae certainly admirable, and therefore worthy our Obervation.

div.head: CHAP. V. Of Tears, and whence they do proceed, as alo of the Glandula Lachrymalis.
div.p:
HAving in my former Dicoure mentioned the paages by which Tears do make their deflux, thee themelves as yet by the bet of Philoophers being but obcurely decribed, hoping it may eem no great digreion, amongt the ret to bring in my mite as to the Hitory thereof, to hew how thee erous drops do decend and fall from the Eyes, and what they are, and whence hewn to proceed: We hall therefore firt introduce the Opinions of divere worthy Writers,Divere opinions concerning Tears. who have writ of the ame. Empedocles believes they are made and framed out of attenuated and eliquated blood. Joannes Baptita Scortias will have
them to arie and be generated in the angle of the Eye from the Animal Spirits, the which being compret by any ene of adnes, doth peedily ditill into water; and gives this as his reaon for his aertion, that as urin and weat are the excrements of the venous and arterious Blood, o Tears are the ame which come from the nervous juice that proceed from the Animal Spirits. But this opinion of his cannot tand on firm ground, for we hall ee many in their greatet mirth have Tears dropping from their Eyes, without any thoughts of adnes at all; neither hath adnes itelf that vigour in it to caue a tumefaction in the glandules, more than mirth, or pain, or orrow; for as to the Animal Spirits, which Steno aith, according to the command of the mind, do either work more or leer prevalently in us, and more or les paringly in the aforeaid paions, and o according to their greater or leer quantity; this hall be more clearly demontrated by our ucceeding dicoure. But to proceed, Georgius Nyenus doth uppoe that Tears do arie from many vapours carried
to the Head by the perturbation of the Bowels, and by the coldnes of the Brain being condened into water, the which is thrown out thence as an unueful excrement. Aritotle in his Problem writes that Tears are weat, or a certain vapour; and Carteius aith, that there are not parts in the whole Body which do afford vapours like the Eyes. Now as Dienters to thee Opinions, both Aquapendens and Caerius do enter the Stage, as two trong oppoers, and do as readily affirm that Tears are a thin excrement of the Eyes, bred out of the reliques of the proper digetion, and collected in the fat and glandules. Others there are that think Tears nothing ele but Serum, which is eparated from the Blood ent up to the Head; the which by a certain motion of the Spirits (the pores being thus dipoed) do caue this outward fluxion, but this goes as the former. And although Steno hath been very fruitful in his conjectures about Tears, and hath with mot excellent arguments eemed to upport the ame, yet whooever hall cloely examine him about them, hall find
that he hath not given the true caue of Tears, neither can involuntary Tears arie hence. Thus with him many others have not arrived at this true fountain of Lympha, although having filled many heets with their conjectures thereof, and likewie willing they hould pas as current. That we may eem to come and enter with a better and more true view thereof,The difference between the Lachrymal and Lymphatick humour. let us with Diemerbroeck, firt examine the difference between this lachrymal liquor, and that lymphatick humour, which is effued from the glandules to the moytning and levigation of the Eyes, paing through the mot thin Lymphatick Veels; their differences being thus hewn, the Lympid being much thinner than the Lymphid, the one flowing from the Lymphatick Veels of the Eyes, the other from the Ventricles of the Brain; a econd reaon is, this is les harp and aline, whereas Tears are to tate both harp, aline, and eroive. Another is this, being but mall in quantity, not offending the Eyes by its plenty, as do Tears, which do oft-times diorder them by their being howr'd. Again, this is
rather grateful to the Eyes than prejudicial, no ways corroding or fretting them, perfectly croing both humour and temper of Tears, which are ometimes een o corroive, that they have conumed the Lachrymal glandulous Caruncles, as we have already hewn. Thee being premied, we arrive at the Tears themelves, and their dicoure, beginning with their definition:What Tears are, and how made. And thee by mot Authors are allowed as the thin and erous particles made and framed out of a pituitous humour collected in the Brain, and thence flowing out of the Eyes;Five caues thereof. and there are alo allowed five caues which do make for the expulion of thee erous particles by the lachrymal cavities: One being the plenty of thee pituitous erous humours collected in the Brain; a econd is their udden colliquation, or trong agitation; a third is the contraction of the Brain, and its membranes; a fourth, no exact contention of the lachrymal glandule being made by the glandulous caruncle; a fifth may be the obtruction of the pongy Bone in the Nares. For the mot part two or three of
thee caues do concur, as hall be made good by the following dicoure, when we come to examine how in divere caues Tears are een to flow from the Eyes.

Tears in adnes hewn.Thus in adnes the membranes of the Brain, with the Brain it elf are contracted; and hence the erous humours of the arterious Blood, out of the ubtance of the Brain it elf, and Glandula Pituitaria, with the mall interjected glandules of the Plexus Choroidis are copiouly expreed into the Ventricles, and plentifully ent into the pongy parts of the inward Nares, by and through the narrow papillary procees of the pongy Bones, the which when they cannot readily entertain, coming fater upon them than was expected by a copious and vicid flux; the thinner and more erous particles thereof do break forth by the mall lateral Foramina, or cavities, into the greater angles of the Eyes, and o wahing them therewith, make them dicharge ome part thereof, and thus do form Tears; the thicker and more vicid parts thereof being much apter for making obtruction in the
pongy Bones of the upper Nares, and thee by degrees thence dipatcht and dicharged by the Nares and Palate, and o ent out by the mouth; and by how much the more this obtruction of the Nares is leened, by o much the more is the production of Tears leened therewith; for this being ublated, thee thinner and more erous humours decending in their paages as through the Nares and Palate, there's nothing that can hinder their proceeding in Natures appointment, and o no Tears can hence be expected, Nature going on gladly in her deigns, and unles a new obtruction be made by this vicid matter, and o puts a toppage to this her methodical proceeding, we hall find no new tock of Tears begot, nor no room left for any further commerce therewith. The ame reaon may be given for other paions;Tears in joy, and how. Thus in laughter we have een a plentiful tock of Tears have iued out, and yet not by the ame reaon as the former, for by this changing of the poition of the mucles of the Body, and the contraction of the membranes of the Brain therewith
adjoined, a great plenty of thee erous humours are expret from the Brain, and its glandules into its ventricles, and from hence into the papillary procees, the which do readily flow to the Notrils and Palate, and thee by extraordinary laughter cauing a pumous or frothy Mucus from the Nares and mouth, they at the ame time ometimes coughing, do hereby occaion and make an obtruction in the paages, in which toppage the thinner parts of this humour do eparate themelves from the more thick and mucous ubtance, and o do force their paage through the lachrymal cavities, and thence do guh out by the Eyes in the form of Tears, and becaue this concuion which thus happens in laughter doth not long continue, hence is it that thoe Tears which do thus alo happen, do not hew themelves in that plenty as they do in adnes. The ame caue may be given why young men, and uch as are given to amorous Courthip, whoe minds are not eaily converant with melancholy, being more readily reolved againt every appearance of the
ame, by enjoying the bet things they can produce or procure; they being not o eaily diturb'd by adnes, or their brains contracted, and o not o readily bearing a part in Tears; whereas we ee old men, infants and children uddenly hewing their Tears: in thee their glandulous caruncles being much drier, more inequal, and more contracted, and they being in thee both more oft and les firm, and the lachrymal cavity o weakly cloed up, that by never o mall an impule of this erous humour, it makes a very ready way for a new hower of Tears. There are many other caues of Tears,Many caues of Tears. declared by everal Authors, and amongt the ret, as a common one, is that of Onions, thee being een both a ready and eaie procurer of the ame, and this they do by their attenuating and inciing acrimony which they have in them, partly attenuating the humour in the Head, and o making it more fluxile, and partly by their tedious trouble and vellication ent from their acrimony to the Eyes and Notrils, contracting hereby both the brain it elf, as
alo its membranes, ending forth and dicharging the pituitous humours lodged therein, and dipatching the thinner and finer part thereof by the Lachrymal cavities, and by their acrimony forcing the ame out by the Eyes from their abence. Whereas Smoke, Dut, Wind, and the like, do fetch Tears from the Eyes another way, for thee do act by a painful vellication induced to the Adnata, contracting herein the Lachrymal glandulous caruncle, and o covering the cavity, the Brain with its membranes being hereby contracted by the painful ene thereof, and ending forth as well as expreing the erous and pituitous humours by this contraction, driving the ame by the papillary procees towards the Os Cribreforme and Nares, and whilt the thicker parts thereof are ent through the Nares, the thinner parts thereof do flow forth by the lachrymal cavities.Ob. Of Tears flowing from overmuch mirth. And that Tears do ometime flow from over-much joy is made good by Willis, when he writes, that in gladnes having admiration joined thereto, the enitive mind expanding it elf very much
hereat, doth mot amply diffue its Sytarii, or emiaries, as it were fearing diolution, doth preently contract it elf; wherefore in uch affect the Blood abundantly flowing into the Brain, wells up all its Veels, and by its urchage doth ditend them, and after this its tumefaction, the veels hereby being contracted, a flux ucceeds, and o does dipatch a great plenty of humour into the glandules, which is thus dimit by Tears.

div.head: CHAP. VI. Of the Parotidal Glandules.
div.p:
Where the Parotides are planted.AT the outide of the Ears are planted thick and large glandules, called Parotides, not placed jut behind the Ears, but rather under them, at the root thereof on either ide of the Head; amongt which are apparant two very large ones, the maller and foremot of which is aid to be a conglobated one, the other being pun out of mamany fragments of glandules, is both by Sylvius and Steno called a conglomerated glandule: they both are very apparent in Sheep and Calves. They are allowed to keep up the veels ent to them,Their ue. and becaue they do alo take into them the erous humours ent to them, eparated from the arterious Blood, and through which ome Lymphatick and Salival Veels
do pas, they do ometime gather together much pituitous ballat into the Emunctories of the Brain; beides thee, there are found many other glandules planted in the whole paces beneath the lower mandible, in which Scrophulous, and many the like Tumours do frequently make their abode, and thee are not called Parotides, but by Wharton more properly named Jugular glandules,Thee called by Wharton Jugular glandules. whoe number is great, and whoe magnitude is but mall. Hores are aid to have thee glandules much larger than any other creatures; and Dr. Wharton writes, that he hath diected a Hores glandule which hath weighed nine ounces, and yet was neither preternatural or tumemefied beyond its natural tate and contitution.Anatomits aign thee three ues. Anatomits do generally aign three ues to thee glandules; as firt to keep up the diviion of the Veels; econdly, to milk and uck up the excrements of the Brain; and the third is to keep all the circumjacent parts in a good moyture. The firt of thee, according to Wharton, is aid to be but of mall moment, no large veel either entring
them or paing through them, they being but capillary Veels which gives them their acquaintance and company; as in anwering the econd he thus writes, as to their ucking up the moit excrements from the Brain, this would be of great ue and weight, provided any ways or paages could be hewn or declared how thee excrements hould be brought thence hither, and o made ready for their dicharge. For in Catarrhs and Rheumatims we do appa ‚Ä¢ ently ee thee thin moit humou ‚Ä¢ s, plentifully flowing through the Nares and Palate, ditilling thither and thence very frequently by the Cribreform cavities, but none of thee are een to enter and pas the Parotides; when as therefore the excrements of the Brain do not at all reach or arrive at thee glandules, I cannot ee how they hould be any ways allowed to pas thence, a more patent way being ordered for their paage, as the Nares and Palate. And as to their third ue acribed them, thee do no more keep the circumjacent parts moit in thee parts, than in the other parts of the Body;
and till ome paage be found out, which hould demontrate their dicharge of excrement from the Brain into thee glandules, o as to afford this quantity and plenty of humidity thus dicoured of, I hall give as little credit to this ue given them, as to either of the former.

Fallopius and Wharton do give them thee two ues,Two u ‚Ä¢ s aigned by Fallopius and Wharton. as that they do ome of them receive the uperfluities ent from a hard branch of a nerve of the fifth pair, and do reduce the ame into the veins; and econdly, that they do refreh the Ears, and its circumjacent parts. Foretus lib. 12. de Aurum morbis doth tell us everal Hitories of thee glandules, as we may read in Ob. 16, 17, 18. libr. ejud. One is of a Woman,Ob. who in the ixth day of her icknes ending for him, being very feverih, and perplexed with a great pain of her Head, and her Heart vexed, where he alo had not only the Parotidal glandules, but alo all her Neck and Throat well'd; he eeing this inflamation thus encreaing with rednes, a Chirurgion, who being formerly called to her, and he being
then preent alo, anointed thee inflamed parts with nguentum Nutritum, and that very inadviedly truly, his duty rather being to dicus than repel the morbifique matter, which gave firt being to this large tumour and inflamation; but Foretus coming to her and applying Cupping-glaes, with Scarification to her Scapula's, and uing uch remedies ‚Ä¢ s were mot proper in her cae as are decribed by him in his Obervat. 16. he recovered of her icknes, and beyond all hopes, was reduced to her former health.Ob. A econd of his is of a Woman troubled with a red face, being made of a anguiolent temper and habit, about thirty years of age, who in the glandules about her right Ear, had a large and red tumour; he being ent for to this Woman, and conidering, he being feverih, and much troubled with this pain, which continually dwelt in the affected part, and knowing that it took its origination from Blood thus plentifully entring thee parts, by convenient purging her Body, veneection and the like Remedies ued, and other external Topicks adminitred,
her Fever ceaed, her pain mittigated, and he perfectly recovered. A third he hath, Ob 18. Itius Libri, Ob. which is of a poor Woman, who having a looe and aedematous tumour, eizing the glandules about her right Ear, made of thick and vicid matter, without much pain or Fever, upon his coming to her, not eeing any great plethory of Blood in her, he in this cae made ue of no venaeection; but for the leening of this pituitous matter, ordered uch things as hould give a better digetion thereto, by precribing her purges and pills, and attenuating decoctions, and the like; and by the ue of proper medicines to the affected parts, he both uppurated the tumour, and by Cautick opened the ame, cleaning the Ulcer, afterwards filled it up with new fleh, and produced a cicatrice to the recovery of the Woman, &c.

div.head: CHAP. VII. Of the Jugular Glandules. (Wharton.)
div.p:
THee had their nam ‚Ä¢ s given them from Wharton, Their names given from th ‚Ä¢ ir places. where having their habitation and abode near the Jugular veels, he gave them the name of Jugular glandules, as you may ee Cap. 19. Adenogr. where he writes, That in a Body diected by him there were found fourteen in either ide thereof, and one above the ret omewhat longer, omewhat disjoyned from them, (lodging on either ide at the root of the Styloidal proces, between the mucles of the Neck and the Jugular Veels), ome of thee are larger than others, and do vary in their magnitude even from the malnes of a Coriander eed to the largenes of a Pea, as he there tells you. Some of thee are planted in the fore-parts, others in
the back parts, ome in the upper parts, others in the lower parts thereof; the upper parts thereof do reach even to the Styloidal proces, and to the lower and back part of the Mandibles; the lower thereof do decend near the ides of the Thyroidis, between the Spine and Thoracick veels, and Thymus into the Thorax; and in uch who have arrived at ripe age, this is taken by ome for the Thymus. In Sheep and Calves, and the like creatures, thee glandules are een to be very numerous, running from the Throat to the Diaphragma, and o do decend even to econd eries of the vertebres of the Neck and Thorax. Their colour. They do bear the ame colour of thoe of the Neck, ave only that they are omewhat redder which are planted downwards, thoe more pale which are placed above.Their ubtance and figure. Their ubtance and figure do no ways anwer thoe glandules which are placed about the Neck, Thighs, or under the Armpits; they eem to belong to the reductive glandules, and are made for the ame ue,Their ues. as for the reducing the uperfluous humidity of the nerves,
which they receive into the veins and lymphatick veels next to them; and this is commonly een in thee maxillary glandules, and in many others planted hereabout, framed for the exonerating and dicharging of the uperfluities of the nerves every way, and therefore whether they do depoe the ame either into the veins, or into any other parts by them, their ue is of the ame nanature in repect of the nerves: And that which is worthy note,Struma's and wellings do mot frequently happen here. is that Struma's and Scrophulous Tumours do mot generally happen in thee glandules and the neighbouring glandules, becaue thee with them being any ways obtructed, they do not perform their uual office, and o give a ready way for the preparation and make of thee aid Tumours, as I hall more largely demontrate in my econd Book, when I hall hew the difference between Struma's and Scrophulas, as to their Species and Originations.

div.head: CHAP. VIII. Of the Tongue, and its Tonils.
div.p:
THe Tongue in Latine called a Lingua √† Lingendo, being the Intrument both of Speech and Tate, and the help of ending down both meat and drink into the Stomach, is placed in the mouth under the Palate; and this in its upper part hath in it omewhat of a glandulous fleh lodged under its Cutis; inwards and downwards it's een perfectly muculous, and does every way hew the ue of its mucles. Arantius will have the Tongue a glandule, although improperly. Arantius is one who will have this to be a glandulous part, and if we may credit him, he doth aign its compoition to be framed out of three various ubtances; for immediately under its membrane, there's omewhat of a pulpy ubtance about its root epecially, the other ubtance of the
Tongue is framed of mot thin and implext fibres, amongt which is planted fat, peculiarly proper for keeping them moit, and making them more fit for ue, and this may be one great caue why he was o ready to give it the name of a glandule, and this his aertion he is ready to confirm with thee three arguments: As the Tongue hath in its ubtance all kind of fibres, and thee o intertext, that they cannot be divided one from another, as may in other mucles. Secondly, There's no ligamental fibres planted in the Tongue for its trength; as is in other mucles. And his Third is, No mucle tateth, but the pulp of the Tongue is the intrument of Tate, as Piccolom; and therefore Arantius affirms that the Tongue is no mucle, but a glandule.The Tongue proved to be a mucle. But we on the contrary hall find that the Tongue's flehy part is muculous, when as in all the differences of animal motion, to the mot ubtile vowels, yllables, and pronouncing of Letters; all which do mot uddenly expres the conceptions of the mind, never tired in their motion, being either contracted,
dilated, doubled, or laterally moved, according to the minds pleaure performing all its actions; and without this were a mucle, and had others joined in conent therewith, thee laudable motions were not thus to be performed by it. But our dicoure at preent not being concern'd with mucles, I hall hew Dr. Wharton's Anwers to Arantius,
Wharton's Anwer to Arantius. where he firt convinces, That the fibres of the Tongue do evince it to be muculous; and that its ubtance, for the mot part thereof is muculous, which appears from its various motions which it performs, and the variety of its fibres o diverely intertext, do only uffice for the diverity of its motions. Secondly, it's no ways neceary that every Mucle mut needs have a Tendon, but that which hath a flehy beginning may have the like end. Thirdly, That Nerves do pas through its whole ubtance, and this is perceived in a Hemeplegia, in which is een very oft one part may be ound, and the other perplexed with a Paley. And then latly, the muculous part of the Tongue doth not tate, but the membrane which
does cover its glandulous pulp, epecially near its root; and thus by the intervention of this membrane it takes notice of all apours. Thus much of Dr. Wharton.

Of the Larynx. The Larynx is formed of divere parts that it may freely enjoy its office modulation of the voice, and this requiring a continual tream of moiture to afford it common liquoring,
Several glandules given to it.
Two very large ones at the root of the Tongue. it hath everal glandules placed as Sponges for its collective ues, amongt which are two very large ones, conpicuous at the uppermot eat of the Larynx, or rather at the root of the Tongue, one on either ide; and thee by the Greeks are called < in non-Latin alphabet > . lodging in the narrow paages of the Fauces. By the Barbarians they are commonly called Amygdalae, yet no ways carrying in them the likenes or figure of an Almond; in Latin they are called Tonillae, and at this day do bear the Englih name of Tonils amongt us: They are covered with the ame coat as is the mouth, and are indued with mall Veins and Arteries, ariing from the Carotid Arteries and Jugular veins; and, as Wharton
aith, although in ound Bodies they are les protuberant, yet in a morbid body, where thee are much inflamed or tumefied, they do carry a good reemblance of an Almond; and hence it is preumed they had this name given them. They are looe and pongy in their nature, and are of a imilar friable ubtance, much reembling Honey and Oyl concreted together by cold, ave only they are more firmly adherent as it were by a membranous connexion; oft to touch, but being boyled, hard: for upon their boyling, they do loe their poroity, and o become indurate: they have various Ductus's,They have various Ductus. and thee proper to themelves; they have one Sinus, both large and oval, on either ide opened into the mouth, whoe skirt doth obtain two large ones, and much leer cavities; in the ame manner are alo many protuberancies, like little Papillae or Teats, dipert through the glandulous root of the Tongue, every of which have their proper perforations allowed them; and out of thee various Foramina is a Mucus ent forth, dipoed thus by the root
of the Tongue, where thee glandules are mot thick (the mouth being opened) doth end the ame by their common cavities into the Throat; and this cavity in an Oxe will admit the entrance of a little finger into it. Fallopius hath oberved, that ometimes the opening of this great Sinus doth in ome meaure repreent a mall Ulcer, and is oft times treated and taken by the inexpert Chyrurgion as the ame; this oft-times hapning in the mouth by a plenty of Tumours falling into this glandule, and o cauing it to give its thus patent appearance, as hall be made good by ome Obervations thereof at the end of this Chapter:Two more under thee, next to the lower part of the Larynx. Under thee Tonils are planted two others, next to the lower Region of the Larynx, one on either ide; at the ides of ome of the firt Annulars, or Rings of the Windpipe, thee becaue they are guifted with many mall Veins and Arteries, do carry a more bloody and olid ubtance in them than other glandules, and do reit the Knife in diection more than others. There's much controverie about the ues of
thee glandules,A Controverie about their ues. ome uppoing they are framed for moytning the Larynx outwardly with a vicous and pinguid humidity, and o making the Cartelages more apt for motion; but becaue there is not much need of them for this ue, I do uppoe they may more properly give aitance to the Salival veels; others, with Riolan do affirm, that they are framed for collecting the humidities which are ent thither from the Brain; and with him do allow that thee were here planted for preventing the fall of the ame upon the Lungs; and that this may appear omewhat probable, he enlarges upon the blowing of the Notrils, and in ucking in of the Palate, by which we find a kind of mucous limy matter or pittle coming thence, which mut necearily proceed from the Brain; o alo he uppoeth that that which enters the Tonils, may alo ditil and fall from thence, for in uch creatures who do want thee glandules, as Peacocks and the like, who alo want Teeth, nor do not chew their humidities, in uch it doth immediately fall into the cavity of the mouth, not
into the Thorax. Again, if the excrements of the Brain mut firt necearily fall into the mouth before they enter the Lungs, and then into them likewie; thee Tonils will make nothing for their ufflamination.Four ues allowed by Wharton. A econd ue which ome do attribute to thee glandules is, that they do convert the humidities ent to them from the Brain into pittle: Againt which aertion we offer this objection,What the humour is which is ent into the mouth by them. The humour which is thus ent into the mouth by the glandules is not pittle, but rather ome mucous and pituitous matter, not much unlike that which is dipatcht by the Notrils, and what difference this carries from pittle, every man may eaily judge: but of this more fully, and more properly when we come to the Salival glandules of Steno and Wharton. A third ue given to thee, is to keep the Tongue moit, and all its circumjacent parts; this ue may be allowed them, the humour coming from them naturally being mucilaginous, and therefore mot proper for keeping the parts mot lubricous; and moreover, the mall Lymphatick veels or Salival veels, as alo the mall
cavites of the membrane of the mouth may very well allow the ame, epecially when the Mouth and Tongue are moved, the which every one may experience in himelf when he pleaeth. And hence when the nutriments are chewed in the mouth, partly pontaneouly, partly by the maticated nutriment, this liquor thus expret out of the glandules doth much more plentifully flow into the mouth, both for the framing a better mixture, ueful for the fermentative preparation of nutriment, as alo for a more ready and more eaie deglutition of the ame: In ret therefore when the Mouth is not moved, and when the effuion of this liquor doth alo ceae, as is generally een in thoe which are aleep, the Mouth and Fauces do oon become dry, being robb'd and deprived of this liquor, epecially if they do leep with an open mouth. A fourth ue is, That they do help Tating, the Which cannot be done without moyture; of which Opinion our worthy Wharton is, who allows thee the primary Organ thereof, the moiter parts mot relating to pitting; both which do much contribute
towards the extraction of the tincture of meats, as alo towards a plentiful matication; and o may more properly be allowed to be framed for the purpoe of Tating or Gut's ake. For dry things, without having ome tincture in them, are altogether unueful as to tate; when therefore the mucilaginous humour is les fit for the extraction of Tincture, and alo les proper in matication for mixing with the meats, how far this may make towards tating, any one may judge; but how far it may conduce towards a gut, when it is as its proper Organ, is already decribed by him. The true ues hereof, allowed by Wharton, are thee five,Five ues allowed by Wharton. which I hall only name: As Firt, he declares thee glandules the primary Organ of Tate; where he alo writes, That in all parts of the Mouth in which Tate is perceived, this glandule by its intervening membrane doth act the ame; Nature never interpoing between the gift which is to feel, and the Organ it elf which feels it; when as therefore the part is een every way exercied in Tate, this approaches near the gutile object,
and this is neceary that it hould be the intrument of Tate, and if it be the intrument, it doth thence convince its gift, which is by him called the firt ue thereof. The Second ue allows them as an excretory Intrument, its office being to eparate ome mucous and pituitous matter, falling from the lower part of the Brain, by the nerves epecially; thoe of the third pair ditilling and flowing thence, partly from the anguinary mas effued by the Arteries, and o refunded into the Fauces and Mouth, as is already decribed by him; but this is readily refuted by Diemerbroeck, when he writes, That whereas Wharton doth ay that thee glandules (without all reaon) are endued with a notable ene, and that they are the true and primary Organs of Tate, and uppoeth that the pituitous matter flowing from the Brain to them by the Nerves, (as if thick and vicid matter could pas through thee minute and viible pores of the nerves o plentifully) is a thing which requires not great difficulty to refute, he allowing them to be a great productive towards this
faculty of Tating. A Third ue of thee glandules he allows is, to moyten the Fauces, Larynx and Tongue, for their better and more eaie repiration, that the voice hereby may be more ound, and that deglutition may thereby alo with more eae be performed. His fourth is, That in plentiful Catarrhs of the Brain, the Notrils at this time being obtructed, part of the matter being imbibed into their pongy ubtance, may hence be dipatcht and dicharged by the mouth. And his lat is, That by its fermentative faculty, the liquor which thence comes into the Mouth, and o entring the Stomach, doth therein promote digetion; by whoe acidity alo it doth contract the ame, the which doth chiefly tend towards the promoting a fermentation, and is the chief caue thereof.

Hitory 1. Langius Epitol. 7. Tom. 2. tells us there of a Noble man, who being afflicted with a continual Cough, ariing by a Stone concreted in his Tonils; Phyicians uing all drying Remedies, in hope of topping his Rheum, which they upected was
the occaion of his Cough; by the ue of which the Mucles of his Larynx were much tumefied; by Langius his advice, Emollients and uppurating Medicines being precribed, the Tumour began to grow oft; and a trong Cough ariing hence by this ditillation, did herein frame a kind of Lime-tone, much like to the Chalk-tone or Tophies which are uually een in the Joints of thoe which are troubled with the Gout, ariing chiefly from glay flegm.

Joannes Jeenius alo writes of one,Hitory 2. who having a Tumour in his Tonils, o as that he could carce breath, or wallow any nutriment, who having made ue of many drying Gargarims made of Red Roes, Balautians, with Roch Allome, and the like; and not well mundefying the whole, by which the thinner part was dried up, whilt the more Terrene part thereof was left remaining behind (the which do frequently happen in Aedematous Tumours) this grew into a Chalky and Stony ubtance, the which advancing in hardnes, and encreaing in bulk, the Mucles of the Larynx being herewith
extended, his breathing grew more difficult, and a ditillation thence ariing, by his trong cougheing, the patient forc't out the Ston- which was lodged therein, and his Spirits very peedily recruited, and he himelf uddenly retored to his former health.

Hitory 3. Foretus lib. 14. de Aegritud. Lingu. Ob. 26. hath this Hitory of a Woman about 23 years of age, who for a long time having much pain about her Mouth, near her Chin and lower Mandible, under her Tongue, in the Muculous parts thereof, and about the root of the ame; Peter Frederick, the Chyrurgion, who viited this patient daily for ome time, and perceiving a hardnes till continuing, did hope that he might bring the ame to uppuration, the which he endeavoured by a cut Fig, applying it to the place; the tumour beyond expectation growing more oft by the ue hereof, at length did break, whence iued a little Stone, omewhat hard, and forc't it elf thence without any inciion, the bignes of a Hael-nut; this being gone, all pain uddenly ceaed, no uppuration,
or Sanies or matter followed it; and that which herein was worthy of Obervation was, That the lips of the wound healed up without any help of Medicine. Soon after which, he writes he aw jut uch another coming out from thee parts, omewhat larger than the former. And

Diemerbroeck tells us a Hitory of a Woman of Breukelens, Hitory 4. who in the year 1659. in the month of April, upon eating of Damask Pruines, which had been boyl'd, and upon her over-ready wallowing one of them, the Stone thereof pat into the mouth of the great Sinus of this glandule, whence the glandule immediately tumefied, in that meaure that it hut up both the paages of her eating and drinking. So that in four days after the ick Woman could neither eat nor drink, he being ent for to conult her ditemper, her Tongue being kept down, her glandule was een very much tumefied in- the right ide, but little inflamed, and this apertion already dicoured of, more than ordinarily opening, not eeing the Pruine-tone; he after
taking the Decoction of Barly, with Syrup of Marh-mallows mixt together, he ordered her to uck it into her Mouth, and putting his Thumb to the outide of the tumefied part of the glandule, and trongly compreing the ame, commands the Woman with her utmot trength to wallow down the ame which he had put into her Mouth; the firt liquor, upon her thus endeavouring, threw it elf forth by her Notrils; but upon the econd tryal, when his Thumb had made a coniderable compreion outwards, and keeping the Tongue down and inwards, this tone flew out of the glandule into her Mouth, preently after which he wallowed both meat and drink very well, as he formerly did. And the ame Woman, he alo writes, in the year 1664. had the like michance happened to her again upon eating of tewed Pruines, in the month of May, whoe glandule catcht into it another Pruine-tone in like manner as the former, which was cured the econd time, but with more trouble. Another like cae happened in the year 1661. in the month of December,
upon a certain Citizen,Hitory 5. who upon eating of Cheee, and having a piece of hard cruty Cheee fallen into this cavity, hindring his whole wallowing; this Cure did not ucceed, he tells us, with the ame eae as the former, but took many days tryal before this Cure could be effected.

div.head: CHAP. IX. Of Wharton's Salival or Maxillary Glandules, together with Steno's new Salival Glandules.
div.p:
THe Mucles being removed, beides the two longih and round glandules, bordring at the beginning of the Aeophagus, are planted many other flehy Glandules, and conglomerated out of many others, as Glandules, Lymphatick Veels, Arteries, mall Veins, and Fibres of the Nerves under the Tongue, about its Bridle, bringing a continual Mador or Dew by the mallet Lymphatick Veels to the Tongue. Moreover, out of either ide from this great and large glandule, which carries in it the ubtance of the Thymus, or very much reembling
the Pancraeas of Man,The ublingual Salival Ductus. coagmentated out of many mall frutles of Membranes and Veels joined together, doth proceed a certain Ductus or Pipe, planted upon the middle Tendon, between the flehes of the Digatrick Mucle, the which from its ue hath the name of the Salival Ductus given it. And although this was unknown to the Ancients, and kept in the Clouds in former times, yet this by Glion and Wharton is now brought into an apparent light: yet this was not altogether kept from all the Ancients, for we may read that Avicen lib. 3. Fen. 6. Cap. 1. calling thee the two Salival effuories, keeping the Tongue moit. Galen alo lib. 11. de uu partium cap. 10. hath thee words of them, The Tongue being dry, cannot effect its motions but very lowly, Nature therefore againt this hath wonderfully provided, that it might not readily be urprized with this affect; and in order thereunto, hath at each ide of the Larynx eated carnous glandules, erving as Sponges to collect moyture for the Tongue's ervice. Both thee Ductus's, as they
do carry the form, o alo they do bear the ubtance of Veins, but are omewhat thinner, having no great cavity, larger in Man than in many Beats, and yet in them eem larger in ome than in others. On either ide doth arie one out of the aforeaid glandule,Whence they do arie. having many mall Originations paing into one Ductus or Channel, acending obliquely upwards from this glandule, and carried even to the middle of the mandible, planted between two mall glandules, the which having pat, it marcheth directly on towards a Nerve of the eventh pair, the which having arrived at and omewhat beyond it, it ends near the Frenum of the Tongue, about the ditance of a tranvere finger from the Teeth, and is opened into a peculiar glandule, the which by ome is called Ranina and Hypoglottis, inveted with a thin and porous membrane, planted under the Tongue on either ide, near the Ranine veins; between the fleh which tyes the Tongue to its neighbouring parts, and the glandules ubtrated at the Bais thereof, being there planted as two oft Sponges,
for imbibing the Salival liquor which thus comes from thee Channel pipes, and o receiving the ame into them. Beides the aforeaid Ductus, Two others lately found out. there are two other placed, one on either ide, found out in the year 1661. and hewn that Year in the month of January, by Jo. Vanhorn in the publick Theatre at Leyden, and thee he call'd Steno's Ductus's, he being the firt which demontrated the ame; thee ariing from the great glandule at the root of the Ear on either ide: Thee Steno calls the conglomorated Parotidal Glandules, the which being diected, many mall branches thence ariing, are een to pend themelves into thee Ductus's; they run outwards to the center of the Mucle called Buccinanator, and do end in the cavity of the Mouth. Beides thee,Other Salival veels. there are ome other mall Salival Veels conpicuous in the Mouth, epecially in the Palate and Cheeks, of which we have already dicoured in our former Chapters. Des Cartes his ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ inio ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶
‚Ä¢ out the Origi
<‚Ä¶> of Sp ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ . Des Cartes eems to be unacquainted with thee Salival paages, when he writes that this pittle doth arie from the Stomach;
and as a guard to defend his aertion, he brings this reaon, That ome parts of the arterious Blood do fall into the Stomach and Guts, the which do there perform the office of Strong water, in promoting the digetion of nutriments; and from thee being hot, he ays vapours may eaily acend by the Aeophagus into the Mouth, and by this method allowed there to form this Saliva or Spittle. Now whereas it manifetly appears that this Salival Juice or Liquor does proceed from the Head and its glandules, and whatoever does acend from the Stomach doth readily occaion vomiting, the which doth not readily happen in this Salival juice: When as alo in pituitous perons, and old men, whoe Arterial and Venal Blood is both cold and mall in quantity, as to the upply of all parts, and alo falling hence to the Stomach, from whence a mall quantity of vapours may be allowed to acend from thence to the Head by the Aeophagus; this Saliva cannot be mall, but mot plentiful; and this doth ufficiently deny Des Cartes's argument and prepoition.

It therefore remains,The true Origination of Saliva. that this pittle doth not pas and acend by the Aeophagus, but that it doth fall from the upper parts downwards into the mouth; and ince this flux is een o plentiful, our next enquiry hould be by what veels it hould make its paage, and to what glandules it is thus ent and dipatcht, and how out of the ame dicharged into the Mouth. Wharton writes, that the ame doth ditil out of the Nerves, but thee having no uch, ufficient paage in them for the ready dipatch of the ame, how can thee properly be allowed its proper Intrument? In this therefore his opinion carries not much vigour; ome others there are who do uppoe that the ame is drawn from the Chyliferous veels; but thee not reaching o far, I cannot ee how they can defend their aertions. Deuingiu ‚Ä¢
his opinion hereof. Deuingius doth uppoe that this is poured out from the Lymphatick Veels into the glandules, and from thence to be ent into the mouth; which opinion, although it may carry a fair reemblance of truth in it, yet certainly both the Lympha and Saliva,
although they do not much differ in ubtance, as to their thicknes, yet they have the ame Origination, and do both arie from the Blood it elf; and ince this is not done by the venous Blood, as drawn from the glandules and other parts, yet this eparated liquor may well be granted to arie from the Arterial Blood, becaue the Arteries do infue the Nutritive Blood to all the parts of the Body, and amongt the ret to thee glandulous parts alo; whoe more erous and ubaline alival parts being mot fit for giving nutriment to the glandules, with the admixture of Animal Spirts flowing through the mall Nerves, is eparated from the other particles, and uckt up by the glandules, and in them by a pecifique manner is there omewhat digeted, and brought into another manner of preparation, and whatoever is there redundant from their nutrition, is indued with a light kind of acid quality, and this is that which falls thence into the Mouth by thee Salival Ductus's, as in other divarications of the Arteries, o alo in thee glandules the
Arteries are een to obtain but mall pores or paages, by which they do depoe this liquor into thee glandules, and this large and great Salivations do prove, be they either Spontaneous, or made o by Art, in which uch a large plenty of pittle is dicharged, that nothing but the Arteries could yield them uch a upply; and it's alo very credible, that thee do take into them the uperfluities of ome Nerves, as I formerly have hewn, and do tranmit the ame into the next Veel, as it is the uual cutome, amongt everal of the glandules: And when by chance a greater flux than ordinary is made by the Nerves to the face, than can be prolated by the habit of the part, and this remitted by the Lymphaducts to this glandule, the Face hereby is apparently een to well, and blown up, as it were tumefied by an aedematous tumour, as we find it frequently happens in uch who having had pain in their Teeth, at whoe farewel we have commonly een the Face to well very much. And ince we have apparently hewn how this Saliva doth pas from the glandules
into the Mouth, our next enquiry will be, to find how it's eparated from the Arterious Blo ‚Ä¢ d, and alo declare what this Salival Liquor is. Spittle therefore is a light fermentacious erous and lymphid liquor,What Spittle is. eparated out of the Ar ‚Ä¢ erious Blood in the Parotides, and in various glandules and glandulous flehes of the Mouth and Fauces, effued by the Salival Veels and other Salival paages into the Mouth:The qualities of Spittle. As to the qualities of this Saliva we find little hitherto hath been written as touching them, nevertheles if we well examine them, they will ufficiently hew that this is not a imple body, but a compound and lubricous, a liquor les fluid, but omewhat vicid; and yields no pumoity out of it elf, but gains the ame by the motion of the Air and of the Tongue; of it elf it hath neither Sapour or Odour in ound perons, the which in ick people it readily entertains from their dicray of humours, and mixtures of other humours therewith: It's no eaie matter to decribe its exact and ingular compoition, the which notwithtanding is very admirable; for it
joyns it elf with all orts of nutriments, and there is nothing which enters the Mouth, which it takes not notice of.

Its ues are various and admirable,As to its u ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ , being much and good. as 1. Me ‚Ä¢ ts being chewed in the Mouth and this mixt therewith, it gives them a more eaie deglutition, without which they being dry, would not without much trouble pas the ame, as is een in Fevers, and the like. Secondly, This takes out the oporiferous quality from dried meats, that is, the apid Salt, which is not to be done without moiture. Thirdly, It extinguiheth thirt by giving its moiture, whence it is that great pitters are eldome dry. Fourthly, It moitens the inward parts of the the Mouth, Fauces, Aeophagus, and the like; and then alo it promotes fermentation of the nutriment ent from the Mouth into the Stomach, and is its primary ferment, being as a light acidity tempered with a Volatile Spirit in plentiful Water. Some Phyicians do make this difference between Sputum and Saliva, The difference between Spittle and Saliva the firt they undertand to be a thin humour redundant in the Mouth
with trouble, uch as is uually ent thither by Catarrhs, or generated by any corruption of the Saliva, or thrown forth by coughing out of the Lungs: By Saliva, they do uppoe the natural liquor not uperfluous in ound Bodies, nor excern'd, but mixt for the moytning of nutriments of the mouth, neceary for the preparation and fermentation of Digetions, as hall more fully be dicovered, when we hall treat of the Liver.

Sometimes it happens that thee Salival Veels are cut, as have been een in wounds of the Cheeks, by which there is perceived a plentiful tock of lymphatick Salival liquor to iue out thence, and by this its continual flux, it makes the wounded part not eaily curable;Obervat. as happened to a Noble-man, whoe Cheek being wounded by a piece of Glas Bottle, the wound being almot cured by the Chyrurgion, ave only in its middle, whence iued a perfect and continual gleet, which continued for about fourteen days (the which pat by this Salival Ductus, unknown to the Chyrurgion) he not with his utmot skill being able to put a top thereto;
by conulting better advice, and by application of an actual Cautery thereto, it peedily topt, and the patient uddenly recovered. Aquapendens relates jut uch another tory.

div.head: CHAP. X. Of the Thorax, and the glandulous parts thereunto belonging.
div.p: THe Trunk of the Body is that we call the middle Venter, and this is that cavity which is upwards circumcribed with Clavicles, downwards with a Diaphragma, on either ide with the Ribs, forwards with the Sternon, and backwards with the Bones of the Back; in this, and under whoe command are planted the Breats, the Pleura, Mediatinum, Heart, Lungs, Thymus, Larynx, Aeophagus, to which alo is annexed the Neck as its appendix. We begin our dicoure of the glandules here with the Breats.

Of the Breats.The Breats both in Men and Women are two in number, planted over the Pectoral Mucle, and covering
it; in Man they are maller than in Women, they being their proper intruments for lactation; and thee do encreae with their years, and in ome Countreys they are een to grow to a prodigious largenes, as in divere parts of the Indies, and the like. In ome Women thee have been o large that they have been een to uck their own Breats; in others alo the Child hath lodged ucking, as if he had laid between two Pillows; they generally do obtain an Hemiphere figure, and a oft and whitih ubtance, being framed of many glandulous Bodies, whoe largenes are alo various, having everal channels and pipes ent to them. Riolan and Wharton,
Riolan's and Wharton's opinions refuted. againt Autopia or Ocular demontration, do write that the Breat is nothing ele but one whole glandule, no ways diviible into ditinct globulars; and yet they do declare that in morbous Bodies they have een thee ditinct conglobated glandules: The which if in icknes, I am ure mut alo appear in uch as are in health. One great glandule is placed in the middle of the Breat, the
ret being but mall, beides which, infinite plexures of the Milky Veels are interjected amongt thee glandules, the which mediating, not only the Milky Juice is carried to all of them, but the maller glandules do alo effue this Milk into the larget amongt them. Again, in thee glandules are many large and copious pores, in which, as in o many mall Cells, is the Milk reerved, till the time of its being uckt up, unles it doth flow out thence of its own accord, by its over plentifulnes or thinnes. The Nipple is planted upon this great glandule, the which is a fungous mall Body, inveted with a thin Cutis, and perforated with many pretty Orifices, the Lacteal Ductus doth terminate in thee glandules, and the Milk, as through a pipe, is let out thence, at the infants ucking the ame. This glandule is of exquiite ene, and carries and gives pleaure in the ucking or contracting thereof, by which both the bulk of the Breat is leened, as alo its weight.The glandules of the Breats allowed five Veels. The glandules of the Breats have five veels allowed them, as Nerves ariing from the Intercotals,
plentifully arriving at the Nipples, giving them the ene which we ee they do obtain. Secondly, Arteries for their nutriment. Thirdly, Veins appointed for bringing Blood towards the ame, the which in Nures ometimes having too much thereof, this is carried from the Breats to the Subclavian Veins, even as the Chyle is carried by the Thoracick Ductus; and being numerous and great, for they do not only carry the remaining Blood, collected from the Nutritive, but in uch alo as give Milk, they do dicharge part of the redundant Milky Liquor to the Subclavians, the which is performed by thee Veins. The Fourth are the Milky Veels, and the Fifth the Lymphaeducts betowed upon them. Thoe Milky Veels are perceived by the Arteries and Veins being variouly interjected in the glandules of the Breats enated from the lower part, and meeting together in the Center thereof, whoe communion and continuity with the Chyliferous Ductus lodging in the Trunk of the Body, hath not till of late been found out by the bet Anatomits,
they not being conpicuous; the Chylous juice not remaining in them, nor more detained in them than the Urine is in the Ureters, but by the compreion of the repiratory Mucles, and thoe parts through which they do enter, it's eaily propell'd, and through thoe that it paeth. Neither is it much to be wondred at, that thee hould not plainly hew themelves to the light, when as the Thoracick Chilifique Ductus it elf being large enough, running according to the length of the Spine, hath never till of late been found out by the mot accurate Anatomits; nor by them could be demontrated, the which in our days appears as clear as the light it elf; the ue and reaon of the carriage of thee to the Breat may very well grant the ame, although denied and obcured from ocular inpection. Antonius Everard Tract. de Ortu Animal. oberving a manifet deduction of the Milky Veels in a ucking Whelp, thus aith, That ome of thee Ductus's do arie from the decendant trunk running about the Abdominal Mucles under the fat, and that the glandulous ubtance
of the Breats did carry the matter of Milk in them, the which having manifet pipes framed for them, doth convey this Milk into a common channel, and this is thence uckt out by the Nipple. And Pecquet, anno 1654. before Riverius, found and hewed in a ucking Whelp, near her third upper Rib a Milky channel reaching to the Breats, from whence a great plenty of Milk ucceeded; which experiment he hath very oft hewn in young ucking Puppies; and as this of Antonius is found in Whelps to arie from the decendant Lacteal Trunk, o in Women they are een to arie from the acendant Thoracick Trunk, planted at the Breats in the Breat. The which happened in a Scriveners Wife, who,Hitory. after her having lain in about a month or five weeks, and having received a fall, complain'd of the little Milk he had in her Breats, and that if her Child hould uck with any trength, he felt a great pain decending from her Breats even to her Back, and about the middle region between her Scapula's; but omewhat lower he eemed to well,
and began to perceive ome pain about her loins, the which upon the Infants not ucking, he perceived nothing thereof: And without doubt this happened by reaon of ome impediment which hindred the tranition of the Milky Veels to the Breats; and hence this Suction being made in the upper part thereof, a plentiful Chyle not ucceeding from the Thoracick Ductus, this pain was excited by the ame Suction collected from the Breats even to the Thoracick Ductus, he never having any great quantity of Milk coming thence, o that the Child was forc't to be put out to nure. Let this erve as one Hitory, amongt many which might be introduced as to the confirming the ame. And this may uffice to confute all uch who do uppoe that the Chyle is not carried to the Breats by the Milky veels, but by thoe Arteries which with the Blood is conveyed thither, and from thee again eparated from the Blood, and o turned into Milk.The ue of the Breats. The primary ue of the Breats is to breed and to form Milk, and to prepare the ame as proper nutriment for the Infant. Milk
it elf being a weet and white Juice prepared in the Breat for their proper nourihment. I hall not here enlarge as to its frame and make, being by ome allowed to be made of Blood, and others of Chyle; many other Authors having pent much time in giving the Rudiments of its compoition; my task more cloely relating to the glandules. All our bet Anatomits allowing its generation to proceed from Chyle, and this the ubtance of the Chyle doth very well et forth, there being no great matter of difference between them, either in their ubtance, apour, or colour. And how this Chyle is converted into Milk, hath as yet but by a very few been demontrated; all the glandules of the Body being deigned for one and the ame ue, that they may take into them ome Lymphatick humour out of the Blood (as Saliva in the Mouth) and perfue the ame with omewhat of a ubacid quality; and this is given both to the Blood, to the Chyle, and to other humours, for their better and more ready eparation. And becaue
ome may quetion the truth hereof,Milk generated from Chyle. by asking if this be true, that Milk is generated from Chyle, and not from Blood, how happens it that in a large flux of Blood, the Milk doth leen in its quantity, or grow defective? To which I give this as a ready anwer, Milk is not always deficient on this occaion, if the Woman eats well; and when this is deficient, this happens becaue Nature is more intent in taking care of, and providing for a greater neceity, as to the retauration of the Spirits of the whole Body, by calling and ummoning in all the Chyle to the Heart, and converting the ame to Blood; and doth end none of it, or if any, but a very mall quantity thereof to the Breats. And uch who do defend the Milks origination to proceed from Chyle, do trengthen their aertion with thee reaons: That they do uppoe that the Chyle is either directly carried to the Breats from the Milky Veels,The defence of the aertion thereof. or firt received into the Veins, and circulated with the Blood by the Ventricles of the Heart, and o thence effued by the Thoracick Arteries into the
Breats, and there the anguinary part ecern'd from the Chylous, and this reduced by the Mamillary Veels into the Body. And that this is Milk it elf, and kept and reerved in the poroities of the Breats for the Infants ue. The firt ue hereof is defended by all Patrons of Anatomy, but the crowning this demontration, and confirming the aertion, would better appear when they would pleae to hew the peculiar Veel, by which the Chyle hould be thus tranmitted to the Breats.

Chritus √† Vega Comment. ad Aphor. 39. lib. 5. Hipp. writes of a young Woman of Bruges, Hitory. whoe Mentrues being obtructed he had Milk in her Breats; the Phyician to whom he was committed (did clear her from the blame which was put upon her by her Mater, and) did excue her modety, by affirming that a Woman might have Milk by the retention or her Mentrues, without conception, he having out-lived above nine months in this condition, he hereby both hewed and declared her honety and chatity, and o kept up her reputation; and in a few days
after her Mentrual flux broke upon her, and he continued well.

Hitory. Braavolus Com. ad Aphor. 26. lib. 3. Hip. writes, That he hath een trumous Tumours in the Breats of Women; and he further declares, That he hath not only een the ame in Women, but alo in the Breats of Men; and in the year 1537. in the Month of April he had for a patient a certain Woman, which had Scrophulous Tumours, which accompanied almot every part of the Body, even to her Groins.

div.head: CHAP. XI. Of the Thymus.
div.p:
THis alo is a glandulous Body,Is is ditinguiht with a threefold glandule. oft, pongey and white; this part in Infants is ditinguihed with a threefold glandule, and eems to carry omewhat of affinity with the ubtance of the Pancraeas in uch as are of riper years, but much thinner. It's annexed in the upper part of the Thorax to the diviion of the Subclavian Veins and Arteries, greater in Women and moit Bodies, than in Men and dry Bodies, it's of a delicate tate, and ofter than the Pancraeas. Wharton writes in his Adenagraph. Ob. that he aw in an Abortive about ix months old, the Thymus annexed to the Pericardium, in its lower part, and being thence bifutrated under the Clavicles decending out of the Thorax to the
ides of the Trachea. In Calves it's een adherent in the lower part to the Pericardium, and encreaing into a greater bulk, paing up to the Thorax, divided, and decending on either ide of the Trachea, running to the Maxillary glandules, and ometimes to the Parotides.

Nerves given to this. Wharton doth attribute Nerves ariing from the ixth pair to the Thymus, the which he uppoeth do throw forth the nutritive liquor, inquinated either by ome impurity or acrimony,He herein refuted. for its depuration ake into this glandule. But this entence of his is trange, for the Milky Veels which are in thee glandules can carce be any otherwie found out than by the inpection of a Calf newly born, or nourihed with Milk, as thee that are interjected in the ame manner in the glandules of Milky Breats, which he takes for Nerves, and decribes for the ame. And he oberves not what juice the Thymus doth carry in it for the nourihing of the Foetus, as whether it be Chylous or Milky, as Harvey ha ‚Ä¢ h it. The which Juice doth not pas thither by the Nerves, but by
the Milky Veels, and here made more perfect, and o tranmitted thence to the Cava, and from thence to the Heart; and this Juice, becaue in young people, by reaon of the over-drynes of their Milky Veels that way tending, ends none, or if any, very little thereof to the Thymus; this part in uch being either much leened or contracted, as is een in the Breats of Women, when they are dried up from their Milk. Wharton alo writes,Lympheducts paing through this p ‚Ä¢ rt. That he hath een Lympheducts frequently paing through this part, and thence dicharging themelves into the Subclavian Veins; neither can it be dienting to reaon, when as in the preparation of the Lacteal matter, this Lympha is required for the promoting and forming the fervent fermentation in the Heart.This allowed a conglomorated glandule. Regnerus de Graaf calls this a conglomorated glandule, and in his many vituline diections (in which he hath found this glandule always large, yet that which he ever oberved thereof, that it is not les leened in Calves than in other Animals after their Nativity) and that he hath found a notable
Ductus in it, repleted with Lymphid humour, which he hath accurately traced; but being never o curious in his laying it bare, this liquor did generally flow out of it, and the Ductus wholly vanihed, before he could attain its exit, and forc't to try ome other means to find out the ame.

Of the Heart.The Heart although its call'd the Sun of the World, and the principal commande o <>
‚Ä¢ he vital actions, yet Vealius
<> , ‚Ä¢ hat he hath een the left Sinus thereof to have in it near two ounces of glandulous fleh. Tulpius writes he hath found a pituitous Polypus in the left Ventricle of the ame; the which I alo found in the diection of a young Gentlewoman, when I lived at Norwich ome few years ince. It was the Opinion of the Egyptians to meaure the life of Man according to the weight of his Heart; and this is both made good by Terence, and confirmed by Diocorides. Hitory. Vealius lib. 1. cap. 5. de hum. corp. Fabric. writes of a young Noble-man, in whoe left Ventricle of his Heart was found two pound of glandulous fleh, omewhat blackih;
much like that of the Womb, extended in that greatnes, that it manifetly declared the contraction of the Artery, and with this thus he lived many months: About his cloing up his lat ands, both his Animal faculty, with the principal functions of his mind continued very well even to his lat minute, and that which forc't this change upon him, was a Gangrene which eized his left ide in his Leg, the which bringing a further toppage upon this Arteries pulation, did oon put out his Candle. And Dr. Walter Needham declared in one of his late Lectures of Anatomy at the Chyrurgions Hall, that he aw a trumous welling hanging at the cone of the Heart, that weighed two ounces.

div.head: CHAP. XII. Of the Aeophagus, or Gulet, and its Glandules belonging to it.
div.p:
BY the Latines this is called Gula, being as the only round pipe and channel, by which both the meat and drink which man takes into him for his nutriment and utenance doth pas, and ent from the Mouth into the Stomach. This alo is furnihed with glandules both oft and pongy, appointed here for keeping it moit, and as ome are appointed for the keeping the inward parts thereof lubricous and humid, which we have already demontrated; o for the keeping the outward parts thereof in the ame temper, Nature hath planted two lower glandules in the back part of the Aeophagus, near
the fifth Vertebre of the Thorax;Where thee glandules are planted. (in that place where the Aeophagus gives way to the great Trunk of the Aorta, carrying it omewhat to the right) and very oft-times they are o much hid between the Aeophagus and the Vertebres, that without much care and inpection they are not to be found out; they carrying in them omewhat of a Kidney in reemblance, cut in the middle, being inwardly convex, and outwardly concave; they do borrow their veels from their neighbours, as Arteries from their next Arteries, and their mall Veins which they have, do come from their next Veins, as well as their Lymphaticks, conveying the Lympha thence into the Lymphatick Thoracick Ductus. Wharton writes that they have Nerves alo ariing from the ixth conjugation, but whereas they do neither feel, nor are moved, thee Nerves thus aid by him to be allowed them may be well enough quetioned by other Anatomits, they more readily being taken for Lymphatick Veels, which he writes for Nerves. Some Anatomits do write, that thee do not only moiten
the outward part of the Aeophagus, Their ues. but do believe that they do bedew the inward parts thereof for a more eaie deglutition. But this is none of their proper ue, for there's no uch need of their outward irrigation, neither is there any tranit made from the glandules towards the inward cavity of the Aeophagus. Their proper ues. But their proper ues allowed by mot are, that they are here planted for the collection of the Lymphatick liquor, and to gather and uck it up from the neighbouring parts, and o to effue the ame by the Lympheducts with the Chyle, as I have already demontrated. Thee glandules ometimes are een to well o much by reaon of affluxion of humours, that they do treighten and make narrow the Aeophagus; and thus keeping back the meat and drink from going in their right paage into the Stomach as its proper nutriment, by this famine and thirt they do rob and deprive mankind of thoe principles which hould keep him from the grave.Hitory. Foretus lib. 1. Oberv. Chirurg. fol. 95. Schol. 276. writes that he aw a Beggar, whoe whole Breat, Neck and Shoulders
were altogether trumous, uch an object he was, that the like thereof he never aw in his whole life. Another of Foretus is of a Struma in a Mans Neck,Hitory. which equall'd the bignes of an Egg, who fighting with another, was wounded in this part; his Father Jordan Foretus viewing this Patient, aw living Lice lodged in the wounded part: This man who for many years had this Struma in his Neck, no Chyrurgion daring to undertake his Cure, upon this accident having occaion to make ue of a Chyrurgion, both his Wound and Strumous Tumour were by chance cured at once, and he dicharged from his lowie companions.

div.head: CHAP. XIII. Of the Omentum or Kell.
div.p:
WE now arrive at the glandules and glandulous parts which belong to the third Venter, and having there laid bare the Mucles and the Peritoneum, the firt we meet with in this Region is the Kell called Omentum quai Operimentum covering the Intetines, it being a thin and double membrane, much reembling the duplicature of a pure, ariing from the Peritoneum, outwardly covering both the Ventricle and Guts; in its forepart it's tyed to the bottom of the Stomach, and to the Spleen, in its back part to the Colon; perfued with much fat, and plenty of Veins, and is therewith intertext like a Net. This Omentum, as Velingius writes, is accompanied with variety of glandules, and thee not
alike not placed alike in all perons,This is accompanied with variety of glandules. ome having more thereof than others; planted here for collecting and gathering up, like Sponges, the uperfluous moit humours which hall arrive here. Riolan writes he could never find any glandules in this part; they generally do appear but mall, and that in the lower part thereof next to the Pylorus, and to the Spleen. Wharton alo writes that they do much reemble the glandules of the Meentery,They are aid to reemble the Meenterical glandules by Wharton. and are deigned much after the ame manner, and for the like ue; and in his 12 Cap. Adenograph. he writes that he found two glandules in the Omentum, Two large ones found by him herein. one being large, not much ditant from its commiure with the Pylorus; this glandule receiving into it the Milky Veels of the firt kind, ariing from the bottome of the Ventricle, running in the Omentum according to its length; and they are ditributed into the ubtance of this glandule, as other Lacteal Veels of the firt kind, and others ariing thence are carried downwards to the right end of the Pancraeas, and at the firt view would be thought to enter it; but paing
by the ame, they march on to the common receptable, and do dicharge themelves into it. The other omewhat les, is planted near the Spleen, and this hath been een doubled and trebled, and ometimes manifold; he there tells you he hath een it in a Hore, as twelve large glandules, whoe Spleen did weigh ten pounds. But this may be attributed either to preternatural effects, or their number viewed to multiply and encreae in morbous Bodies, as in Strumous or Scrophulous dieaed Bodies, they not o evidently appearing or hewing themelves in Bodies that are ound; as hall be made good by divere obervations of Hildanus and others at the end of this Chapter; and where any of thee do thus ucceed, they mut fall upon the adventitious glandules. For in the Omentum, Various preternatural effects hown in thee glandules. as alo in its glandules, various preternatural effects do evidently hew themelves, their dieaes ariing from one and the ame Origination, and do for the mot part bear the ame caue, whoe dependancy comes and proceeds from Obtruction. Hence is it that this is ometimes een to arrive
at uch a montrous bulk, as Authors have writ it hath been een to receive, and to receive thoe unuual hapes and forms, which dieaes are readily een to put upon it. As a truth of its running into a very great bulk,Hitory. Fabritius Hildanus doth tell us of a very remarkable Hitory thereof, happening in a Woman, who being opened after her departure, her bowels were een very healthful, excepting her Kell, the which grew and encreaed into uch a vat glandulous bulk, that whilt the Woman was alive, it made uch a greatnes about her Belly, as uually is een in Hydropical perons; this bulk was every way membranous, but inwardly glandulous, adipoe and Scirrhous, in its middle was found a fetid cavity which was filled with ordid Sanies, weighing fifty ix pounds, and was taken thence without injuring the other bowels, and was een wholly tyed to her Stomach.

Another of his obervations of the Omentum is of a young Gentleman,Hitory. about nineteen years of age, propoed by Hortius in his Obervations
lib. 7. cap. 4. the which ometimes by the commotion of the Body, moved out of one ide into another: But in this peron this large Tumour was fixt, and was oberved to tend towards the Navel, in an orbicular form, the breadth of the palm of the hand conglobated with many glandules. Bartholine writes that he hath een a Kell altogether flehy. Wharton writes that he aw a Kell wholly flehy, or rather glandulous, brought to him by Dr. Wybard, Hitory. taken out from a Virgin of nineteen years of age, who for near three months before her death was troubled with a Diarrhaea, as alo a frequent vomiting of porraceous matter, whoe pule was languid, her urine mall and intene, her Belly about the Navel being hard and tumefied, being afterwards perplext with hortnes of Breath, and drynes of Tongue, and a Fever thereunto adjoyned; three days before her Death he was much bound in her Body, and her Urine wholly uppret: The dead Body being opened, the Liver was een of an ill colour, and the Bladder of Gall furnihed with black liquor, her Kell,
as I aid before, was thick and almot coraceous, o as it did as it were contract all the Bowels in its Latitude, the intetines as it were glewed o to it that they were not eaily eparable from it. The Hitory declares the obtructions of the Bowels of this Maid, the Omentum it elf grown hard, and as it were infarched with thee glandulous flehes intead of fat, and for certain her being urprized with this Fever before her Death, was the nearet caue both of her extenuation, as alo of her Death. In Scurvies the Kell is een frequently to appear friable, as appears by this following Hitory, writ by Wharton of one Mr. Beale, Hitory. who being very melancholick, and afflicted with the Scurvy, and drinking plentifully of Tunbridge Waters, upon his return to his Houe, he oon changed his Life for Death; the Body being opened, Dr. Bathurst and Dr. Ridgley being preent, the Omentum was een both black, lacerated, friable and almot putrid, and detitute of fat, adhering in many places under the Navel to the Peritonaeum, with black and turgid Veins,
the only true igns of Obtructions. Sometimes the Kell is een to be removed out of its place, as by falling into the Scrotum, as alo in the Epiplocele, or by an umbelical rupture, as in Omphalocele, of which Columbus doth make mention.Hitory. And Vealius lib. 5. cap. 4. de corp. hum. fabr. thus writes, he hath een more than once the Omentum fallen into the coat of the Seminal Veels, and in wonderful manner to well therein beyond its natural contitution: as when the whole part of the Omentum omewhat falling upon the Intetines, hath carce weighed a pound, or half a pound, yet herein he aith he aw the Kell o preternaturally well'd, that it weighed four or five pounds, and by its weight did draw down the Stomach from its natural place, and by this weaknes various Hiccoughs thence ariing, he collected thence that this weight was the occaion of the mans death who was thus troubled.

div.head: CHAP. XIV. Of the Meentery, and of its glandulous Affects.
div.p:
THe Meentery, which by the Greeks from its ite is called < in non-Latin alphabet > ,It hath many mall and oft glandules. which is placed < in non-Latin alphabet > , or in medio intetinorum, hath many mall and oft glandules lodged in its membranes, whoe number are various, not only in divere pecies of Animals, but alo in various individuals of that pecies.Where few in number great in magnitude. Thus in Man where they are found fewet in number they get it up in their magnitude, all which are appointed by nature for the better attenuation, and greater perfection of the Chyle, as is ufficiently manifet; for by and through thee do both many Milky Veels and Chyle pas, affued into them for the greater perfection of the glandulous humour, embrewed with
