ome ubacid and light faculty, and ent out of thee into the great middle glandule, by Fallopius and Aellius called the Pancreas, and by mot Anatomits at this day called Pancreas Meenterii, although improperly; the true Pancreas being more truly planted under the Stomach, and thus by right and hort Ductus's carried on to the Receptacle of the Chyle, into which they do lighten the Milky Juice.Ma ‚Ä¢ y dieaes ariing hence. And this both Reaon and Experience doth evidently make good; for hould thee glandules be any ways obtructed, or the liquor bred in them neceary to be mixt with the Milky Juice, it would oon turn acid, and o the Milky Chyle abiding herein would as eaily curdle, and coagulate like Cheee, and by its plentiful influx they would readily tumefie, and hut up as it were the Chyle, and hinder the ame from any further paage: Whence we have een uch as have thus been troubled and dieaed to have a Caeliacal flux econd the ame (and this occaioned by the hindrance of the Chyle's ditribution) as alo a pain of their Bellies going along therewith.
And by reaon of nutriment thus being denied its proper paage, an Atrophy hath necearily followed, the which at length pends thoe that are thus afflicted, even to death it elf. And this hall be made good by many Examples, which hall conclude this Chapter. By all which it will appear clear enough when you have read them, that both a Celiacal flux, as alo an Atrophy may both hence arie from obtructions formed in thee glandules, and that thoe general ues betowed on them by Anatomits, as their erving to prop up and keep warm the Veins and Arteries dilated through the Meentery are altogether invalid. But herein we may affirm,Its ue. that in thee as well as in other glandules, there is bred and begot omewhat of a ubacid fermentative liquor or juice, mixt with the Milky Chyle, and this they do keep and reerve for the Milky Veels; and thee uffering any injury hereby, or gaining any ill contitution hence, uch as is frequently caught by a vicious ferment which is admixt to the Chyle in the Duodenum, oft-times this
proves a great caue of a large Colluvies of bad humours, of mall conuming Fevers, of various contumacious and tedious affects, kept and upheld between the membranes of the Meentery.Various opinions about the Meentery. Various are the Opinions amongt Authors about the Meentery; ome thinking it is the ink of the body, to which the whole Colluvies thereof do make its conflux. Hence Fernelius writes it the caue of Choler, Melancholy, Diarrhaea, Dyentery, Cachexy, Atrophy, of Fevers, and of Melancholick Dieaes, of Cholick pains, and of various Tumours and Abcees, thee parts being very ubject and obnoxious to michiefs, and bearing the very frequent blemihes and ufferings of our intemperance.

p.note: How thee may be obtructed five ways hewed by Wharton.
p.U:
hews five ways how thee Veels may be obtructed, which are thus: Firt, in their entrance of the Milky Juice into the Orifice of the Milky Veels. Secondly, in their paage by and through the glandules of the Meentery. Thirdly, in the tranite of the Blood out of the Arteries into the Veins, and from them into the ubtance of the glandules.
Fourthly, in the aqueous and lymphatick Veels; and Fifthly, in the Nerves. Firt, if obtruction happens in the narrow paage of the Milky humour, the Chyle is not attracted out of the Intetines, whence follows a dejection of Appetite, and the Chyle it elf frequently, as happens in a Lienteri√¢, is evacuated per anum, and the Milky Veels being detitute of the warmth and moyture of the Chyle they uually had received, in time they grow parcht, and o runs the whole Body into Conumption. Secondly, if obtruction of the Chyle happens, after its entrance into thee Veels by the glandules of the Meentery, it caueth firt a leening of the nutriment, and o conequently produces an Atrophy. Thirdly, if the paage of the Blood be obtructed by thee glandules, and o alo with it the Chyle loe its paage, thee do both leen the nutriment with their obtructions. Fourthly, if it happens that the Lymphatick Veels be obtructed, which are very frail, and o eaily rent, and o letting out their liquor into the cavity of the Abdomen, hence
uddenly an Acites does certainly follow. And Fifthly, if any obtruction hould happen in the Nerves which are ent to the Intetines, there would oon ucceed a reolution thereof; as is frequently perceived in a Paley; and here for certain there mut necearily follow a diminution and extenuation of nutriment, if not an Atrophy of the Spermatick parts, the vital contitution being entire and trong enough. Compreion of thee Veels ometimes do alo make them narrow, as ometimes does happen in inflations both of the Stomach and Colon, in Cholick pains, and alo in ome wellings of the Meentery; and here we may ee Tumours of two kinds, Windy and Humoral, as Wharton hath it. The Meentery becaue it wants cavity is eldome ditended by Wind. Tumours,Three caues of Tumour in any part of the Body. happen in what part of the Body they will, they do demontrate three epecial caues of their product, as afflux of the matter flowing to the place, its tranition impedited, and their felling; for where there is no afflux of matter there can carce any caue of Tumour be expected; thus
in dead Bodies we meet with no Tumours, becaue in thee all afflux of humours do then ceae. Tumours with inflamation do argue ome putridnes of matter going along in the well'd part, and many of thee inflamations are allowed to arie in Dyenteries ill cured: Tumours without inflamation, putridnes and Fevers are various, and thee do take a long time for their growth, and thee do frame Chronick ditempers, of this ort are reckoned Abcees, Atheroms, Steatoms, Meliceris, Strumae, Schirrhus, and the like. Riolan doth place the root and foundation of Struma's to be lodged here, and doth declare that no Struma's do break forth and hew themelves outwards, till the Meentery be firt fill'd with its Scrophulated glandules; after whoe opinion Guido eems to be a follower, affirming that Struma's have no further affinity with the glandules of the Meentery, only allowed for a further preparation of the Chyle; neither can Struma's be aid to have any caue or origination in the Meentery, when as every days ue thereof doth teach
that mot trumous people being ound in the Body, have uffered many troubles ariing from this Meenterick dieae: of which opinion Wieman alo is, when he writes, That whenoever the outward glandules do appear tumefied, we may afely conclude the Meenteries to be o alo, they uually being the firt parts which are attacked with this malady; Which opinion of his Anatomy doth very much confute, for I have diected everal trumous Bodies, whoe Meenteries have not been tumefied with glandules, and yet I have opened others which have been plentifully fill'd with the ame, but this will not keep up his general opinion of the Meenteries being the firt part attacked with this ditemper; All which is contrary to the Curative method,This aer-contrary to Anatomy. the which for the mot part is performed by Topicks, the which can no ways be allowed available here, if the fountain of this evil hould be in the Meentery, and this is manifet in the diection of dead Bodies who have dyed Scrophulated, in whom ome of thee have been found to have had their
Meentery no ways toucht with the ame; and therefore Riolan's opinion mut necearily meet with reproof as well as the other. In Wharton de Adenograph. you will meet with a Hitory of a Woman there cited by Paraeus, Hitory 1. whoe Meentery was well'd with an immene tumour, which weighed near ten pound and a half, outwardly Scirrhous, in which was very many abcees, included in their everal bags, as you may read more at large fol. 49. eju. Libr. Diemerbroeck doth produce three Hitories very much relating to this preent dicoure, the which I do intend here to introduce, and then to bring an Obervation of my own amongt ome others. The firt is of a Scotch Souldier,Hitory 2. who coming from the Indies, by making ue of dyet of ill juice, and hereby pining away under a bad dieae, with a Caeliacal flux, and gripes in his Belly, after having for three or four months taken Medicines to cure this dieae, although in vain, he at length died Conumptive, and was pent (as our Englih Proverb hath it) to Skin and Bones, his Body being opened,
his Spleen was found to be large, hard and black, his Pancreas hard alo, and much well'd, and of an ah colour, and very many glandules were found in his Meentery, carce een in ound people, thee were very turgid and hard, ome of them exceeded the bignes of a Bean, and mot the largenes of a Haelnut, and ome few of them appeared as big as a Nutmeg. Thee being diected, nothing but a certain kind of whitih Cream was found therein, hardened into a Caeous or Cheey ubtance.

div.p:
The econd was of a Girl about eleven years of age,Hitory 3. who being perplexed with uch another kind of flux, accompanied with gripes, and an extreme emaciation of Body, afterwards dyed; he being opened, by the deire of her Relations, in the company of many Phyicians, in her Body was found many and almot innumerable hard and tumefied glandules in the Meentery thereof, ome of which exceeded the largenes of a mall Nut; others of thee which were maller, upon opening them, we found a mot white Milky Chyle
iue thence, concreted into the form and hardnes of Cheee, yet in her the Spleen nor Pancreas did not exceed its uual bignes.

The Third was of one about even or eight years of age,Hitory 4. who being troubled with a great Atrophia, acaccompanied with pains of her Belly, for many months together, which at length overcame her life: She being opened, the Liver, Spleen, Heart, Lungs, Kidneys, Stomach, and Guts were een all ound, her Pancreas only being faulty, well'd, and of an ill colour; but the true caue of her death was found to be the Meentery, wherein was een many glandules tumefying it, made of a ingular hardnes, and ome of thee being much larger and harder than others, all of them of a white colour, in which alo was contained a Creamy ubtance, concreted into a Cheey hardnes, hindring the tranition of the Milky Chyle, which was thought the only reaon of the Atrophy, as alo of her diolution.

This fourth was an Obervation of a Gentleman which came from Oxford, Hitory 5. and was my own patient,
who having ued everal methods and medicines there without ucces, came to his Majety to be toucht for the Evil, but at that time was o far pent with weaknes that he was forc't to be carried to the King; ome while after he was advied to come to London, to ee what better hopes he might gain there, and was committed to Mr. Peare's, his Majeties Chyrurgion, and my care, in whoe icknes Dr. Lower was alo conulted; upon examining of whoe Leg, which was both a great occaion of his lamenes, Hectick Fever, and Atrophy, we found a very large Tumour had eized the upper part of his foot, and caued a rottennes or Caries in his Bones; London air not agreeing with him, he after three or four days ret there, was ordered to Kingenton; where the bet of advice and means were not wanting to him, but he till conuming daily under our hands, who from the firt had been under our care not above twelve or fourteen days, at length cloed up his day with the night of Death: I being deired by ome of his friends to open his dead Corpe,
amongt the things of note, as much as we could (for the dead Body had a very bad mell preently eized it) we found his well'd Leg, upon opening it, to have a perfect Caries pat through it, o that I could very eaily pas my Probe through the ame; his Intetines were extreamly tumefied and dicoloured, and his Meentery fill'd up with an infinite company of large Glandules, his Spleen was diordred, and his Liver was very large, exceeding its uual bignes in a great meaure, his Heart and Lungs being both very ound and entire.

div.head: CHAP. XV. Of the Pancreas.
div.p:
THe Body being opened, and the Intetines and the Stomach being removed, the Pancreas doth next appear, of which, becaue many things of great note are writ thereof, I hall preume to dwell omewhile upon this Chapter, and take a urvey of its bounds and limits, both as to its ubtance, ight, colour, figure, quantity, veels, and the variety of ues deigned it. It's a word compoed (although not well to be allowed here) of < in non-Latin alphabet > and < in non-Latin alphabet > , which ignifies a flehy bowel.Its ubtance wholly glandulous. The ubtance of the Pancreas is wholly glandulous in it elf, for it is formed out of many minute globular glandules, every of which have their firmation and hardnes given them, that they
may endure eparation one from another, and from their looe connexion they do form a oft body; o that by ome the Pancreas is aid to be a oft and looe glandule; again, every of the glandules contituting the Pancreas hath a particular membrane given to them; yet all eem as it were coupled together by this trong coat, it ariing from the Peritoneum, by whoe benefit they are kept in their places.Its Site. In Man it is planted under the back part, and in the bottom of the Stomach, about the firt Vertebre of the Loyns, where, to the Peritoneum it is firmly annexed, it is extended from the cavity of the Liver to the region of the Spleen, and gets a tranvere ite there. If we take a view of its colour,Colour. it carries in it the pale colour of many or mot of the glandules, for the Blood that paeth into it, is of a very bright and light colour. Its figure is longih,Figure. larget and thicket about the Duodenum, thinner and narrower towards the Spleen, obtaining a various contitution in diverity of Animals. In ound Bodies this carries but a moderate bignes,Quantity. its length generally being
about eight or ten tranvere fingers, and this it eldom exceeds in men of a good and healthful contitution. Its breadth is generally een two tranvere fingers, and its thicknes in dead Bodies, as hath commonly been oberved, hath not exceeded the thicknes of one tranvere finger. Its weight is various, according to the diverity of mans contitution: And Dr. Wharton aith it generally is een to weigh about 4 or 5 ounces, and in Hores it weighs about 11 ounces. It hath 4 orts of Veels allowed it.Veels. viz. Arteries, which it takes from the Caeliacal Artery; Veins, which it takes from the Splenetick branch, Nerves which it hath from the ixth pair, and a Ductus, which it hath given it peculiarly proper to it elf, unknown to the Ancients, ariing from its own Parenchyma. This Ductus being membranous, and although thin, yet it is made very firm, whoe greatnes does very near equal that of a Gooe quill towards the Gut called the Duodenum. In its progres it eems divided, and then attenuated into both greater and maller lateral branches, and running hence to all the glandules
of the Pancreas, as to the variety of ues given this Ductus, and the liquor which is kept in it, Regnerus de Graaf hath at large in his Book De Succo Pancreatico declared, to which I hall recommend the Ingenuous Reader. As to its ue alo,Its ue. this hath as many given it, as Phyicians can well put upon it. Thus ome will have it as a Pillow to the Stomach; and this opinion Vealius doth defend, as you may ee in his Book de Omento cap. 4. but this opinion of his doth not carry much validity in it, becaue in Birds and Fihes, and many other Animals, this is een to bear no ue at all. Others defend that it lets out the Chyle from the Intetines; and this Baccius and Folius do vindicate, where they do tiffly maintain the Chyles paing out of the Intetines to the Liver and Spleen by the Pancreatick Ductus; and this alo is contrary both to the light of Sene and Reaon, for none of this Juice is ent out of the Gut into the Pancreas, but ent thence into the Guts. A Third ort do write that this part doth purge the Chyle, of which number is Velingius. But he is readily confuted
both by Aellius and Riolan, and others, and Experience doth joyn with them in their oppoition; for this humour contained in the Pancreas is never een bitter in tate, and therefore can no ways be allowed acquaintance with Choler. Others there are who account it the bilious Veicle of the Spleen, amongt which the Worthy Bartholine appears, as to its conjunction therewith, as is een Anatom. cap. 13. where he writes, That Choler is expurged by this Ductus, and o will needs have it the Biliary Veel of the Spleen, being made for its ue. But this gets a peedy refutation alo, this Ductus not reaching the Spleen, neither hath the Spleen any commerce therewith, by having any of its Veels ent either into its Ductus, or ubtance. Others alo do write, That the thicker and more feculent parts of the Blood are by the ordinary Law of Nature purged out into this. Of which opinion is Lindanus, who affirms, That this doth purge the excrements of the Blood, and this eems to carry but little truth in it. When as the Pancreatick juice, as oft as it
hath been truly collected, hath appeared like the Lympha of Wine; and therefore what can be conjectured of this excrementitious humour which he puts upon it? Others alo think that this part was formed for the reception of excrements which do fall from the Nerves: And this our worthy Countrey-man Wharton doth affirm in his Adenograph. cap. 13. where he writes, That this glandule doth adminiter as all the other glandules to the Nerves, being as an excretory glandule, and doth receive the uperfluities from the Nerves, the which doth dipatch thence by this proper Veel into the Intetines. But becaue Nerves are made and framed for the dipening of the Animal Spirits, I cannot perceive how this mot excellent man would have an excrementitious humour pas through them, and why they hould be more depoed into the Pancreas, than into the Spleen, or any other part of the Body, I cannot well undertand; for the Pancreas is a long way from the Brain, and too long, I am afraid, to receive its excrement, and therefore by his leave, his opinion mut
meet with the ame contradiction as the former. Others alo do uppoe that in the Pancreas both every ueful and neceary humour is ecerned and eparated herein. And here Silvius de le Boe gives the eventh opinion thereof, who writes that nothing is carried from the Intetines through this Ductus into the Pancreas, nor that any unprofitable excrement is in the Pancreas ecreted by the ame to the Gut; but a laudable humour prepared out of the Blood and Spirits in it is thence carried to the Guts, and this he thinks mixeth it elf there with the other aliments. And becaue perhaps he thought that nothing could be ent to the Guts, unles firt having pat by the Stomach, and o uckt up by the Ductus Biliarius or Pancreaticus, and did les conider that not only in Intermitting Fevers the ick people are perplexed with various troubles about their Lumbar Region, but in other dieaes relating thereto, as Hypochondriack affections produced from the Scurvy, or a Cholera, accompanied with gripings and the like, ucceeding them, by
raiing corrugations and acid humours in them. This Pancreatick juice being in its own nature ubacid, tempered with the Animal Spirits; and he judging Choler, which is bitter, and o a perfect enemy to acidity, leaves the puruit of its generation to others, he himelf acknowledging it being pat his knowledge to define. As to the collection of this juice, Regn ‚Ä¢ rus de Graaf hath mot admirably in his Book De Succo Pancreatico atisfied in cap. 3. eju. libr. We now come to hew that this Pancreatick Juice is no excrement, as is made good by the diviion of the aforeaid glandules of the whole Body; & that we may declare its true & proper generation, we mut propoe allits glandules, by ditinguihing them into conglobated and conglomerated glandules, and Silvius de le Boe doth make thee two ditinctions between them:The difference between conglobated and conglomorated glandules hewn. And thee he calls conglobated, being framed as it were out of one continued ubtance, having an equal uperficies, of which kind are the glandules of the Meentery Inguens, and many other parts of the Body. Thoe called conglomerated glandules,
which are form'd out of many mall glandules put or joyn'd together, of which ort may be reckoned the Pancreas; and many other in the Fauces, Nares, Eyes, and the Thymus it elf. The ditinction between each of which Glandules is not fictitious, but real, as experience doth evidently evince:Made good by demontration. For take off the Membrane or Coat which covers either of them, and end into the Ductus Pancreaticus, or Salivalis, any liquor by a Syringe being thereto fixed, or to the Arteries belonging to either of them, we hall ee the conglomerated glandules eaily to eparate, and part from one another; epecially if there be care taken in the diviion of the membranes, as they pread into bulk. The which, ue the greatet care you can, you never hall expect to do the ame with the conglobated glandules.By their ubtance. Another thing which hews their difference, is their ubtance; for by Natures Decree and Law, we find a Cavity in the middle of the conglobated glandules, where I am ure none is to be expected in the conglomerated glandules. To the confirmation of which, worthy
Steno doth readily aent; where writing of the conglobated glandules, thee are his words: Outwardly they are globous, not hallowed inward with any Pelvis, yet if you trace their eparation aright, you will meet ome lips, and cleft every way between their protuberancies. Again, beides their differences as to their ubtance,And in their Veels alo. their peculiar veels do alo declare the ame. For the conglobated glandules are properly framed for the Lymphatick Veels, which marcheth upwards towards the common Thoracick Ductus, whereas the conglomerated Glandules do depoe their liquor into peculiar cavities, as the Salivals into the Mouth, the Pancreatick into the mall Guts, &c. Various are the paages of Glandules, and divere are their ubtance; ince therefore we have traced thus far into their differences between thee two orts of Glandules, we mut not leave off here, but ought to earch whether the liquor or humour which is found in them be one and the ame in quality. And here we hall find much difference as to their quality,In repect of their quality. for we hall find one humour in the
conglobated, and another in the conglomerated glandules; for that which is eparated in the conglobated glandules is always of one and and the ame nature; which is not only proved and made good by their ubtance being always alike, but by their paages by which they do exonerate and dicharge the ame. Again, upon a trict enquiry we hall find that the liquor which ordinarily does proceed from the conglobated glandules hath more of oftnes, and les of acidity in it than that which comes from the conglomerated glandules of the Pancreas, and yet that this hath more of acidity and altnes in it than thoe of the conglomerated Salivals. For upon tating either of thee liquors we wall find a notable difference; for the Saliva is temperate and inipid, the Pancreatick juice is acid & Saline, or thereabouts. And ince we find their juices to be various,As alo in their ues. let us enquire into their ue, and this is thus made good; all the liquor of the conglobated glandules is ent into the Thoracick Ductus, and mixt there with the Chyle; as the chief part of nutriment, going
along with it throughout its whole journey: and runs along the Jugular and Subclavian Vein, whence necearily decending with the Blood being as yet confue, it paeth along with it through the right Ventricle of the Heart, from or by the right Ear of the ame: And this, I hope, mut no ways be allowed excrementitious or unueful, excrementitious humours being altogether eparated from the Blood, o that by Natures Laws they are to have no further convere therewith, but utterly dimit thence; the which is eaily perceived in the Vein, ecreted from the Sanguinary mas in the Kidneys, and ent thence by the Uriters into the Bladder, the which after a mall while lodging therein do make its lat exit. Thus the juice of the conglomerated glandules being effued through particular Ductus's into various cavities of the Body, where it meets with other humours nourihing the ame; this alo is not to be allowed excrementitious, for this works as the former, in their various places and ues. Thus the Saliva in the Maxillary Glandules, as well upper as
lower, ecreted from the Blood, is carried by the ame Salival Ductus into the cavity of the Mouth, where having met with the nutriments taken therein, and mixing it elf with the ame, doth march thence with it into the Stomach, and there creates a ferment; and uch therefore who do think this unueful or excrementitious, are as much to blame as thoe who accounted the former as needles.What the Pancreatick Juice erves for. Thus alo the Pancreatick Juice lodged in the glandules of the Pancreas, do work as the former Ductus, where we hall as readily find this Juice, ecreted in man four tranvere fingers under the Pylorus, continually pending it elf into the Duodenum, and there mixt with the fermented nutriments which thence decended from the Stomack, and driven thither downwards by the Peritaltick motion of the Guts: In which propulion its greater part, together with the more pure and liquid part of the Chyle is thence dicharged into the Milky Veels, and hence into its proper Cytern, whence by the Thoracick Ductus it is ent to the Subclavian Vein, and o marches
along till it arrives at the right Ear of the Heart, and gets thence into the right Ventricle of the ame. And if thee be excrementitious humours, thoe which do upply the whole Oeconomy of the Body may as well be allowed the ame. Thee ues of thee glandules I do believe were altogether unknown to the Ancients, who thought that they were framed as Sponges, to uck up all excrementitious and uperfluous humours; but our learned men of late, having with more care, tudy and labour lookt into this tructure, do eaily hew how lame they were in the ues deigned thereto; and how former ages have lived in their errours, as touching the noble ues of this Pancreas, every reading man may judge, by the arguments already dicoured of the ame. I hall cloe up this Chapter with ome Hitorical dicoures hereof, where we hall find Riolan and Plempius granting the Pancreas the eat of intermitting Fevers, and of Hypochondraick melancholy, and the only caue of many Chronical Ditempers.

Riolan. Anthropog. lib. 2. cap. 16. writes there,Hitory. That he hath een the
Pancreas to have equall'd the Liver in its bignes; and this he makes good by the example of a Worthy Gentleman, Augutine Thuane, who being of a melancholick dipoition, troubled about four days with Cholick pains, with weight and heavines of his Stomach, his Hypochrondries no ways welling, but being eized by a Gangreen from the right foot upwards, died within ix hours, with direful cruciations: The Body being opened, his Liver was een Spherical, his Pancreas equalling the weight of his Liver, wholly Scirrhous, accompanied with many Globes like a Pidgeons Egg, and the Spleen was o mall that it carce weighed an ounce.

Hitory. Highmore corp. human. Anatom. lib. 1. part 11. writes that he once oberved in a Noble Woman, who for ome years was perplexed with Convulions, Epilepy, and Hyterick paion, thee having made her yield to Death; her dead Body being opened, the Pancreas was wholly found ill-affected and ulcerated.

Hitory. Aubertus Progymn. Exercit. 44. ad lib. abdit. Fernelii, writes this tory of
a rich Merchant, who in his virile age did enjoy all his faculties very briskly, as eating and drinking, and the like; but when he endeavoured to leep, he had both a cold weat eized his whole Body, and fell into a woon, the Phyicians that aw him in thee fits did conjecture his dieae might arie from his Stomach being ill affected, and therefore did precribe him Hiera Galeni, but without any ucces, he being much wore after the taking the ame than before; after this they precribed Cordials for him, but thee had little ucces in him; and all the remedies which they ubcribed no ways leening his pain, he in this mierable condition put an end to his trouble, by leaving the World: His Body being opened, in his Pancreas was een a perfect abces, accompanied with much putrified matter, which infected his whole Body; and this was the only occaion of his peedy departure.

div.head: CHAP. XVI. Of the Liver.
div.p:
THe Liver is a vat Bowel, planted in the right Hypochondry, under the Diaphragma, in its convex or gibbous part it's round and light, in the lower part thereof concave; it hath a oft and reddih ubtance,Its ubtance made of glandulous kernels. much reembling concreted Blood. Malpighius who by his Microcopes hath mot accurately hewn the ubtance thereof. Lib. de Hepate cap. 4. oberves firt, That its ubtance in man is framed of many lobes, and that thee are formed of glandulous Kernels, the which do afford this heap of Ramifications, and covered with a proper Membrane. Secondly, That the whole ubtance of the Liver, coniting of divere glandulous kernels and ramifications of Veels, that they may perform their
offices together, Nature thought it neceary to place thee glandules between them for the more ready execution of their offices. Then,That the Veels are not joyned by any Anatomois, but thee glandules. that the aboveaid Veels are not joined by any Anatomits, but thee glandulous kernels chiefly framing the ubtance of the Liver are planted as a mean between them; from which obervations he concludes, that the Liver is a conglomerated glandule eparating the Bilis; and this he eems to confirm by the aboveaid reaon. And becaue this office is particularly due to conglomerated glandules (as is een in the Parotides, Pancreas, and the like) he aith this Veel is the Biliary pore in the Liver, where, with the felleous veicle, it joyns. Thee new obervations of Malpigius have dicut many things of the Liver left in the dark by the Ancients, and have given the ame a better face of light. And that the unfortunate tate of this Bowel being by them call'd the principal Bowel, and put by Galen as the great Throne of anguification, and had in the highet eteem with them of any other part of the Body, that in our
times it hould loe a great part o ‚Ä¢ that excellency which they betowed upon it, and tripping it from all its bravery with which they cloathed it, like a Silk-worm pinning its lat thread, it only now gets the name of a conglomerated glandule, and appears as a new veel rais'd from the Grave, gaining in it the new life of its knowledge and ue. Aellius writes he hath oberved a branch of Milky Veels in the Liver; but without doubt he was in the dark, he taking the Lymphatick Veels to be that branch; there being neither Lacteal or Chyleliferous Veels any ways ent to the Liver, but many Lymphaticks have been een to arie thence. Thus Charleton lib. de Oeconom. animal writes, that never any part of the Chyle doth enter the Liver.The Original of Lymphaducts. And indeed by all Anatomits the Lympha is allowed to arie out of the conglobated glandules planted in the hollow part thereof, and o marching forwards. And Fredericus R ‚Ä¢ ych, a mot accurate Anatomit, hath oberved that he hath een many Lymphaducts ariing from the Spleen, not only out of its uperficial part, but
from its interiour part alo: And further affirms, that he hath een them in many other parts of the Body, which have taken their Origination from conglobated glandules, in which glandules he allows there remains a pecifique vertue, for eparating the acid part of the Serum from the Blood, & for giving the aline eparated part a light acidity. And here he writes further, That by ligature he hath found that all the Lymphaducts which are in the Lungs do exonerate themelves into the Subclavian, Axillary, and Jugular Veins. Some do affirm that they have found conglobated glandules in the Joynts, and without doubt doth thence deduce their Origination, and as to their inertion, they do hence exonerate themelves into the Chylifique Veels, and divere Veins.Its Veels. The Veels of the Liver, by this glandulous ubtance or lobes, are mixt after a wonderful manner, as is made good by a friable Liver, as Glion doth demontrate.

The Office of the Liver is to moyten the Blood with a ulphureous dew,Its Office. and with the aitance of the Spleen, doth frame a ferment of the
Chyle.The action of the Liver, Spleen and Pancreas, made and deigned for one and the ame end. The action of the Liver, Spleen and Pancreas, are by mot Authors allowed to be framed for one end; for they together do prepare the ferment both of Blood and Chyle; for the preparation of which there is required three everal offices, and this is not to be compleated by any one or two of them. This, as Flower,The manner of this preparation of ferment. being put into warm water, mixeth it elf with the ferment readily, and by this the more terretrial and thick parts thereof are diolved, and the more pirituous parts lying occult and conopite, are hereby likewie attenuated, and thus framed into a whole lump or mas; and thee attenuated Spirits being thereupon poured, it becomes lighter and eaier of digetion. Thus alo is it neceary for the mixing the ferment to the Chyle and venous Blood, whereof the Spirituous Particles herein lodging, are attenuated, and thus the whole mas is made more apt for a Hematois, and nutrition. The ferment of this Bread alo (by which we may eaily find out both the knowledge of the Blood and Chyle) is generally made of ome quantity
of Flower, to which warm water is added, as alo ome alt and acidity; and this kept in a warm place, till both the Salt and ubacid Spirits are by this heat omewhat volatiliz'd, and this gets poeion into the mas, and o doth both dilate and eparate the ame; and thus does by degrees make the whole mas ubacid and fermentative. This being done, a mall quantity thereof is ufficient to leven the whole Loaf; for this mall quantity entring into the Dough or Pate, doth both attenuate and divide thee Particles, and diolve the Spirits lodging therein. And be the ferment what it will, this for certain mut be allowed, that it is framed of ubacid, ubaline and corroive parts, a moderate heat interpoing therewith, with ome volatization and liquefaction; the which hould they be either more thick or dene, the force hereof would not o uddenly hew it elf, but require much more time to act the ame part: If therefore by ome Sulphureous Particles thee grow more Spirituous and Volatile, they do ooner and more readily run into ferment; as we ee in Ale, the
which in the pace of half an hour or les, doth abolve: this work, becaue thee pirituous acid Particles hereby getting freedome, do alo attain a more penetrating quality, and o hew a quick demontrance of their intents and inclinations, making a more peedy diolution of the thicker parts, and o force alo a more peedy ucitation of the latent pirits; but a moderate heat is a main agent in this work, for this is the mater both of the acidity and alo of the volatization. Thus tands it with both the Blood and the Chyle; the which if they be not attenuated before an Hematois, and prepared by an admixt ferment fit for the ame, they do not ufficiently pirituize it in the Heart, that is, the Spirits o lodged therein not being diolved from the more thick and erous matter therein remaining, the Blood hereby doth oon become thick and aqueous, and o les capable for nourihing the Body, making it hereby les able to perform its functions: And thus the whole frame of Nature is put out of order, her natural and animal faculties wanting that life and
vigour, which gave them courage to proecute the ame.The ferment both of Blood and Chyle made by the Liver, and how this is performed. This ferment both of Chyle and Blood is performed by the Liver, for whoe accomplihing whereof, the Chyle firt paing from the Stomach, is afterwards entertained by the Duodenum, where it meets with the Pancreatick Juice as its aitant; The matter of which the Liver frames this, is the venous Blood ent from the Gatrick and Meeraick veins flowing hereinto by the Porta, to which there is therein mixt a ubacid or aline Succus or Juice, made in the Spleen out of the Arterial Blood and Animal Spirits, paing through the Nerves, the which is carried through the Splenitick branch into the Porta, and thence conveyed with the Blood to which it is annexed in the Liver; and thus whilt it bears a harp and corroding quality in it, by the Specifique and Digetive virtue of the Liver, both the aline and ubacid Particles lodged in the Blood are both diolved and attenuated, and o becomes fermentated, and their thinner parts, like the mot fine and thin water, paing the conglobated glandules in
the caveous parts of the Liver, and o receding from the thicker part of the Blood, are hence dimit by the numerous Lymphatick Veels out of the Liver to various Veins, preparing the venous Blood towards the Heart; for the furtherance of which performance, the Saliva paing by the Mouth, as alo the ubaline and ubacid Lympha, collected out of the glandules of the Axillaries, Inguens, and other places, as alo of the Pancreatick Juice out of the Guts, doth utain the Chyliferous Veels, together with the Chyle.The origination of ferment. And if any enquire how thee harp, hot and fermented Particles do or may arie in our body, I hall give them this anwer, They do arie out of Sulphur and Salt; the firt being from Sulphur, but the chief acrimony doth take its ubtance from Salt; the which beides its Sulphurious quality it bears in it, is innate in all our nutriments, for we eat nothing which doth not carry in it a aline quality; this Sulphur diolves this Salt, and brings it into a fuion, this being looned and attenuated, doth by its
acrimony both corrode, enter and diolve all parts of our nutriments, and o doth fetch out the Spirit lodging in them, whoe operation is Fermentation, without which no man can be kept alive; and when this is either debilitated or vitiated, his life is but very troubleome to him. And that we may trace this Fermentation more happily, we by the natural Saline intinct of nature, which is in all nutriments, do add our help thereto, by putting Salt upon the meats which we uually do eat, making them of a hard ubtance, hereby giving them both a greater fermentation, and a more efficacious ferment for their digetion; by o much the more we love or affect a greater altnes in them, as in Beef, Pork, or the like; becaue Salt in uch is the only caue of their eaie digetion; a manifet example whereof we have in Herrings, the which being Salt, do eaily diget in the Stomach, but not being alt, and much boiled, they are not digeted therein without difficulty. And thus the true action of the Liver, Spleen,
and Pancreas, is aid to make the ferment; whence follows, that where thee bowels are well, and do enjoy their proper functions, the whole Blood is excellent good and pirituous, and the Body becomes active and brisk; but where they are diordred, innumerable dieaes do arie from an ill ferment of the Blood and Chyle. And hence although the Liver doth not carry the ame Honour with us as it did with the Ancients, who reckoned it as one of the principal bowels, and the office of Sanguification, yet it wants not the reputation of an ueful Veel, whoe ue we cannot well be without, its dieaes being dangerous, and the cure thereof not eaily performed without difficulty.

Hitory. Cyriacus Lucius de Ob. propriis, writes that he hewed in a dead Body a globous Liver, acending with the Diaphragmae into the Breat, and to the right Breat, who alo had a very large Spleen therewith. Fernelius lib. 6. cap. 4. Pathal. writes,Another Hitory. That ometimes yellow Choler being lodged a long time in the Liver preternaturally, and not timely purged out
thence, hath much thickned therein, and produced very dangerous obtructions therein, the which alo hath grown tony in proces of time. Joachinus Camerarius de Oberv. propriis doth therein write of a Gentleman,Hitory. who being eized with a great coldnes of his Thighs, and of his whole Body, with a conternation of mind, having alo a Cough and Rheumatim going along with it, the which did occaion a Tumour under the Cartilago Eniformis, or Sword-like Cartilage, which was hard, in colour equal, without pain, welling beyond expectation; he neglecting the ame, not in time uing convenient remedies, he fell into a Cachexi√¢, or ill habit of Body, and vomiting, taking its origination from his Cough; this Tumour very much encreaing, and the Cutis of the Abdomen being hereby much extended, the Patient eemed crooked, and, as it were, drawn back into himelf; and uing Stomachick and hot Oyls thereto, without any ucces of eae, and this Tumour till growing more upon him, took him from his Stomach, and caued a
weaknes in all his faculties; hence followed wellings in his face, as alo in his feet; in this condition he flyes to Phyicians and Chyrurgions, amongt which the learned Dr. Volckerus declared this Tumour hewed it elf to be an abces, and needed opening, to the which this Patient agreeing, and the others willing to ubcribe thereto, it was dilated, and not without admiration of the beholders, many Veicles did break forth with great force, ome partly rent, ome being whole, and filled with a thin waterih humour; ome of thee were the bignes of a Hens Egg, or a Pidgeons Egg, and ome leer, the which were ent forth by his Cough; with thee Veels did come forth a kind of thick humour, with a concrete vicidnes, as alo not much irreembling fat, and did very well bear the name of a Steomatical abces; thee Bladders were near three hundred, as they could be guet, which were aid to hold in them about 4 pound of Water: The third day after this apertion, thee Veicles did not o frequently appear,
but then iued out a foetid matter, and vicous humour, but not o plentifully as formerly; the Patient hence grew weak, and although all ueful Medicines were precribed him, yet he at lat dyed with a Conumption. He being opened, his Liver was een much tumefied, and livid in colour, and in the upper part, towards the Diaphragma, this abces appeared full with Bladders filled with a putrid matter, as it were a Cartilaginous Membrane, both which corrupted the Liver, and corroded it even to the Bladder of Gall. In his Lungs alo was found a large abces, wherein was contained putrid matter, to the quantity of near ix pounds. The third abces, which was the bignes of a Gooe Egg, was annexed beneath the Liver at the Cholick gut, whoe Membrane was thick; the Heart enjoyed its true poition, the Ventricle, Spleen, Kidneys, Intetines and Bladder, being all firm.
Trincavilla lib. 3. cap. 27. de Comp. Medic. writes, That in the diection of Bodies, he hath frequently een Steatoma's in the ubtance of the Liver.

div.head: CHAP. XVII. Of the Spleen.
div.p:
THe Spleen hath alo many mall conglomated glandules,Many mall conglobated glandules herein, from whence doth arie this plenty of Lymphatick Veels. from whence do arie thoe plenty of Lymphatick Veels, endued with the which by Malpigius are aid to many Valves; contain a certain yellowih or reddih liquor, and by perpicuous paages are een to carry the ame through the Omentum into the Receptaculum Chili, they ariing out of many mall conglobated glandules lodging in the Spleen, altogether denied by Wharton in his Adenographi√¢. Malpigius was the firt which oberved thee glandules in the ubtance of the Spleen worthy note: Of which he thus writes, cap. 5. eju. libr. in the Spleen are found and dipert mot copious branches of
glandules, much reembling Grapes; they carrying in them an oval form and hape, not much differing from the Renal glandules; they have a white colour, as he hath always oberved; and although the Spleen be tumefied with black Blood, yet thee till do keep their colour; their ubtance eems membranous, but oft, and eaily friable; and this is one reaon why Wharton will not allow the Spleen glandulous: Their cavities being very mall are not to be een by the harpet eye, they are very copious and almot innumerable, overpreading the whole Spleen; they are wonderfully planted, and are pendant from the branches of its Capulae, or from the fibres thence ariing; and conequently from the ends and terminations of the Nerves and Arteries; they are only een by the laceration of the Spleen; in Man they are carce dicernable, if notwithtanding the whole body of glandules be tumefied by any dieae or ditemper, they are more apparent, encreaing in multitude and magnitude; as he oberved in a Maid that dyed, whoe Spleen was found
prinkled with thee conpicuous conglobated Glandules; We owe much to Malpighius for bringing us into this Light, be demontrating to us that with clearnes, which was kept in the dark from the Antients, and only allowed conjectural. In the ubtance of the Spleen, The Spleens Subtance. which is ubacid (the which is eaily perceived in a boild Spleen) are contained many Glandules, and the Blood which is infued into thoe Glandules; to which alo are added animal Spirits, coming from the ends of the Nerves ending in them, but much les in quantity, the which together making the ulphureous Spirit of Blood, giving it ome light acidity wherewith it is endued by preure of the circumtantial parts, it drives the ame from the ame Glandules; and being uckt up by the root of the Splenical Branch, marches by it to the gate of the Vein, and to the Liver, and before it attains the root of the Veins, it tops awhile in the Cells, whoe ubtance being Acid, by its delay there, doth obtain a greater Acidity, like Wine kept in a Vinegar bottle, growing by its delay therein, both
more ower, and more harp; thus Choler lodging longer than its uual time in the Bladder of Gall, gains a greater degree of acrimony in it. Many ues are deigned and acribed to the Spleen,Ues deigned the Spleen. amongt which, Galen and many of the Antients did uppoe, that its action was to eparate the feculent or melancholick part of the Chyle; and that it did attract the ame by the plenical Branch; and having once collected the ame into its Dominion, did therein give it another digetion. But thee both Bauhine, Riolane, and Bartholine have already refuted; for in the Spleen is no ample Cavity to entertain this excrement; or if there were, there is no apparent paage een therein, for the dicharge of the ame out again. Others there are, as Vealius, Platerus, Bauhine, Spigelius, and Pio, with many others, who will have the Spleen a Sanguificant Bowel; and with Aritotle do call it the Livers Vicar. The Liver being ill dipoed, this performing its Office for it; and to back and trengthen their opinions thereof, they do further tell us, That the Spleen was made for forming Blood for the
Veels which are contained in the Abdomen, as the Liver was for the other parts of the Body: but this loes ground apace, ince neither by the Spleen nor by the Liver Sanguification is made, but by the Heart only: Beides, the Spleen hath no Veels in it, by which it could end any Blood forth to thee Abdominal Veels; and that which detroys the whole Opinion, maintained and propagated by them, is the Bloods Circulation, which originally doth proceed from the Heart, and thence paeth through all the Arteries to all the parts of the Body. The true ue of the Spleen is to make a ubacid Matter out of the Arterious Blood,The true ue of the Spleen. from which being again excocted with ulphureous Particles in the Liver, in a pecifique manner, it there frames a Bilious Ferment both of Chyle and Blood,How the Spleen doth make the ower Juyce. becaue alo this Acid Liquor herein generated, is not readily explained, we hall ee it thus performed. A ubaline Subacid, and ower Juyce we have already hewn, is made out of the Arterious Blood in the Spleen, by the large Splenetick Artery, ending the ame vigorouly into this Bowel; the
which by a plentiful affluxion of animal Spirits by the Nerves, and alo by this Bowels own mediate virtue, is intantly varied; and that ulphureous Spirit which was formerly een in it, is now obtunded, fixt, and uffocated, and the alt and acid Spirit therein remaining, is produced into action; and the aline parts being omewhat eparated do take predominancy. And hence is it, that the fervid and weetih Blood flowing by the Arteries into the Spleen, and being a while kept therein, the ulphureous Fervour with its weetnes loe themelves, and it becomes ubaline and ubacid, and o marcheth from the Spleen by the Splenical Branch to the Liver. And that this primary matter of Ferment, perfected by the Liver, doth firt come from the Spleen, is thus made good by experiment: For take the Spleen of an Ox, Swine, Sheep, or any other Creature, and cut it into pieces, and put them into warm water, and put ome of this warm water, wherein thee have for ome mall time been laid, and put the ame to Dough or Pate, you will oon find it dilate the ame,
and frame a Ferment therein, as well as Yeat or the like, the which will better declare it elf, if you will but add a little Vinegar thereto. We come now towards its concluion,How Dieaes of the Spleen do arie. where we may make ome enquiries how dieaes do arie from the Spleen; if therefore the Spleen be weak, leaving its ubacid quality, not being well liquefied, attenuated, or volatiliz'd, but remaining thick, tartareous, and terrene, a large part of the Spleen being accumulated with a plenty of this vicous Subtance, giving a great occaion to the Spleens increae into a larger bulk; this pirit lodging in it, not being timely tirr'd up, but boiling in its narrow confines, doth in a great meaure occaion its larger ditention, hereby making it very ready to receive any ditemper whatoever. Thus when a Scirrhous Spleen being any ways obtructed, or otherwie vitiated, in generating of an ill fermentative juyce; this makes it ubject to a thouand evils, all which do hew the action of the Spleen ufficiently evident. Hildanus Ob. 44. Centur. 2. hews you there the Figure of a Spleen filled with a greay kind of Matter,
where it appears as it was diected. Hollerius writes that upon opening a Woman who had a Stone in her Womb, he had no Spleen in her, but was detitute of the ame.

Various have been the Spleens een in divers People, both as to their weight and bignes.Hitory. Thus Vidus Vidii lib. 10. cap. 10. de Curat. Membr. writes there of one whoe Spleen was no bigger than a Pidgeons Egg, and that o hard and compact, that it almot equall'd the hardnes of a tone. Whereas Columbus writes,Hitory. that he hath een Spleens weighing Twenty pounds, and George Garner de Obervat. propriis doth there tell us of one of 39 years of age, who had a Spleen o large, that it filled the whole Abdomen, uppreing both the Stomack and Guts; the which being cleared from the Body, weighed 23 pounds, and being cut in the middle cros ways, did every way anwer the ubtance of a ound Spleen, no ways changed in its colour, ave only the Blood which was in it not being o black as uually it is; his Liver alo was very hard, obtructed, and very large, and weighed Eleven pounds,
his Stomack being o mall, that it appeared but like a Bladder. Turneierus in examin. rinar. there makes mention of a Noble-woman, who had a Stone in her Spleen, the largenes of a Chenut, omewhat white, weighing Two Ounces, and a half, and a Drachm, concreeted with a cruty outide; this Woman was young and beautiful, and was taken with a pain in her Left Side every full Moon for Three days together.

div.head: CHAP. XVIII. Of the Kidneys.
div.p:
THe Office of the Liver and the Spleen being dicours'd, next in Order to the Rules of Anatomy, we arrive at the Kidneys, where the Serum mixeth its elf to the Blood. The inward evacuatory paages of the Serum, being the Kidneys, and the Bladder, we hall only Treat of the Firt, being nearet of kin to our preent Dicoure. The Kidneys by the Greeks do take their derivation, < in non-Latin alphabet >
fluere, the Urine paing through them as thorough Rivulets. The ubtance of the Kidneys do appear to our view as they were fibrous, framed out of a Concoure and commixture of mall Veels,Their Subtance having ome carnoity interpoing; in outward Contact hard, inwardly moderately Spongeous. Thee things do offer
themelves to ocular inpection, as touching the Kidneys. But Malpighius by the advantage of his Microcopes, hath given us better knowledge thereof; by whoe benefit he hath deliver'd us from many things which were kept in the dark from former ages. For in his Book De Renibus, he writes, whereas in Men of growth the Superficies of the Kidneys commonly appears equal; yet in a Foetus and young Children its found otherwie.Infinite minute Glandules found out here. The membrane of the Kidneys being ablated, and injection of pirit of Wine, tinged with a black Colour, being injected into the emulgent Artery. Malpighius hath oberved innumerable minute Glandules, fixed every way to thee bifurcated Arteries, and that they have been coloured with the ame; which Glandules, with the Sanguiferous Veels welling with this black Colour, being produced into the form of a pecious Tree, they hang as an Apple. From thee Glandules where the ends of thee Arteries do terminate, he uppoeth the Orifices of the Veins do arie, and that mall Nerves alo are there produced. Their action is to eparate and
dicharge the erous redundant Humidity from the Blood;Action of the Kidneys. the which with it is carried by the emulgent Arteries, from which Blood in its tranition, a good part of the Serum is eparated, and ditill'd into the Pelvis, by the Renal Glandules, Urinary Fibrilla's, and Papillary Caruncles, and o falls thence by the Ureter into the Bladder, the remaining part being ent by emulgent Veins to the Vena Cava.

The Kidney is a common Receptacle, and doth receive into it both moit and dry things; and this is made good, both by Hitory and Example.Hitory. Thus Langius 2 Epit. 40. writes of a Virgin, who by carelenes wallowed down Five Needles into her Stomach, the which after Three days were dicharged from her by her Urine.Hitory. And Alexander Benedictus, Lib. 3. Anatom. cap. 9. writes, of one who having wallowed a mall Key imprudently, within a mall while afterwards having a Stone drawn from him, the which Stone every way joyned to this Key, and the Key was its firt foundation; this Key came from him
with the Stone.Hitory. Nicolas Florentinus Serm. 9. Tract. 4. cap. 29. tells us there, of one who not well chewing Fungus's or Muhrooms, had ome great pieces thereof came from him through his Bladder with his Urine.Hitory. Julius Alexandrinus annotat. ad cap. 14. lib. de ubtant. Facult. natur. writes of pieces of Smallage Roots being eaten by one, many parts of which he hath oberved, have come out of the Body with the Urine. Thus Anie-eed, Fennel-eed, and other Seeds, being wallowed down, many of thee have been een to come whole out from the Body, by, and with the Urine; and its believed, that all thee things do pas the mot narrow pores of the Kidneys, which the Blood cannot pas; and whether this of the pores pecial Figuration, and aforeaid Aptitude, be ufficient for doing thee things, I can carce believe: For thee hard and great things thus paing the milky Veels, then marching by the Vena Cava, and the right Cavity of the Heart, and then inenibly, and without injury, to pas along thence by the mot narrow and winding paages of the Lungs, to the Left Cavity
of the ame, and from thence by the great Artery, and emulgent Arteries before they come to the Kidneys, through all which paages they mut enter before they can arrive at them; and then, that thee can be trancolated by their Urinary Fibrils, and Papillary Pores, as no Blood can go, doth confound both Faith and Reaon. Neither can this be made good by experience; for in all my Reading, as to this point, in which I have taken a little more than ordinary pains, could I ever find that any Phyitian or Anatomit, hath declared he hath een, either Needles, or Keys, or uch hard things, or Seeds of any ort, in their opening of their dead Bodies, either in the Vena Cava, Ventricles of the Heart, or in the Lungs, or the great Artery, or in the Kidneys, but in the lat, Stones have frequently been een and found there.

div.head: CHAP. XIX. Of the Renal Glandules.
div.p:
THee Renal Glandules are by Caerius called Succenturiati, Their Name. and by Bartholine Capulae Atrabilariae. The Omentum and Pancreas being laid aide; thee do readily hew themelves; And Wharton calls them Glandulae ad Plexum. Their Site. They are Two Glandulous Bodies, one being given to each Kidney, planted under the Diaphragma, above the Adipoe Membrane, o as the right is joyned to the Vena Cava, and the Left put towards the Ventricle; they are found in the place where the Plexus of the Nerves do appear, to which they are firmly affixt; they do not generally exceed the number of Two, carrying in them much of the ubtance of the Kidney, ave only their being more looe, of a Reddih Colour, omewhat
inclineable to Fat; they are een to carry and bear everal Figures in divers Perons and Animals, being een ometimes Oval, ometimes Triangular, and ometimes Round; their Magnitude is not always alike in young People,Magnitude. they equal the bignes of a mall Nut, and are mall, and the Right doth generally appear larger than the Left, and it's very eldom that the Left do get the ame advantage; they do not increae in proportion according to the other parts of the Body, nor bear a like time therewith as to their growth, and about pubertation to further Increment, they plainly do ceae their growth; in large creatures thee Glandules do appear larger, than they do in thoe who are of a more lender and maller growth; and age coming on, they leave off growing with it; and when many other parts of the Body do by icknes or diater meet with change, as to their former Being, yet thee parts do eldom feel any thing thereof, for they do retain their bulk, as is made good by the example of Dr. Glion, Hitory. in his Book De Rhacitide, where writing of a
Child falling from the Rickets into a Conumption, and Fever uperveneing, forc'd her to quit her Life; he being opened, altho her Thymus was near conumed, yet thee Glandules were found firm. They are covered with a thin Coat, by which they are firmly annext to the exterior Membrane of the Kidneys: They have an apparent inuous Cavity,Cavity. but this is o mall, that it carce admits a Pea into it; and this is better een in a Foetus than afterwards, the which contains a black and feculent Matter in it, with whoe colour its inward guard is tinged. In the greater end of this Glandule is een a certain conpicuous Cavity, into which many Cavities ariing from the ubtance of the Glandule, do terminate with open mouth, and this Cavity opening its elf into the next Vein, is defended with a Valve opening towards the Vein, and hut backwards. They do for the mot part take an Artery from the Emulgents, ometimes from one, or many Membranes of the Aorta, or great Artery.

Ues.The Ue of thee Glandules is yet unknown, but many conjectures are pat upon them; thus ome with Velingius do uppoe, that they do ait the Tract of the Serum, and do collect the Atra bilis; the which like a Coagulum or Crud, doth promote the eparation of the Serum from the Blood; others do uppoe, that they do defend and keep up the diviions of the Reteform plexus of the Nerves; Some think that they do give warmth to the Stomack. Glion doth write, that they do eparate the Juyce deigned for the nutrition of the Nerves, from the Blood, that hereby it may be ent to them more pure and refined: All which Opinions are meerly conjectural; and whereas there are ome who do think that in thee, ome Coagulum is made, which thence paing to the Kidneys, do there make a fit eparation of the Serum from the Blood; altho this Opinion may in all likelyhood carry much Truth in it, yet till thee paages, which make their way through thee Glandules to the Kidneys be more apparent, how this eparation is performed (as we have already hewn of the Spleen)
this mut only come under the name of conjecture. And ince their ue is at this day kept in the dark, and that no Phyicians or Anatomits have given any light as to their ues; many dieaes being believed to arie hence, ome ingenious Men would do the World good ervice, and their Profeion, Reputation, to make known thereto, what obervations they have made of them in dead Bodies, both as to their Dieaes and Ditempers.

Eutachius lib. de Renib. does give a very remarkable tory of the Kidneys of a Woman,Hitory. who after her Travel in Child-bearing and a plentiful excretion of Blood which came from her, he dying, and her Body being opened, her Kidneys were een white, fragile, and putrid, under whoe proper Membrane o much of Wind had been collected, that it eemed as it were divided from its ubject fleh; being o ditended and turgid, that it very much reembled the pecies of a great Tumour. And that we may ee all parts are not in all men made alike, we hall find Jacobus Carpus in Iagog. Anatom. telling us there, That in the year 1541. he aw in a publick Anatomy,
one Artery, making or framing a paage out of the Emulgents into the Right Side out of the Kidney; the which pat in a notable ditance under the Kidneys into the Uritery paage, ariing from the aforeaid Kidney, and both went, or were carried by one channel to the Bladder; yet this Emulgent Artery alo entred the Kidney in its due place; and in this individual, the Kidneys were whole and eemed as one, and had two Arteries, and two Emulgent Veins, and two Ureter paages, covered with one only pannicle, which alo kept the uual places of the Kidneys, about the middle of the Back, that is in that place, between the Spleen and the Liver, a little beneath it. Hercules Saxoniae obervat
Hitory. hewed the whole fleh of the Right Kidney cut away from its proper Membrane, fallen into the Bladder, before Fifty and more of his Auditors: where alo he tells you of the whole ubtance of the Kidney being reolved in Caruncles, and thee being ent into the Bladder, did there produce uch a uppreion of Urine, that it procured the death of the patient which was therewith troubled.

div.head: CHAP. XX. Of the Teticles both of Men and Women.
div.p:
THis Dicoure begins with the Teticles, o called from the virility which they bear witnes of, whoe ubtance by Galen is wholly aid to be glandulous,Allowed by the Antients to be glandulous though improperly. whoe opinion of which is owned and allowed by Riolan, Fallopius, Spigelius, and Velingius; every one of which affirming, that they are made of a white, oft, and glandulous ubtance. But Regenus de Graaf. & Diemerbroeck doe plainly hew their errors, who allowed this ubtance glandulous; they neither having in them the ubtance, temper, or ue of the Glandules, but are parts deigned for noble ues, hewing and declaring the trength of Man, and are of great excellency,
both as to his procreation and conervation.How they are ordained for Generation. For in Man are two Organs framed, which erve for Generation, ome for making the Seed, and others when thus made, for ending the ame into the Womb, as into its fertile Field. Our preent dicoure only touching upon the Firt, I hall pretermit the Second; And becaue Nature, which preerves her iue by Procreation, and Humanity gets further growth and friendhip in the World by Progenity, both Sexes being therein and therewith concerned, I hall in this Chapter give you a mall draught of each Sex, as to the compoition and ubtance of their Teticles, and then declare their ue. They are generally Two in number,Two generally in number. and therefore by Herophilus called < in non-Latin alphabet >
gemelli; partly that the generation of Seed might more happily proceed, and partly, that one being lot, the other might perform its Office: In Man they are planted outwards at the root of his Yard,Not planted alike in Men and Women. but in Women they are kept inwards, placed in the lower Cavity of the Abdomen, two tranvere Fingers from the bottom of the Womb, to whoe ides they are
annexed by a trong ligament, by mot Anatomits called Vas Deferens, becaue the Seed by this, may the better be tranmitted from the Teticles to the Womb: thee are not upended by a Cremater Mucle, and are lodged in the inward Cavity of the Belly, for the better performing of their Office there deigned them; in their lower part they do obtain a emi-oval gibboity; in their upper part they are plain, their largenes do omewhat vary, according to age, contitution, and bulk.Thoe in Women much differing from the ame in Men. Their ubtance being much different from that which is in Man; their inward ubtance being framed of many ibrillous Membranes looely tied together, in whoe aforeaid membranous ubtance are lodged many veels fill'd with Liquor, Nerves, and preparing Veels, running along much in the ame manner to the Teticles as they do in Men, and covering their whole ubtance, in whoe coats many plentiful branches do vanih in a copious divarication. But to proceed with the Teticles of Man, and herein we are to enquire into the greatnes of his Teticles, where alo we hall meet
with variablenes as to their largenes, the general bignes not exceeding that of a mall Hens or a Pullets Egg, and in old and decrepid perons they do not arie at this magnitude, but are much les, and do grow flaccid. The Right is by the general conent of the Anatomits, both larger and hotter than the Left; and hence is it that ome do declare, that the Right doth beget Males, and that the Left doth generate Females. And now to enlarge upon their ubtance according to the Antients, and here we hall ee Galen lib. 3. de Aliment. Facultat. cap. 6. doth there pronounce the ubtance of the Teticles glandulous. Riolanus alo joyning in Opinion with him, lib. 11. cap. 3. where he aith, that the Teticles are glandulous and pungy bodies, framed for forming the Seed. Fallopius, Various Authors proving them glandulous, but thee confuted. Spigelius, and Velinguis, as I have already hewn, do all maintain the ame; when they write that the Teticles are made of a ubtance which is both glandulous, white and oft. And N. Higmore. lib. 1. Part 4: cap. 11. doth add this to the opinion of other Authors, that in the middle of the glandulous ubtance of the Teticles,
there is found a certain white, and thick Body, not much irreembling the Vas Deferens, furnihed with no apparent Cavity; or if with any, a very mall one, acending from the bottom of the Teticles to the upper part thereof, into the inward part of the albugineous coat into which it is trongly implanted; neither is it only affixed to this coat, but doth perforate the ame, and is een to inert its elf into the head of the Paratatae, to which it o cloely adheres, that it's not thence eparable but by inciion, tied in the lower and middle part of the Membrane by the intervention of Veels. Wharton in his Book De Adenograph, writes, that the ubtance of the Teticles is both glandulous, white, oft, looe, cavernous or pungy; the which altho it doth want a manifet Cavity, yet it is perviated into a nervous Channel running through its middle, its whole length. But when you have read the Opinions of all thee great Men, you may eaily ee how they have walk'd in the dark, as to the ubtance of the Teticles: Their Opinions carrying in them, no hadow or appearance of
Truth, they writing that the Teticles are glandulous Bodies, they hereby creating a trange mitake, they having in them no reemblance at all of a glandulous ubtance; and he that exactly examines their fabrick and ubtance, hall eaily find their errors,They are made of nothing ele but of minute Veels. for they are made out of nothing ele but a mas of minute Veels framing the Seed; for they are eaily een unravel'd, and that ometimes to a good length, the which no glandule can admit or allow: and for the proof hereof Regnerus de Graaf de Organis Virorum, fol. 56 ejus lib. he there brings this Obervation; Take the Veels of a large Dormoue, and you will readily ee the Veels of the Teticles appear tranparently, white with Seed by the Albugineous coat; the which being laid bare from the aforeaid coat, if they be thrown into a Baon full of water, and tirred a little about therein, you will ee each part eparate from other, the which if they were not made of the ends of Veels, they would not thus admit this eparation and diviion. Such as do want thee Teticles, we do generally call Eunuchs. And
whereas in ome perons very oft times one Teticle hath been een; o alo in others there have been found more than two. Of the Firt ort John Riolan writes of a young man about 25 years of age who had but one Teticle,Hitory. as you may read in lib. 1. cap. 31 and Petrus Borellus Cent. 11. Ob. 60. writes of a Monk having the ame. And Regnerus de Graaf. in lib. de Organ. virorum, Hitory. doth tell us of a Man opened at Leyden who had but one Teticle, no Cicatrice being found either in his Inguen or in his Scrotum, he having had Four Children by his Wife, and he being eriouly asked whether he knew he had more, he ingenuouly told him, her Husband had never but one Teticle in his life. Contrary to thee, we alo read of ome who have had three Teticles, and that thee have o gone along in ome Families. Thus ome Anatomits have writ, that amongt ome of the chief Families of Colen, many have been een to have Three Teticles. And Fernelius lib. 1. Patholog. cap. 8. writes,Hitory. he knew everal Families in which many had Three Teticles; and Foretus lib. 27. Ob. 15.
writes in his Scholio, That he knew a Citizen of Antwerp which had Three Teticles, and was a man who was extraordinarily addicted to Venery. And Petrus Borellus doth alo tell us of both Father and Son, who had each of them Three Teticles. Johannes Riolan, and alo Anthropolog. lib. 11. cap. 29. writes, That he knew a Nobleman who had a plentiful tock of Children by his Lady, who had one of his Teticles, that is, his Right Teticle lodged in his Inguen or Groin, which deceived both his Phyicians and Chirurgeons. And Silvius de la Boc. writes, That in a Nobleman he aw his Teticle lodged in his Abdomen.

div.head: CHAP. XXI. Of the Epididymis or Paratatae.
div.p:
THE Epididymides are frequently by Anatomits, called Paratatae, and by Fallopius are decribed long Bodies tied to either end of the Tetis; planted at its head. Vealius doth very acurately decribe their Figure,Various Opinions about their ubtance. and o doth Regnerus de Graaf in his Book De Organ. Virorum. But as touching their ubtance, various are the Opinions of Authors. Thus Vealius writes their ubtance, much reembling the ubtance of a dry Nerve. Fallopius oppoeth his Opinion in Anatom. Ob. fol. 290. aying this hath not well been oberved by Anatomits; for altho the exterior part of the Epididymis appears nervous in man, yet its inward ubtance is wholly glandulous;
and being cut or divided, you will find it woven out of many minute Glandules. To whoe Opinion both Bartholine, Velingius and many others do willingly aent. And Highmore eems willingly to erre with them, when he ays, lib. 1. Part 4. cap. 11. that the beginning of the Paratatae is made of a glandulous ubtance, like that of the Teticle, being allowed no Cavity, and framed of many glandules, knit together by Membranes. And altho Highmore hath writ the bet of the Paratatae, of any of the former; yet in this Opinion of his, he apparently errs: For whooever doth trictly examine the Epididymis, It is made of everal flexures. hall find, that it is a Body made out of various flexures, and that this is evident, its firt and upper Membrane being laid bare which covers its Body, and tied to the Tetes, you will find many are fractions and windings, the which may with eae be eparated each from other by the knife, without any hurt to the Veels, and thee have after this eparation, been een drawn out to a ufficient length; for they are generally een revolved from one ide
into another, and are kept in their ite by a Membrane which they take from the Albuginea. But to proceed as to the Epididymis, they have not only been een extended, but alo ub-divided, the body being diolved, and this performed without much difficulty; if the thin Membrane which kept up thee anfractions be divided, where you may ee the Veels thereof, as well as you did in the former, whoe flexures are o cloely knit, that by former Anatomits they were taken for one Body; the which, with a little dexterity and patience, may eaily be confuted, epecially if the Epididymis be tumefied by the Seed, or any other ways by Liquor, ent thither by a Syringe. As to the ues of the Epididymis Spigelius does unhappily give it the emnifique faculty wholly, Spigelius and many other Authors ues, acribed to the Epididymis, altho not without error. not allowing the Teticles this Virtue; no Seed being found in the Teticles, as he uppoeth, but a erous Humour only; but he does not hew how Nature made a greater part for the eparation of the Excrement, and a leer for this emnifique faculty and action: nor does he demontrate by what
paages thee collected Excrements hould be dicharged from the Teticles; but in this error he is not alone by himelf, for many others do keep company with him in his Opinion; he uppoing that the permatick Veels did not enter into the Teticles, but arrived at the Paratatae, but that thee do enter the Teticles themelves, and not the Paratatae only, is abundantly manifet; and that the Seed in the Paratatae is made pirituous in the Tetes,That the Seed doth gain it further digetion in the Paratatae. and paing out thence by many other inviible Veels alo, gains a further digetion, and in its longer journey it attains a greater perfection, the which it maintains till it arrives at the Vaa Deferentia, into which it empties its elf.

div.head: CHAP. XXII. Of the Protates.
div.p:
WE next come to the Protatae, the which by the Antients were called nothing ele but a pongy Body made up with many Glandules;This made up of Glandules and hence by Vealius this was called Corpus Glanduloum. Thee Protatae are as aitants to the eminal Veels, and are indeed as two Glandulous bodies, hard, white, and pongy forwards, and backwards depret, round from the ides, about the bignes of a mall Nut or Walnut, or a large Nutmeg, having a thick fibrous and trong membrane from the Vaa Deferentia and lower part of the Bladder. And altho they may eem to contain little humour in them, eeming to have but little commerce with the Vais Deferentibus; yet in
people much addicted to Venery, they are een to well very much, preently after coition, with ome certain ubmucid erous Liquor, the which by compreion does iue out by two mall Ductus's into the rethra and eminal paage.Its Subtance. Thee Protates are aid to have a double ubtance allowed them, as being both pongy and glandulous, every way covered with a trong Membrane, framed thus for the more aptly contringing the Body, for throwing forth, or dicharging this humour eparated from the blood. Thee Protatae, Its Sene. or glandulous Bodies have allowed them as harp a ene as the Teticles, and do make much for the advance of pleaure in Coition. And altho both Dr. Glion and Wharton do acribe them many Nerves, yet Diemerbro ‚Ä¢ ck allows them but very few, and thee aid to be very mall. Its framed of an Oval Figure, and beides the Nerves, Veins, and Arteries which it enjoys, whoe ramifications are plentifully pread over the exterior uperficies of this glandulous Body: in its inward Cavity are een many Ductus's, all which as they are planted at the ides of the great Caruncle,
do exonerate and dicharge themelves into the Urethra, whoe Orifices are accompanied with certain mall Caruncles, o that the matter made in this glandulous body, hould not iue forth continually after the act of Venery, or the Urine flow through thee Ductus's into their body.

If the Ductus of this glandulous body be ditended by Wind,Ob. and then tyed up, you'l find its whole body much ditended; and if it be kept dry after it hath been thus ditended by Wind, and tyed up, it will wholly appear pongeous, becaue the glandules, which firt of all were found about its uperficies, do vanih upon its thus growing dry. As to its ue and Office, its allowed to give the Seed made in the Tetes a greater perfection,Its Ue and Office ending and dipatching the ame into the eminal Veels, and kept there as a reervatory againt future coition: Others diallow this ue deigned it, by reaon of the mall and lender commerce there is between thee Protatae and the eminal Veels. The truth is, the ue of this glandulous body, hath more
than a little tyred the bet Anatomits; for the knot is not yet perfectly untyed;Various ues deigned this by Authors. for beides, the former ues given it, others do aert, that herein is lodged an acrimonious and erous humour eparated from the body, made for giving a greater titillation, or excitation of pleaure in the act of Venery: And ome alo do affirm, that Seed is made and framed herein. But thee are all eaily refuted; for as to the Firt, if this was true, there mut necearily be a communication between the Vaa Deferentia, and thee Protatae, or Corpus Glanduloum, as to their paing out of one into another. As to the Second, this is quite out of doors; for if any one will tate this Liquor, he'll find no Acrimony in it: and this lat has not hit the nail on the head, for catrated people have ometimes been een to eject their Seed. Wharton's Opinion of this glandulous body doth alo meet with oppoition, when he writes, lib. de Gland. cap. 31. that the Seed hath three everal parts for its make; the Firt and mot noble part whereof he aith is framed in the Teticles; the Second and more erous
part thereof in the eminal Veels, and the thicket and mot vicid part in thee Protatae. But this his Opinion gains no foundation: for as the Seed is made in the Tetes, it gains a greater and better perfection in its paage through the Protatae; but much more arriving at the Vaa Deferentia, wherein its lodged till the proper time of its excretion, o that there is no need of this threefold method of making the Seed in three everal parts of the Body, as he uppoed.

Having thus explained the ues both of the Tetes and Protatae, a quetion may hence arie by ome, which ought mot properly to be allowed the Seat of a Gonorrhea. This proved the eat of a Gonorrhea And as anwer to thoe confirmed by Regnerus de Graaf, this may well be allowed the Seat of a Gonorrhea, as well as the Tetes; which Gonorrhea takes its name from < in non-Latin alphabet >
emen genitale, &
< in non-Latin alphabet >
fluere, or if you pleae you may call it genitalis eminis profluvium. And that this may be allowed the proper eat hereof is thus proved; If this Body be o affected, that this kind of matter is not only herein generated, but the ame continually hence excern'd, and this Flux is
generally allowed a Gonorrheal Flux. For Phyicians and Chyrurgeons do not make any difference between this and the Seminal Flux, ave only that they do declare the one to be more virulent than the other. And that uch a Flux may happen, is proved from Tears and grief, in which a continual plenty of Salival Matter, or pituitous Humour is excern'd by the vitiounes of the Glandules. And that alo a great Colluvies of other humours by the illnes of thee Glandules may hence be excern'd, nothing can contradict or gain-ay: for the Patient having taken any Medicine, this hath either pontaneouly, or by ome way or other depoed the gathering together of thee ill juices of the whole Body; the which alo may be allowed to have the ame property and place in this glandulous Body, epecially it being debilitated by Venery, or any other Malignity.
