For our Humours do keep in our Bodies, like Theives in a Prion, where when they do intend to get free thence, they do not begin their exit with the tronget parts thereof, by undermining them, but do eize the weaket.
Thus ill Humours lodged in our Bodies, do not enter the tronget parts thereof, but do force their malignity upon thoe parts which are the weaket, and o the more ready to give them entertainment; neither doth Reaon only, but experience alo prove, that this glandulous Body may be thus affected. For there are many which by experience have tetified, that in diecting of dead Bodies they have een ome affected with this Gonorrheal Flux, even to their Lives end. And for the confirming our Opinion hereof, we can make good by many examples, That thoe who have been great Riders, and ufficiently haken by their Hores, that they have by the ame uffered a kind of Gonorrhea, much reembling a virulent Gonorrhea, ave only, that this doth not o readily proternate the Faculties, nor proves o dangerous as may be made good by Bartholine lib. 1. Anatom. reformat. cap. 23. where he writes of a certain Patavian, who above 30 years laboured under uch a Flux, without any detriment to his health.

Hitory.And Vealius writes, lib. 5. cap. 33. of one perplexed with an involuntary Flux of his Seed, whereupon opening him, and dividing this glandulous Body, as alo the Tetes, they were both found full of Seed; and for the confirming hereof, others as well as Bartholine do declare, that this glandulous Body may well be allowed the Seat of the Gonorhea.

The Teticles alo allowed the Seat of Gonorrhea. And that the Teticles may alo be allowed the Gonorrheas proper manion, is beyond all controverie; And this is thus proved, for we do frequently and apparently find, that upon Quacks and Mountebanks not treating this Dieae aright, as by adminitring untimely Retrictive Medicines in this dieae;And this proved by unskilful giving of Retrictives improperly. they have given it an unhappy uppreion, which hath evidently hewn its elf by the Teticles running into Tumour, which have bee ometimes een to well to that vat bulk, that thoe who have therewith been troubled, have been forc'd to keep them up by Trues, and other convenient bandage oft ued in the like caes, the which thing could never have hapned, unles they were the Manion and place of this
Gonorrhea. And hence it is that when this Seminal Matter which pat through thee Foramina, or mall Cavities, is by the ue and application of thee Retrictives, too much obtructed from any further flowing into the Epididymis, and is o accumulated in the Ductus's of the Teticles, that the Teticles with the Epididymis do run and increae into that great bulk and welling which we jut before mentioned. Women alo having no Protates, Women ometimes troubled with this dieae. ometimes (altho more eldom than Men) are een perplext with a Gonorrhea, which dieae in them without all doubt, doth proceed from their Teticles, they wanting all other Organs allowed proper for forming their Seed. Foretus Ob. 9. lib. 26. writes of a young man troubled with a Gonorrhea, Hitory. whoe Spirits not being much pent, nor his Body emaciated, had this dieae eiz'd him by o're plenty of Seed, which o proved from too great a Plethory, for the multiplicity of Sperm, doth arie from multiplicity of Blood; he being conulted, and finding the Patient Rubicund and Plethorick, by precribing him a thin
Dyet, cooling and drying Medicines, with other Remedies there et down, the Patient uddainly recovered of his detiny.Hitory. Alexander Benedictus lib. uo 24. cap. 3. de Curand. Morbor. writes of a Woman, who being much troubled with uppreion of Urine, her Protates being dryed up by Varices or Glands, planted between her Teticles and eminal Veels, without much pain and trouble, her Bladder not being unloaded, her parts being by Unctious Medicines looned, and her Urinary paages being well cleaned and freed, he enjoyed her former health to admiration. Schenkius in Ob. uis, tells us of Stones happening in this glandulous Body, which did adhere to the neck of the Bladder, one of which is this following.Hitory. Where he writes, we have oberved in this glandulous Body a Stone fixt, whereby the Seed, unles it were mall and aqueous, could not dicharge its elf thence, in coition; This peron being by a Mountebank cut for the Stone, dyed in the Operation under his hand. Cornelius Manilius the Chyrurgeon writes, that he hath found a Stone in this glandulous
Body. And Rhais writes, that he hath een Stones herein alo, as Marcellus Donatus writes Hitor. Med. Admirabil. lib. 4. cap. 30. Aetius Tetralib. 3. Serm. 3. cap. ult. tells us of a young man,Hitory. who when he was concern'd in Coition with a Woman, he could no ways end forth his Seed, but being aleep it readily came from him, and frequently; whence may be collected, that the Seed Veels receiving much humidity with Cold, cannot be warmed, whereas having in leep been warm, they eaily do dicharge the ame, Ret warming the inward parts, and cooling the outward.

div.head: CHAP. XXIII. Of the Glandules of the Artus, or Articulations.
div.p: WE conclude with the Axillary and Inguinal Glands, to which might be annexed, ome which are lodged in the flexures of the joynts, as thoe of the Elbow, Knee, or that great one of the Thigh, commonly called the Popes Eye; and the only thing which offereth its elf as touching thee, is to declare their differences as touching their Names, Magnitude, Figure, and Ues.

As to their Names.Some of thee have proper Names given to them, thus thoe in the Inguen are called Buboes; others known from their ituation, and thus in the middle of the Thigh we call the Popes Eye: And the Axillary Glands do take their Name from their place belonging to the Arm-pits. Thee Glandules
do very much vary alo in their Magnitude,Their Magnitude. for thoe in the Thigh are by Wharton allowed to be Eight, and thee een very large; the Arm-pits have Three uually given to them, but thee are leer than the former; thoe in the Flexures of the Knee and Thigh maller than both the former, and that leer than all the ret, which is planted near the Elbow; their Figures alo are various, ome being round, others Oval.

Wharton in his Book De Glandul. Artuum. tells us of a great Affinity and Commerce between thee Glandules and the Nerves, Wharton's Opinion of thee Glandules. o that he uppoeth the Nerves do conveigh to, and take from thee Glandules; for its proper enough to allow the Nerves bringing omewhat to them, as by ending them ome of their excrementitious juyce; where alo he writes, that thee Glandules do not dicharge themelves into excretory paages, but into the neighbouring Veels next to them, which is generally thought the only reaon of their being planted at the greater diviion of the Veels, for the more eaie reception of the uperfluities of the
Nerves depoed into thee Veels, to which they are trongly annext.

And that they do alo carry omewhat away from the Nerves, is as probable, (vid.) a certain nutritive juyce, the which being milkt out by a imilar attraction of this glandulous ubtance, doth throw forth this mixture of its Lympha into the Lpmphaducts, and by their virtue doth keep the ame thus received from them, and this their own ubtance doth ufficiently make good, which is both weet and delicate, and does carry a very near Nature with that of the Nervous Juyce.

Dieaes happening in thee Glandules, are either imple Tumours, commonly called Buboes, or complicated with venereal or petilential wellings. And thee Caues hereof by Wharton are generally reckoned Two, the Firt being the Blood, obtructed in its circulation, and hence a Tumour arieth, from the hindrance of the Bloods impetuous Flux from the Heart by the Arteries, and its recoure back again out of thee by the Veins. The Second may originally arie from the Nerves, as from their
uperfluities which they let fly and pend into the Glandules, vitiated either by quantity or quality; now where thee uperfluities do only erre in quantity or quality, as occaioned by vicidity, thicknes, or the like, this occaions a imple welling only but when a venenate or contagious Matter arrives here, it begets a Tumour like its elf, anwering the ame Matter of which it is made, be it either venereal or petilential.

Aetius tells us,Hitory. lib. 6. that trumous wellings have not only appeared in the Neck and Throat, but have been een and found in the Arm-pits, and Inguens, Sides, Womens Breats, and the like. And Julius Pollux Gramaticus affirms, that Scrophules do not only arie in the Meentery, but have been found in the Arm-pits and Groyns. He tells us of a Woman in Florence who had a Scrophulous Tumour in her Thigh, which weighed above 60 pound, whoe ubtance did o mightily increae, that therewith he was forc'd to keep her Bed for Five years together, the which at length, was by trict bandage and cauteries wholly eradicated.
Hitory. George Wyrtz Phyician, writes of a Gentleman who had a Struma in his Groin, or rather if you pleae, a Steatome, which exceeded the weight of Forty pounds.

Hitory. Hollerius Ob. 23 lib. Propria, tells us of a noble Painter who had uch a large Ganglion or Wenn in his Thigh, that it exceeded the bignes of a Childs Head; having another large Tumour annext to it: both which were wholly eradicated, and the Patient perfectly dicharged from the ame, and cured.

Hitory. Benivenius, cap. 14. tells us of a Woman, who had a very large trumous welling upon her Thigh, which weighed above Sixty pound, the which proved o troubleome to her, that he was forced to keep her Bed, he being intreated by her Prayers and Supplications to undertake her cure; by a trict Bandage made of Hair and Silk wrought together, he cut the ame near half way thorough; the other part thereof he dipatcht with a red hot Intrument, by which the flux of Blood was wholly uppret: the Woman being near dead, was put into her warm Bed to refreh
her elf, and by having proper Cordials to upport her Spirits, great care ued, and proper Medicines adminitred, he was brought to her perfect health, by God's Bleing going along with his endeavours.

div.trailer: The end of the Firt Book.

div.p: CHAERADELOGIA: OR, An Exact Dicoure OF STRUMAES, OR KINGS-Evil-Swellings.
Wherein are dicovered Their Names & Natures, DIFFERENCES, CAUSES, SIGNS, PRESAGES & CRE, In that Modet and Plain Dres, That the Meanet Capacity may hereby find out the DISEASE.
Written by JOHN BROWN, Sworn Chyrurgeon in Ordinary to the King's mot Excellent Majety.
LONDON: Printed by T. N. for Sam. Lowndes, over againt Exeter-Exchange in the Strand. 1684.

div.head: To the Right Honourable, HENRY Earl of Arlington, Lord Chamberlain of His Majeties mot Honourable Houhold, Knight of the mot Noble Order of the Garter, One of His Majeties mot Honourable Privy Council, and Lord Lieutenant of the County of Suffolk, &c.
div.p:
SInce we generally do meaure the Greatnes of the Sun by the Shadow of the
Earth, and his Goings in the Dyal by the little Thred thereof; Thoe vacant Hours of Leiure which I catcht at Windor this lat Summer, were the only Wings which gave firt flight to my deign in giving a Shape or Form to this Strumous Dicoure; a Dieae as niveral as any other whatoever in our Age. In this therefore I have preumed to preent your Lordhip with the Differences, Caues, Symptoms, Preages, and Cure thereof, according to the bet Medical and Chirurgical Method. And ince I have hewn that
the Court is extreamly viited with this Popular Dieae, and a multitude of poor People do give His Majety trouble too oft for Curing their Dieaes, they will have to be the Evil, although not really o, ave only in their own Conjectures; I have herein undertaken to unmask the ame in that Order, and give it that Light, that the Meanet Capacity may become a good Judge thereof.

As my Obligations therefore to your Lordhip are as well known to the World as great in themelves, o I hope
I may not appear troubleome in making a publick Expreion of my Gratitude to your Honour, and humbly crave Protection under your Wing for this my Scrophulated Treatie; whereby your Lordhip will let the World ee, how great a Mater of Condecention you are, in giving Countenance to this Deign, Life to my Adventure, and Breath to my Dedication.

The whole Kingdom knows your Lordhips Integrity to your Prince, in the Eminent Place of Trut your Honour enjoys, your Steddines and
Contancy in that Religion we do profes; your Prowes, Jutice, Piety, Temperance and Prudence, are as o many Illutrious Gems of your Great Name; all which do both weeten your Noble Nature, appear as Lawrels to your Virtue, and true Heralds of your Perpicuous Lutre.

If your Lordhip will pleae to favour this Addres with your Honourable Acceptance, and pretermit the Lapes both of the Author and his Dicoure, this will infinitely ecure me from the hard cenure of others, and
make me ever more tudy how to declare my elf,

closer.signed: Your Lordhips mot Obedient, and mot thankful Servant, JO. BROWNE

div.head: To the Indutrious Reader.
div.p:
SInce it is the Mode of the Age not to let any Book look into the World without a Preface, it may well eem a wonder, that amongt the multitude of Books with which the World hath been o plentifully tockt, o little hath hitherto been writ of this Strumous or Kings Evil Subject; it evermore having been a Dieae of ancient tanding, and
o general concern with the Sons and Daughters of Men; epecially ince there is carce any kind of Skill but may be learnt by Art, and brought into the Rules of a Curative Method, for the Benefit and Advantage of poor dieaed Mortals.

It was a Law among the Athenians, That every new Act hould be heard with ilence and applaue: which cutom, as it gave a favourable and repective appearance to the Actors thereof, and their Endeavours; o it finiht and compleated the ame with an inevitable danger of digrace for the future, if any lape hould ucceed. The truth is, Men of Learning, Reaon and Experience, and uch who have been free from Fumes, have evermore encouraged the Indutrious
Hand: But we live now in uch an Age, that an Author mut as well tudy the little Plauibilities of the People, who are the great and brisk Maters of Fame, as the value of the Dicoure, the reality of the Matter, or the general good of the Deign, (thee being very kind and zealous where they affect, and as cruel and clamorous where they reolve to contradict) and where Men do once build their Wit upon contradiction, the bet Subject mut hazard their Tet, and uffer their Cenure. And this I have evermore oberved, that never any yet entred the Lits with an Ignorant Bugbear, but he lot much by the Encounter.

But to leave thee: That I may omewhat relieve the Readers patience, I hall enter the
Subject Matter of our Dicoure, wherein although I may well enough agree with Columella's Opinion, that Nihil perfectum aut √† ingulari Indutri√¢ Conummatum, That no Man can oberve all; yet I hope that Huntsman is not to be blamed that catcheth ome, although he may mis others. And becaue I know there are ome ort of Men may think that I live better upon Trancription than upon producing new Matter; yet in this I hope the Crime is not very great, o long as the Reader hath it brought home clean. Others I full well know there are, who will readily uppoe that I have borrowed a part of my Treatie from others; yet ince I had it from the common Stock, and have ditributed the ame for the
advance of publick good, I would willingly know where lies the Injury.

If in this alo I have eem'd to tep aide from the Opinion of the Ancients as touching thee Strumous Effects and Dieaes, I being rather inclined to raie a new Pile of Matter for their Production and Generation, yet I uppoe I am not the firt which have wum againt the tream of their grave Suppoitions, or gray-headed Thoughts, I evermore having been converant in Chirurgery almot from my Cradle, being the ixth Generation of my own Relations, all eminent Maters of our Profeion, ome of the latter of which have been extraordinary well known for their Parts and Skill by many of the mot worthy and knowing Maters
of our Society. I came early alo to the practice thereof in this great City, and have for above Twenty Four Years een the Practick, as well as read the Theorical Part thereof; and this not at Whiles and Intervals, but I had the Eye of the Hopital as my firt and early Gleanings: And ince I could write Man, the late Wars had my Skill hewn on my elf as well as many others who were committed to my Charge.

But to come nearer our Strumous Dicoure, ince I have been blet by my Dread Sovereign's Command to attend as one of His Chyrurgeons at all Healings, (although the meanet) and have een everal Thouands approach his Royal Preence for Eae and Cure, I thought it my Duty as well as my Zeal
to earch into the Roads and Circuits of this Evil, which is een thus frequently to viit the Court. And the only reaon which invited me to this Undertaking, was partly intended to prevent the tedious Journeys of many poor People, who unhappily have undertaken the ame upon pretence of their being troubled with this Dieae, and partly to ecure His Majety from being cheated of His Gold: The firt of which is intended and made good in this, the latter demontrated in the following Treatie.

I have herein therefore (kind Reader) preented thee with a more plain dicovery of this Dieae, than hither hath as yet appear'd in the World, and this perform'd with that plain and
eaie Dres and Method, that the meanet Capacity may be allowed a ufficient Judge in the decription thereof by way of ditinction to prevent confuion.

In this Dicoure therefore is laid down the Name and Nature of Strumaes or Kings-Evil-Swellings, with all their Differences, Caues, Signs, Preages and Cure, in a more full and ample draught than hath hitherto been ever preented to publick view. And becaue I do not deire to keep the Ingenuous Reader too long upon the Title, if he pleae to take an inward urvey of the everal Caues of this Strumous Dieae, he will find that I have introduced the Pox and Scurvy as two great Clubbers towards forming the ame, (epecially in our days, where the Families of
Mankind are generally een more or les tinged therewith) and do keep equal pace with the ame by Seminal Traduction: Both of which being much altered from their firt Beings, by getting an acquaintance almot with every Dieae, they having a very familiar and common dependance one upon another, bred and begot from a tainted Fermentation in the Blood, and an Ebullition of vitiated Humours, by which a common exchange of Symptoms is kept up and maintained between them, according to the Inclinations of uch weakly and debilitated Bodies on which they do make their entrance. But let, kind Reader, I may be thought tedious in keeping thee too long in the Paage, I have this only to ay, That I have
pent this lat Summer with great atisfaction in examining and tracing the Evil in all its Nooks and Corners. If thou findet any thing in it worth thy acceptance, take it freely; and what is wanting in the Authors Capacity, make good in thy elf by a richer piece of Service.

div.head: The Second Book OF THE Kings-Evil,
CHAP. I. Of the Struma, or Kings-Evil in General.
div.p:
AS ome Dieaes are nearer of kin to England than to other Nations, o by the general received Opinion of Phyitians, they do hence take their Caues; their relation to Ditemperiety, aociating with Dieaes which
are mot general and common with them. Thus we frequently ee a vicious Contitution of Place continuing for ome time amongt us: or if for ome mall eaon leaving us, and then making its quick returns upon the Sons and Daughters of Men, this in a very great meaure gives being and growth to a Dieae.

And hence is it that divers Countries have their own proper Dieaes allowed them,Divers Countries allowed various Dieaes. (proved and maintained by all Ages.) Thus to Egypt is granted the Leproie as its proper Dieae; Attica kept up the Gout; Hungary has its particular Fever, Chritned by its own name; Apthae, or Ulcers of the Mouth and Palate in young Children, are very frequent in Syria Some have laid the firt appearance of the French Pox upon Naples, although it long ere that time dwelt in the Wet-Indies, and had longer being ere that in the World, as hall be ufficiently made good in this Dicoure. Plica is generally granted the Polony Dieae, and the Scurvy believed to Sail from the Baltick Sea. Sphacelus was firt thought to arie from a cold Country near the Northern Pole, bringing with
it a Mortification on the Nervous and Membranous parts. Carbunculus allowed an Evil of the Province of Narboenis, and Bronoochele is o common a Ditemper in Bergomy, that the Inhabitants thereof do not take any notice of the ame, they living without pain that have it, generally granted to take its Origination from their common Liquor they Commonly make ue of. And whilt we have thus far travel'd, we have only taken a view of the Dieaes of other Countries, let us come nearer home, and behold our own Iland, and here we hall find it to bear a part with Dieaes and Ditemperiety as well as other Nations; and as England had once the Name of an Englih Sweat,Englih Dieaes. o it hath been very fertile in producing Strumaes, or Kings-Evil-Swellings, Jaundies, Rickets, Scurvy, Conumptions, and the like. And without our Bodies had, and till were ubject to change, we hould not find them o readily aume thee ickly impreions. But Reaon doth ufficiently evince the ame, thee ariing either from the Diet therein made ue of, or ill Habits therein bred, or changes of Temper made by Air, and the
like. Thus we read the Scab of Ethiopia did arie from their exceive Eating, they commonly feeding upon Locuts, which bred this depraved dipoition in them. The Gowt in Attica alo had its being from delicious Food, & their over frequent ue of Venery. And, that Air may very well be allowed an expert Ingredient in forming Dieaes, our own Country can readily confirm, by ending of their numerous Ofsprings (of this Evil we dicoure of) up hither o frequently to be healed.

England very prolifique in producing Dieaes.For whooever examines England in its Nature and Contitution, hall readily find that it is as prolifique in producing of Dieaes, as he is fertile in procuring of Conceptions; and its forty to one, if he gives not as ready a Remark of the one, as of the other, he being no more barren in the one, than he is in the other. And hence is it that not only the trong and Vigorous Man, who enjoys the delight and bleing of Wealth, but the weak and infirm Peron does propogate and beget Children, as every day makes good. And that Women alo who are infirm, and of an ill habit, and Cacochymick
Contitution, do mot readily bear Children, this alo is as plain. And whoever do conider thee both as they ought, may reaonably allow, that a Child begot and bred from uch a Parent, may both eaily and readily derive a Dieae from them, being by Nature made like oft wax, which every one knows doth with eae receive every Impreion which the Seal gives to it.

This Child therefore coming into the World ditempered from its Mothers Womb, enervated,Dieaes from the Mothers Womb. and every day giving greater and better Signs and Symptomes of its depraved Contitution, what can deny its ready yeilding to any Dieae whatoever? I would not willingly be here mitaken, (this not reaching the whole race of Woman-kind) that they themelves are either all infirm, or that they mut necearily erve the World with a dieaed Off-pring. But this I hall preume to aert, that where uch a mixture of ill conditioned Parents do meet in Coitu, and therein and thereby do ue their endeavours to raie a Natural Stock; where uch a product is made, their Children are very eldome
een to carry better metal in them, than they have derived from their Parents; and may as well be allowed to hare of their depraved Natures and Contitutions, as of their Etates and Fortunes.Several Reaons to make good the Aertion. Several Reaons alo might be given for the confirming the ame; for how oft alo hath this been found to arie from the abue of the Commodities cheifly and motly in ue in the Country where thee dieaed People do inhabit? Thus by eating too much Fruit, how many have we een readily urfeited? by drinking too much Wine, too many enfeebled with the Palie and afflicted with the Scuvy and Gout? by living very high, and at eae, not uing much Exercie, have hewn themelves the mot ready Maters for Venery, Debauch, and Lues? All which may well enough be allowed to have ufficient Efficacy in them, to give Being and Breath to Dieaes, and do mot readily either ex toto, or ex parte, daily make good the truth hereof, according to the Times, Places, Natures, Tempers, and Contitutions of the Agents or Actors thereof.

And that this Struma, or Kings-Evil, may well enough alo be allowed Complication
with Pox, Scurvey, Gout, Jaundies, and other Dieaes, hall be ufficiently made good by convincing Arguments enough: For if the Pox hould perchance keep company therewith, or ent, or derived thither, either by Contagion begot from Nures, or an Hereditary Right of Parents, this makes it quite another Dieae from what we have already been dicouring of, both in its Nature and Eence, which by no means may be allowed to have any commerce therewith: But this by time may alo be granted to uffer a ufficient change in its form and nature by the ame, and may be allowed to gain Affinity therewith, and take ome meaures of its Praeternatural Indipoition, as hall be ufficiently made good in my Dicoure of the Caues. The Scurvey we ee alo gets very near acquaintance with this alo, and this is either contracted by Chance, or procured by an Hereditary Right in the tender Contitution of the young Patient; or collected and gathered out of its ill Regiment thereof, as to its Order of Diet, Air, and the like, all or any of which are powerful enough to promote the ame: for
this has no more relation in Children in thee Dieaes, than it hath in others of a longer continuance; in which, by length of time, the Blood becomes tainted, contracting a greater illnes, and to this it eaily yeilds, by reaon of the Infants a verion to Motion, and Exercie, the which does expoe, or rather depoe the Body to a Scorbutick habit; and thus, according to the thick and vicid humours which the Blood contains in it, cattering the ame about ome parts of the Body, does force thee parts which are thus therewith perplexed, to carry the ame Marks, and bear the ame Symptomes as it declares and bears in its elf.

div.head: CHAP. II. What the Kings-Evil-Swelling is, with its jut Name and Nature.
div.p:
WE come now to treat more particulary of a very frequent Ditemper of our Age,The Kings-Evil a Ditemper of our Age. which looks as if it got birth from Commerce and Converation with Mankind; it arriving at that numerous Off-pring, that it meats us almot in every Street; and this for the mot part doth happen in that Age which Philotheus calls < in non-Latin alphabet > , or Tertia Aetas, and it is therefore reckoned by Hippoc. Aphor. 36. amongt Childrens Dieaes. Celus, Aetius, Paulus Aeginetta, Antonius Mu. Braavol. Fallopius, Guido, and everal others do call thee Strumous or Scrophulous Swellings < in non-Latin alphabet > ,Its proper Name. or Adenes Induratae, they allowing them their Originations from pituitous Matter and Blood, generated in this Age of Children
from their voracity, and intemperance of Diet. This is a dieae alo in magnitude having been een to well to a vat bulk, hunting out both the Animal and natural Faculties, lodged chiefly in the Neck and Throat, called by Galen
< in non-Latin alphabet > , or Adenes, or Strumae induratae, as to their ubtance. Phyitians at this day (as to their breeding) are not agreed, ome affirming that they do arie from a plenty of matter, uch as is eroe and glutinous, coming into the Glandules; Galen affirming, Aphor. 36. that they are made of a cold pituitous Matter, Placentinus and Theodoricus with many others as tifly aerting that they are bred from Flegm and Melancholy. Celus contrary to the ret, contends for their haring from all Humours in the Body, in working them up into Tumours. Scrophulae are by mot Authors derived from Scrophae, or Swine, thee Creatures alo being very ubject, and the Subjects of this Dieae; this in them ariing from their Guloity, bred and begot from thick Flegm and Melancholy, having ome fluxile matter therewith adjoyned for advanceing their encreae. And as thee by the
Latines are called Strumae, o by the Arabians they are called Scrophulae. Wharton makes this ditinction between them in his Book of Glandules, where he calls Scrophulae, Wens, and Strumae, the Kings-Evil: of either of which he alo gives this Decription, allowing Scrophulae to run into great Bulk, the which have been een of a vat weight, and do contain in them variety of Juices, which gives them this may ubtance; Strumae, not always increaing, but ometimes een to act their changes in Humane Body, being not always at one tay, they ometimes diappearing, whilt at other times they have been found to hew themelves more apparently. Guido, Laurentius, and everal other Authors do declare Strumae to be indurate Tumours of the Glandules, or as I may ay a kind of Scirrhus therein; and mot Authorities that I have tricktly examined about them, do declare them indurate Kernels, lodged and contained in a glandulous membrane, found evermore either in the Neck, Throat, Bret, Axillaries, Inguens and the like, making their chief abode amongt the Veels, bordering on them, or related to them;
Valecus, cap. propr. calls them Apotems bred in the oft Fleh, or hard Apotems in oft Fleh bred from Flegm and Melancholy. Avicen calls them Glandulae Scleroticae. And amongt all thee Worthies, ince we have given you a urvey of all the Glandules in our firt Book, give me leave amongt thee Worthies to aert my Opinion of this Dieae, commonly called the Evil,The Authors opinion of the Dieae, and its definition. which is no fictitious Ditemper, or imaginary Evil; but rather a proper dieae; and that the Matter of our Dicoure may oblige every common Eye, in its entrance, and make every believing Man joyn with me in the Truth thereof, whereby every one may become in ome meaure a true Judge of the ame, uch things as we have een with our Eyes and treated with our Hands, hall jutly reach their view, and if poibly gain their Approbation.

What the Struma is.This Strumous Dieae therefore, or Kings-Evil o commonly called from his Majeties healing of the ame, is a cold and moit praeternatural intemperiety, generated in the Glandules from a Subaline and Subacid Juice, collated from the wheyih part of the
blood; the which whenoever it enters them, or approach their Membranes, it doth both harden, concrete, incraate, and convert the ame into a coagulate caeous ubtance.

And whereas ever Dieae is contrary to the part which it beiegeth, o it doth daily more and more damnifie and impair the ame; and when this arrives at any conitence, or gains a Habit or Contitution therein, nature her elf beginning to grow weary thereof, and o not able or willing to hold out the conflict, or maintain the battel, is forced to yield thereto, by which the Dieae gets greater footing, and advances into Increment, and augment. For we commonly ee that although the beginnings of Dieaes are obcure, and this Dieae leeps as it were for ome time, yet other whiles they give ufficient Tetimony of their appearance, and make the dieaed apparently convict of their near acquaintance. And as Flegm,Flegm a great Agent hereof. which by all Phyitians is allowed the colder and more moit part of the Blood, or taken commonly for the erous part thereof, o it conequently mut be allowed a great Parent of this
Evil Brat, through which carrying but a mall quantity of Spirit with it, it proceeds more lowly in its coure, than the other part thereof, and may therefore be well enough granted a great Agent of the ame as we hall manifetly make good when we come to treat of its caues.It allowed a moveable contitution.

This Strumous Dieae may alo well enough be allowed a moveable Contitution, it oft-times changing it elf, and keeping its variety of Turns, of being either remitted or intended without any diolution of the whole, and may as well be granted to arie from an inequality of Nutriment, no part exceively increaing and running into greater Bulk than another without an inequality and diproportion of Nutriment. Whereas the common Tone and Harmony of parts is preerved and kept up by the common qualeties equally embraceing each other; and where there is any reces from the jut Mediocrity to either of thee Extreams, there mut necearily follow a viciounes of Harmony,Looenes of parts a great favourer of Strumaes. as is apparantly made good in Strumaces, where we may perfectly behold a Dicraie of Tone in this affect made good by
looenes of parts, the which is alo a great Agent in forming of Tumours, and giving them their Increment: the which being once over-tretcht, does not only run the part into a weaknes, not having in it trength enough to maintain its former vigour, but makes it every day more pliable than other to its commands, till it hath got that greater and looer bulk which we find may uffice for giving entertainment to thee Swellings it is thus een to poes and enjoy.Looenes and moitnes two ineparable Companions in our Bodies.

And that which doth more clearly heighten the truth hereof, is, we hall evermore find, that where there is een a Lubricity of parts, Humidity evermore keeps company therewith: for Lubricity and Humidity are ineparable Companions in our Humane Bodies; o that where-ever we meet with any Lubricious or looe parts, we hall evermore find them moit; and both thee together do call into them a third Companion, which is Stupefaction, and there's nothing that I know hould forbid the ame. For when the Spirits being in their Exaltation hall contract an Acrimony, as is oft-times made good and perceived
by Spirit of Wine upon Aqua Vitae, the Aqua-Vitae being benummed by the Spirits trength, by how much this is advanced in Stupefaction, by o much there is made a greater quantity of Lubricity, and a leer of Acrimony: whence we may conclude, that the dulnes of the Spirits lodged in the affected parts, does much favour this Looenes and Lubrici ‚Ä¢ y, and the Spirits thus loing their Vigour, do give us a true remark of the ame, as Doctor Glion well notes in another cae, and as Galen hath it, (with which I hall conclude this Chapter) Bodies of Children are mot paible, by reaon of their Humidity, Laxity and Softnes.

div.head: CHAP. III. Several Differences of the Evil, both from the Ancients and Modern.
div.p:
STrumae is the common name given to this Dieae; not Struma, Differences of Strumaes. becaue we eldom or never do meet with a ingle one, but many do from thence arie, and that matter thereof which gives being to one in the Glandules, doth alo make way for the entrance of another, the firt growing harder, and o making more ready way for a econd and third; and thee increaing into an indurate ubtance, do alo enlarge the looer parts, and make them more apt to receive as many as they can get in.The manner of their Birth. And thus whilt the Matter is flowing which is thin, erous, and waterih, firt forming a oft Tumour, this in time becomes concrete and indurate, and this alo
incraates therewith. And I preume this may be allowed a reaonable account of their birth and beginning; the Matter again ometimes flowing into three or four Glandules at once, and the Phyitian or Chyrurgeon endeavouring to dicus the ame, they hereby only dicharging the thinner Matter, lay platform ufficient for a Scirrhus, to build its elf upon the thicker and more vicous part which is left behind.

The patients trength or weaknes is alo another conideration.Another difference hereof may be taken from the Patient's trength or weaknes, either of thee having in them power ufficient to procure a greater or leer degree of this Strumous Dieae: For as the Vital and Natural Organs do keep up and maintain their Vigour and Harmony in their Contitution, o alo the Spirits may be allowed to contain in them more or les Vigour, and o be granted more or les dangerous.

Another difference from its ‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ es.Another difference may arie from the Times thereof, which by Phyitians are generally allowed four, viz. Beginning, Augment, State, and Declination; which by Galen are thus decribed, when he calls that Beginning,
when the Crudity of Matter occaions the Dieae; the Augment, when the ame is better digeted; that the State, being drawn from its Excretion; and that allowed the Declination, reducing the remainder to its Natural State: But this comes nearer the Dicoure of Fevers than Strumaes, they no ways maintaining uch a regular Order or Coure. Amongt thee alo Strumaes may be allowed much to differ both in their Magnitude, Nature, Place, Origination, Multitude and Multiplication of Veels.

In their Magnitude,In their Magnitude. they being greater or maller, from their Natural Condition, ome being therewith o lenderly affected, that one would carce believe them concerned or troubled therewith, they both eating, drinking and leeping as well as any Peron whatoever, ave only now and then they have ome twitches and marks of its cloe acquaintance; and and thee dicovered either by their upper Lips, Neck, Throat, Breat, and the like; and although this Dieae may ometimes run into great bulk, as is frequently een, yet it is time alone that gives it this Increment: for the
Motion is low and dull, and unles it be quickned by ome other humour which hath power enough in it to mend its pace, and raie it into a more peedy Motion, it marches on but lowly and leiurely.

In their Nature alo they do much differ,Different in their Nature. as alo in their Contitution, ome of them being benign and without pain, others being more malign, and very painful; ome oft, others hard; ome yielding to Suppuration, others expecting Dicuion.

Different in place & mobility.Different alo in Place and Mobility, ome of thee being elevated, others depret; ome uperficial, others profound; ome being fixt and immoveable, others being looe and moveable; ome een planted in the fore-part, others in the back-part, and others bordering at the ides of the Neck; ome dwelling in the Eyes, others in the Lips; ome in the Neck and Throat, others in the Breat, and ome alo in the Articulations or Joynts: and beides all thee places, although ome there are who pretend greater Judgment in the knowing of Strumaes than others, yet do not, nor yet ever have hewn their greater Reaons for the
ame than others may; yet with their favour and leave we hall find thee Strumous Swellings exerciing everal other parts of the Body, as the Fingers, Toes, Junctures, and the like, which I have often oberved in Childrens Hands, ometimes in their Writs, ometimes found the ame in their Anckles, and at other times in their Feet and Toes; although thee all allowed not Strumaes by ome, they very well bearing their Nature, and increae like Strumaes; and that this may alo be made out very well, more Glandules are dipered through our Bodies which may give being and growth to thee Tumours than we yet have found out.

They alo do much differ in their Origination and Number,Different in their Origination and Number. ometimes thee being een (although rarely) ingle, many times double, and o daily increaing their tock, ome being few, others appearing more in number; ome large planted in the Plexures of Joynts, where Glandules are appointed for utaining and keeping up the Veels jut under the Cutis; others being more properly called Glandulous Bodies, whoe Habitations are
een in the inner parts of the Body, as the Omentum, or Kell, Breats, Pancraeas, Meentery and the like; ome are ariing in the Neck, others in the aforementioned parts. And amongt Flegmatick Excrecencies are thee following numbred, many of them being very near related to Strumaes, or Strumous Effects, of which ort are thee: Glandula, Nodus, Lippitudo, Bronchochele, Artheroma, Steatoma, Meliceris, Bubo, Tetudo, Botium, Cancer & Spina Ventoa, of every of which I hall preume to touch in their Order.

What Glandula is. Glandula, which by Guido is aid to take its name from Glans, it very well reembling a Hailtone or Kernel, is oft, moving and eparate from its circumjacent parts, bred generally in the Emunctories. And that which hews the difference between this and Struma is this: They being generally made both of one and the ame Matter, and bordering about the ame places, the Strumae generally living, if not always in the Glandules; and the Humours which feed them being different from others; And herein lies the difference between Glandula and Strumae, the
Matter of the Glandule being more ubtile and thin, that of the Struma thick and vicid; and hence Galen, Lib. 3. de Loc. affect. writes, that when this thin and ubtile Matter does incraate and grow vicid, it readily forms Strumae; and this is alo defended by Aeginetta and Avicen. And becaue indurate Glandules are more eparate from the Fleh, o that although without much difficulty they may be known from the ame, by the touch, yet it will not eaily appear, how thee Strumae may be known from thee Glands acting the ame parts in its Neighbouring Fleh. Avicen tells us, thee are generally found in the Hands and Feet, as alo in many other Nervous parts of the Body, calling them Glandulous Apotems bred from Flegm. Valecus ays they are een larger or maller according to their greater or leer quantity of Matter or Humour which gives them their Increment, allowed ometimes to grow from a mall Pea or Cizer, to the largenes of a Melon, as Rhais writes he once aw. Glandula therefore is an Excrecence framed by indurate Flegm, and Strumae differs from this becaue
they are conjunct, and many planted together, neither are they vexatious, or accompanied with much pain, Glandulae being fewer in number, and not o eaily traduced from one place to another.

What Nodus or Ganglion is. Nodus or Ganglion is alo bred from a hard, thick, and vicid Flegm, happening motly in the Nervous and Tendinous parts, but chiefly in the Head and Joynts, on the Hands and Feet. A Node therefore being allowed a knotty-coagulated Tumour, does much vary from Strumae, whoe proper Abode and Habitation is in the Glandules.

p.U:
o called by the Greeks from Bronchus the Wind-pipe, and Chele Hernia, or Rupture. This Tumour by Celus is allowed to arie between the Cutis and the Wind-pipe, whoe Matter being lodged in a Cytus, or Bag, is dull Fleh, omewhat reembling Honey or Water. Or if you pleae,
it is a large round Tumour, generated from a Flegmatick Matter, ometimes een to take up the greatet part of the Neck and Throat, wherein variety of Matter hath been found ometimes reembling that of Atheroma, ometimes that of Steatoma, or Meliceris, ome Countries affording more plentiful examples hereof than others. Thus the Inhabitants of Piedmont are thought to take this Dieae o common amongt them, from the Liquor of which they make their uual Drink, being for the mot part as is reported made of melted Snow. And this by mot Authors is taken for another Companion of the Evil; and if you do accurately diect the Anterior part of the Neck from the right ide to the left, you will auredly find firt the Wind-pipe whence this Bronchochele takes its Origination, and upon this you'll meet very large Glandules, quartering under the Larynx, which makes up thee exuberant Swellings, commonly called Gozza in the Country it's o frequent in. After this maller in their ides, and thee are thoe which makes your Scrophulae, or Strumae, whoe conitence hingeth either upon ome
Internal Jugular Vein or Artery, and Recurrent Nerve: the which parts if you curiouly examine, you cannot be mitaken in finding a Bronchochele from a Strumous Tumour, and likewie as readily prevent the dangerous extraction of one from the other. I have known many people alo cured of this by His Majeties gracious Touch only.

div.p: Atheroma, Steatoma, Meliceris, are generally allowed Flegmatical Swellings, and Excrecencies; and they do differ from other Tumours by their being lodged in everal Bags or Membranes, and do every of them carry in them diverity of Matter, they generally hapning in the Membranous parts, and in thoe places which are different ditance from Mucles; and every of thee do take their Names from the variety of Matter which they do carry with them.

Thus Atheroma by ome Authors is called Nodus Pulticulous, What Atheroma is. the Matter which is contained in its Bag or Membrane much reembling Pule, ariing from mixt Humours, in which Flegm is a very great Agent; for from this it takes its white colour it eems to contain
in it, and doth maintain other waterih Qualities, it appearing much like Whey, and is a longih, round, ublated Tumour.

What Steatoma is. Steatoma alo is called Nodus Adepinus, carrying in it the ubtance of Fat or Sewet, much reembling Sewet, which the Greeks call < in non-Latin alphabet > , which bears a great part of its Name, it being at firt mall, and by length of time purchaing and contracting a hardnes, becoming a round Tumour, not elevated, but rather depreed; and as Aetius doth affirm, it adheres firmly to the Cutis, its ubtance not being fluid, but compact and coacted, and not contained in a Cytus, or Bag as the former, but lodged between two Membranes or Coats, and may in ome meaure be allowed to generate like Fat or Sewet from intemperiety of parts, or dicraie of Blood.

What Meliceris is. Meliceris is alo called Nodus Melleus, containing in its Bag Matter much reembling Honey, wanting pain, carrying a round Figure with it, by Aetius it is thus decribed, being an abcee incloed in a Nervous Coat, containing in it Matter much like Honey, wanting pain, having a round Figure,
eaily yielding to touch, and as eaily gaining its former hape and figure; all thee are, and have evermore been reckoned in the number of Strumous Tumours; and of this ort alo I have known very many cured by His Majeties Touch alone.

Bubo taking its proper Name from its place the Groins,What Bubo is. (which by our common Englih-men is alo taken for that place which is called Popes-Eye) bears in it the Strumous, as well as the Venereal and Petilential Swellings, this place being the part where the Nerves do end forth their Excrementitious Juyces, as well as the Axillaries, both being Natures bet Emunctories, by which he dicharges her Illuvies from the Humane Body, as alo the only places to which he deigns the ame. And as Venereal Swellings having herein appeared by the Corruption of the Blood, it being deprived and tript of its former Vigour and Eence, and altered and changed by this malign Humour, and the Plague acting in the ame manner by poyoning thee Glandules with their Venom and Foetid Humour, o are both the Axillaries and Inguinal Glandules een
uually afflicted with thee Strumous Swellings.
What Tetudo is. Tetudo is a Tumour both large and oft, its greater part being made of Flegm, and its leer of Melancholy.

What Botium is. Botium is always aid to live in the Throat, and becomes larger than the former, and its Increment doth proceed from a Flegmatical Carnoity begot from Rheum, ditilling from the Brain into the Throat, happening more frequently in ome Regions than in others. Thus in Calabria, the Inhabitants thereof drinking commonly a thick, vicous, and muddy Water, are frequently een troubled with this Ditemper, being bred from a great part of Flegm, and a leer part of Melancholy; and this does hew its elf more fluxile when Flegm exceeds in quantity, but when Melancholy gets the upper hand, this gives the Swelling the hardnes we find it bears; this by many Authors being alo called Parythimia.

What Cancer is. Cancer, which takes its Name from a Crab, having expanded Claws and Feet, being of a Livid or Cinerih Colour, does much reemble this Tumour, whoe Figure is round and of a Livid
Colour, and does as cloely adhere to the parts on which it enters, as a Claw of a Crab in its gripe. And although ome Authors will needs have this to have affinity with the Struma, I cannot o readily comply with them, unles the Struma proves Ulcerous, and then it may as well prove Cancerous: for Flegm, as it is a dull, heavy, flatulent Companion, and void of pain, and does not carry much ene in it, or with it; yet when it takes Adut Choler into its cognizance, and this gains better and nearer acquaintance therein, this in time maters the other, and makes the Patient feel the Vigour of its prevalency, by its corroive, cruel and terrible pain which it brings along with it.

Spina Ventoa is a Tumour of the Bones;What Spina Ventoa is. and although the outward Shell thereof may appear hard, yet the inward Juyces are all putrid and rotten within; and this does comprehend in it all the mall Bones of the Hand and Foot, Fingers and Toes, the Skull alo and Mandibles, and carce a Bone in the Body but may be liable to this effect: thee I have very oft thus found in Strumous Bodies in my own
practice, where I have frequently oberved, that although the Cortex of the Bone hath eemed ound, yet the Body thereof hath apparently hewn its elf pongy and rotten. And this was evident enough in a young Gentleman which came from Oxford, who was Patient to Dr. Lower, where Mr. Peare and my elf were concerned as his Chyrurgeons, whoe very mall Bones of his Intep were o rotten, that I did pas my Probe quite through the whole Intep, without any oppoition whatoever, after he was dead, as everal of his own Friends aw, and ome other Chyrurgeons, who aited me at his opening.

The Evils proper Names according to its proper places.The Struma, or Kings-Evil therefore, when it eizeth the Eyes, its proper name is Lippitudo, bringing frequently with it a hardnes, wellings, and drines on the upper Lip.
If it arieth behind the Ears, its proper Title is Parotis.
If it eizeth the Neck and Throat, and o marcheth down all along the Matoideal Mucle, this is Struma, or Scrophula.
If it covers the Wind-pipe with Tumours, its called Bronchochele.
If it enters the Glandules of the Throat, Parythimia and Botium.
If it eizeth the Axillaries or Inguens, Struma Axillaris, or Bubonoa.
If it gets into the Bones, and begets a cariounes in them, Spina Ventoa.
If it carries variety of Subtances in it, according to the Humour or Matter which is therein contained, it may well enough be named, either Atheroma, Steatoma, or Meliceris.
If Flegm be the chief Agent, it may make Tetudo, Ganglion, or Glandula.
If it meets other Humours therewith complicated, as Melancholy, or Adut Choler, it may properly be allowed either Scirrhous or Cancerous. And thus much as touching the Differences of Strumaes.

div.head: CHAP. IV. Several Caues of Strumaes, or Kings-Evil-Swellings.
div.p:
‚Ä¢ . Antecedent caues of Strumaes.I Begin this with the Antecedent Caues hereof; and here we hall oberve, That uch Dieaes which may be allowed a near relation and affinity with this, may alo be granted to agree with the Eence thereof; as thoe which are of a cold intemperiety, or moit, or relating to both: for this temper is the proper Bais of this Dieae, by which it produces uch an innumerous off-pring of little oft Swellings, the which afterwards are een to run into Concretion, and at length becomes incraate and indurate; whereby we may alo preume to introduce this Obervation, That violent Dieaes do not o eaily and readily change into mild Ditempers, as
thee do, or may do into Dieaes which are more forcible. Thus if a cold and dry intemperiety hould happen in a Child, it would from its own temper peedily beget a change as to a cold and moit ditemperiety; and hence is it that cold Digetions are made imperfect, and hence Crudities and crude Homours do ucced, the which in this tender age of Infancy and Youth may well admit of a moit intemperiety to keep company with them, every Man knowing that the Sperm of Creatures, by how much it is more moit than the Creatures which are thereby produced, by o much alo is it more lippery, the Fleh of younger Creatures being more oft and lippery than that of Old age, and the like.

Another caue hereof alo may be referred to an inequality of Nutriment;2. This alo may be allowed to inequality and diproportion of Nutriment. not an inequality of Nutriment acribed to it, for when we ee one part thus exceively increae, and another wants its due and decent quantity, ther's a neceity of allowing a diproportion and inequality of Nutriment, having ome prae-exitency in the Body, where one part borrows and gets from another, whilt the other loes
and leens in its mediocrity and true proportion: for uneven Swellings do declare ufficiently the Liberal Nourihment in their tumefied parts, which the extenuated parts do as readily hew in their los and want thereof. But eeing this inequality of Nutriment is a depraved action, and does appear and hew its elf as a caue of the Organical Vices, we hence ought not to allow thee Organical Vices the firt Radix of this Dieae, whilt we hew agility and activity of Body to heat and warm, and the coldnes and denity thereof declaring themelves by their tardines and lownes. Take this therefore as a plain Demontration thereof, when and where we ee thee helps which do excite, increae and cherih heat in the outward parts, does in a plentiful meaure add to the Decription of the Matter or Humour contained in thee Swellings; the which being cat together in a Lump, hath power ufficient to dicard and banih this Dieae, whereas a cold Ditemper in its own natural Contitution being firt herewith affected, may very well be granted the primary caue and eence of this Dieae.

The Spirits alo being defective in the affected parts,3. Another caue from defect of the Spirits. do alo declare and demontrate an evident ign of their Lubricity; and as their flaccidnes doth comprehend a looenes, o they do arie both from one and the ame caue; and as thee two do include a certain vacuity or emptines, its evident that from the Stupefaction of the inherent Spirits, the plenty and vigour thereof being augmented, the lank or flaccid member or part is eaily hereby rendred turgid and tumefied.

Provident Nature as a Guard to this hath not excited Vital Spirits in the Arterial Blood for their own ake only, neither are they ditributed to the parts, and joyn'd to them only for their own advantage, but rather that they might enliven and brisk up the inherent Contitution of the olid parts; and hereby actuate, invigorate, and promote their Faculties. Hence we ee all Creatures, the more liberally they do feed, the fatter and more flehy they grow, unles ome impediment does intervene: but if the due quantity of Nutriment be ubtracted, they grow lean and extenuated; when therefore any one part hath a more liberal
diproportion thereof than another, reaon mut allow this to increae, and grow into a Bulk, whilt the other becomes as it were tarved, being robb'd and tript of its jut and even meaures. For when the attractive, retentive, and digetive Faculties do recede from their firt Vigour, and do unduly and ineffectually execute their Offices and Functions, thee may well enough be allowed alo another primary caue of this Dieae; and for clearing hereof, where looenes, oftnes, and lubricity of parts, as I have already mentioned, does appear, the expulive Faculty herewith becomes vitiated, and the breathing is too eaie and diipative, and the Circulation of the Blood becomes lippery, the retentive Faculty alo through weaknes of parts loes its pritine Vigour; and where the Expences do exceed the Incomes, there mut conequently follow a decay of the publick Stock, the Exportation being found to exceed the Importation.

4 The purile age another caue hereof.Amongt the other antecedent caues alo may be reckoned the purile age; for as Hipp. hath it in Coac. praenot. from the 42 year of Mans age,
even to the 60th year thereof, neither Strum, Stone, Gravel, Doral, or Renal Pains are generated, unles begun before, and o till continued: but of this more when we treat of Hereditary Dieaes.

Thee two following may appear as good caues of this Dieae,5. Two other caues. as when the Matter out of which thee Swellings are made being thick and vicid, having a contumacy therewith adjoined, and here the bet of skill may be hewn to eradicate thee Strumaes, and extirpate both them and their Radix, by taking hence a new upply of Humour fitted for its purpoe, there remaining here ome Ahes (as Galen hath it peaking of Fevers, Agues, and the like) which are apt enough to blow up a new Fire, being already warm, corrupting the next Humours, and inflaming them, whence he uppoeth doth ucceed the Renovations or Returns of Dieaes which are daily een to bear. A econd may be the Folliculus, or Bag to which every of thee little Tumours are o cloe adherent, that they are carce thence diviible: whence it happens, that the Matter thus left in them, although
partly dicharged, yet the remaining part behind does give a very great occaion to the increae to a new Generation of Strumaes, bred from a depraved Humour: and were this Bladder by the Indutry of Chyrurgery totally extirpated, yet there may be ome Ramifications left behind like Ligaments which may give being to a freh growth and increment of the ame.
Quet.But here may arie a Quetion, How it happens that ometimes thee Strumaes hall be een lodged in Bags, and other-whiles they hall be found free thereof?

Rep.To which I hall give this Anwer; Thee Folliculi, or little Bags, are nothing ele than ome mall Membranous Veficles, in which thee various Humours are lodged, and that thee Membranes (as Hipp. hath it in Libr. de Carnibus) are made of the dryer part of the Blood, and that part thereof which is mot glutinous and congealed by cold, (he alo writing that all Membranes are made from the beginning of their Origination) while therefore this glutinous Matter thereof is congealed by cold, we hall find
it covered with a thin Membrane, as we ee the Blood is in Diection of Humane Bodies, or in Phlebotomy, where the thinner part of the Blood flies out briskly, being hot and moit, the which when it is cold, we hall find the ame as it were covered over with a thin Membranous Vail. Thus Strumae, in which the Matter is void of vicoity and glutinoity, although it may in time omewhat thicken and congeal, yet it does not make any of this Membranous Coat: But on the contrary, when as there is found a glutinous part therein, and when the Matter therein lodged is concreted, as Hail is out of Snow by Coagulation, this kind of Cutis is made about it as its proper Tegument, the which it properly takes to its elf, and in it does frame and form its Incraation.

Tumours alo which do obcurely and by degrees fall into the Nervous parts by the Membranes from the external part of the head into the Glandules,6. Another caue. and once getting therein footing, may be well allowed great Promoters of Strumaes, and when-ever adut Choler or Melancholy does intermix therewith, they do generally
beget a virulent and fierce Ulcer, which we commonly call Struma Carcinomatodes.

Another caue is Congetion of Humours.Another efficient caue hereof alo may be allowed Congetion of Humours in the Glandules; Now the caue of Congetion is Fluxion of Matter to a place, and attraction, expulion, or concited Motion in Humours is the caue of Fluxion, the caue of all which is the Congetion of the ame in the Body. Again, ill Diet, looenes and weaknes of parts, as I have already ufficiently made good, are great intrumental occaions of Congetion; and hence is it that young Children are o frequently een troubled with thoe Swellings, and mot ubject to thee Dieaes, they neither uing any regular method of Diet, much abounding with Crudities, and coacervated with many Excrements by want of Exercie.

Avicen calls them Melancholy Products,7. Flegm another caue. and Galen will have the efficient caue thereof to be Flegm, which is the Excrement of the firt Concoction, the Liver in uch being much better and weeter than in uch who have lived to a greater age. And the truth
is, whether Flegm be taken for the colder and moyter part of the Blood, or the Whayih part thereof, or for Spattle, or for the Mucous Subtance which paeth from the Notrils, or Jaws, or for the Pancreatick Juyce, take it for which you will, if this be long continued and contained in the Body, it hath a direct reference to this dieae, and may well enough be allowed the caue thereof: for as it is cold and moyt, o it is low and thick, benumming the parts, being but little Spirituous, and affected with an Internal Lubricity; all which does evidently demontrate this as a primary eence of the ame. Wherefore upon a uperfluous Accumulation of this humour, managing a production of this affect, it in jutice ought to be allowed a proper caue, and primary Agent thereof. Thus far have I travelled upon the general ground of caues, where I have een and hewn them as they have been allowed by the bet of Authority.

But becaue I am well atisfied thee may not pleae every Mater, I hall take a Turn or two, and examine the Caues hereof nearer home, and trace
this Strumous Dieae as to its Hereditarines from Parents to Children; wherein, that we may fully atisfie the World, we hall make this good by comparing Dieaes which are properly, from thoe which are o improperly called: wherein alo the Parents faults are to be laid open in every repect, as giving being thereto. Next we hall hew the Caues of this Dieae, being o incident to Children: wherein we are to take notice of the five non-natural things in their ue, as to the Air, Meat and Drink, Motion and Ret, Sleeping and Waking; of the other five things praeternaturally cat out and retained, and why this Dieae happens more frequently in England, Scotland and Ireland, than in any other part of the World; and the reaon of its natural inclination to them; and as a concluion to the whole, I hall make good, That the POX and SCURVY are very great Clubbers towards its advance and growth, epecially in this our Age, where Debauch is o frequent, and Venery become the common Harlot of the Times.

We begin with the firt,8. Whether this Dieae be Hereditary. of which I hall preume to offer, That before we hall or can atisfie this point fully, we mut make good thee two differences of an Hereditary Dieae; the one properly o called, the other improperly o termed. That which is to be allowed properly o, is ever uppoed to be pre-exitant in both, or one of the Parents, and from thence derived to the Succeors; whereas an improper Dieae o called hath not the ame kind of pre-exitence in either of the Parents: yet the ame fault preceeds which imprints the like in the Children, which thence o readily fall into this improperly Hereditary Dieae.

Again, A proper Hereditary Dieae is two-fold, either in Conformation,An Hereditary Dieae two-fold. as a lame Father begetting a lame Child, or a blind or deaf Parent acting in its like, or in the Similary Contitution, as when a Gouty, or Scurvy, or Strumous Parent begets the like Children. An improper Dieae o called, may alo likewie appear in Conformation, or Similary Contitution: In Conformation, when neither of the Parents are blind or lame, yet thee have begotten
a blind or lame Child, by the very fault of Formation. And in Si
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¶ ary Contitution alo there may lodge an Hereditary Dieae o improperly called, as when a Melancholy or intemperate Parent begets a Gouty Child, or a Strumous Brat, although the Parent never himelf was ever troubled with either of them. And this we have apparently een, that although neither of the Parents were in their Infancy or Childhood afflicted with this Strumous or Evil Dieae, yet Symptomes thereof have uddenly hewn themelves, and their dipoitions thereto in their Infants and Children; epecially in uch Parents who before Coition were evilly dipoed by vitioity of Body, or errour of Life, having enough in them to tranmit and tranplant the relation thereof to their iue: but of this more by and by, made good by Arguments prevalent enough.

Again, Children however they may borrow ill dipoitions from their Parents, as we frequently find it happens, which may produce the like effects in them; yet they are eldom therewith troubled before they be
born; and when at any time they hew themelves therewith perplext, their effects are both violent and turbulent; and for proof hereof we do affirm, (as worthy Dr. Glion does in another cae) That this Dieae does conit chiefly in a cold Ditemper of the firt affected parts, with an inequality annext thereto. And this inequal coldnes of the ame parts is of o great moment in this Dieae, and that alo in relation to the inequality its elf, that it does much advance the inequal ditribution of the Vital Blood to the parts thus affected. But in the Womb this inequality of Nutriment is much amended by an equal heat, the Womb equally in each ide embracing and cherihing the Body of the Embryo, and hereby drives away a great part of this Dieae, or at leat does much hinder its invaion to it.

We come next to give ome account of the Parents caue of this Dieae,10. Caues on the Parents ide for begetting this Dieae. as being nearet in kin to them; and here may the faults of their Sperm enter as a great Agent thereof in relation to the Generation of the Embryo, others having reference to the Embryo ready conceived, and carried in the Womb.
The faults of the firt proceed either from the Man or the Woman, or from the whole Body, or ome parts thereof deigned by Nature for Generation.

The Parents faults depending upon the whole Body.The Parents faults depending upon the whole Body, mut necearily be allowed to have a powerful influence in the Child, tranmitting uch Matter to the Seed in its Generation, as may improperly be thought fit to have abode in thoe parts deigned for this Office. And when we come to reckon up thee parts, we hall find them reduced to four Claes.

Four Claes hereof.The firt containing in it a cold and moit ditemper of the Matter whereof the Seed is generated, and this is bred from a cold and moit ditemper of the Parents, from whence unto which we alo may refer a predominancy of ill Juyces, epecially that which is moit and flegmatick. To this alo may be referred the French Pox, Scurvy, Jaundies, Rickets, and the like, in all which affects the Blood is polluted with filthy Excrementitious Humours, corrupt Exulcerations, and the like; all which are not eaily to be changed into a laudable and fruitful Sperm.

The econd hews the lendernes and paucity of Natural Spirits, which hould be generated in good Seed; a good Seed never iuing from uch a kind of Matter; and the Caues which hatens this impure Matter to the Generative parts, are the extenuated Bodies of the Parents, wated or conumed either by abtinence, or ome vehement Evacuation of Hepatical Fluxes, or Chronical Dieaes, all which are powerful enough to pend the Radical Moiture, to create an indigetion in the parts from an imperfect and defective Concoction: And ince uch a coniderable part of the Dieae conits in the paucity of Natural Spirits, it cannot otherwie be, but the iue which thence proceeds, and is propagated by uch a crude and almot piritles Seed, hould be tainted with uch a Natural Propenion to this affect, the which is afterwards deduced into act.

A third hews the Stupor, or Dullnes of the Matter tranmitted to the Generative parts, whereof the Seed is framed and produced; and hence is it that Phyitians do produce thee caues of Dieaes, when they allow
the Blood and Humours being either too fluid, or moving diorderly, or that ometimes it is found unapt for motion, being les fluxile, and unactive to anwer expectation. But now as to Parents in this Strumous or Scrophulated concern, wherein as in a Glas the Childs oft, looe, and effeminate Contitution, and its weak Dipoition, or (as I may better ay) its Indipoition to exercie, and then examine its great intemperiety of Diet and Epicurim, the two great products of Crudities and Flatulencies, where meeting with an eaie and edentary life, tript from perplexities, anxieties, or vexations, as well as exercies, eldom or never accutomed to labour, care or danger, thee being the never-failing Companions of peace, eae, and tranquility; all which does mot clearly demontrate a lazines and effeminacy in parts. And whereas the Blood in its Circulation and paages through thee parts cannot readily pas thorow without borrowing omewhat of their nature and acquaintance, as well as cognizance of their temper, it mut necearily therefore bear a part therein, and carry ome hare thereof to the
Generative parts; and I hope where uch Influences are derived in the Seed, it hall not need or require much trouble to prove, that that Child who takes its Origination from uch Principles, mut with it alo take ome of their Nature therewith, or at leat ome proportions conformable to this tupidity; and that this proportion after birth, when the aforeaid preervation is leened and taken away of its equal cherihing whilt it was in the Womb; this may as readily be reduced into act; and ince this tupidity, as I have already hewn, may be allowed as a part of the primary eence of this Scrophulous Dieae, there mut conequently follow ome vitiated principles, which may lurk in the Body, ready to create and tamp the like effect derivative from one or both of the Parents.

The fourth hews a vitious dipoition, if any uch there be of the Parents, who themelves in their Childhood were thus affected: for thee do properly indeed imprint a Continuandum thereof, and tranmit the ame to their ucceive Generations. But becaue in our Dicoure hitherto the
fault of the Parents may well enough be referred to any of thee Claes, or all of them, let this uffice,

The Genital parts allowed proper Agents of this Dieae.And come we now to a nearer Enquiry as touching their Genital parts, and oft-times we hall ee thee the only faults or framers of this Dieae, they ometimes uffering a cold and moit intemperiety in them; and when ever an over-plenty of moiture does enter thee parts, it doth create a looenes and weaknes therein, wherein and whereby the Seed thus ejected becomes either no way fertile, or if o, it proves fruitful for Dieaes. Again, we find thee parts frequently affected and afflicted with Gonorrhaea's, French Pox, and the like, where the Seed thus thrown forth is either putrid, or not ufficiently elaborated, or no ways capable of producing a firm or ound Embryo.

11. Fluor albus and Mentrues.In Women alo we hall as readily ee them troubled with their Fluor albus, as well as Mentrues, both which alo can act a diverity of change in the compoition of the Embryo, all which does carry, tranmit, and ditribute of their own nature and kind to the Seed thus prepared in them,
and dipoeth the ame without any delay to their Progeny or Stock; and this as readily receives the true effects thereof. And having traced thus far in our intended deign, by opening the very Womb, to earch out the firt caue of this Dieae from Parents, by examining their prolifique Seed, the great Production both of Patient and Dieae, we proceed now in a more gradual manner, and open the Mothers fault, Man alone not being the great Intrument hereof: And here we may begin with the time of her bearing this Embryo. Now where there happens a cold and moit Ditemper of the Womb it elf, this may with eae I hope be allowed to communicate the ame to the Embryo which is kept in it by contact, or where cold and moit Juyces do here arrive, thee converted by Excrementitious and corrupt Humours, in tead of laudable Aliment or Nutriment, pray what may hinder a cold and moit imperfect digetion, not being timely concern'd, and o ent and tranmitted with the Mothers Blood for the Nutriment of the Embryo? And if a cold and moit intemperiety with this Matter does invade
a Woman with Child after her Conception, no quetion but this impure Nutriment which nourihed and cherihed the Seeds, or the Dieaes, may eaily be allowed tranmiion and dipenation to the Embryo. But hitherto we have been dicouring of the Embryo whilt it was framing, and dwelt in its Mothers Womb; now let us look upon it as it came into the World, and examine and trace its way of living, and getting this Dieae of the Evil which our Dicoure hath chiefly aimed at, and this alo comes under the Names of Its Caues.

12. Caues of this Dieae incident to Children.Our ubject Matter therefore now is to hew the Child as it appears in the World; where we may offer, That thoe Children which are prone to this Strumous Dieae from their Nativity, are eaily therewith affected: whereas others free from ditemperiety do not o readily fall thereinto, but upon more powerful Caues, and yet thee Caues mut have omewhat of affinity therewith, and do only differ in degree.
Quet.And here a Quetion may be offered, Whether Contagion may be admitted amongt the number of Caues of this Dieae.

Indeed by its Circuits and Travels about the World, whereby it hath made it elf o well known and common to the Sons of Men, and dipert it elf through many Countries, any one at firt view might think it carried a Contagion with it:Rep. But he who more cloely looks into it, and its nature, will find it far otherwie; for all Dieaes conpire to change, and aimulate thoe Bodies which are nearet to themelves, & yet this is not enough to make them be call'd contagious Dieaes: For to frame a contagious Dieae, as Sennertus well oberves, is to create a certain Seminal Fermentation of its elf, the which ecretly getting abode in our Bodies, may by degrees introduce a Dieae of the like Species into our Bodies. But in this, here's no uch Fermentation ever een or found: for the firt beginning of this Dieae, (as I have already ufficiently made appear) does arie from a cold and moit ditemper, where, not meeting a ufficient inherent Spirit to invigorate it, and this endeavours an Aimulation in any parts of the Body, they do not only attempt, but enter the ame with or by open violence:
For we have een Children much of an age, brought up in the ame Houe, whereof one or two perhaps have been troubled with this Strumous Dieae, whilt we apparently find others thereof no whit concerned therewith; and therefore if any Contagion went along therewith, or this were catching, as ome people do fancy, this could no ways thus happen.

And if we examine this Dieae aright, we hall find that the five nonnatural things in their ue may be well allowed advancers hereof; and this was my next Task to make good according to my Aertion.13. Air a main caue of this Dieae. Air therefore may well enough be allowed a great Promoter and Procurer of thee Strumous Dieaes, as hall more appear when we come to peak of our Neighbouring Nations as well as our own. A cold and moit Air therefore doth very much contribute to the begetting this Dieae: for eeing it generally eieth and enters the Circumferential parts, before it gets being in the fenced Bowels, it directly imprints in them this inequal and tumefying ditemperiety. And whoever further traceth this Dieae in its progres, hall find
that places near the Sea and Marih Grounds, where Rains mot commonly do fall upon, and fed with a number of Springs, are very fertile and fruitful Friends to this Dieae, thee creating a more or les looenes in the parts, and making the Circulation of the Blood too lippery; and hence is it that Chyrurgeons are never een to apply any cold or moit Medicine to thee Strumous Swellings.

As touching Meat and Drink alo,14. Meat and Drink another caue hereof. whatoever Diet is moit and cold, vicous and obtructing does manifetly nourih and cherih this Dieae, as Fih, Cheee, Curds, and the like plentifully fed on: Feeding too liberally alo is a great advancer of this Dieae, by choaking the heat, and thereby accumulating many raw and crude Humours.

And for Motion and Ret,15. Motion and ret others. thee two alo ought to be well conidered in thee Strumous Effects: for as too much Motion and Exercie does peedily diolve the Bodies of Children into great weat, o want of Exercie does give a very great being to this Dieae: for a tupidity of the parts is an occaion of their want of heat, being ufficiently
cherihed, whence teals in this cold ditemper, accompanied with its Excrementitious and uperfluous moitures, which ought to have been thrown forth by due tranportation. And here it looens and oftens the parts where it enters, the Pule hence and herein becoming tupid, the Blood alo waxing low, and les in quantity, and more lippery, the Vitals leening of their Vigour, growing weak, all which do wonderfully evince the ame an efficacious caue of this Dieae.
16. Sleep & waking others.As to Childrens Order and Government, they ought to leep longer and oftner than Men, yet too much hereof gives a good eay to the growth of this Dieae alo.

17. Another caue.All our former caues may alo in a great meaure be reduced to this following: for whatoever is contained in the Body, and praeternaturally altered, as it is praeternatural, it requires ablation, and may o far be allowed to be thrown forth nevertheles of its being praeternaturally retained. And Nature hath provided o many and various ways of Excretion, or throwing forth into the Body, that carce any Humour can be produced by alteration
which does not relate to the ecretive or excretive faculty of ome Bowels, or ome other parts appointed for its evacuation. Thus the whole Mas of Blood being any ways praeternaturally altered or infected with ome Humour, the peccant Matter which cannot be overcome by alteration, is quickly exterminated by excretion, made from ome part or bowel, unles therewith the expulive faculty thereof be ome way or other obtructed.

We come next to hew why old People are not o ubject to this Strumous Dieae as Youth;19. Why Old People not o ubject to this Dieae as Youth. and here we may take in Children from a year or two, to ten and upwards: then we take and make the difference between Young Men and Old, by calling the firt Juniors, and naming the latter Seniors. And upon examination hereof we hall find, that younger Children are of a colder temper than elder, every day adding heat to their temperament even to Mans etate. And here it is thought to tand at a tay; and when it arrives at Old Age, here it is een to decline daily, and leen. And eeing younger Children
are more cold, no wonder if they be thus ubject to cold Dieaes: And this makes the difference between Youth and Old Age, the one being o framed by Nature in temper, the other being robb'd and tript thereof by their continual expence of Spirits, which gave Man thoe warm parks which formerly did both enliven and invigorate his Faculties and Functions. As young Children therefore are more cold, o alo are they more moit than elder; for the heat of the temperament is advanced from the time of the birth, even to Mans etate. Young Children alo, becaue of their tendernes of parts, are much prone to diipation, and colliquation of the inherent Spirits, and therefore by conequence upon leer and maller caues they are the more ready Subjects and Objects of this Dieae.

Again, Their compoition and conitance of parts makes them more ubject to dieaes, being form'd like young Twigs forc'd to yield to every blat of wind, they wanting that trength and confirmation which Old Age enjoys. Again, young Childrens Exercies are not to be named in the hour
with thoe of elder Age, who enjoy both a greater and larger degree of heat, which both nourihes and cherihes them; and o this cold and moit Ditemper is een with more eae to be got looe from them.
