And as a concluion to the whole hereof as to their Nature and Temper, we hall evermore find younger Children as they are les capable to maintain the ground of this Dieae, o alo are they mot ready to comply therewith, they not in their own Nature, Temper, and Contitution, being either able to reit it, or defend themelves when it once eizeth them.

We come now to hew ome Reaons why this Strumous Dieae is known to be o frequent with us in England, Scotland, and the like,20. Why this is een o frequently reigning in our three Kingdoms. and why it is o natural with the three Nations.

A common Dieae therefore properly o called, is either Original,21. A common Dieae either Original or Adventitious. or Adventitious: That uppoed Original, which in the firt Inhabitation of the place infeted the Inhabitants thereof, of which kind perhaps was reckoned Bronchochele amongt the People who dwelt about the Alps;
a Calenture under the Torrid Zone; and Sphacelus near the Northern Poles by extremity of cold, with many others which I have named at the beginning of this Treatie. A new and Adventitious Dieae is that which is brought into a Country by ome common caue, and this is threefold, this ariing either from faults of the Country prevailing over the health of its Inhabitants, or by ome innovation or alteration happening to the Country it elf, or ome dicongruity between the place, and the complexion of the Natives thereof. As to the firt, it poibly may be granted, that the trong and firm Bodies of its firt Inhabitants might powerfully reit the unwholome Influences of the Country, and yet the Poterity afterwards may uffer a change therein both in Complexion and Nature, and o made the Subjects of a common Dieae. Thus Poland maintained both the Plica and the Scurvy, which are both common Dieaes to the Samaritans, Polanders, and its Neighbouring parts; and yet thee are thought no old Dieaes. The econd may happen by Innovations in Countries, or Inundations of Waters, or
ome Malign Apect, or bad Influence of the Stars. Thoe places alo are motly the occaions of Dieaes which have power enough in them to tranplant and form a Dieae, being quite of another temper and nature from that place wherein they formerly inhabited; and this is very oft een the occaion of Dieaes more prevalent than others. Thus Ireland is known to be a fruitful place for producing the Dyentery, or Bloody Flux, Ireland a fruitful place for producing D ‚Ä¢ eaes. as alo of this Evil; and the Wet-Indies thought to be the firt ground of the French Pox; the firt of thee depending partly upon the contitution of the place, and their prepoterous Diet; the other as readily annext to the Humours and Dipoitions of the Inhabitants. The French we ee commonly troubled with an Itch and Scabbines from their Air; the Scotch troubled with the Scurvy and the Evil from their luggih and lazie Dipoitions. But to leave them, and travel a while in our own Country; herein alo we hall find evidences enough to prove our Nation as fertile as any of the former, and as common with the Evil as any of the former: Therefore I preume to offer,
That he who ever hath travelled over our Englih Iland, England as fruitfu ‚Ä¢ l as Ireland. mut needs acknowledge with me, that it is an Iland which borrows a plentiful tock of moiture from the Neighbouring Sea, it being furniht with an innumerable company of Fountains, ending forth from thence variety of Rivulets and Springs plentifully fill'd with its Liquor, the Heavens themelves being thought by many to betow more plentiful howres thereon than upon any other Nation whatoever: all which does declare its coldnes and moitnes. And ince a cold and moit Ditemper is the greatet part of this Strumous Dieae, pray what can or may hinder its raging thus amongt us, more than in other hot Countries? And as a cold and moit Ditemper is a common part of the eence of this Dieae, and yet not o much as that every cold and moit Ditemper does produce the Evil, o we find England more readily dipoing the Bodies of its Inhabitants hereto than any dryer Regions whatoever.

Again, Both trong and weak People are both very fertile in their Conceptions, and not over ubject to Abortions: Now where infirm Parents beget
infirm Children, the ucceion is generally een to bear the Nature as well as the Fortune of their Parents, as I have already made good.

Again, An idle edentary life,22. Another caue a edentary life. and a looe kind of living, is a great ingredient of a moit and oft temper, and thee every day filling themelves with Excrementitious Humours, their Children which they beget mut necearily be harers thereof with them; and whooever examines thoe troops of People which do yearly come to the King to be toucht for this Evil, mut needs allow it hath made ufficient remarks in the three Nations of its abode and being; where although it has given to ome but its light touches, and gentle notices thereof, in others it hath to a wonder hewn it elf apparently to the World. And becaue I very well know that every Man's Breath will mell of his uual food, and thoe who pretend to any Novelties can but Inventis addere: And although my aerting the French Pox and Scurvy to be the two great Clubbers towards the advancing and increaing the Evil, may eem harh to ome People, who have a better opinion
of themelves and their Ancetors than to think, and therefore much more unwilling to approve of the ame; yet with their leave I hall with a Salvo to their Modety hew the proof thereof. Where we hall find the Pox and the Scurvy, Pari Pau, keeping equal pace therewith on Mankind by way of Seminal Traduction, from Father to Son, and o becomes Hereditary, as I have already hewn: And whooever does not oberve the ame in curing Dieaes of this Age, (now the Families of Mankind are een generally tinged more or les) will mitake of his aim. And although perhaps in this following Part I have and hall recede from the common Opinion of the Ancients; yet I preume I am not the firt that have wum againt the vulgar tream thereof. And this makes me fall upon the two eminent Dieaes of our Times, where if we examine their Nature, Exitency, and Origination, we hall find them of longer continuance than our late Writers have been pleaed to allow them.

I begin with the Pox,23. The French Pox no new Dieae. which although it was formerly warmly treated at Naples, and had a plentiful entertainment in the Wet-Indies, yet it had being in the World long before this, as Hitory tetifies.

The Scurvy alo,24. The Scurvy proved a Dieae of long continuance. although by ome reckoned a Dieae of late date, yet we hall prove this to be of longer being amongt the Sons of Men. And who-ever looks into the Old Tetament hall find it more than once by its proper Name mentioned there: What may we think of the firt, when we read in Levit. 13.2. When a Man hall have a Riing in his Skin, a Scab or bright Spot, or rather as it is in the Margent, a Swelling, then he hall be brought to Aaron the Priet, and to the Sons of the Priets. In this next you will meet them both together, Levit. 21.20. where it is written, That no Man hall offer Bread to his God that is either crook-backt, or dwarf, or that hath a blemih in his Eyes, or be Scurvy, or cabbed, or his Stones broken. And in the 23 Chapter of the ame Leviticus, Ver. 22. you meet all thee three together, where we read that neither blind, or broken, or maimed, or
having the Wen, (or as I may well enough ay, the Evil, this being accounted one part thereof) or Scurvy, or cabbed, hall offer up unto the Lord. And Hoea hews the reaon of the whole, in Ho. 4.2. when he tells us, that by committing of Adultery they break out. Thus much from acred Scripture.

And for a more ready clearing up of which, becaue I well know that thee Scabs here mentioned will be commonly taken as the marks of the Leproie, I hall next take the whole a pieces by examining the near affinity and acquaintance there is between them both in their Nature and Eence.

What the French Pox is.The French Pox therefore is a praeternatural dipoition, by which the Body is enibly hurt in its Operations, and diordered in its Functions: And Philoophy allows that o many ways as the Body is hurt by ditemper praeternaturally, and o hindring its action, o many kind of Dieaes it eaily aumes. And this explains its elf with all imaginable eae to uch as
undertand the natural action thereof, which is dicovered by Complexion, Compoition, and common unity of Body: for in this Dieae, as well as in the Struma, many parts of the Body are extenuated, whilt others gain greater bulk thereby, as alo thicknes, and thee not only Similar, but Organick parts. Whence we may rationally conclude, that this is a Compoitional Sicknes; and this we do thus make good, the firt kind of Compoitional Nature we calling Plamatick or formal: for the better performance of which there is required a good Figure, and a convenient Tone, accompanied with a due Aperity, and decent Lenity. Now if any Member falls from hence, and gains a new quality, it frames a Dieae in form, and hence we take both its igns and cognizance. And that the Members are made gros by this Dieae, is apparent by the Putles and Putulous Cutis, the Face oft-times een well'd, and the Body appearing Satyrick. Jut as Galen mentions of the Leproie, where he writes that they are of that near kin each to other, that they are carce to be ditinguiht by their marks or
ymptoms: for in the one, o in the other are many Putles found in the Cutis, and thee ariing from abundance of black Melancholy, throwing it elf outwards; of which kind alo is the Leproie; and in our days where we hall ee the Pox mot common and frequent, we hall as readily perceive the ame, ometimes their Botches appearing white, ometimes red, with a kind of Livid colour admixt, both which do only repreent the matter of which they are made, being framed either of Melancholy Blood, Adut Choler, or Vicid Flegm. And Galen is of my Opinion, when as it grows populous, he writes it to be allowed an Elephantiais; and in his Book de Atra Bile, he ays there are many Putles in this Dieae without Fever, thickning, drying, and cruting up the Cutis. And whereas the Blood of pale Women does generally look pale, o uch as are black have a more Grumous and Melancholy Blood go along with them in their Contitution. The Figure of thee Putles alo does make well for the knowing of their caue; and whoever deires further knowledge herein, let him but examine
Nicolas Maa De Morbo Gallico, Jacobus Cataneus, Hieronimus Fracatorius, Petrus Maynardus Veronenis, Alphonus Ferrius, Antonius Gallius, Caper Torr ‚Ä¢ ll ‚Ä¢ us, and everal other excellent Authors, who have well writ De Lue Venerea, and there they may be more fully atisfied both of the Pox, and its near relation to the Leproie. Thus much of the firt part.

We next proceed to the Scurvy,What the Scurvy is. and hall hew it painted in its Colours: And here we hall offer, that a bad Ferment is the general caue of mot Dieaes; and Sennertus aith, That the Blood of Perons toucht with a Scorbutick Tincture, becomes of the Nature of Vinegar; and uch alo is the Blood of Melancholy Perons, whereas in its right tate in ound Perons it is compared to Generous Wine; where alo he writes, that the Scorbutick Humour is bred much after the ame manner as Vinegar is out of Wine; where he ays, that by cating a little leavened Bread thereinto, this brings the Wine into its own Acrimoneous Quality, and Acid Nature. Thus when an ill Scorbutick Ferment comes any way into the generous
Liquor of the Blood, and turns it into an Acid Ichorous and Acrimonious tate; this will corrupt the whole Mas of Blood: and this he further affirms, that the main caue of the Acid tate of this Blood arieth from the abatement of its Sulphur and Spirit, the which he confirms by comparing it with good Wine, which oon turns Acid upon its Sulphurous part, being tript from its Saline by Evaporation or otherwie; and o that Salt which was formerly Volatile, becomes now fixt and Acid, which is the true caue of its thus turning into Vinegar, which is made good by putting Vinegar to a Candles Flame, and you'll not ee it burn, it being robb'd of its Sulphur, and its Winey Spirit extinct, and the more this Sulphurous Matter and Spirit is lot, the nearer it is drawn from its true Body and Subtance.

Thus have I given you a hort and general Dicoure of the Scurvy alo, of both which I may well enough offer, although our Region was not the firt Mitres which they courted, nor the Englih the firt Man that they greeted; yet if I mitake not, we are here as well acquainted with thee two Dieaes
in our days, as any other Nation or Country whatoever; and ince both of them have found the way to London, they have given ufficient remarques of their cloe affinity and converation; and we have received the Faults as well as Fahions of our Neighbouring Nations.

Now that the Pox hath a very near affinity with this Strumous Dieae,How both agree with the Evil. is hence eaily made good, by ending forth of its Venereal Venome into the Glandules, there tumefying them; and as other Symptomes by which we may know its Complication herewith, we hall find it either from the Parent or Nure which were firt infected; and thus therefore if Ulcers in the Head or Face, Mouth or Notrils, or eminent Putles, or cruty Tumours do hence arie, not giving way to ordinary Medicines; if hard or Nody Tumours keep company herewith, or carry a rottennes of Bones in the Head, Feet, Thighs or Legs, or any other parts; if Nocturnal Pains go along with the ret; if Inguinal Buboes infet the Glandules with virulent Matter, or keep them tumefied by Venereal Poyon, all thee may be
accounted apparent Signs and Symptomes of the Pox, as well as of the Evil.

If the Scurvy be herewith complicated, frequent looenes attends the Scrophulated Patient, with difficulty of breathing, many Athritick pains go along with this Evil, they have a more frequent and inequal Pule, and frequent Palpitations of their Hearts. And where we meet Strumaes untoward and unlucky, this gives us no lender upition of ome ill lurking inwards, epecially where they meet with a curted Neck, a hort and narrow Forehead, compret Temples, and large Mandibles. Beides the former, we hall find the French Pox and Scurvy both of them o trangely altered from their firt appearance, that we ee them rather daily advance in their number, than in their nature, and almot creep into acquaintance with every Dieae as well as the Evil, and in ome meaure do bear their Colours, and decribe their Decriptions and Symptomes, and are een as often preented to the King under the diguie of the Kings-Evil, as if they were really nothing ele, they
getting that familiarity and common dependance upon one another, that no mean Artit may pretend to be a true Judge between them: for as Intemperance of Dyet, and Luxurious Debauch does as well procure a tainted Fermentation, as an Ebullition of ill and vitiated Humours, by which a common intercoure and exchange of Symptoms is kept up and maintained; o when the Evil hath got either a Pocky or Scorbutick Ferment going along with it, bred from a vitious Habit of Body, this may as readily be granted to be a harer of the whole; for thee two Ferments do put on other Formalities, whether they proceed joyntly or eparately, and do diguie themelves under the Habits of everal Dieaes, according to the Inclinations of uch weakly Bodies on which they do make their entrance, they ometimes appearing like themelves when they march in the common road, but when thee Ferments do propagate themelves, they eldom appear like branches of uch a tock, but being tinctur'd in the Blood and Humours of the Body, they do aume uch a hape of Ditempers as the Body
is able to afford and allow them. And whoever reads Zacutus Luitanus Prax. Hitor. Cap. de Morbo Gallico, will find that he aith, the Pox is an Univeral Evil, and may be well enough complicated with any other Ditemper: for Ditempers do herewith unite either through likelines of matter, or ome other the like vitiounes of Humour. And thus I uppoe I have in ome meaure made good my Aertion of the Pox and the Scurvy's being Clubbers to this Strumous Dieae, or Scrophulated Evil, by their affording this Dieae a tate of their tainted Ferments, and a vitiated tincture of their vitious and depraved Humours, by which they creep into its acquaintance.

div.head: CHAP. V. The proper Signs of Strumaes, or Kings-Evil-Swellings.
div.p:
OF what great concern an inequal Nourihment of Parts in this is, we have in our lat Chapter very plentifully dicoured: This preents you with the Signs of Strumaes, which gives the fairet view and figure of the Parts thus inequally dicovered: where we hall meet with a greater fulnes in the lively Complexion of the Face, being compared with the other parts of the Body; and yet this more apparent in ome perons than in others, this Dieae lying ometimes more obcure before its publick appearance, and as it were unperceivable; and therefore this may be reckoned as one of the Signs, which is a greater fulnes of Face, it being and appearing thus, whilt it is as it were
in the Embryo, and arrived at no great matter of growth, or hath gained much ubtance or matter to give it a greater being and bulk.

This again having got ome entrance amongt the Glands, as it infects them, and advanceth into growth, it is mot commonly een to march along the Matoideal Mucle of the Neck, and this requires time to give it uch a progres, and where uch appearance is made thereof, this infallibly denotes the abode of this Dieae.

When we hall perceive knotty Swellings and Excrecences in this affect in other parts of the Body, as in the Eyes, Noe, upper Lips, Breats, Axillaries, Inguens, and the like, all which do declare their acquaintance therewith, where thee ever happen, they give us a Pathognomonical Sign of its Habitation, and without all doubt do et forth the mot clear pecies of its reidence.

Where-ever outward knotty Excrecences do apparenly hew themelves, thee may jutly give ome upition of inward Glands in the Bowels; but if they do only inwardly increae,
no certain Sign can be demontrated thereof.

Such as have hort Necks, low and narrow Foreheads, compret Temples, and wide Mandibles, are motly ubject to thee Strumatical Tumours and Excrecences, and this is the general received Opinion of the bet Phyicians and Chirurgeons, as being a mot ignal Obervation of the Evil or Strumous Affect.

Again, other of thee Strumaes are taken from their ight whereoever they do appear, and in what part of the Body oever they do hew themelves, they appear either round or longih, much of the ame colour of the Cutis under which they lay, for the mot part hard and without pain.

Rogerius gives us this method of them, and thus ditinguiheth them, by taking Leaves of Ground Ivy and Cedar, the which being beaten together, and applied to the Scrophulated parts, if the Tumours hall hereupon be een to vanih and diappear in three days, its a perfect ign they are Glandulae, not Strumae: but if the Medicine thus applied does occaion
pain in the part, o that it becomes both inflamed and painful upon this Application, this perfectly demontrates them to be Strumaes.

In Bergomy where Scrophulous and Strumous Tumours are very frequent in both Sexes, you will meet them very large planted in the fore-part of the Neck, being commonly moveable, oft, and pendulous, the which as they do bring no great matter of pain along with them, nor hinder any action in Humane Body, o they give them their acquaintance and company all their lives; and this Dieae is reported to be in their Nation bred from their Water which they commonly drink, this having in it as trange an Antipathy to the Glandules and Glandulous parts, as Cantharides have to the Kidneys and Bladder; the People in thoe parts neither giving themelves or their Chirurgeons trouble of ever being concerned therewith.

Again, thee Strumae are een to differ from Glandulae in their Colour and Contitution, the one made from Melancholy, the other begot by Flegm, every of which does declare their Frame and Contitution by the
ame; and hence ome of thee by Avicen and Aetius, Cap. 5. Lib. 15. write, that ome of thee are een to be and appear very painful, whilt others are very mild; and according to the greater or leer quantity of the malignity, they prove ooner or latter Cancerous; and where Choler and Flegm joyn together, as I have already mentioned, it mut give pain to the part, and make it either a Strumatical Cancer, or a Cancerous Struma.

Strumae do not enter one Glandule only, but many, wherein they hew both their hardnes and inequality: for herein the Pox hews its elf acquainted therewith, but does till keep this difference, that the Pox eldom eizeth more than one, its venenate matter poeing the ame, cauing a hardnes and Tumour therein, and yet this not to be accounted a Struma; and therefore for making of Strumae, there mut be more Glandules than one concerned; for thee are een to pread themelves like a Vine, welling, increaing, and growing hard.

p.U: aith he hath found Strumaes in Womens Breats, as alo in Mens Breats; and reaon it elf cannot deny this Aertion of his, becaue thee are Adenous parts; and he further tells us, that in the year 1537. in the month of April, he aw a Woman Scrophulated all over her Body, even to her Groins.

div.p: Scrophulous Swellings are frequently bred in thoe parts, where crude and vicid Dyet is made ue of, as well as in the Air that is of a cold and moit temper, where alo the Water of the place is vicous or muddy.

Again, the Signs of Strumaes are to be divided three ways, as conidering their Quality, Quantity and Eence. As to their Quantity, and hence they gaining their largenes; as to their Quality, this hewing their Nature and Temper; as to their Eence, this demontrating their Origination and being.

The multiplicity of Strumaes, and their overpreading the Body, and the extraneous heats which go along with them, do frequently hew that they are the product of interiour Scrophulaes, as Arnoldus oberves. And
hence he further writes, that we may gues at the inward Swellings by the outward numerounes of thee Protuberancies; and that thee do more frequently happen and fall upon Children than upon Old Men, by reaon of their guloity and rarities of Bodies, the which are not o in Elder People.

p.U: aith, That thoe Perons who have a curted Forehead, compret Temples, and large Mandibles, are mot ubject to thee Swellings; for in uch Perons this Scrophulated matter is more readily derived and conveyed into the Neck.

div.p: Cornelius Celus writes, That Strumaes and ick People do give much trouble to the Phyitian and Chirurgeon; becaue let them be treated as well as poibly Art can, and Nature likewie erve them, yet they will fly out again; and although the bet methods imaginable are ued for their extirpation, yet we uually find them relape, and gain new birth again.

Strumaes, if they be benign, obtaining a moderate hardnes, and free from pain, inflammation, and Ulcer, being purely bred from Flegm, are
proper igns of its good Nature: but when this Flegm gets any commerce with Adut Choler, this makes it malign, and here wait on it pain, inflammation, a hot pule and trouble, appearing inequal to touch, and vexed with every application of Medicine.

p.U: ays Strumaes are Aedematous Tumours ariing in the Glandules, bred from a cold, thick, and vicid Flegm, having in it omewhat of Melancholy adjoyned.

div.p: Aqua Pendens tells us, Strumaes are no Strumaes, but rather ought to be called Cancerous, they not being made from Flegm, and Melancholy only, but having an Atra bilis or Adut Choler joyned therewith, which gives them this Cancerous Nature and Dipoition.

And latly, Joannes Colle Bellonenis gives this as a ign of Strumaes, which ought to be undertood as well in Genere, as in Specie, conidering the place, the form, and the effect thereof; It being a hard Tumour of the Glandules, ometimes equal, otherwhiles inequal; ometimes appearing few in
number, ometimes many; if white and indolent, they arie from Flegm; if blewih or black, from Melancholy; if hard, exquiite, painful and red, from Adut Choler; this lat ign comprehending a great part of mot of the ret. Thus much of its Signs.

div.head: CHAP. VI. The Proper Preages of Strumaes, or Kings-Evil-Swellings.
div.p: EVery Phyician and Chirurgeon, according to the Rules of Art, ought diligently and prudently to contemplate on the Prognotick Signs of a Dieae, that he may the better be intructed in foreeeing the everal events thereof; and here both Diagnois as well as Prognois is very proper to be undertood, the one hewing the preent etate, containing and declaring the Origination thereof; the other foretelling its growth, increae and conummation.

Firt therefore, this Dieae being properly Natural, is mot dangerous, and do eldom, if ever, end in health, without new eruptions: For Zaculus Luitanus writes, that there is a depraved Excretion in the Seed, or a certain
occult quality infecting the ame, and inherent in it, which imprints the like Tincture in the Off-pring; for the dieaed defects of the Parents are derived by force of the Seed to Generation, by which they do perfectly and exactly reemble their Behaviour, Gate, Countenance and Contitution. And becaue ome are very apt to contradict this paage, and aert, If this were true, it would continue thus for ever; whereas others have as plainly een, that it hath mit ome of the ame Stock, and hath only fixt upon others of the ame Family, the firt Generation having ometimes been een wholly to mis and ecape it, and this has given none of its appearance perhaps till it came to the Grandchildren of the ame Family.
Small and Superficial Strumaes are more healthful in Children, and more eaie of Cure, than thoe that are malign, and more deeply fixed.

The more early the invaion of Strumaes is after the Birth, the more danger it carries with it; for hereby the Spirits are both robbed, and much weakned; we commonly alo eeing as they grow up, they are better acquainted
therewith, and are better able, and more eaily cured than younger Children.
That Struma which is bred naturally from Parents is harder of cure, than that which is contracted by the meer errour of the Nure or Mother.

Again, That Strumous effect which the Infant brings with him from his Mothers Womb, is of harder cure, and proves more deperate than that which is occaioned by Air, Vicous Diet, or any other outward Effect.
The greater the Heads of Infants and Children are, the horter their Necks, the more compret Temples they have, and the wider Mandibles, the more ubject thee are to Strumous Dieaes than others.

All thoe who do attain to the conitence of this Dieae, do ecape the danger thereof, being carefully examined, unles by chance ome other Dieae be therewith adjoyned, or does afterwards come after it, and diturb the Patient with a higher increae.
If the French Pox therefore be complicated with this Strumous Dieae, be it either Hereditary, or contracted by Infection, it makes it almot incapable of remedy.
If the Scurvy alo be herewith complicated, this does very much retard the cure, although not o much as the French Pox.

All Strumatical Tumours, either Internal or External, do not very much upend the hopes of Cure, although otherwie of themelves they are not eaily ubdued in this tender age: for the external parts being inflamed with pain, do wate the Spirits; but the internal much more, epecially if they do invade the noble parts with their weight and bulk.
Every Struma again is not to be overcome with eae, but uch as do happen in Children are better managed, than thoe which happen in old People.
Where-ever they happen without pain, they are not eaily to be extirpated.
Avicen declares that thoe who are acquainted with Struma, or Scrophula in the Head or Neck, are generally een to be of moit Complexions.
He alo writes the places wherein they do generally breed, are the Neck, Armpits, Inguens, and the like, where the Flehes are oft, but their empty paces are fill'd up with Veels.

Numerous Strumae entring the exteriour parts, and o exerciing divers parts of the Body with ome Adventitious heat, thee hew that they are the off-pring, and bred of inward Glands, as Arnoldus de Villa nova writes, and well oberveth.
Avicen writes that Strumae which have pain, and a hot Apotem adjoyned to them, with hot matter tending to Suppuration, are thereby eaily cured.
Purging Potions, and Diuretick Decoctions, and Specifique Alterant Drinks, do all much conduce to the curing of thee Tumours.
Children by reaon of their rarity of Body, and intemperance in Dyet, are een frequently troubled with this Dieae: Old Men on the contrary are eldom een troubled therewith.

Strumae at bet are troubleome to the Chyrurgeon, for they never give way to Medicine readily; and hould they be cured either by Medicine or Intrument, yet they are een to break out afreh before a perfect extirpation be made.

Inciion of thee Abcees in as much as may be is to be avoided, epecially happening about the Belly, Neck, and Commiures, by reaon of their affinity with the Veins, Nerves and Arteries, let hereby uch an Hemorrhagy be raied by inadvertency, that is not eaily to be allayed by the greatet of skill.
Thoe alo are ooner cured which are pendulous, than thoe which are fixed.

Cancerated Strumae, and the like Tumours, they being cloely concerned with the Veels, do bring great danger of Hemorrhagy in their Cure, where it is performed by Inciion, and are carce to be taken off, they dwelling
amongt the Veins and Arteries, which are the parts of great concern as to our preent beings.

When a Contitution ubject to errour, or actually erronious, is fixt to ome certain part, this highly concerns us to have a repect to that part in chief, becaue this Contitution thus ubject to depravation, does require a particular preervation to be aociated to particular Curation.

div.head: CHAP. VII. The Practical Curative Method of Strumaes, or Kings-Evil-Swellings.
div.p: THis Curative Method is generally guided by the two Aitants of Reaon and Experience,Reaon & Experience the ground of practice. both which together do comprehend the greatet skill of the Artit: For by Experience was founded the Hitory of Dieaes, the Succes of Medicine, and the Judgment of its events: all which being weighed in the balance of Approbation, are een either to get or loe in their Weight and Meaure.

Reaon therefore is the Judge of Truth; for hereby Man is een to comprehend the deign, to give reaon for the ame, to apprehend, comprehend or divide it. And for the
proof hereof, he mut needs be thought unkind to Nature in burthening her with the name of a Propoition, who is not himelf apprehenive of its Terminations, or ignorant of its propoe on which its een to conit; every indication or intention eeming to call in Mans reaon to conent as to the Curative part, as well as his Opinion and Judgment. Now as every Indication does declare omewhat which is to be done, or o intended from whence this Term it elf doth properly arie; the thing therefore which chiefly relates to our preent dicoure is, either a Modical or Chyrurgical Act, or both; the firt making good the deign, the econd proecuting the ame, he himelf being the Agent, and his Medicine the Curative Intrument.

Our Art firt deigned for the health of mankind.Our Art therefore was firt deigned by the Almighty for the health of Mankind, and the procuring their health was evermore the great Indication of the Action: yet this is ditinguiht in the Duty of a Phyician or Chirurgeon, becaue the purchae of health is not always attainable,
and therefore no part of their Duties to maintain Impoibilities.

The Eence of this Dieae therefore partly coniting of a cold and moit Ditemper,The Eence of the Dieae to be chiefly minded. this therefore requires omewhat which is hot and dry, and being alo robb'd of its inherent Spirits, uch Remedies therefore as can recruit the ame, or can retore or increae them, may very well be here allowed very ueful.
Again, Stupefaction of Spirits have been premied another caue, and therefore uch things as do incraate and thicken the Spirits, and o fixing them, are to be utterly prohibited.

Another was the due Obervation of the Tone of the parts, and their due Harmony, the which being either oft, looe, or flaccid, they therefore do require the favour of ome warming and trengthening Medicines, having omewhat of atriction added to them.

Again,All caues of Dieaes to be removed. as another caue was proved to be an inequal ditribution of Heat and Nutriment, ome parts being too liberally erved, whilt others are tarv'd and robb'd of their jut meaures and proportion; thee therefore
alo ought to be brought into a Medium, by leening the Bulk of one, and giving a more plentiful proportion to the other. Thus far I thought convenient to keep time with ome of the mot eminent caues which have been Promoters and Procurers of this Strumous Affect.

And although thee common caues do not immediately eem to attain to the production of the Eence of a Dieae, yet in repect that they do hinder Nature in her deigns, they may be allowed retarders of the cure, and therefore their removal is required. And becaue the Humours which give being to thee Strumaes are een low,Preparation of Humours the firt thing indicated. gros and clammy, Preparation thereof ought firt therefore to be conidered and thought upon, and the firt thing indicated; and this is to be performed by inciive and attenuating Remedies: And as the Dieae becomes Chronical, the matter not being wholly to be thrown forth at once, thee preparing and evacuating Medicines ought by turns to be made ue of: and whooever that will herein proceed in a right method, mut know and uppoe that as Cholerick Humours do
require one Preparation and Evacuation, o Blood, Flegm and Melancholy do each of them indicate their proper Preparations and Evacuations, according to Hippocrates his Rule, Before you purge the Body you mut make it fluxible: And thus before we arrive at the ue of Catharticks, we are to begin with Preparatives.

All Contitutions therefore in this Strumous Affect being for the mot part weak and infirm, which may well be allowed from the Conideration of the Patients tender Age and Nature, do therefore require both a general and particular regard as to their Contitutions.
In this Strumous Affect therefore the election of the bet Nourihers, and uch as are eaie of digetion, are nearet of kin, and mot agreeable to the Age and Nature of the Patient.

Benign and gentle Evacuations therefore well corrected, are herein both very proper and ueful, and advantageous, and may be given in moderate quantity, and in jut and due time, all violent Purges being here utterly forbidden. Alterant Remedies
alo, and uch as can prepare the Humours, or correct the Dieae, are here alo approved of, thee in themelves being both kind to Nature, and a Friend to the Patient; evermore taking this caution along in your Curative Method, that the Remedy you deign to cure Strumaes do arrive at the eat, and penetrate the very caue of the Dieae; and in regard that all Children are naturally een to loath Phyick, the form thereof therefore is to be preferred, which hall be oberved to be leat ditateful to them.

Timing of Dieaes very material as to their cure.Such Medicines alo as you deign Strumous Patients mut be given in their due time, for timing of a Dieae aright is a very great matter in the cure thereof. Thus we commonly ee Evacuant,Directions for giving of Preparatives. Attenuant, and Inciive Remedies are precribed to be taken early in the morning upon an empty Stomack; and if thee be to be repeated, four of the Clock in the afternoon is thought the mot eaonable hour for giving the ame.

Thus much as touching the general Rules and Method which ought to be
tudied and oberved by every Artit who deires and deigns to cure Strumous Affects according to Art.

We proceed now cloer to the true Curative Method of Strumaes, whereas we have preumed to premie, that the Medical Matter is to be found out by Experience, o it mut be continued to every caue of the ame Affect.

This Curative Method is generally een to be guarded by thee three Heads,Three Heads as to cure Strumaes. wherein is declared the Pharmaceutical, the Chyrurgical, and the Dietetical Matter. The firt comprehending in it all Medicines ueful for vanquihing and overcoming of Strumaes, thoe only excepted which belong wholly to Chyrurgery, as being either relative to the Caues or the Eence of the Dieae; and thee are generally een to march under two Heads, as Internals and Externals; and thee are ranked into Simple or Compound Orders. The Internals having mot repect to the inward parts, for cleaning their paages, and this is performed by Preparatives and Catharticks, and Specifique Alterant Medicines, and uch as correct Symptomes. And yet in the Adminitration
of thee, thee three Rules are to be oberved, that the Stomack be not herewith naueated by any ingrateful tate which may beget an abhorrence in the Patient of all Medicine for the future, nor load it with too great a quantity, nor yet o made as it may be immediately thrown up again.

The everal Humors to be everally treated.The Humours which alo are thus to be prepared, are either Flegmatick, and o cold and moit, which ought to be tempered with heat; thick, and o requiring attenuation; or vicous, and o expect inciion, or Cholerick, and thus being burning and corroive, are to be allayed by lenifying and contemperating Medicines; or Melancholy, and this either feculent or terene, and this to be rendred fluxile. Now where thee, or any of them do enter in any part of the Body, they do require appropriate Medicines, and Remedies proper for the dicharging of any of thee Humours.

Again, the matter of the Dieae it elf being prepared, and the paages opened,The matter to be expurged. we are next to tudy the expulion of this peccant Matter; and this bears in it a double relation, as both looking towards the Humours,
alo the parts to which they flow, or are een to lodge. And here we mut alo (as I have already oberved) give every Humour its jut way of purgation, and always direct our Catharticks at the Eence of the Dieae, as its mot proper white or mark, which in its own nature ought to be moderately hot and dry, dipelling all Stupefaction of parts, trengthning the oftnes and loones thereof, cherihing and nourihing the vigour and activity of the inward parts, and warming and comforting the outward, always having a regard both to the age, trength and complexion of your Patient. Thee things being premied, we fall upon the Method it elf, wherein as we find that evacuation is a great Radix in the cure of Strumaes, by abating of its repletion, and diolving of gros and tough Flegm, the great Mitres of its bulk and growth, o Subtilitation of Regiment is een as proper in this Dieae, being hid and lodged in the ofter parts of the Body.General Rules as touching the Intitution of Life.

And now for our General Rules here to be oberved as touching the Patients Intitution of Life, we ought
here (as I have already well noted) to frame our Medicines according to the Temperament, Strength and Contitution with whom we are or hall be concerned: for we are not to deal with Children as we do with Men and Women, who have arrived at a better age and trength, who are as much different in thee, as they are in their age, complexion and abode. Great care therefore is to be had to the fluent matter which is already got into the parts from whence it is to be dicharged, and that the Flux it elf may be abated, and topt in its motion.

And he whooever intends to deal with Children as to purging Medicines, mut alo have the purile age both in his thoughts and view, and conider that it is but infirm, and therefore requires a mot kind, gentle, and eaie method; this rather alo to be oft repeated & reiterated, than adviing tronger Medicines, and more forcible Remedies, they very oft bringing more hurt than good along with them.

Bleeding.As for Bleeding, neither the Age or Ditempers of Strumous Patients
do very well admit thereof, unles this Strumous Affect does or hall happen in uch who are able to bear it, and then it may be allowed as ueful and neceary as any other Remedy whatoever.

Various are the Opinions amongt Authors concerning Emeticks in this Strumous Dieae;Vomits. Aetius is een to commend and highly approve of them, others altogether do condemn them; to which later Opinion I preume to make my elf a true Devoter: for although the antecedent matter may or might hereby be omewhat leened by Emeticks, yet the impact matter is but a very little hereby abated, but rather more acerbated. Beides, it's certain that the Head is much more repleted by Vomits, the Jugular Veins hereupon tumefying, and the whole healed by being brought into conent therewith; and this was the only reaon which made Hippocrates cry o on't, or exclaim againt Vomits in all Effects either of the Eyes or Ears.

As to the Patients Dyet,As to the Dyet. let all uch who are troubled with Strumous Affects abtain from flatulent, vaporous, and windy Dyet, uch as is Beans,
Chenuts, Pork, Cheee, Beef, as alo from Leeks, Onyons, and every thing ele that hath power enough in it to beget or breed gros and vicid Humours; Fih and all Salt Meats alo are to be hunned.

Immoderate motion is very hurtful to Children.Immoderate Motion in Children is alo very hurtful, epecially when they do weat much about their Head, becaue hereby the matter is moved, the which afterwards is precipitated, and this gives the increae to the Strumous Affects which we commonly ee they carry with them; Violent Motion and Exercie therefore are to be hunned, and no ways allowed of.

p.U:
aith, The Air of Strumous People hould be clear and erene, dry and hot in temper, not cloudy, thick, troubled, waterih, marih, or too cold; and daily evidences hereof make good that uch that live in cold and moit Countries are much more troubled with Strumous Swellings, than uch as do dwell in a hotter and dryer Climate. Long Sleeps are to be hunned, Fear, Sorrow, Sadnes, Melancholy, and every thing that
may create, produce or force a plenty of Humours to the Head and its parts, are utterly forbid.

div.p: Let the Exercie of the Patient therefore be moderate before and after Dyet, and let his Dyet be both attenuating and of good digetion, as Veal, Capon, Mutton, Lamb,What Dyet mot proper. Rabbet, Cocks Broath, Pheaant, Partridge, and all mall Birds, and the like. Let his Bread be made of good Corn, to which may be added a little Salt. In his Broaths may be boiled either Mint, Balm, Marjoram, Marygolds, or Pennyroyal; let him abtain from all things which may be thought either to engender Crudities, Rheumatims, as uperfluous Drinking, too much Eating, and the like; let him drink Wine but in a mall quantity, or mix the ame with Small-Beer or Water. Odoriferous Spices, or hot Seeds may alo be put into his Broaths. All thee are the general Indications required in his orderly regulation.

We now proceed to the Medicines which are to be taken inwards, and thee are both Simple and Compound Preparatives,Simple and Compound Preparatives. and proper Catharticks which here firt do offer themelves: amongt the Simple may be reckoned Syrup. div.p: Thus much for preparing and purging Medicines. The Dieaes therefore being thus prepared and evacuated, or at leat in ome meaure conquered, the next Intrument to make it quit its quarters, is the Specifique Alterant Medicines, which, as it were with all peed does fly in the very face of the Dieae it elf, they being formed of matter, perfectly contrary either to the nature or temper of this Scrophulated Dieae, againt which they are wholly deigned to encounter when ever they are made ue of, as you may gues by their following frame and make: for whereas we ee Strumaes arie from a cold and moit being, o we hall not only likewie ee thee Remedies hot and dry, but alo uch as are cherihing and refrehing the natural Spirits, and trengthening the parts, they eem to attenuate all thick, vicid, and gros Humours, and brings a certain equality to all the Juyces that have their Circulation in the Sanguinary Mas; and thee alo are of divers orts, thus made good.

div.p: Having thus finihed my intended deign as to Internal Medicines, as they are allowed properly to be adminitred and precribed in all Strumous Affects; Our remaining Dicoure hall only touch upon the external parts, which we have reerved to the lat place, this being nearet related to our our own profeion of Chyrurgery.

The Chyrurgeons duty as to the outward parts.The thicknes and vicidity therefore of thee Strumous Tumours is not ometimes to be eparated but by Putrefaction, Intrument, actual or potential Cantery. But if this vicidnes be but moderate, here the cure is to be attempted with mollifying, diolving, and diipating Medicines, all which copes Averrhoes makes out very well in 7 Collect. 31. where he writes, that when Strumaes are made of ubtile and thin Matter, thee are to be cured with Emollient, inciive and diolving Medicines: If from a hard, thick and vicous Matter, purging Medicines are inwardly to be precribed, and the outward Swellings to be treated with more powerful Remedies, Intrument, or Cautick, all which are to be acted by a dexterous, skilful, and knowing Hand.

If thee Tumours do tend to Suppuration,The method to be ued if they do tend to Suppuration. then this method is cloely to be followed: for the Chyrurgeon mut evermore endeavour to treat Nature in her own way and method he her elf deigns, that the matter may more readily de dicharged and healed; and this is known by a rednes or bright colour hapning in the Tumour.
Now Medicines proper for performing this part of the Cure may be reckoned uch as thee following.

Avicen, Rhais, and Albuchais do all advie, that where we meet with large Strumous
Tumours,When to ue Emollients and dicuives here we are to treat them with Reolving and Dicuive Medicines; and where vicid, thick, and tough Humours are, thee are to be oftned and diipated.

Emollients therefore are of this kind which are firt to be made ue of, uch as thee following: Hens Fat, Mans Fat, Oyl of weet Almonds, Mucilage of Lineed, Fenugreek-eed, Lilies, and Marh-mallows, and the like, of which with other Additions may be compoed very excellent Emollient Remedies.

Amongt the firt are reckoned Figs, Calves Dung, Honey and Lilies, and many others. Amongt the econd, are Bean-Meal, Barley, Meal of Lupines, Lineed, Fenugreek-eed, and the like. And for the third are reckoned Pidgeons Dung, Goats Dung, Gooe Dung, or Sheeps Dung mixt with Honey, and o applyed in form of a Cataplam, which will anwer Expectation. div.p:
Thus much may erve for Emollients and Reolving Medicines, every of which is very proper and effectual in its place and due application. But ince we have een ome Strumaes which have been very well treated by the bet and mot proper of Medicines, and yet to little or no purpoe; in uch a cae as this Manual Operation is required, and where this is to be made ue of,Manual operation is ometimes required in curing Strumaes. caution and skill ought to joyn together in the Operation: for ince we find that thee incraate and indurate Tumours do require Extirpation and Extraction, o this alo is to be o dexterouly performed, as that no part be left behind; which may either give occaion to a new Birth, or return of the Dieae, or the Dieae renovate and renew by the remains that are left behind; they being much like Galen's Ahes, the which being themelves warm, can readily dipoe of their heat to the neighbouring parts, or as I may ay, give life to a econd
increae of thee Swellings. Our greatet advice in the ue of the Knife is to have a particular and pecial care to the Veels bordering upon thee parts, viz. The Nerves, Veins and Arteries, let they being injured hereby, may give too apparent igns of danger ucceeding thereupon. For about the Neck every Anatomit knows do lodge and are planted the Recurrent Nerves appointed for the voice ariing from the ixth pair, the Jugular Veins, and the Carotid Arteries, all which do require the care and caution of the Operator. Arnaldus de Villanovanus does therefore forbid the ue of Inciion as much as in us lay, but when we are compell'd and forc'd to make ue thereof. Albucais gives us this Method, that is, When we find Strumous Tumours which are good natur'd, and bears a kind dipoition with them, whoe colour is not much different from that of the Cutis, every way moveable, and no ways fixt or tyed to the Veins, Nerves or Arteries of the Neck, nor lodge o deep but that they may be reached with eae here; and in uch caes as this is,The Method thereof thus hewn. we may begin our Diection upwards, and o guide and trace our Knife to the lower part of the Body thereof, then dilating the Lips, the Glands are to be extracted with great care and caution, o as no Veel whatoever may be injured by the Operation; and if any Flux of Blood may happen in this Operation, it is preently to be topt with Retrictives; and this method is to be proecuted
till every part of the Citus, or Bags thereof are perfectly and throughly eradicated and extracted; the which being done, and the part clean, mundifie the Ulcer, diget, incarn, and then induce a Cicatrice. And thus we have given you a Draught of curing Strumaes, or King-Evil-Swellings: To all which methods, if they will be o rebellious as not to yield, there is no other hope left of Cure but by the Hands of our Sacred Majety, whom God preerve, that he may live many years to exercie this Healing Faculty.

div.head: TO THE Right HONORABLE AND Right Reverend Father in God, NATHANIEL, Lord Bihop of Durham, AND Clerk of the Cloet to His MAJESTY.
div.p:
SInce our Minds do naturally hunt after knowledge of Novelties, and carce ret atisfied with the preent tate of things, (uch being the boundles limits of our Conceptions): Man is generally een to meaure the length of his Age by the
fathom of his Knowledge: Judgment being as the Preident over all his Actions, whil't Sene and Motion becomes the two Interpreters of his will and pleaure. As Hitory therefore is ever allow'd the mot proper direction for the Life of Man, and Learning accounted the only Treaure which can enrich his Mind: The one better teaching by example than Precept; the other making fuller Dicoveries of Mens Lives and Actions. If the actions therefore of Princes may be granted the ubjects of Hitory, ure this of Healing
ought to take place, where it is not only to be recorded as Hitory barely, but deerves regitring amongt the mot Divine Gifts, and Eminent Qualifications of their Majetick Vertues.

Amongt the bet and greatet of which Worthies, I hall preume to preent this Healing Vertue of our Dread Soveraigns, in which action he appears as the Soul to the Body; and is een to maintain his three Nations in Health as well as Peace: as Nature does rule in her humane Empire with three Faculties, for as her Animal, Vital,
and Natural Faculties are kept up and preerved by their Nerves, Arteries and Veins, by which Mankind hews both his Motion, Sene and Life: So whooever coniders the daily Blesings our three Kingdoms do receive from his Sacred Majety, mut necearily be convinced, That as the animal Faculties lodge in his Royal Head, which gives that ene to every affair we proecute, o his Sacred Hands are weetned with that acred Salutiferous gift of Healing, which both upports the Body Politick, and keeps up the Denizens and
Subjects thereof in vigor and courage.

And if we can give Faith to the vertues of inanimate Elements and Vegetables, as Stones, Herbs, Plants, and the like, what hall we allow the Living Stones of the Church, our Kings and Queens, its Nuring Fathers and Mothers, where we hall find both their hands mot admirably qualified? In whoe right Hands are the Nerves and Sinews of the Church and State, which gives them that decent Form, orderly Motion, and admirable Dicipline we ee them enjoy.
In their Left, we ee the life and pirit of the three Nations upported and preerved by their miraculous Gifts of Healing: and as the firt etablih'd them the Defenders of the Faith, the econd confirm'd them the Preervers of their People: The one diplaying the Royal Emblems of their acred Piety and Jutice: The other engraving the Remarks of their overaign Clemency and Charity. The former, making the whole World pay Veneration and Reverence to our Englih Kings, and their Royal Names: The later, illutrating
with wonder the acred Riches of their Divine Natures: Their Royal power manifeting their Majety, and this overaign Gift of Healing, their higher Rays of Divinity. And as one does adminiter Order and Peace, which gives life and being to Devotion; o the other brings health and eae, which keeps up Society, and makes Communication flourih in a Nation.

As Nature therefore, the Mitres of Society, does evermore prefer publick before private Good, and Man was born for converation ake;
o by the tream of Duty, I have preumed to Elect your Lordhip as the bet Patron of this Treatie, Entituled, The Royal Gift of Healing. Where if Congruity makes Dedication bear correpondence with Deign, I'm ure I am very happy in my choice, if Your Lordhip will grant me the freedom of my Election; Where although I begin the hew of my Devotion with a mean Sacrifice, wrought up by an unskilful hand, yet I hope your Honor will not meaure my good-will by the value of the Preent, but by the brightnes of your own Goodnes,
who are a great Mater of Excellent Learning, Religious Life, and Pious Converation. My Lord, The eminent and well-deerved place your Honor enjoys in the Kings preence, as well as in his Princely and Royal Palace, being Clerk to the Cloet of his Sacred Majety, do's not only place you near your Soveraign, but puts you at his Right hand, by whoe clean hands the Royal Gold which is ued at our daily Healings, is preented to our Sacred Majety. And this makes you as great a Judge as Oberver of thee his wonderful
and miraculous Cures o frequently made good by his Sacred Hands: the which as they have been infinite in number, o ought they to be accounted miraculous in their Nature. Your Lordhip hath been a ufficient witnes hereof, and can jutifie the Effects and Events of the ame to all the World. But let I may eem tedious to your Honor, well knowing the minutes of Great Men are Sacred, and not to be invaded by every little Addres, I commit the enuing Dicoure it elf (whereof I claim nothing to my elf but the Faults) to
Your Honorable Patronage, Begging pardon for my preumption and lapes, humbly preuming to write my elf,

closer.signed: Your Lordhips mot obedient and faithful Servant, John Browne.

div.head: To the Reader.
div.p: IN this I have given thee the firt on-et, who might't otherwie well wonder to ee me o uddenly again in Print; (the truth is, I cannot well blame thee) Perhaps thou, like ome others, may't think me vainglorious; as alo uppoe that I pretend to know, that I may be publickly known in Writing. But aure thy elf, the Vanity of the Writer hall never poion the Nation with his Winter Endeavors, nor give Mankind the trouble of a Fly with any more of his Summer Undertakings.

The Matter hereof, however mean it is, I call it my own. And although others may refreh
themelves with the weet Flowers of Rhethorick, or pleae their fancies with the gaiety of its mell; or atisfie their humors with the beautiful Tapetry of its Figure or make: yet whoever hall lend this a few hours Reading, will find this mean Production to be the Iue of an elaborate Endeavor. Wherein although I have hewn my lat Follies to the Worlds diverion, if my Zeal, or publick Repect made me o apparently idle, I hope the Ingenuous will with better Candor pardon my rahnes. And although it cannot be denyed that I have been as great a Scribler in Chirurgery, as almot any of my Time and Age, yet I have this as my Guard, I never yet Writ or Publih'd any thing, which did not bear my own Name: Neither was this
ever purchas'd by the eay terms of Familiarity, but forc'd from me by the trong hand of importunity, or deired by the venerable and jut demand of uch Nobility as were able to give Life to its intended deign, and helter to the work it elf: I being never tickled hereto by the itch of Printing, or puft up with the publick deire of Otentation, but readily yielding a generous obeyance to univeral converation, as well as atisfying ome Friends, who put me upon this work in my own deffence; not mierably attackt, or drawn thereto by the blind guids of Self-interet, and common Fame, the two general Harlots of our preent age.

The Truth is, in all my Books which ever yet aw Print, I never had the happines of Reading
by another Mans Eye, or turning over my Books by another Mans Hand, but without any kind of aitance (but what I purchas'd by no mean endeavour from Authority) of mutual Phyical help, or Chyrurgical co-operation; o that this may erve as a Salve to cure the Men of little Thoughts, as touching others. And amongt the ret, they may, if they will give themelves the trouble to Read all the Books I have writ, by the tile of the Penning, as well as the method of the Matter, with eae, ee that they all had but one Father, which any honet Man, void of prejudice, may convince himelf of, and every one ele, but he that wears Spectacles, which are made of contradictory metal.

And ince my skill for ome late years pat, hath been quetioned, as touching this Dieae; and my Judgment thereof hath met with many uncivil rubb by ome of our Profeion (altho I cann't ay many) my thoughts thereof might well have cool'd, and my reolutions chill'd, had I not with new upply taken up freh courage to out-brave the pleen and malice of thee deperate Opponents. But ince I am obliged to give the world ome reaon for this my o ready appearance again in Print, to make good my former Aertion, Necee et ut aliquid haereat; and indeed to prevent any longer looking aquint, and leen the mean Thoughts I have purchas'd, I like a good natur'd Fellow, have taken this task upon me, to demontrate the Symptomatical
appearances of the EVIL, that every Man may ee I am not afraid to appear for the Evil Caue, that is, to hew all the apparent Caues of the Evil in publick, more fully than hath hitherto been hewn; And ince I have taken this publick reolution, I am as ready to defend the ame, if I be at any time hereafter forc'd thereto by uch Men of our Profeion, who mut be better atisfied.

And becaue I would not have this Treatie of the Evil march abroad without having its parts firt viewed and examined, and ee what hape it bears in the World, as well as Figure, that it may not appear montrous evil, I have preumed the Favour as well as the Honour to get my Brother Mr. James Molins, one of His Majeties
Chyrurgeons, a Man of as great Reaon and Judgment, as of Art and Experience to look into, and trace this Dicoure all over in its Three Parts, before I deigned it hould ee the Light, whoe approbation thereof with the mot eminent of the Colledge, and His Majeties Phyicians; as alo His chief Chyrurgeons, the which they have allowed by their Hands thereto, hath given Reputation enough to its Pasport, and is a ufficient Defence againt all uch who may be o evilly minded to Treat it ill upon the account of the Author only. But let I may be thought to write with Vinegar intead of Ink, I come now to the ubject Matter it elf, &c.

But now to the Matter it elf. When this Royal Gift of Healing doth preent its elf: I hope its Name bearing Majety in its firt Front, continued and maintained by many Ages of Princes, will be Argument enough to bles my Undertaking, and require your calm acceptance.

And as our Bleed Saviour, his Apotles, and good Men in former Ages enjoyed a Healing Vertue, as well as other Divine Qualifications, of Propheying, cating out Devils, and the like; all which were tranmitted to their Succeors: So whooever coniders both the length as well as the trength of their Divine Qualifications, may likewie ee, that as they abated in their number, o they leened in their nature and appearance. And
ince I have tract the teps of mot Fathers, and hewn the Gifts of the Apotles and Holy Men, I hall begin next with Edward the Confeor, the firt Undertaker of this great Work in our Englih Nation, known from the others of his Name by the Sacred Titles of Saint and Confeor. Of whom o much hath already been writ, and that with no paring Pen of his praie, that I hould but appear idle to live long on it. In the Dicoure I begin with him as the firt Curer of Struma's, by Contact or Impoition of Hands. The Deign thereof, preents you with the Origination of the Gift of Healing proved, in which are delineated both its definition, and its efficient Caue, Man being allow'd the Intrument, and his Maker the Agent. In it are
hewn various Cures performed by diverity of Hands, as by the Apotles and good Chritians; with the difference between Nature and Miracle, and the frequent ue of thee Miracles, even to the 600 year of our bleed Saviour, proved and made good by Hitory and Authority.

Where Kings and Queens alo, as Nuring Fathers and Mothers, have been always thus qualified with this Sanative Virtue ever ince the Confeor, and England proved to have evermore kept up the ame in the Regal Line, long before any other Prince or Potentate whatever. And although the French King doth Cure by Contact, yet he derived the ame from the Englih by Sprig of Right, and he mut evermore account our Englih Monarchs the eldet
Brothers thereof, confirmed by Hitory, and made good by example, both which received this alutiferous Gift with their jut Rights to the Crown, confirmed and made good to them at their Inaugurations. In this Treatie alo you have the Chyrurgeons Duty laid down, who dicovers the Dieae by examining the ame, by whom Certificates of the Sick People are to be taken in, and Tickets delivered out to them. Herein is alo hewn a ready method for eaing the Dieaed of their tedious journeys, and a preent remedy of ending them back: He brings them to His Majety on his Knee, and delivers every ick Peron to the Kings Sacred Hand to be Toucht. The next concerned is the Clerk of His Majeties Cloet, and Chaplains, the Firt preenting the Gold to the King, the other Reading the Ceremonies and Prayers appointed for this purpoe; in all which is hewn the great Charity, Piety, Clemency, and Humility of our Dread Soveraign; the
admirable effects and wonderful events of His Royal Cure, throughout all Nations, where not only Englih, Dutch, Scotch and Irih have reaped Eae and Cure, but French, Germans, and all Countreys whatoever, far and near, have abundantly een and received the ame; and none ever hitherto, I am certain mit thereof, unles their little Faith and Incredulity tarved their Merits, or they received His Gracious Hand for curing another Dieae, which was not really evermore allowed to be cured by him: And as bright evidences hereof I have preumed to offer, that ome have immediately upon the very Touch been cured; Others not o eaily quitted from their Swellings, till the favour of a Second repetition thereof Some alo loing their Gold, their Dieaes have eized them afreh, and no ooner have thee obtained a Second Touch, and new Gold, but their Dieaes have been een to vanih, as being afraid of His Majeties Preence;
wherein alo have been cured many without Gold; and this may contradict uch who mut needs have the King give them Gold as well as his Touch, uppoing one invalid without the Gift of both. Others eem alo as ready for a Second Change of Gold, as a Second Touch, whereas their Firt being newly trung upon a White Ribond, may work as well (by their Favour.) The tying the Almighty to et times, and particular days, is alo another great fault of thoe who can by no means be brought to Believe, but at Good-Friday, and the like particular eaons, this Healing faculty is of more vigor and efficacy than at any other time, altho performed by the ame Hand. As to the giving of Gold, this only hews His Majeties Royal Well-wihes towards the Recovery of thoe who come thus to be Healed. This Gold being hereat given as a Token of His Sacred Favour, and Pledge of His bet deires for them.

In this Treatie alo you have the marvelous and miraculous efficacy of the Blood of our late Sacred Martyr King CHARLES the Firt; wherein by trange Examples are dicovered this efficacious Virtue of Healing, by many true Devoters of His Great Name, the which, altho tript of its Life, yet not robb'd of its vigor, made good by many, who collected the ame in Linnen, and applying thereof to their Scrophulous Swellings, by which they found immediate eae, and preent relief. His very Prayers alone miraculouly working and effecting the ame in the time of His Troubles; and this alo made good by eminent Authority.

The Reaons of their Ceremony and their Ue, erving only as Prayers, and giving of Thanks for the Sick, and their Recovery; thee being nearer akin to the Solemnity, than aitant to the Cure, the bare Hands and Prayers of our Kings effecting the ame to a
Miracle; the which Sanative Gift hath for above 640 years, been confirmed and continued in our Englih Princely Line, wherein is not o much of their Majety hewn, as of their Divinity, conidering the Liturgy thereat ued is Holy; the Reverence of the Ceremonies performed with all Decency; he that exercieth it being thereto call'd by Divine appointment: The Author of the whole Work being the Holy Ghot, and the Gift thence ariing: Where God is only Worhipped, His Holy Son Venerated; The King thus Sacredly Gifted, and His poor and dieaed Subjects perfectly cured; where no difference is made between Peer and Peaant, delicate or deformed, not acted in the dark, but in the face of His People, in His Royal Palace, and places appointed for Divine Worhip, in his Maters Temple; where the Holy Spirit meets His Sacred Hand, and weetens the ame with its Sanative Virtue. In the conummating therefore of
the whole, you have the variety of Opinions hewn about this Curative method; concluding the ame with many Hitorical Illutrations of trange Cures performed by their Sacred Prayers, Touch, Blood, and the like.

And now altho this rich lading hath been hitherto hid from the publick view of the curious Eyes of trangers, and never as yet aw the face of Day, till unhappily puht forward by my mean Pen; I have preumed to offer it as neceary, that this Princely Vail might no longer be kept over our Nations, but that all the World may admire our Englih Ile, and have the mot Venerable and Sacred Thoughts of her Mighty Monarchs, who thus can banih Dieaes by their Touch, and heal the Countrey Infirmities by their Sacred Hands. I hope this mall labour will get o much kindnes in the World as to raie Men of greater parts to polih and refine this Dicoure, which appears as it were a Chaos, or indigeted lump; If its greatnes of Cures be not ufficient
to make it pas current, I hope the certainty of its reality may advance it, having taken what is herein writ from the infallible tetimony of mine Eyes, in a great part, the which, altho perhaps they may not be allowed the quicket ight, yet they have everal times had the Honour and Advantage of reiterating their peculations, as to thee His Majeties Healings. And if he which vieweth a long time, altho his Sight may not be of the bet, yet doth commonly ee more, than he that looks hatily, be his Eyes never o good: o I who for everal years have had the opportunity of eeing, as well as the late Honour of Waiting at thee great Solemnities, have certainly een as much as I write, and can confirm the ame with more certainty, altho with les Eloquence. And where you meet other Authorities, you meet their Names in the ame line with their own obervations; about which alo I have been as careful to take the valuable meaures of Truth, as the Worth and Quality of the Contributers.

And now kind Reader, if thou dot
detet Anarchy, and expect to hare in the good of this Bleing, acknowledge thy own happy Nation and preent Government, where our preent Blis, and Englih Interets are afely wrapt up in the afety of our Prince, as well as in our Religion; where its Dienters are daily een to crumble into Atomes, and its Churches Enemies o cowardized, as not daring to tread any longer on Englih ground; where the greatet Sects are found hifting themelves under divers marks, ahamed of their own Follies, and frightned by their own incontancies. Let every Loyal Subject therefore, (for with any of the Canting Tribe, I hope this will never get favour) offer publick Thanks and Prayers for His Majeties Sacred Health and miraculous Preervation, who Cures not only His Subjects, but Preerves alo His Three Kingdoms in Peace, Order, and Tranquility; under whom I may preume to conclude, That England doth enjoy as many more Benefits and Bleings, than ever Rome did uffer Mieries and Calamities under the greatet Tyrant.

div.head: CHAP. I. The Origination of this Healing Method proved.
div.p:
THat England hath her particular Dieaes, as well as any other Country or Nation whatoever, is o great a Truth, that no coniderate Man can deny. And to view thoe many Ditempers which have lately crept into the World (altogether unknown to the Ancients) epecially with us in Europe; as the French Pox, Scurvy, Rickets, Struma's, or Kings Evil, Swellings o commonly called, may well put a trange Face upon the Earth: Their proper Reaons and Caues being as yet lock'd up from Humane Undertanding. The truth is, whether thee do happen by viciitudes of Things, Sins of the People,
ill Habits, or wore Contitutions, we cannot o eaily atisfie. Sure I am, Sin is as great a procurer of this, as it is of any of the former Dieaes; for we daily ee it porting its elf lighly under everal Diguies to afflict the Sons of Men.

But having in my former Treaties been more large as touching this, I hall preume, with hopes to offer, that there is no Chritian o void of Religion and Devotion, as to deny a Gift of Healing: A Truth as clear as the Sun, continued and maintained by a continual Line of Chritian Kings and Governors, fed and nourihed with the ame Chritian Milk, which Divine Healing Faculty did arie from the firt time of Chritianity, having thence been derived from the great God of Heaven and Earth.

Hence may we preume to take a view, and behold the great Monarch implanting Soveraign Dignity on his Earthly Majety; giving him his Laws, making him his Vicegerent, guarding his Tongue, preerving his Lips, bleing his Hands with this Salutiferous Gift, and defending his Body from outward Injuries and private Plottings.
Thus we read, Prov. 16. Divination lodgeth in the Kings lips, in Judgment hall not his mouth err, much les his heart, which is governed and directed by the Almighty: For as the diviion of Waters, o is the heart of the King in the hand of the Lord. And in another place, where there is plenty of Widom, it appears as the health of the Nation, much more in a wie King, as the Foundation and Bais of his People: For we are daily Witnees of thoe great and Divine favors which are tranmitted from above to his Sacred Majety, ever denyed to his Subjects, as being too High and Holy for their reach and capacity. Thus Nature her elf doth by a Chain of Caues carry us up to the acknowledgment of a Deity, by bringing every thinking Man to an Original of every uccesful Individual by coure of Generation.

And as to this great Gift of Healing, peculiarly given to his Gracious Majeties Royal hand, by the reception of the Holy Oyl which at his Inauguration he made ue of, and which entitled him the Soveraign of our Nation. Where I hall further atisfie, that
England and France, as to their Kings, had the honor of receiving this Holy Oyl with their Sacred Titles, they being generally anointed in three parts, as hath been well noted. As firt, on their Heads, to ignifie their Glory: Next, on their Breats, to hew their Sanctity; and then on their Arms, to denote their Power. And from hence did arie the three equalizing Fames given to them, of being Holy, Sacred, and Divine. And from thoe early days, whoe Power and Sanctity was ever given to their Sacred Perons; uch Peron whooever hould dare to trike upon the Sacred Ground on which they did tread, hould loe his hand for this his preumption. And amongt the ret of his Divine Favors betowed upon him, let this Sanative Faculty amongt all Mankind, be reckoned one, which doth denote both his Right, Title and Merit, and as a econd Gift given from Heaven, by thoe many Thouands cured by him ince his happy Retoration; and this acknowledged not only by the Perons themelves who have been thus Cured, but by relation of Phyicians and Chirurgions, and others throughout
his univeral Realms and Dominions: all which in a great meaure doth declare his excellent Charity which weetens the Gift, as alo his Piety and Clemency in granting poor Souls his Sacred and ready Touch.

We come now to prove the Origination of a Healing Faculty,The Origination of Healing proved. and this is proved out of Corinth. 1. c. 12. v. 8, 9, 10. For to one is given by the Spirit the word of Widom: To another, the word of Knowledge by the ame Spirit: To another Faith by the ame Spirit: To another the gift of Healing by the ame pirit: To another the working of Miracles: To another Propheie: To another the dicerning of Spirits: To another divers Gifts of Tongues: To another the interpretation of Tongues. And this Scripture alone is enough to prove a Gift of Healing.

The next Quetion which hence will arie, is,Whether every one may pretend to this Gift. Whether every one may pretend to this Gift, or whether it be ditributive to all perons at all times, and in all places? And this is as readily anwer'd as the former: For when our Saviour acended up into Heaven, he gave Gifts unto men; as to ome the Gift of Widom, to ome the Gift of
Knowledge, to ome Faith, and to others the Gift of Healing, and the like. And as in this no Man can affirm that he enjoys all the above-mentioned Qualities, o cannot any Man ay that he is tript of all.

In the firt Face therefore of the Primitive Church, as an Orient Gem, or Fulgent Adamant, did this Gift of Healing appear with plendor and admirable Form, o that the Church was perfum'd with its Divine Qualities, where was Widom declaring her elf amongt the Learned, whil't others did as readily demontrate their great Knowledge; ome hewing their Faith by their Works, others curing the Sick and the Lame: And whil't ome lent the World the weetnes of their Dicoure, others as readily Propheified of things to come. And thus according to their variety of Gifts, they had diverity of Names given them: ome being call'd Apotles, ome Doctors, and others Prophets: ome excelling in Virtue, others as richly qualified in this Gift of Healing. Thus when poor indigent Souls had ought out Remedy from Phyicians in vain, God in his own time ent them eae by
the aitance of his Holy Spirit, and made thoe rebellious Dieaes which corn'd Medicine, and trampled on the bet of Remedies compoed by the wiet Phyician and mot able Chirurgion, in a moment yield to Gods command, and retreat at His Majeties Sacred Touch.

And might there any Quetion arie about the firt Phyician which cured by Touch, the Anwer is very ready:Chrit the firt Author of Healing. The firt and lat, the bet and greatet Recoverer of all Dieaes is our Saviour Chrit: For he acended into Heaven, and gave gifts unto men: He pat through Galilee and its neighboring Nations, curing thoe which were oppret with evil Spirits, the which he dicharged from them by his Virtue, and the Holy Spirit; and not only thee, but uch as were troubled with the Palie, Leproie, Lunacy, &c. Incurable by others, as you may ee Luke 6. and Matth. 6. v. 14, 15, 16. When Jeus was come into Peters houe, he aw his wifes mother laid ick of a fever; and he touched her hand, and the fever left her: and he aroe and minitred unto them. And when the
evening was come, they brought him many poeed with devils, and he cat out the evil pirit with his word, and healed all that were ick. And all this done without the help of Pharmacy, or compoition of Medicine, for he cured by his own Virtue.

Matth. 19. & 21. v. 14. And he departed from Galilee, and came into the coats beyond Judea beyond Jordan, and great multitudes followed him,Matth. 21. and he healed them: and the blind and the lame came to him in the Temple, and he healed them. Acts & Luke 6. 5.12. And it came to pas, when he was in a certain city, behold, a man full of the Leproie, who eeing Jeus, fell on his face, aying, Lord, if thou wilt thou canst make me clean; and he put out his hand and touch'd him, aying, I will, be thou clean, and immediatly the Leproie departed from him. All which does declare the brightnes and clearnes of our bleed Saviours curing and healing of poor Souls.

Whether Apotles and Religious men had this Gift of Healing.We next proceed to Apotles and pious Men, where may arie this Quetion (Whether this Healing Faculty was tranmitted to them?) It is without all contradiction that there were twelve which did hare therein: But
whether others ariing from them had this Gift conferr'd to them, and o tranmitted to their Succeors, will thus appear, from their being called into Society with them, Matth. 10. v. 8. Thus, When he called unto him his twelve diciples, he gave them power againt unclean pirits, to cat them out, and to heal all manner of icknes, and all manner of dieaes. Acts 5. Heal the ick, cleane the lepers, raie the dead. And that wch gives greater light to this Anwer, is, That not only Peter, and Paul, and John, the ons of Zebedee were thus qualified, but the other Apotles alo; and by the hands of the Apotles were many igns and wonders done amongt the people. And Mark 6. v. 7.13. And there came a multitude out of the cities round about unto Jerualem, bringing ick folk, and they were healed. And he called unto him the twelve, and ent them forth two by two, and gave them power over unclean pirits, and they anointed with oyl many that were ick, and healed them. God Almighty did wonderful works by the hands of Paul at his coming to Epheus, o that from his Body were brought unto the ick, handkerchiefs, and aprons, and their dieaes departed
from them, v. 12. And that of Publius's Father laying ick of a Fever and Dientery, Paul viiting him, Praying with him, and laying his hands on him, he was preently healed; which is evidence enough to convince the tranmiion of this Gift from our Saviour to his Apotles. They therefore who will preume to put limits to the Almighties Power, or fix his Favors to particular Seaons, Times, Perons, orders of Men, or diverity of Places, mut be allowed o far different from acknowledging a Benevolent Deity, that they do both leen his Power, and call in quetion his Authority and Soveraignty.

The Knowledge of Man dies with him, as well as his hours and his age; but this Almighty Gift doth continue to the very lat Age of the World, o that we may affirm, That not only the great Apotles, but their Succeors, have been harers in their mot excellent Endowments, as well as in their Natures and Contitutions. This attending them as an expanded Pleaure of the Divine Will: for the Almighties hand is not hortned,
who aith, He will be with his to the end of the World: A Leon too great for any Atheit to deny, and too good to be let lip without a Reverential acknowledgement.

div.head: CHAP. II. Herein is hewn what this Gift is, and when, and how often ued.
