div.p: OUr firt Chapter looks but as the Rigging and Sails of a Ship which we are Lanching into: This gives us the dimenions and its proper ues, where we are to examine, Whether this Dieae be naturally curable or incurable, not hitherto fully decribed: And that we may not keep it too long upon the Sands, we hall find it the Gift of God which makes it ail thus univerally throughout the World, Fetching and procuring Health by the Holy Spirit to the Sons of Men, by whoe aitance, one Man may as well guide her in her Curative Paage as an hundred.

And as this is a Gift or Grace betowed on Chritians, given to them by the Holy Spirit for the Cure of one or many Dieaes, and this by the Impoition
of their Hands on them, and Prayers, and Gold put over their Necks, is a great Gift beyond all dipute, and next to a Miracle done by any of the former Apotles. And that this comes from above, I hope no coniderate Man will deny: For inful Man can only call Sin his own. S. Augutine joyned to this Gift, Charity, Mercy, Clemency, and Sanctity; thee being as the four Pedetals on which this Royal Gift doth fix its proper Bais: It is performed by the Holy Spirit, from whom doth proceed every good and perfect Gift; and this is not given to all Men, nor to all Church-men, for every Man hath his particular Gift allowed him, and Health doth demontrate the particular nature of Caues ariing from the habit and ue of the Gift. God Almighty having an Infinite, and Immene Goodnes in him, not to be drained out by Time, or les'ned by the utmot of Age. As therefore in the early Times of the Church this Gift received much Honor; o becaue we do live in Times which do bear equal weight, and hare with the like Dieaes; I ought to bring again to life this Divine Gift,
ent by the Almighty to our Sacred Majety, thus exercied as the lat and bet Remedy. To him therefore be given the greatet Reverence and Honor, to whom the greatet Veneration is due.

The Definition of this Gift.We come now to examine the Gift it elf, what it is, as alo in what times it was firt ued: And that I may enter the Scene without fear, Truth being my great General, I hall begin its definition which the Apotle makes mention of, Cor. 12. which declares both the efficacy and action thereof: For the greatet praie of this Gift conits in the action thereof. Who therefore hall preume to make any further doubt, but acknowledge, that he which hath this admirable Gift in him,The frequent ue thereof. may make ue thereof at his own will and pleaure, for the Curing of poor Mortals which hall approach his Royal Touch? Sure there is none but inconiderate Men, which either can or will deny this Healing Faculty, or make any quetion of it, and that it is as plain as it is Hereditary, is as ready to be aented to. For it is laid down as a general Maxim amongt the
mot grave Senators, That they which are bet gifted, or do excel others either in Art, Widom, Knowledge, Oratory, or the like, mot excellent Qualifications, thee are confirm'd and etablih'd upon them as Divine Habits running in their Veins, and excellent Qualifications going along with them throughout the whole coure of their lives, and tranmitted more or les to their ucceeding Generations. And although thee may eem trange to the Man les knowing, yet every Ingenuous and coniderate Peron which hath the rules of Undertanding in him, will find, That Widom doth lodge in the Kings lips, and that the words of the Wie are as goads and nails fatned by the Maters of Aemblies: In the ame manner, he that hath Faith, and is bet intructed for the doing and undertanding of all things, hath a greater degree of Divinity implanted in him. Heb. 11. v. 32, 33. Thus by faith, the Fathers of old did overcome Kingdoms. And what hall I ay more? for the time would fail me to tell of Gideon, and of Barack, and of Sampon, and of Jepthae, and of David alo, and of Samuel and the
Prophets, who through Faith ubdued Kingdoms, wrought Righteounes, obtained Promies, topt the mouths of Lions, &c. Faith being like Virtue, evermore active: And uch as the habit of Humane Body is, uch Fruits uually we hall find it yield, either to its excellency or demerit. But as to this Virtue of Healing, and the like ublime Qualifications, as of Propheying, Gifts of Tongues, examination of Spirits, thee do rie much higher than the former; for this puts Man upon the thinking and conidering part. Thus when pious and good Men are tirred up by the Divine Spirit, they open Miracles themelves, and puts advantage to the bet of Thoughts. Amongt thee may I well place this mot admirable Healing Gift of our Dread Soveraign, appearing herein as a fixt Star in the midt of his People, or as a greater Light among the leer ditributing according to his own will and pleaure, of this his Curative Faculty, to his poor mierable and dieaed Subjects of all Ages, Sexes, Orders and Degrees whatoever,Its duration proved. by which they are tript from their Dieaes, and rerelieved
from their Pangs, and this not palliated or dimit for a while, or done by chance or good fortune, but he cures by deliberate and erious conultation, prepared thereunto by the Almighty Power tranmitting his Holy Spirit for the better accomplihment thereof.

They mut needs therefore be allowed no good Subjects, who dare deny this Sanative Faculty, which o many thouands have received even to a Miracle. And without doubt amongt the wort of Mankind, it mut be allowed an Act of Grace, and a great and pious condecention of his Gracious Majety thus to give eae and relief to every ick and lame Peron, by his Sacred and gracious Touch, wherein and whereby we may ee the Almighty revealing many things to his, which are denyed to others; which doth implant a greater Knowledge in them, and yet they do not enjoy all Science, the perfection of the Divinity whereof he reerves to himelf: Neither are they ignorant or unknown to him, for were they o, where would be their familiarity with the Holy Spirit, by whom this great
work is performed: for o oft as they have therewith been concerned, they could forehew many things to come, as converions of Republicks, ruines of Kingdoms, Death of Nobles, and many other the like Obervations. This Healing Faculty is always preent with and in the Almighty,Gods aiting hand gives perfection to the Cure. his will conenting to his Soveraigns pleaure, and in the proecution thereof: and this is very ueful and profitable, being conducted by a Divine motion or intigation of the Holy Spirit. For the Almighty hath given Mans will its certain limits, and hath circumcribed bounds thereto.The efficient caue of Healing. But as touching this Divine Qualification of Healing, whence it cometh, and what the efficient Caue thereof is, whether proceeding from the naked dicoure of the words ued at the Ceremony, or the Solemnity of the Pious and Religious action, or of any created Virtue ariing hence, I hall preume to offer this as a Foundation againt all Dipute whatoever.Whether this be in Man, or derivative from God. That no Miracle, howoever glorious, which we ever aw, read, or heard of, was ever done by an inherent Virtue created in Man alone, not this of
His Majeties Royal Healing, procuring and affording hereby this Health to the Sick, which we daily ee and find they do hereby purchae and enjoy: But there is and mut be God Almighties hand going along with it, for no Mortals Virtue, or Piety, or Power, hath trength or efficacy enough in it to perform this Soveraign anative Faculty: Nor can the Ceremonies or Vetments any wie effect the ame; for as to thee, thoe which were carried to Paul (viz.) the handkerchiefs and aprons, were only igns and tokens for begetting and confirming the Faith of thoe who were cured in Paul's abence. And for a more clear undertanding hereof, this Gift which he received from the Almighty, was not fixed or tyed to his Body, and o much the les dipenable to the ick people which thus came to him for help, or ent to him, and which aw him not: But God wrought thee Miracles by his hands, and his hand was the only Intrument by which this great Work was performed, whil't his Maker was the great Agent thereof: Much les could the Ceremonies and Vetments procure
this which are put upon it: Gods Hand is the hand of Health, and his Arm wants no trength to perform every kind of Cure beyond humane capacity: The which Peter well knew, when he tells us of a Man, which was lame from his mothers womb Acts 3. who eeing Peter and John about going into the Temple, asked an alms; and Peter fastning his eyes on him with John, aid, Look on us: In the name of Jeus of Nazareth rie up and walk; and he took him by the right hand and lifted him up, and immediatly his feet and ancle bones received trength, and went into the temple praiing God. And although Peter, through Gods aitance, did give this great cure to this Cripple, yet primarily he received this Divine Power from above, before any effect could be wrought. And that alo is very remarkable, Acts 9. when Peter did pas through all Quarters, arriving at Lidda, where he aw Aeneas, who had kept his bed eight years, and was ick of the palie, and Peter aid unto him, Aeneas, Jeus Chrit make thee whole, God the Agent, Man the Intrument. arie, and make thy bed, and he aroe immediatly.

This hews the great Gift of the
Almighty, performed by the leer intrument Man, even as the Sun is no ways leened in its plendor by the light of the Moon, or leer Stars: For thus Man doth receive this Gift from the Divine Giver, as the Moon and leer Stars do borrow their light from the Sun: For the Almighty doth diplay and communicate his Gifts to Mankind, whoe Rays are implanted in his mind, clear'd up, and freed from all cloudines, there to be kept in him as his choicet Treaures and Divine Qualifications. Thus therefore Man mut be allowed the Organ and Intrument, God himelf the chief Agent and Mater of the Operation, Man being his ervant, which receives the honor and glory thereof: and by this Divine and Humane conjunction, thus mot excellently agreeing together, this mot admirable Healing Faculty is thus produced for the benefit, advantage, eae and cure of many thouands of poor, mierable, ick, lame, and ditempered people.

div.head: CHAP. III. Whether Dieaes Curable or Incurable.
div.p:
WHat the Struma is, or Kings Evil, o commonly called from the Kings healing thereof by his Sacred Touch, I have already atisfied in my econd Book, wherein is hewn both its Definition, Caues, Preages, &c. For the unravelling this skain, pun out of o many fine threds, in which are found many knots about curing Dieaes curable or incurable: We mut begin to unty it in its proper place, by examining its Age and Diuturnity. Thus Paul, when he cured the Father of Publius of a Dientery and Fever, the Cure was admirable, although both the Dieaes naturally curable: for a Fever we ee, be it never o vexatious, its forc'd to quit its tation by true Phyick and a right method ued. The Dientery alo is as readily conquered and by the like
means. When our Bleed Saviour alo cured the Palie, or the Hemorrhagy: No man can deny but that both thee Dieaes in themelves are curable, but our Saviour cured thee by his own Power, which by others were not to be performed but by proper means, and therefore this ought not to be allowed an ordinary way of Healing.

Hence Chrit forbids not the curing of the Sick by the hands of Chritian Kings, Princes and Governors,Apotles and good Chritians allowed in former times to cure Dieaes. who do follow his Rules by Prayer and Impoition of Hands: For we have read of many Holy and Pious people who have cured Dieaes after everal manners, and where any thing of a Divine Influence is implanted, what hould deny the hand thereof to declare the ame? and although this Dieae is natural, no quetion but this Method is upernatural, the which may be made good by Hitorical Illutrations. For as this Struma, or Kings Evil Swelling is a popular Dieae (bred out of Matter and Blood, ent into the Glandules, and therein making a further bulk according to the Quantity
of Matter ent thither) and paring neither Age or Sex, and yet curable if any man coniders its nature well; unles it be uffer'd to run into a great extream, whoe Malice bids defiance to all Cure, the time being neglected which might more mildly have given it its dipatch: and ince its Curablenes or Incurablenes conits in its Matter, it mut needs truckle to him who hath this Divine Gift of Healing tranmitted to him. And as a further advantage to the clearing of this Point, we never ee his Sacred Majety enquiring into the age of the dieaed, or the Dieae it elf, being relative either to youth or old age, Men, Women or Children, rich or poor, all which he cures by his Sacred Hand; with ome Ceremonies and Prayers therewith annexed for the Poor thus waiting on him for their Health and Recovery: The which I have had the Honor of being an eye-witnes in the Place and Quality which his Sacred Majety hath been pleaed to confer on me, as one of his Chirurgions attending at this great Solemnity, where I mut, with St. Augutine, preume to Offer, that this great Gift of his
may well compare with a Miracle and we ought to give it the ame name, if not allow it the nature thereof, when we hall ee o many Dieaed People come from all parts of the World, even tired out of their Lives by their Ditempers, and perplex'd with troubleome Swellings, thus readily to gain Victory over them, and become ound, and tript from all their enormous Swellings; and this with extraordinary peed, only by the application of his Sacred Hand, and this een to be done without, and beyond all expectation of the poor People themelves, their Friends or Relations: their Faith being as a great Ingredient to this Compoition. All which may well enough come within the Pale of a Miracle, being done beyond our knowledge and the coure of Nature.

St. Augutine, The Difference between Nature and Miracle. Lib. 6. Contr. Faut. cap. 3. doth there thus ditinguih between Nature and Miracle in its dicriminancy. We commonly call that Nature which is known by its coure and cutom: On the contrary, when God works or makes any thing beyond this, this properly comes under
the notion of Miracle. Under which lat, this Gift of Healing may well take place, whoe miraculous Efficacy, although there may be ome inequality with it with Miracles, yet the Dignity thereof is to be admired, and the ue and benefit thereof being not much unlike, they hould bear alike date with us.

Chrit tells his Apotles, That thoe who believe in him, the works which he did, they hall alo do, and greater than thoe: and whatoever they hall ask in my Name, that I will do, that the Father may be glorified in the Son. Amongt the ret of Miracles, may be reckoned the falling back of the Sun, and the tanding till of the Moon; both which do declare the Divine Will and Omnipotent Power of the Almighty. But to give ight to the Blind, to make the Lame walk, to give Life to the dead, and cure to the ick of their Dieaes, and this only by the Impoition of Hands, is much greater: wherein is hewn a greater Meaure of Divinity, which ought to be reckoned amongt the greatet of Miracles.

Rarefaction and Denation of Air,
or reolution of the ame into drops, by the Prayers of Moes and Elias, is a thing very great and tupendious: Yet this is no Miracle. To give Health to Struma's, to help the Paralytick, and to dicharge and banih other Dieaes, may not eem trange to a knowing Phyician, and to an able Chirurgion, where a curative Method is ued according to Art: But to Heal by the Touch, or by Contact, and by Devotion of Prayers, to procure Health to the Sick, and to banih Dieaes from poor Mortals without the help of Medicine; and this done immediatly, this ought not to come much beneath a Miracle.

div.head: CHAP. IV. How long this hath been in ue, and when began to flourih.
div.p: THat the apotles have had this gift betowed on them, hath already been hewn and made good: And that their Succeors have been harers therein with them, may be cleared as bright as the Sun. For no Age of Chritians, by the light of Examples, hath ever been without it, although ome Ages hath had it more frequently than others, and the Repetition of its admirable Effects hath frequently evinced and made this good. That we may therefore atisfie all Objections, and prevent Calumny where ever it may meet or offer its elf, we hall introduce ome Examples of long continuance.Its long continuance by Tetimony of Authorities.

St. Augutine writes, That few Miracles hapned in his time, neither were they permitted to lat long which o
hapned. Thus he writes, Lib. de vera Religione, cap. 25. in thee words, Let the Soul hould evermore hunt after viible things, and Humanity in its earch hould hereby grow cold therewith, and its novelty. This is true, that until their hands were put to be Baptized, they never thus received the Holy Spirit: By which they enjoyed thee Gifts of Tongues of all Nations, or arrived at the Shadow or Tranciion of the Teachers of Chrit: By which the Sick were thus healed, the which then hapned, and then afterwards ceaed. But our curative Gift runs not along in this Stream, and if we look into the Times of St. Augutine, we hall find admirable effects gaining trength in the times of the Apotles, even to the Age of Simeon, in whoe time the Church appeard incorrupt, and as a pure Virgin: and after him, it carried the ame vigor to the ucceors thereof. For as Euebius witneeth, The Divine Spirits did exercie themelves in his times, and hewed their admirable Virtues and excellent Qualifications, even to the times of Adrianus, under Antoninus and Marcus Aurelius, then Governors; by
which it abundantly appears of what value and eteem this ancient Virtue of Healing was in former Ages. Irenaeus, who lived a little after Tertullian, followed a long time in thee Gifts: Thus Irenaeus, altho a Lad, heard Polycarpus in Aia: Polycarpus alo a Diciple of the Evangelit St. John, maintained the ame Gift of Healing, the which he thus exprees, Lib. 5. We have heard many Brethren in the Church, having the Gifts of Propheie, and of Healing, and of Speaking univeral Tongues by the Spirit, producing and bringing many things to view, obcured and hid from former Ages, for ue and explaining the Myteries of God according to the participation of the ame Spirit; as alo Lib. 2. cap. 58. Some of thee having in them the Knowledge of things to come, and of Viions, and of Prophetick Sayings; and others of curing the Sick and Lame of their Dieaes, by laying their Hands on them, and o recovering them.

Its numberles to tell the Gifts of thee from God throughout the World, done in the Name of Jeus Chrit, not by Invocation of evil Spirits, or Inchantment, or black and
dark Curioity, but by pure, clear, and clean Prayers made to him, who directs us in every thing and gives a Bleing and Succes to this Undertaking of his own Anointed, which have been obtained above 600 years; all which may be made good by the clearet light imaginable, and hall more fully hew it elf in its proper place.

When Origen aw all thee Divine and admirable Gifts perpetuated and continued in the Church, and that as clear as the brightet Light, the Eyes of all People being open to ee and vindicate the Truth thereof, againt any Opponent whatoever, he thus replies thereupon: Thee Miracles, (aith he) are to be examined by certain rules of Judgment, let they bring Damnation unto men, or correction to their manners: That we may ditinguih between thoe done by the help of Satan, from thoe which are performed by a pure and pious mind, adorned with the Divine Spirit; ome may enter and offer here, that in the Bloody times of the Church, when it laid under Perecution for near 300 years, all
thee Gifts or mot of them continued in vigor, but when it once abated of its Flame and Troubles, it lot of its power and efficacy, and became more paring in its appearance to mankind. It would be an infinite, as well as troubleom task, to bring all things into number, omitting St. Athanaius, who lived in the time of the Nicene Council, and one of the ame Judgment, where he numbers Bailius, Lib. 6. de Spiritu Sancto, where he writes the Gifts of the Holy Spirit to be, Delight, Joy, Peace, Goodnes, Prudence, Widom, Counel, the Gift of Healing, &c. But who is more curious in the earch thereof than St. Bail? And if any will till doubt of thee Gifts, and of their perpicuounes, he is to be brought into a mean; and if credit therefore cannot be given to St. Augutine, or St. Bail, both evermore accounted good and pious Men; or to Origine or Tertullian, who were ever eteemed men of great Learning; nor to Irenaeus, or others of his Faith and Belief, the Faith of all Hitory mut perih. And if we cannot lend our credence to thee worthy Church-men, in
whoe times thee great Miracles were wrought, we may as well lacken and tye up our Faith to any other thing whatoever. I know, and do expect that this Aertion will not go off moothly, or pas by the blats of the Envious without a Reprimand, but mut take as much contradiction as their pleaures hall think bet to put upon it; yet in this I hall think my elf happy, that I have a Cure for their evil Breaths, when I hall offer no Authority but uch as hath evermore been accounted faithful and praie-worthy in their Generations. And in order thereunto, I would willingly know, who ever was a more Luculent Author than Divus Hieronimus, or a more happy witnes than blet St. Augustine? who more happy in their times for Prediction of admirable effects of theirs and their former times? all their Books being filled with Wie Sayings, and cherihed with Worthy Examples; neither could any thing lie hid in the dark, which ever arrived at the light of their Writings.

Kind Reader, What hath thus been produced by Example, hews that it
mut be a Holy and good Man, which is to perform this Cure, which is not to be performed without a Divine Pleaure.
Quet.But a Quetion may alo arie: Whether our Sacred Majety did conult his Phicians, before he applyed his Hands to the Sick, and did take their Opinions about the ame?

Anw,In Anwer whereunto, There was no need hereof, ince the great Phyician of Heaven and Earth being herein Invoked, and the Holy Jeus joyned therewith; to both which the Holy Spirit being interpoed, what hould or could hinder this Divine efficacy of a Sanative Faculty?

Quet.Some alo will tart another Quetion, which is: Whether His Majety doth Cure that by his Gracious Touch, which hath baffled both Phyicians and Chirurgions in their ndertakings, and hereby ending health to the Sick, which Art and Skill could never arrive at or procure?

Anw.And in Anwer to this, St. Hillaries
Oration hall be ufficient, where he aith, God working with him, he performs both great and mall Cures by his Servants, and by his or their Faith and Prayers to the Son of God, they do receive the ame, who tells them, Whatoever they hall ask in his Name, hall be given unto them. A blind Woman being brought to this St. Hillary, who had a long time laid under this mierable condition, even till he had pent her whole tock on Phyicians and Chirurgions: He tells her, If that which he had thus conumed had been given to the poor, Jeus the true Phyician would have made her well. She till earnetly begging and entreating his mercy, he pit on her Eyes, and preently he became whole. And the more and greater Faith is given to this Sanative Power ariing from the Holy Spirit, the greater Efficacy and Virtue it carries with it. Thus much of Hieronimus the great Man writ of Antoninus and Hillarion, who arrived near at his Age; for he lived about 78 or 79 years, as Proper tetifies in his Chronicle. St. Augutine out-lived him much about that time, being as witnees of his great praie:
for hould we enquire into his Converation, we hall find his Authority much eteemed as to its verity, whoe Judgment was harp, whoe Wit accute and ubtile, even to a Miracle, both in the knowledge and events of admirable Effects: No man need be ahamed in following o good a General, who hath been o curious a Searcher into this matter which I have preumed to dicoure of. Another ort of People there are, who put us upon anwering a fourth Quetion.

p.hi: Wherefore are not thoe Miracles which have been performed by the Preachers and Pious Men of former times till continued?

div.p:
Anw.The Anwer for uch is ready and eaie: It was neceary the World hould be taught Credence, that it might be brought into a tate of Belief, into which every one ought to enquire for Beliefs ake, for there are many Miracles done atteted by them; amongt which is that reckoned as one, Of Chrits acention into Heaven with the ame Fleh, as he did arie: And this is beyond all denyal; and
this was done, that it might be believed it was done: and they who did give a more lively Faith thereto, had a greater hare of Light thereof given to them? St. Augutine is een to mention this egregious Miracle in everal places, and particularly in his Book of Retractions, cap. 4. & De Unitate Eccle. cap. 16. where he thus expreeth it: Throughout the whole World where our Communion went, there were uch and o many admirable Gifts of Healing delivered and revealed to the ick; where amongt the ret is reckoned the blind Man of Millain, who for many years together had lot his ight, and then again recovered the ame. But we leave Italy and come to Africa; and here at Carthage, amongt many other Hitories, I hall et down that of St. Augutine, which he mentioneth of a Religious and innocent Woman, who having a Cancer in her Breat not curable by Medicine, and o judged to be taken off by Hippocrates his Rule; and he being hereat much concern'd, he threw her elf wholly into the Hands of her Maker, as her lat and bet Phyician: This Woman being admonih'd in her leep
to come to the Penticot, as the cutom of that Country was, to be Baptiz'd; and being there Baptized, ignifying the ame by the ign of the Cros, he recovered her health: Some while after, the Phyician who pronounced her Incurable, meeting her in o good condition, and being deirous to know how he conquer'd this her terrible Ditemper, the which he uppoed would have peedily rob'd her of her Life; he telling him her method he made ue of, giving thanks for her happy ucces, he rather contemns the ame, than joyns in thanks for her great Recovery: uch being the Pride and Opinions of ome ill Men, that although they ee ome things done before their Eyes, they have carce Faith enough to believe them, or Civility ufficient to acknowledge them: Not declaring with St. Augutine, That the Almighty is more glorified hereby, by hewing his wonderful and miraculous Methods to the Sons of men. I hould be too tedious and voluminous, hould I reckon up thee Hitories of St. Augutine, relating to thee trange and wonderful ways of Cure: thoe of Baus of Hippomenes; of the
young Man grieved with the Palie; of Paulus and Palladia, who both were troubled with a Trembling over all their parts. And that he might not eem erronious herein in his Hitories, he gives every of them their proper names, and proper places: And hence this Holy Father concludes, That out of o many accidents, many Miracles have been performed by the Almighty, by and through uch Intruments as he hall pleae to appoint, and when he pleaeth: That a more ready congratulation may be given to the Almighty, he advieth, That thoe who have thus received their health, hould let the World ee what great things he hath done for them, and to record the ame, that future Ages may behold and admire his Widom and Goodnes to poor Mortals. Let us therefore, Chritians, who do live under the bet of Princes, and in the perfect Light of his Wonders, yield Praie, Thanks, and due Obedience to him for the ame; and not with the ingrateful Man, think and uppoe thee things Fictitious. For who can be o blind, eeing thee things daily done and made good, as to deny the
truth thereof, but hould rather, according to St. Augutines example, triumph in thee Works done in England, the which ought rather to be regitred than forgotten: That ucceeding Generations may behold the Examples of the wonderful Cures which hath been performed before their days, by the Sacred Hand of our Bleed Soveraigns.St. Augutines way of Curing declared by Poidoneus.
Poidoneus in Vit. Augut. cap. 18.29, 30. thus writes of St. Augutine, That when he was afflicted with his lat ditemper, there came a Woman with a ick Man to him, and deired that he would touch him that he might be cured: He being told in his leep, That if he went to St. Augutine the Bihop, and he laid his hands upon him, he hould be relieved of his Dieae. Upon his coming to St. Augutine, he tells him, If he would pleae to touch him he hould be whole: St. Augutine, it is aid, laying his hands on him, he went home ound and cured of his Dieae. And Poidoneus writes this as one of St. Augutines great Miracles: He dyed the fifteenth of September, Anno Chriti 430. but left this Gift of Healing behind him; for we hall find, after his
time, this till flourihed and encreaed; for from his time even to Jutinus the old Emperor, that is to ay, to the five hundred and eighteenth year of our Saviour,Frequency of Miracles to the 518 and 600 year of Chrit, proved by Hitory. vid. Hooker. it ran in the ame tream near eighty years, in which many and wonderful Gifts of Healing were exercied, as Hitory doth fully atisfie; and o continued even to the eventh Age, that is, the Six hundred and tenth year of Chrit, even to the Council of Nice. We hall not trouble you with any other methods and by-ways ued for Cures, taken up in thee days by evil Spirits, or unclean Peudomungers, rather naming the Virtues and Divine Gifts of Pious and Holy Men. And that this Virtue hath been tranmitted through all Ages of the World, not only Africa bears witnes, but our Aia, called Europe, can tetifie the ame. And as the Meridian and Orient times were illutrated by thee Gifts betowed on the ervants of God above 670 years and upwards, o alo our Occidental times do receive the ame by the Septentrional Light. And our Britain can as well peak of this, as any Age or Country whatoever: for out of Properus
his Authority it appears, that Germanus the Bihop of Auocerre was ent into Britain from Celetine. Contantius aith, that this Germanus and Lupus Bihops of Troys (eeing all weather fair to willing minds) were both Men of uch Learning and Holy Lives, that a grave Father of their Time, called Lupus, the Father of Fathers, and the Bihop of Bihops, and yet but a Second to Germanus the Principal, much reembling Paul and Barnabas. They being ent as two Legates into Britain, as the Chief and Principal of the ret; thee by their great Learning and Virtue did weeten a great part of the Country with their Doctrine, and confirmed the Orthodox Faith, and made many of the Pelagians, whoe Religion, or rather way of Worhip, wch they had formerly ued, to revolt from that which they had formerly taken up, and reclaimed the Erronious Preaching in Fields and High-ways; and as the Kings preence did make a Court, o theirs did make a Church. For at this time Pelagius, which was a Britain, and had ecured many Diciples to himelf which came out thence, and infected the People
with the Pelagian Hereie, did begin to leen both in his number and reputation. For God Almighty, as it were by a wonderful Compendium, did confirm the Catholick Faith, by hewing a Miracle performed by a Man of the Tribunative Power, who coming into Church with his Wife, and having his Daughter blind for about ten years, they carryed her to the Priets, where they joyned in Prayers with her Parents for her Recovery (whil't on the contrary the Pelagians waiting to ee the ucces) Germanus after having invoked the Holy Trinity, the Daughter immediatly was een cured in the publick view of all the By-tanders.

Constantius remembers, that in the lat Legation of this Germanus coming into this Ile, that Elephias a great Man hapned in his way, and plac'd his Son, who although in the flower of his Age, had his Members withered, his Knee contracted, and could not walk by reaon of this contracted drynes which hapned in his Ham: this Germane made him preently to et down, and did extend the contracted parts, and gave him a peedy cure, o
that his drynes received moiture, and the Nerves regained their proper functions: The Son return'd to his Father, the People hereat were all amazed, and the Catholick Faith by this means grew very firm and table in the Breats of all Men. This Gift of Germanus, as I have aid, was founded on the Orthodox Faith, which both eaily and readily did confound its Enemies the Pelagians. This Pelagius alo as he was a Britain by birth, was by ome called Morgan; and every Man, as Dr. Fuller writes in his Eccleiatical Hitory, is born a Pelagian, naturally proud of his Power, and needs little Art to make him think well of himelf, and Britain only bred him, and he himelf begot and bred his Hereie; and in this, our Iland is as happy as unfortunate, for as it bred him it oppoed his Errors; even as the bet Father may have an unhappy Child, who by the fore-ight of his Sons extravagancy may quit him from his favor, and o give no countenance to his evil Coures. And that which is almot as great a Miracle, is that one relates of him, The ame day that Pelagius was born in Britain, St. Augutine was born
in Africk: The Almighty ending both the Poion and the Alexapharmick together into the World, in one and the ame hour or day.

I hall not preume to appear o curious, as to look into the coure of Gods thus confirming his Truth with uch Seals and Miracles done in the Church; we ought rather to conult the Scriptures, which are the proper Fountains of Truth.

But to pretermit many Authorities with which I could eaily well up this Dicoure,Some Cures wrought in the Church, and after the time of Gregory. I proceed to the time of Gregory the Great, who writes, That he aw Holy Men working Miracles by many Virtues, as cleaning the Lepers, cating out Devils, healing the Sick by touching them, and Propheying by the Spirit of Propheie: and he brings John to the example of ome of thee; one of which, was the blind Man which he cured; another was one born Lame and Dumb at Contantinople; yet all Ages of the Church did not receive the purity of the Scriptures, nor charity of Learned Men. Whence I cannot be o readily brought
to believe, but rather demur to their ayings, and the frequent miraculous Performances which are aid to be done by St. Augutine and his Companions, of which both Gregory and Beda makes mention; neither can I believe all the Miracles aid to be done by him, but hall rather joyn in Opinion with Dr. Fuller, who aith, That he who believes all which St. Augutine and his Companions are aid to have done, had need to have a hard Plate in his Front that reports it, and he a oft place in his Head which believes it: Many Miracles aid to be done by him, being rather but lightly to be touch'd, let by long handling they come to be cruh'd, and o vanih either into Smoak or Vapor. Let King Edward the Single and Famous be our Englih Hero, and the Glory of Miracles about this time of the Church, be alone had in Veneration, of whom I hall more enlarge in its proper place.

Its Antiquity proved by authority of the Ancients and Moderns.Here St. Malachias, the Bihop of Armach, of whom St. Bernard writes in his life-time, is aid to perform many Miracles, the which he acted not
according to the form and method of former times: For if we read him aright, we hall find, he neither wanted Propheie or Revelation, nor the Gift of Healing, nor changing of Minds, nor raiing the Dead. And St. Bernard doth place him before his Companions, for he is aid, in one day the Dioces of Contantinianus, to cure eleven which were Blind, and ten Lame Creatures. And if Antoninus may be believ'd, the true Witnes of thee Times, the Miracles of the Fourteenth Age of St. Bernard, and St. Katharine of Senens there Recorded, are plainly aid to be incredible: Let their Faith be according to their Authors. As to the main thereof, this I can affirm, as all the Miracles aid to be done by them may in no means be allowed fale, but omewhat of Truth may go along with them, yet what part thereof which is o, is o intermix'd with falhood, that it is no eaie matter to ditinguih between them: And as I hall not much pin my Faith upon their Miracles, o will I not detract from the Virtue of Gods Servants, or rather the Finger of God working by them.

All Ages have had their fale and educing Lights of Faith in them, by which we have een the infinite hapes of Vizards, Prodigies, and Romantick Stories mot excellently delineated; all which were deigned to cheat the foolih, and to bring the illiterate into the ready Knowledge and Worhip of unknown Gods. Hence had our manifold Idolatry its firt Birth and Beginning: hence followed the Worhipping of Idols, Invocating of dead Souls, Adoration of Statues, ending Indulgences from their dead Caves, and the like unheard of Fallacies. Hath not England its miraculous way of Healing, and in this do we meet any of thee Figments go along with it, or concern'd with any part thereof? Doth not St. Augutine himelf ay, That all Saints have not this Sanative Power given them, nor all the Gifts of Divination, more than the Gift of Propheying, and the like. St. Chriotome doth hew ome igns hereof, and anwers the Quetion when he faith, Signs are made that Men hereby might be brought to believe: and he further enquires, Why in the times
of the Apotles thee igns were made, and not in his time; he reolves this likewie, when he aith, By how much the more certain and neceary thee things are, the les Faith they do carry with them; and by how much the Argument is the more certainly demontrated, by o much the value of its Faith is detracted: therefore Signs in preence are not to be done. And this for certain we may aver, that all Miracles are not fully ceaed, as may be proved both by Ancient and Modern Authority: For Centur. 4. Lib. 2. Cap. 3. This is not to be pat with ilence, aith Magdeburgenis, that the Apotles did affirm the Gifts of external Miracles, hould reach all Ages: for without doubt, amongt the ret thee would forehew the Evangelical Doctrines being confirmed: But they do not mention this Healing Faculty amongt the ret of their Miniterial Functions: I exhort therefore, that upplications, prayers, interceions, and giving of thanks be made for all men, for Kings, and all that are in authority, &c. 1 Tim. 13. But Paul was the firt which firt taught this great Art
of Healing, as you may ee, 1 Cor. 12. which was not ditributed to all alike, for all have not this given to them. Thus much thereof from Eccleiatical Hitories: it is mot probable this till doth continue amongt us, yet it is not allowed as a Miracle, nor brought into the ame Number, nor Species, nor Dignity: It is a great Gift, and no vulgar one, not proper to all orts of Men; not to thoe of the Church, although otherwie gifted But is a Gift confirmed on Chritian Kings, whoe Patrimonial Virtue of Sanative Power doth run in the Royal Line, who do peaceably poes the ame to them and their Heirs, holding the ame of the Almighty in chief; and this may not much come beneath an External Miracle, the Church calls it. The inward being allowed the Spiritual Miracles, and thee are performed in all places, and at all times, by Adminitring of the Word, the Prayers of Holy Men, by the virtue of our Bleed Saviour, and this dipened by the Holy Spirit; amongt which are reckoned the raiing from the Dead, the keeping
up the Church againt the Devil and all his machinations, and all thoe its evil Agents, who make it their buines to create rents in the ame, and rob it of its pritine Vigor and Excellency.

div.head: CHAP. V. In this is hewn the Univerality of its Cure, without any repect either to Age, Sex, Temper, or Contitution.
div.p:
HItherto hath our Dicoure kept company with its Witnees, which hath plentifully declared its long continuance; and this atteted as well by the light of Examples, as by the fulnes of Reaons, to take off all Calumny that dare interpoe upon this Soveraign and Royal Gift. This Gift and its ue evermore keeping time together, and are neither to be dijoyned or dicluded by time or place: If therefore we would defend the Truth thereof, we ought to conider the Qualities of the Perons thus gifted, what kind of Men they are, how well Qualified, with what Holines endowed, with what Faith exercied, with what Manners intituted, with
what Religion pollihed, with what Dignity adorned, and with what excellent Virtues cherihed? all which do declare the acent of their Honor; being as o many teps to their heighth of perfection, every of which do concenter in the earch of the Caue by which they do arrive at this Sanative Faculty. Its credible alo that Ethnicks, and Antichrit, and with him Antichritians and Hereticks, and ill Chritians, omtimes have been een making Signs and Prodigious things. But uch as do the ame in the light, and in the view of the Church, mut needs be of the number of the Faithful, being in the order of pious Men, and uch as do oberve Religion in its true order and decency. And Gregory doth affirm this as a reaon of the ame, when he aith, Every fair work doth adorn the Houe of God: And then he adds, We have een Holy men doing great and wonderful Things, as cleaning the Lepers, cating out Devils, curing the Sick and Lame by the Touch, and the like. Thee omtimes being hewn and done by perons of another rank, Matth. 7. who hall in Chrits name be aid to cat out evil
Spirits, and yet keep the ame Spirit within themelves: And this Gregory jutifies when he aith, Many come, and ay they do work Miracles in Chrits Name, many in the name of Antichrit; and of thee Tribes are many fale Prophets, and many workers in the Dark, who dare not venture at the light of the Sun their miraculous proceedings.

Fallacies & cheats, impoters & witchcrafts, filling up evil Spirits to procure Cures.And as we allow all Pagans, Infidels and Atheits, to be out of the pale of our Church, o we hall find both clean and unclean Spirits in it. And whatoever this black kind of pretended Curers may do, I am ure whatoever is thus done, is compleated by the Devil their Tutor: Of this kind was the Magick of the Gentiles, writ by St. Augutine. And without all doubt, This Mater of Black Art interpoing with thee his Pupils, can work wonderful things. Suetonius is not to be contemned, who declares, That Vepaian the Emperor did retore ight to the Blind man of Alexandria, and made the Lame walk. But Cornelius Tacitus with more truth denies the Poition; for this Cure was procured
by ill method, affirming, That thoe Dieaes which are in their own Nature curable, do require and deerve les of Diabolical Art to ait them. This Evil named by Tertullian, was a Dieae wholly generated from the Evil Spirit, the which falling in one of his Eyes, and into one of his Feet, did hinder the ue of his Members; and therefore the means which hurt him, was found to be the bet Remedy to cure him.

Satan is a wonderful Artit, and a great Profeor of admirable Operations: The ame may be aid of Antichrit and his followers, all which are not to be reckoned in the ame day with the ublime gifts of good Men. Magicians and Antichritians do work much after one and the ame method, but neither of them after the good Rules of pious and good Chritians. For as St. Augustine writes, Magicians do work Miracles one way, good Men another way; ill Men only by Demoniacal Contract,If any Miracle wrought, this to be attributed to the Church. good Men by publick Jutice, evil Men under the reemblance of the ame. Ill men do work Miracles in the anctity of the Church, not in the anctity of the Peron, for confirming
and etablihing of his Faith: The which alo is imitated by the wort ort of Men, but in another form and manner. Gregory tells us, That Corporal Miracles do omtimes hew Sanctity, not make it, but Spiritual Gifts wrought in the Mind, do not hew the Virtue of Life, but do form it: But this is carce the property of any Saint. And St. Augutine doth give a very good reaon for the ame, when he aith, Thee Miracles are not given to all Holy men: Nor are the infirm to be deceived, for in thee acts are greater good things hewn, than in the works of Jutice, to which Eternal Life is compared. Peter the Apotle raied the Dead, Simon Magus did many Wonders which were beyond many Chritians power and skill to arrive at or attain. But whence had they this? Their names were writ in Heaven. In Miracles the curioity of the Eye is deired, but this is not from the Father. The true Rule therefore of Miracles is this, If God gives the power of doing good to any one, let him proecute the ame and proper in the action. Thee being given according to the will which can and will do
what he pleaeth: In former times we have hewed that this Gift was betowed on Pious and Religious Men, of which ort in thoe times were great plenty to be found. But our ucceeding Ages have much leened in the number thereof: For in our days, not only paucity of People are thus gifted, but the Gift it elf is celebrated and known of ue by its effects by very few; and thoe which are een thus to enjoy them are the Heads of the Church, and the chief Rulers of Nations and People; as Kings, Princes, and Governors.

div.head: CHAP. VI. Whether Kings and Queens of England, as Nuring Fathers and Mothers were thus particularly qualified with this Gift of Healing? and whether the French King doth cure by Stroaking the Evil, as well as our Kings of England?
div.p:
KING Ptolomy asking the Quetion of his Wife Interpreter, In what occaions a King hould chiefly exercie himelf? The Anwer was thus given: To know thoe things which formerly have been done; to read Books of thoe matters which daily do offer themelves; and to enquire after thoe things which do mot conduce to a Kingdoms Preervation: All which three do mot happily center in this Gracious and Salutiferous Operation. For here may we ee his Majety exerciing his Royal Hand by
performing what hath been done by His Royal Predeceors: At which Solemnity are read divers Prayers which call down a Bleing on his Sacred Touch; and that nothing can conduce more to a Kingdoms Preervation, than the free Gift of this benign Charity by which they are kept in Health, no man of ene can or will dipute or diprove. Our Dicoure hath hitherto atisfied us of everal Gifts given to diverity of Men, ome of which have been allowed more extraordinary than others, yet all found ueful to Mankind; and how thee have been performed, we have cleared by Hitorical Illutrations. And becaue every Age, Sex or Orders of Men have had in them omwhat more excelling Faculties than others, thee Gifts being given according to the Divine Will and Pleaure of the Almighty: Thus we ee our calling, Cor. 1.1. whereof not many wie after the fleh, not many mighty, not many nobles are called. And that this Gift is given to Kings, as Sons of the Church, and to Queens as Daughters thereof, is hewn by Iaiah, Ia. 60.16. Thou halt uck the milk of the Gentiles,
and halt uck the breats of Kings: and Ia. 49.23. Kings hall be their nuring Fathers, and Queens their nuring Mothers. Out of every part of the Earth, God will take ome of his People particularly to himelf, and will et up his Standard amongt them, by which they hall declare the Power of the Almighty, which doth betow this admirable Gift on them. And this Prophet doth extend the ame to Ilands and to Kingdoms, when he aith, Bring the Ilands unto me, and let the Nations tend from afar off: As the Poet hath it, Divios Orbe Britannos. And ince there is nothing more apparent ince the opening of the Church, than that it is adorned with many noble and excellent Ornaments, ure I am, where Kings and Queens are planted as its Heads, it mut far excel all other Churches which are detitute of their Royal Preence. That therefore which happens in the whole Figure of the Body, although it hath mot delicate Hands and Feet, and had therewith joyned the goodlines and beauty of many other parts, yet unles the Face, Eyes, Mouth, and other parts, did carry the like ymmitry and
proportion of parts therewith; thee would but deform the whole, and leen the beauty and eteem of the ret.

The ame ue may be made of the Chritian Church,Many Gifts given to Men. if ome of its Denizens be endowed with this or that extraordinary Gift, or furnihed with more Virtue or Grace, or greater Gifts from the Almighty, who hould by the ame appear as greater Lights, and more eminent amongt the maller and leer Lights thereof; unles thee Men who are thus upereminently gifted and qualified, do declare and preent the ame to view by a more trict and exact way of living, they do only make way for the leer Lights to out-hine them. This enters the Dicoure by the by, that all Men might undertand, that out of this heap of Celetial Graces, the Almighty doth betow the bet and richet Mercies and Plenty of Divine Gifts upon his Principal Men and Primary Women;Peculiar Gifts to Kings and Queens. viz. To Kings and Queens he tranmits the ame, whoe Perons are Sacred with him. Thus on Johua he betowed Fortitude and Courage; Meeknes
he gave to Moes; an Heroick Spirit to Deborah; Magnitude and magnanimity for a time to Saul; to David a heart according to his own heart; Judgment to King Solomon his Son: To the chief Elders alo he gave divers Gifts; and out of his plentiful tock of favors, he did ditribute variety of Gifts to diverity of Men.

Thus to Contantinus he gave the Gift of proclaiming the firt of the Evangelick Emperors, commanded by him to his Succeors: To Theodoius he gave power to entrench and environ Religion, as with a quick Hedge, made and confirmed by a knot of Politick Law, which had heretofore been haken with the various Storms and troubleom Tempets of Hereies. To Chritian Kings, and Princes, and Queens, he hath given this Sanative Faculty, by which both their and their Subjects Faith might the better be confirmed, and be more gloriouly commended to ucceeding Generations. But every one hath his proper Gift and Talent allowed and afforded him, and ome have more than others thereof; and ome of thee are more particularly attributed to particular Perons and
Places. Thus our Kings of England, and the French Kings, do only Cure the Struma or Evil, denyed to all other Kings, Princes, Potentates, and Emperors whatoever. Guido tells us, That the French King in his time cured this by his Touch only, ome Divine Virtue going along therewith; he lived in the time 1348. under the Bihop Clement the Sixth. But our Englih Hitories do procure a better memory he ‚Ä¢ eof, and do give it a longer Being and Continuance with us, the which both the French, Italians, and others, have already declared. And John Tagnultius writes alo in his Chirurgick Intitutions, That the mot Chritian King, endowed with this Divine Gift, doth cure many Scrophulous Tumors by his Touch only. And further he aith, That King Edward alo, as Hitories do report, did by his Touch cure the ame, ome Prayers and Hymns being ued and recited thereat: This Tagnultius was a French Man: an Italian doth alo acknowledge the ame. Laurentius alo reports, That when Francis the firt King of France was kept Prioner in Spain, notwithtanding his Exile, he
daily cured multitudes of poor people of this Dieae, according to this Epigram made of him,
Hipanos inter anat Rex Chaeradas etque.
Captivus uperis gratus, ut ante fuit.
The whole Medicinal Virtue not being affixt to his properity but to his peron, this continuing with him his whole Life.

And this we mut affirm for our Britih Glory (where every good Country-man ought to contribute towards the Reputation of his Native Soil) that by how much the Faith of Chrit was taken ooner into the World by Britains, than it was by the French; by o much in all likelyhood, this gift of Healing had its more early appearance in England than it had in France. For Britains were converted to the Faith, made good by Gelda, in the time of Joeph of Arimathea, and in the time of King Lucius, and Elutherius the Arch-Bihop, who writ in the Year 167. Ye have received of late, through Gods mercies, in the Kingdom of Britain,
the Law and the Faith of Chrit; ye have with you within your Realm, both parts of the Scriptures; and according to the Prophet which was a King: O God give Judgment unto the King, and Righteounes unto the Kings Son. And Tertullian further aith, Thoe places of the Britains to which the Romans could not approach, were ubject unto Chrit, although it is not certain who firt Preached the Gopel to them, nor whether they were Greeks or Latines. The firt of the French Kings was Clodovaeus, who lived in the Three hundredth year and upwards after Chrit, as appears by the Faith of Worthy Hitory: Its very probable, that our Kings in the earlier times of the Church, did receive thee great and wonderful Gifts from God himelf, and did exercie the ame in their Dominions: and it was then an old aying, That the Kingdom of England was the Kingdom of God.

The French KingsThe French King had this Gift after the Englih. (whoe whole Provinces were evermore ubject to the Juridiction of our Kings of England) did only borrow this Sanative and Salutiferous Faculty from the Primitive
Power of our Englih Kings, under whoe Government mot of the French Provinces were once ubjected. For it appears by uncontroulable Arguments and Evidences, that both the Crowns of England and of France have for many years been inveted with this Miraculous Gift: o that our Englih Kings are the eldet Brothers thereof, and had this in its firt poeion: For if St. Lewis King of France, of whom we have already made mention, who was contemporary with our King Henry the Third, was the firt of that Royal Race which healed the Evil; his Cradle was more than 160 years after the Coffin of our Edward the Confeor, Edward the Confeor the Curer of Strumacs. as mot Authors have very well oberved; from whom, as is aboveaid, our Kings do derive this mot Excellent and Divine Gift at this day by contant Succeion, as witnes Andrew Chane a French Author, and everal others of their own Countrymen.

The truth is, dark and obcure was the Morning of Healing, till cleared up by the bright Sunhine of Edward the Confeor; and Polydorus doth declare many admirable Virtues which
he had in him; and ome Authors do write, and amongt the ret, the Monks of his time had too heavy a hand in picing his Life with Miracles, making the relation thereof too hot for any Gut of moderate belief. There is no quetion but that there are many things recorded of this great Man which do carry abundance of truth in them; but again, many other things are reported of him, which with afety of truth are not to come within the rule of a general acceptation; and amongt the ret this may erve as one, That he was declared King by conent of his Parliament, when as yet he was in his Mothers Womb, his Father having many other Sons alive, the holy Monk Brightwold of Glaenbury deploring their los, had in Viion this Edward, then an Exile, preented unto him by the Apotle Saint Peter himelf, who then anointing him King in his ight, telling him his Reign hould be peaceable, and Twenty three years for continuance: Brightwold being yet unatisfied who hould next ucceed, demanded the Reolution, and was by Peter anwered, That the Kingdom of England was Gods own Kingdom,
for whoe Succeors himelf would provide: with uch vain Predictions our otherwie true Stories of him are overcharged, that Comineus being hereby therewith moved, eemed to tax the Englih with over-much credulity that way. As to this great Man's Birth, he was born at Ilip in Oxfordhire, and was Son of King Etheldred, Queen Emma being his Mother, who by her Maternal affection ent him into Normandy to Duke Richard her Brother, to recue him from all Dometick Quarrels; and before the dead Corps of his Father was interred, with a general conent of the Nobles, he was choen King: his Coronation was at Wincheter, the Celebration of which was performed by Edine Archbihop of Canterbury, upon Eater-day 1040. he being then towards forty years of age, and was in number the 37th Monarch of England, where he Reigned with that Jutice and Clemency, that he obtained the Venerable Name of Saint, and is ditinguihed from the other Edwards by the Title of Confeor; and that he deigned his Crown hould continue in the Englih Blood, he
ent for Edward his Nephew, the Son of Edward Ironide, who o long kept out of England, that he was called Outlaw, and him he intended Heir to the Englih Crown, had not haty Death prevented, and put a top to his Inclinations: He Reigned Twenty three years and ix months, and died the fourth of January 1066.

And now as to his excellent Deeds; He appeared in the World not like a Mortal Creature, his Miracles and Preages much keeping reemblance with thoe of the Apotles, the which here to aert, were to fill up whole Leaves with a needles urcharge, and create a upition of other great and admirable things done by him. He was famous for many peronal Miracles, the which he is aid to have entailed as an Hereditary Virtue on his Succeors the Kings of England, only with this condition, That they do upport and maintain the Chritian Faith, as to the cure of this Struma, or the Dieae commonly called The Kings-Evil; the which Dieae this King cured only by his laying his hands on the ick party; and this hath ever ince continued in the Princely
Line, where the Scepter hath been weighed by Gods Vicegerent. But as to the Origination of this Cure, there is till much controverie kept up amongt the Learned,Divers Opinions about this Gift. ome numbring the ame amongt < in non-Latin alphabet > , whoe reaon is not to be hewn; others do bring it to the power of fancy, and an exalted imagination. Thus when a poor Creature who never aw the preence of a King, hall behold his Princely and Royal Hand with a charitable confidence and touch to chae away his troubleome and loathome Swellings; to ee a Hand o humble, of an Arm o high, hew uch condecention; of a King o great to troak the Sores of o mean, and low, and depicable a Subject; to ee Him who its in his Royal Chair, vouchafe his Preence and helping Hand, where many or mot of his Subjects would both top their Notrils, and hut their Eyes at, as corning to come near them; this may well raie and enlarge the Patients fancy, ummoning his Spirits to ait Nature for the encountring this Dieae with the utmot might.

Other Learned Men, and amongt thee particularly Caper Peucerus, although acquitting this Cure from Diabolical Conjuration, yet taxes the ame as guilty of Supertition; and with him all uch others do leen the brightnes thereof, who do or dare quarrel at the Ceremonies ued at this Healing; being either dipleaed at the Collect read here, as nothing relating to this purpoe, or unreolved at the efficacy of the Gold put about the Patients neck, or ecretly unatisfied therewith: All which Exceptions mut needs fall to the ground, when it hall be avowed and made good that notwithtanding the omiion of uch Ceremonies (being nearer kin to the Solemnity than aitance to the Cure) the bare Hands of our Kings having oft effected the ame to a Miracle. Some there are again who make this a clear Miracle, with Gods own Finger put into the Healing hands; o that when the Art of Phyick is nonplut, and Chirurgery tyed up, and all other humane means baffled, that then this Dieae which was made by the hand of God, hould be thus cured by the
hand of his Vicegerent, doth not come much beneath one.

The truth is, I would willingly ee what hould give any denial to any reaonable Man hereof, ince we find every Vegetable hath its virtue and energy given to it, and allowed it: And that neither Stones, Metals, Waters, or Herbs themelves, and the like, do but hew forth and declare the honor of their Maker, by hewing us their various Virtues, and divers ditributive ues for the good of all Mankind. And why hould we Men, and Chritians, and true Denizens of the Church of England, be o narrow Soul'd as not to conceive, that Chritian Men, the mot noble of all Corporeal Creatures; and Kings, the mot of Chritians; and Kings of Great Britain, the firt-fruits of all Chritian Kings, hould not receive this Chritian peculiar Priviledge and Sanative Power; whereof daily intances do give us a greater light of the truth thereof. And here we may ee the difference between Papits and ill Protetants: the firt courting thee Miracles, even in their Embrio, and before
they come at any appearance of Birth, greedy to catch hold at the very empty hadows and reemblances thereof, whil't the ill-natur'd Protetant and Dienter are o far from giving credence to the truth thereof, which every day manifets to their eyes, that they bend that little Faith they have utterly againt it, be it brought to them by the puret Light and brightet Reaon. This Royal Gift hath been preerved in the Royal Line, and maintained by theame above 640 Years and upwards, and is een every day more and more to flourih amongt us, to the eae, comfort and relief, of many thouands of poor Souls: If therefore there be any that can pretend to have had an earlier poeion thereof than we have, they mut be of a more ancient Standing, and they mut take it (as the School hath it) from God himelf: and from the firt of Chritianity to its eldet pinning.

As to the exercie of this Gift, Eilredus Rhivalenis doth very well remember it, in the time of Edward the Confeor, as may be een in Vit. Edvard. Confeor. ex Manucript. Celeber.
Antiquar. Cambden. Wetmonat. who hath there writ of his Miracles with no paring Pen: Hence did Miracles encreae, Signs multiplyed, and more ublimely declared for the merits of Kings and Princes, the hand of the Omnipotent taking them by the hand. And amongt the ret, he writes of a young Woman newly married, who met with a double diadvantage, as having her face deformed with this Dieae, & Barrennes for ometimes depriving her of her Breeding hopes; under her Fauces was indeed a new Birth of unheard of Swellings, which made a trange and montrous hape in her Face, turning her blood into matter, by putrifying Humors lodged under its Cutis, whence oft times were Worms een to proceed, which afforded a moit, noiom and unpleaing mell; this Dieae begot ill Humors in her Husband, and her Barrennes leened his affection to her; he lived very unhappily with him, proved a trouble to her Parents, trange to her elf, and uneaie to her Friends by this amazing change of Apect, as alo by the loathome mell he ever carryed about her: Hence contempt, orrow and
pining, were the only Companions he enjoyed: Phyicians eldom being een ready of giving their time and skill where plenty does not atisfie their pains, and from thee he had but little comfort; he being thus rob'd of all hopes of Cure, and tript from every appearance of amendment: The great Phyician of the World, mot ready to hew his skill, when humanity had given over the Dieae as irrecoverable, She begs of the Almighty after this manner: Lord, Looe me from this trouble! The Woman being in a Dream, he thought that he was commanded to be brought to the Palace by a Viion which he aw, and to trut in the Kings Touch; the which if he were once touch'd by him, and wah'd, and igned, he hould receive Cure: The Woman being awakened, and preenting her elf to the King in the ight of the By-tanders, before whom he laid open her condition, he prayeth for her Health; and being overcome with Piety and Pity towards her, neither minds the Filth or the Stench, but laying his hands on her, and putting the Sign of the Cros upon her, and the like; all which being done, the Cutis
preently rent, the Worms turned out with Matter, the Swellings abated, the Pain ceaed, and he in a very hort time, to all admiration, happily cured. And that nothing may be wanting to extol this Kings Glory, This Woman is aid after this to become fruitful, and by her bearing Children to her Husband, did reconcile his love to her. This Eilredus writes in the aboveaid Book, amongt the ret of the Hitories of this great King who lived in the ame time with this Woman.

Our Gracious King doth excel his ancetors herein.Unto whom hall we mot likely reemble, or preume to compare our Dread Soveraign King Charles the Second, King of Great Britain, France, and Ireland, Defender of the Faith, &c. who its as the great Moderator of our Englih Ile: The great Parent of our Health and Safety, and the Royal Well-wiher of our Lives and Fortunes as to our Properity and plentiful Enjoyment, who hath as far excelled his Predeceors in this Sanative Faculty, as King Edward did his Ancetors; who as he was given to us for our health, and the health of our Nation, o in this Curative Faculty he outhines
all the World. And as he takes in him the Ruling Power of his People, by which he governeth by an Hereditary Right from his Royal Ancetors, o he confirms the ame to us by this Balamick and Sanative Power, derived to him from his Royal Forefathers inherent in him: By which he helps and relieves all uch Poor as do or may approach his Royal Touch.

Fortune hath her greater and maller Regalities, as we have hewn,This Gift given him at his Inauguration. conidering either its State or Republick, or the felicity of the Church therein: for what is more admirable, than to ee a Prince excelling his People in Widom, Prudence, Conduct, and the like, who is not only their Delight, but alo of him which made him; who doth not only way and rule his own Nations in Peace and Tranquility, but by his Advice and Councel doth keep and preerve all others in Amity and Concord? And what can be aid more for the Fame of a Nation, than that England hath a Soveraign, which for above thirty odd years, hath Reigned with Glory and Renown, hath Ruled it both in Peace and in War,
both by Sea and Land, in which he hath not only defended and protected his own from their Enemies, but alo kept them afe from all Foreign danger and hazard? And in this Religious Work (which hath taken up our whole Dicoure) is not o much of his Majety hewn, as of his Divinity. For this is the great gift of the Divine Majety, and is every where found worthy of a Divine Progeny, and of a Royal Unction, who by right of both, to which his Sacred Rights and Priviledges being annexed and conecrated to him, he doth in a moment end eae to the Sick, and retore health to the Dieaed. And I preume, there is no good principled Man, or any o vain and inconiderate, who having a little more ene than a Brute in him, or that only deires to live upon contradiction to all Sene, Reaon, or to any thing that is good, will ever deny the ame or appear a Dienter thereto, ince it is the Kings Right, as his peculiar Priviledge given to him: By which his Royal Scepter doth flourih in his Sacred Hand, and his Princely Peron gains more Veneration and Honor than his Predeceors.

And becaue I have been oft converant, and attending at many of thee laudible Operations, having waited on his Sacred Peron both at publick and private Healings, as one of his meanet Chirurgions, where I have een many thouands of poor Souls touch'd and cured by his Sacred Hand (and as a more particular account hath lately been given in, that he hath healed above Six thouand this very lat year) I am obliged both by Duty and Concience to give my Faith to his Royal Touch, eeing the daily and innumerable effects thereof: Many of which, as if amazed at the peedy farewel of their Dieaes, have immediatly been cured to admiration, even in the Preence, before they have got out of the Banquetting-houe at White-Hall, where his Majety doth mot uually heal; and ome, although brought in Lame and Blind, yet have within a very little and hort pace of time, recovered their Limbs and gained their Sight, as will plentifully be made good by divers Examples in our lat Chapter. And whatoever Opinion ome men may have
of our Prince and of our Religion we do profes in England, as alo of his great Piety, Charity and Clemency; yet this I will not be afraid to affirm to any Man, of what averenes oever, That when both in Town and Country, the bet Phyicians and Chirurgions have been conulted for curing the Sick troubled with this Evil Dieae, and their bet Skill and utmot Art hath been exercied, and yet proved ueles and of none effect, uch afterwards who have come and obtained his Majeties Gracious Touch, their Dieaes have been een immediatly to vanih, as being afraid of approaching his Royal Touch. If he therefore were not the right Heir to the Crown (which I hope the wort of Mankind dare not pretend to confute) and conducted thither by Divine Authority, and etablih'd in his Throne by the Almighty Power, thee wonderful effects would not o apparently be een performed by him: For this Work carries more of Divinity than Majety in it, and is wholly the Gift of Divine Majety; and when both
thee meet together, and Center in their right Lines, you will ever find a Divine Bleing interpoing.

And as a farther acknowledgment of His Majeties ucces herein, although I may, perhaps, by the bet of Authority, give as full an account of Struma's as any before me, as to a Curative Method; Yet when I conider his Majeties gracious Touch, I find my elf readily nonplut, and hall ever affirm, That all Chirurgions whatoever mut truckle to the ame, and come hort of his marvellous and miraculous method of Healing; and for further manifetation hereof, I do humbly preume to aert, That more Souls have been Healed by His Majeties Sacred Hand in one Year, than have ever been cured by all the Phyicians and Chirurgions of his three Kingdoms ever ince His happy Retauration. Whereas hould an Uurper or Tyrant urreptitiouly, by Pride and Bloody Maacre, forcibly enter his Royal Throne and touch at the ame Experiment, you'l never ee uch happy ucces; as tryed by the late Uurper Cromwell in the late Rebellious
Times, Influences flow from thence, he having no more right to the Healing Power, than he had to the Regal Juridiction: His Tryal rather chequering and darkning the bright Rays hereof and o bringing it into Obcurity, than affording it any appearance of Light. Let no Man therefore preume to lay violent hands on Gods Anointed, he having from Heaven, as a particular Mark and ignal Token, this Curative Faculty tranmitted to him, and implanted in him as a Seal of his Mercy, Clemency, Goodnes, Providence, Omnipotence, and Truth thereof. And let this Healing Virtue of our King, amongt our Englih, bear the time of a Miracle, if not allowed to keep equal pace and touch with the ame.

div.head: CHAP. VII. Part of the Manner and Form of the Healing; wherein is demontrated the Kings Excellent Piety, Humility, and Clemency in Curing Strumaes, with the Ceremonies thereto.
div.p:
WE come now to hew the Manner and Form of His Majeties Gracious Healing, wherein we hall preent the Ceremonies thereat ued; in which Dicoure, we mut acknowledge His Religion, Piety, Charity, Clemency and Humility, appearing as o many Gems belonging to His Royal Peron; into whoe Soveraign Hand, above all His People, is this mot Divine Gift etled and confirmed, the which He exercieth as frequently as He pleaeth, being either upplicated thereto by ome of
His Nobles, or of the Poor themelves who are thus afflicted, which He performs both by publick and private Healings: And as a ignal favour of Him herein, He never makes any exceptions of Perons, being either Young or Old, Rich or Poor, Beautiful or Deformed, every of which do receive a like hare of His Sacred Touch.

And that none may approach His Royal Preence but uch as are really troubled with the Evil, everal Officers are appointed for this great Ceremony; amongt the firt of which are His Majeties Chirurgeons in waiting, who are to take in Certificates, and deliver out Tickets in order to a Healing or Healings; where this following method is to be oberved.

No Patient having this Dieae hould come to the Chirurgeons for a Ticket, without he or he brings with them a Certificate, igned and ealed under the Miniters and Church-wardens Hands that they were never before Toucht by his Sacred Majety. And that no Peron whatever may loe their labour, as a very proper Experiment by way of prevention for the
future of any further Cheats by counterfeit Certificates and the like, great care would be taken of the method of Certificates, and their form: for as thee are the only proper Intruments to procure Tickets, o they hould alo come with that jut conduct which may defend the Bearer, and preerve the Kings Gold. Wherefore I preume to offer, If Printed Blank Certificates were ent to every Bihop of his Dioces, and thee igned with their own Hands and Sign Manual, and thence communicated to every Surrogate throughout his Dioces, who at their everal Meetings & Viitations hould acquaint their Brother-Miniters thereof, or ditribute of the ame to them, that uch who have the Evil may have their Names certified therein, together with the Miniters and Church-wardens Hands and Seals likewie, and the Name or Names of uch dieaed Perons entred in their Church-Regiter-Book, with the day of the month, and the date of the year when uch Certificate was delivered out. This would be an infallible Remedy againt all counterfeit Certificates whatever. And although this may at firt view
eem to carry trouble in it, yet being once put into practice, it will prove both very eaie, and of great ervice to the King and Country.

And to prevent all tireome Journeys, and tedious Travels of many indigent and ick people, who do venture to march many hundred of miles not really having this Dieae, ave only on their own uppoition; for a more ready piece of ervice to thee, to bring them to a horter paage, they hould do well to go to ome Neighbouring Phyician and Chirurgeons, and get them to earch and examine them, to know whether their Dieae be the Evil, or not: and if they find it o, to ignifie the ame under their Hands in the aforeaid Certificate; o that this Certificate may very well be allowed of double ue and advantage, as by giving eae and atisfaction to the Patient, and quiet to the Chirurgeon; the one atisfying that the Patient never before this came to crave His Majeties Touch, the other confirming the Dieae by Men of Art to the Chirurgeon in waiting.

This being cleared thus far, the Chirurgeon in Waiting hould or ought to keep a Regiter-Book, where every Parties Name is to be kept Alphabetically therein, and their Certificates fill'd up. This Book alo will hew its elf of great ervice and atisfaction to other ucceeding Chirurgeons: for as Chirurgeons are no more Immortal than other Men, o we hall find that People do not always inhabit and dwell in one place, or part of the World; and he that perhaps might have lived this year in one County, may the next year live in another; and ince where-ever he lives, if he has the Evil, and be not cured thereof, and may in one County gain a Certificate, and by that, Gold; o in another place where he goes to dwell, he may endeavour to procure another Certificate, and by this cheat the King of a econd piece; a trick not now to be learnt by many, but rather tudied by divers, who look more after the Gold than the Cure: for prevention of this, where any upected peron hall come to the Chirurgeon, for the cure of uch Cheats, he may look over the Alphabet
in his Book, and there ee if he can find the Name of him whom he may or hall upect therein. I know of no other way imaginable to prevent this Cheat; and if there were uch who can find out a better, they would do great ervice to the Nation.
Another advantage he will have hereby, when by this true account-keeping he may atisfie both His Majety and the whole World how many are yearly Healed by His Sacred Hand.

Thus far have I preumed to clear the method for poor Peoples making ready for their Journey towards their being healed: But after this, great care would be taken, (when they are arrived at their Happy Port, as I may well call it, it being the only aim they had in all their Travel) to meet with a quick dipatch, in order to their peedy return, and not to be kept o long in Town till both their Money and Credit is gone, (which God knows amongt the generality of thee ort is not much nor great) and therefore doth both require and merit a hort, ready, and peedy dipatch.
But as the cae now is, its harder to approach the Chirurgeon, than obtain a Touch; and more tireome for them to wait day after day upon him, whoe chief buines hould be to attend their coming, than it was to get every thing in readines for his dipatch of them. But there may be a convenient Remedy found out for this Evil alo, which is as bad, if not wore, than the former: Could His Majeties Pleaure be known of his times of Healings for Summer, I mean at Whitehal, Windor, and the like, publick Notice ought to be given hereof in the Gazette, by which all people may readily undertand His Majeties Pleaure of Healing, and the times thereof, after which none hould dare to preume any further trouble. This being done, as an abolute cure to delay, or any initer blind way of management, if His Majety would be graciouly pleaed to appoint ome place in Whitehal, or other place, for the performance of this Service, where a Phyitian and two Chirurgeons ought always to attend to view, examine, and dipatch the poor, dieaed, and maimed people; and there, after having His Majeties
order for a Healing, acquaint them thereof, and when they are to wait to be healed: This I am confident will be found an excellent, as well as joyful method to the poor people, and a great deal of eae as well as atisfaction to the Chirurgion, and prove a ignal remedy of leening the ill opinion the Chirurgion goes under at their continual and tedious waitings at his Houe, and abate omwhat of the hard cenure is put upon him by everal people.

In Winter alo, when his Majety touches altogether at White-Hall, the ame method hould be maintain'd, and His Majeties pleaure undertood about it, which may eaily be known by the former directions, and the Sick with abundance of eae be conducted to His Majeties preence to be Healed.

It would alo be well, that the whole World might take notice how many, and what great Cures have been performed by the King, as I have already offered, and how they have arrived at a better tate of health. And here may we very well bring in another great mitake of everal People,
who when they have received His Majeties Gracious Touch, that this therefore mut be doubled upon them, and their Gold mut as readily be changed, ele their Cure mut conequently be ineffectual, the Kings Majety not being allowed capable of curing them, without he oberves and complies with their Humors and abominable Fancies: a confidence only grounded upon uncertainty, and kept up with immutability: a Ditemper which ought to be inpected as to its cure, as much as the Evil it elf; for its conequence is dangerous and deceivable; for here we have an Anguis in herbis, which doth both readily and greedily feed upon the glittering change of Gold: and this Legerdemane trick is finely performed, by putting the Change upon his Majety, and yet this with a dihonet Man is not eaily found out or dicovered, but where Truth, Jutice, and an honet Reolution maintains the Principles, and inhabits in the Center a perfect detetation of uch things does readily appear.

I would gladly ee any Man of ene deny the eaines of the aertion, who may
