at a very little hole perceive how a Man, whoe humor does cloely alute advantage, and whoe mind does keep company with elf-preervation and interet, looking till forwards to the yellow glittering Metal, to purchae to himelf an advantageous parcel of Gold in time, by taking leave of changing an old piece of Gold for a new Ticket; or as I may ay, cheating the King of his firt Medal, by giving a new Ticket for a econd: Thee things I have heard were in ue very frequent formerly, and it were well if they be not by ome to this day yet put in practice. A Remark in this Point I hope is enough, for I dare preume to aver and offer, that there is nothing which does more impoe upon his Majeties Sacred Honor, or upon the welfare of them who come to receive the Bleing, as well as the benefit of his Healing, than the leening this Royal Virtue communicated to his Sacred Hand by the Almighty, than for uch who hould pay all Obedience and Veneration thereto, either to obtruct the ame if poibly, or abue to it by their dark initer or purblind bribery: As a Cure therefore
for this alo, if His Sacred Majety hall be graciouly pleaed to allow any poor Soul a econd Touch, let him or her, or whoever they be, bring up their own Gold to the King, and put a new Silk Ribbon into it, which if he pleaes to put over them, will be ufficient for them without any further charge of Gold.

There are another ort of People who makes it their tudy to cheat the King of his Gold, who having been Touch'd and received their Gold, are ready to ell and part with it; and were this not true, and very commonly put in practice, without all quetion His Majeties touching Medals would not be o frequently een and found in Gold-Smiths hops; and ince thee Cheats are too apparent, great care ought to be made as to their Inpection; wherefore I preume to offer, that having, as I have already mentioned, a Phyician and two Chirurgions ready to inpect and examine people, uch Cheats will not eaily be detected, for as the Proverb aith, Plus vident oculi quam oculus; and the Names of all people being et down in an Alphabetical order and method, the King cannot
o eaily be cheated, nor his Chirurgions, whoe care it hould be to prevent the ame, be either deluded or quetioned. Thus much as to the Chirurgions Office and Duty.

The next Peron which comes in order, is Clerk of the Cloet to His Majety, who is the only proper Peron for keeping of His Majeties Gold ued both at private as well as publick Healings, he being Check to the Chirurgion. The great Mater of this Office, is the Right Reverend Father in God, Nathaniel Lord Bihop of Durham, who always being in waiting, doth preent to His Majeties Sacred Hand upon his Knees, uch Gold as is delivered out to every dieaed peron: Under whom Mr. Tho: Donkelly, His Majeties Cloet-keeper, doth alo attend with Gold on his Arms ready trung, and likewie doth preent the ame to the Clerk of the Cloet; his Office being alo to take an account from the Chirurgion how many Medals hath at every Healing been dipoed of by His Majety, and to have the ame ignified under the hand of the chief Chirurgion in Writing in
his Regiter Book, which he keeps on purpoe for the ame ue, with the day of the Month and the date of the Year, and the numbers of them that have been Healed: He alo, as I am well informed, doth give a Receipt to the Exchequer for all the Gold he receives, to ballance the Privy Pure; o that from his Office a true and jut account may yearly be given in, how much Gold the King doth expend on this charitable Office, and how much is annually received for this purpoe, a draught of which ever ince his being in this place, I have with his careful aitance, given at the end of our Dicoure of the Evil.
Thus much of thee Perons and their Places.

The Tickets being delivered out, His Majety does generally appoint his day of Healing, of which the Chirurgion is to acquaint thoe who are to be Touch'd, the which for the mot part does happen on Sundays; but whether on Sundays or other Days, it matters not much, the effects of his Cure being as good at one time as at another. The Day being come, before His Majety doth approach to His
Royal Chair,The Ceremonies laudable. which is generally after Morning Prayers, the Chief Officer of the Yeomen of the Guard doth place the ick People in very convenient order for their approaching the King without trouble or noie: The which done, His Majety enters his Royal Chair uncovered, at whoe beginning there are generally two Chaplains attending: One of which reading the Ceremonies appointed for this Service, His Majety all the while being urrounded by his Nobles, and many other Spectators: The ick and dieaed People being kept back by the Chirurgions till the appointed time, where after having made three Obeiancies, they do bring them up in order. The chief in waiting delivers them one by one to the King to be Touch'd; the which done, the other takes him or her from him, and this method is ued throughout the whole number which comes to be Healed.

The whole Method is as followeth. The Chaplain thus begins: The Gopel written in the 16th Chapter of St. Mark at ver. 14. Jeus appeared unto the eleven as they at at meat, and cat in their teeth their unbelief, and hardnes of
heart, becaue they had not believed them which had een that he was rien again from the dead. And he aid unto them, Go ye into all the world, and preach the Gopel to all creatures, he that believeth and is baptized hall be aved, and he that believeth not hall be damned: all thee tokens hall follow them that believe. In my name they hall cat out devils, they hall peak with new tongues, they hall drive away erpents. And if they drink any deadly thing, Where the infirm Perons are preented to the King on their knees, the King lays his hands upon them. it hall not hurt them. They hall lay their hands on the ick, and they hall recover. The which Saying is continued between every Healing of His Sacred Majety, till all the Sick be touch'd by him; the which being finih'd, he begins this following part.

So when the Lord had poken unto them, he was received into Heaven, and is on the right hand of God. And they went forth and preached every where, the Lord working with them, and confirming the Word with miracles following. The which done, he begins the Gopel written in the firt Chapter of St. John, ver. the firt: In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with
God, and God was the Word; the ame was in the beginning with God, all things were made by it, and without it was nothing made which was made: in it was life, and the life was the light of men, and the light hined in the darknes, and the darknes comprehended it not. There was ent a man from God, whoe name was John, the ame came as a witnes, to bear witnes of the light, that all men, through him might believe. He was not that Light, but was ent to bear witnes of that Light. Here the Chirurgions come up the econd time, making their three Obeiances as formerly, where the Clerk of the Cloet on his Knees doth deliver to the King his Gold ready trung upon a white Silk Ribbond; and when thee following words come to be read, the King puts over the Gold.

p.note: Here again they are preented to the King, add the King puts the Gold about their necks.
p.hi: That Light was the true Light, which lightneth every man which cometh into the World.

div.p:
This running through the whole coure of the Ceremony, which words are continually repeated between every one which receives the Gold. This
being finihed, Thee following words are read: He was in the world, and the world was wade by him, and the world knew him not; he came amongt his own, and his own received him not; but as many as received him, to them he gave power to be made ons of God: even them that believed on his name, which were born not of blood, nor of the will of the fleh, nor yet of the will of man, but of God. And the ame Word became fleh, and dwelt amongt us, and we aw the glory of it, as the glory of the only begotten Son of the Father, full of Grace and Truth.
This being finihed, the Chaplains, with the ret of the People on their knees, do pronounce thee Prayers.

q.p: Ver. Lord have mercy upon us.
Rep. Lord have mercy upon us.
Ver. Chrit have mercy upon us.
Rep. Chrit have mercy upon us.
Ver. Lord have mercy upon us.
Rep. Lord have mercy upon us.

div.p: Then the Chaplains read the Common Prayer; viz.

p.q: Our Father which art in Heaven, hallowed be thy Name. Thy Kingdom come. Thy will be done in Earth as it is in Heaven. Give us this day our daily Bread. And forgive us our trepaes as we forgive them that trepas againt us. And lead us not into temptation. But deliver us from evil. Amen.

q.p: Thee Anwers thereto be made by them that come to be healed. Ver. O Lord ave thy ervants.
Rep. Which put their trut in thee.
Ver. Send help unto them from above.
Rep. And evermore mightily defend them.
Ver. Help us, O God our Saviour.
Rep. And for the glory of thy Name deliver us, be merciful to us inners for thy Names ake.
Ver. O Lord, hear our Prayers.
Rep. And let our cry come unto thee.

p.note: Then the Chaplain reads this Prayer following.
p.q:
O Almighty God, who art the Giver of all health, and the aid of them that eek to thee for uccor. We call upon thee for thy help and goodnes, mercifully to be hewed to thee thy ervants, that they being healed of their infirmities, may give thanks to thee in thy Holy
Church. Through Jeus Chrit our Lord. Amen.
The Grace of our Lord Jeus Chrit, Here he concludes. and the Love of God, and the Fellowhip of the Holy Ghot, be with us all evermore. Amen.

div.head: CHAP. VIII. This hews the Certainty of its Events, and the Admirable Effects of its Cure.
div.p:
THe truth is, this great Gift of Healing doth call the Chritians Faith, and alo Humane Reaon into conent therewith; for without thee do march together, the Events will not anwer expectation. And in truth would be againt God himelf as well as His Sacred Majety, to wih for Health, and not preerve the memory of thoe great Cures done by Him; to read their Names thus cured, and commended to Poterity, if Faith did not march along with it: For what is wore than to bury the knowledge of the remembrance of Favours done? the only black mark of Ingratitude, and nothing more kind than to allow the
memorable Cures done: For what is Piety but a willing conent thereto in its Parents? and what more kind than to allow the ame to the Father of our Nation? Our Faith doth therefore command our keeping in memory the Health we receive from our Gracious Soveraign, and to regiter the ame in our belief; ince we find thee Dieaes do no more pare the proud Citizen, than the depicable Country-man, and that both thee have found benefit by His Majeties Gracious Hand, is as clear as the Sun that hines: Hath not the French,The admirable Effects of His Majeties Healing to all Perons of the World. Dutch, Scotch, Irih, Welh, and Englih, been all happy partakers of the benefit of His Majeties Gracious Touch? Hath there been carce any City, Town or Country which cannot peak well of His Curative Faculty? Has there or is there carce a Street in this Populous City, that hath not found the benefit of His Sacred Hand? And yet as if this Dieae did get a new Birth by Converation, it meets the King where-ever He goes, with as much vigour and plenty as if the work were now to begin. And as a very trange remark hereof, although I do
believe near half the Nation hath been Toucht and Healed by His Sacred Majety ince His Happy Retauration; yet upon any new appearance of a freh Healing, they are een to come in afreh, and as fat as if not one had yet been Toucht by Him: A thing as trange as montrous!

To my own knowledge I have known many perfectly cured the firt time,Some cured the firt time. Others not cured till the econd Touch. Some elling their Gold, their Dieae hath eized them afreh. they having been Touched by His Sacred Majety. Others again having been een healed upon His econd Touch, which could not receive the ame benefit the firt time. Some again having received His Majeties gracious Touch, and loing their Gold, their Ditemper has De Novo eized them again; and thee alo upon gaining a econd Touch, and new Gold, their Dieaes have been een utterly to have been chaed away, and they themelves perfectly cured.

Now as to particular times and eaons of Healings, as Good-Friday, and the like,As to the Healing on Good-Friday. which do carry a trong Faith with ome people, who unles they can be Toucht by the King that time, their belief is o weak and tender, that they do preume and uppoe any
other time in the year is not o fitting, or do or can carry the ame efficacy. But to thee delicate ort of people,The reaon of ome not being cured. who I am ubject to believe are as wavering in their Faith as they are in their Opinions; and unles the Almighty will pleae o far to condecend as in every degree to anwer their Humours, by working more than an ordinary Miracle in them, they may with abundance of eae be brought to think that there is little or no effect of cure in the whole. A in I am ure it is to tie the Almighty to particular times and eaons, and therefore not to be accounted (amongt Men of ene) to have more efficacy than at other times.

And to put top to another old received Opinion of the Gold;The putting over the Gold only a token of Charity. which is, If the King doth not find, and give the Gold, as well as put the ame over their Necks, this will not anwer expectation, ome of thee ort putting a higher eteem upon the Gold, than upon the Hand that put it about their Necks. But all uch may know that this Gold thus ued and imployed, is no more than a reemblance of Health, for the Cure has oft been een done
without any Gold at all given, ometimes the ame has been performed only by Silver, as hall be made good by everal Examples in the lat Chapter.

Another ort of people alo there are,About changing the Gold. who if they can procure the favour from the Chirurgeon to procure them a econd Touch, they mut likewie have their Gold alo changed, (ome effect of which I have already toucht at) as if the later Gold had any more effect in it than the former, they both coming from one and the ame Royal Hand; an unneceary trouble, as little efficacious, and perhaps more deceitful. And that Gold is not the great Ingredient in this Cure, may eaily be thus proved, by calling into remembrance the Rebellious Times, when Tyrants turned this once happy Nation into an Anarchy of Confuion, and by their unlawful upet High Court of Jutice, or rather Injutice, forced the bet of Kings, where He was wont to hew the Grandure of His Majety due to Princes, there to make His Funeral Pulpit, laying down the Sacred Trophies of His Greatnes, whereon the
Enigns of Renown had formerly been planted, by their cured Hands, and compell'd to quit His three Nations by their mot cured and barbarous Cruciations; and yet all this done under pretence of Devotion and Sanctity, bringing Him under their Tyrannical Judgment, to ubmit to their bold and bloody Aaination; in whoe horrid Maacre, and after whoe inhumane and barbarous Decollation, its pretious Blood left not its vigour which it kept whilt it was warm in His Purple Veins, being either taken up by Handkerchiefs, or collected by other things, with which thee Strumous Swellings being but touched, or therewith concerned, they have een uddainly to vanih and diappear: and this alo hall be made good by ome Obervations thereof in my lat Chapter. And if His Royal Corps, tript from Life, was thus accompanied with this Divine and Heavenly Virtue, what hall we think and ay of the Action performed by the Life, as by the Blet and Sacred Hands of our Dread Soveraign? Beides, if the Virtue did wholly lodge in the Gold, I would
have uch as give this great Reputation to the ame, to make tryal of a piece of their own Gold, in putting the ame about their own Necks, and ee then if this will in any meaure anwer their deired ends: The ucces I leave to them who hall hew their folly as well as give themelves trouble to make uch a tryal thereof.

Thee two may be very well granted convincing Arguments enough to prove the truth hereof: for this of His Majeties pretious Blood was een done, and known to be performed in the midt of the Kings Enemies, and in thoe times when Trayterous Uurpers took leave to enter the Royal Throne; where not only the troubleome Mobile, but the rigid Maters of Presbytery and Independency, were o far from agreeing and conenting to His Majeties Healing Faculty, that the little Faith they had, they employed to confound the ame: uch were the great Reverence thee Rebellious Tribes gave to this Divine Virtue. And in this I may preume poitively to affirm, that uch as do not give Credance to the
King as Gods Vicegerent, and to the many thouands cured thus by Him, they do, ever did, and ever hall be thought to give as little belief to God Himelf, let His Miracles be never o many, or never o great, uch being their churlih Humour, and ill compoed Dipoitions.

To the believing Man, I hall produce Saint Chryotom's words, < in non-Latin alphabet > , That according to their proportion of Faith they do, may, and hall be great Sharers in this Sanative Faculty. And as a farther Confirmation of the ame, he aith, < in non-Latin alphabet > that is, Tantum influit quantum invenerit Oblatum ibi fidei vaculum.

Thus every unbelieving Man may ret atisfied, that without he brings Faith enough with him, and in him, that His Majety hath Virtue enough in His Touch to Heal him, his expectation will not be anwered: whereas the Man of Faith, who confides on the ame, will as readily find the benefit of the ame. And although this method doth not always anwer expectation,
yet its Effects are wonderful, and its Cure mot frequent, as is and hath been ufficiently and atisfactorily made good. And this may appear as a Vindication of the Certainty of its Events, as alo of the Admirability of the Effects of His Majeties Sanative Power.

div.head: CHAP. IX. Several Doubts reolved about this Curative Method, made by Atheits, Sadducees, and ill conditioned Phariees.
div.p:
SInce there is nothing o excellent in its nature, or opinion of Men, or blet by good Men, and held in admiration by the Religious Men, but may be blated by the envious breath of the wicked and ill natur'd Man, and o made either the ubject of their corn, or yield a ower tate of their malevolent Humor: I hall in this Chapter endeavor to allay their fury, and omwhat blunt and abate the edge of their calumny which they have evermore been ready to put upon this Sanative Faculty. And in undertaking hereof, I hope I have made ome on-et already: but let this hould not be prevalent enough to conquer their incredulity,
I hall offer this as a farther Anwer: Whereas there are ome who do wholly deny the ubtance of the Action, and preume to call the thing in quetion;Various Opinions as to this Cure, and others, who do not o much blame the thing it elf, as the ubtance thereof and its Ceremonies, bringing hereby the whole Operation under Supertition, whil't others by pleen, didain, ridicule, and private injury, will needs put a blind upon this mot excellent Operation, altho confirmed to them by Ocular Demontration as clear as the Sun; and are not to be brought to the belief thereof, although they ee it done before their eyes, no ways allowing a Divine Power going along therewith, it being performed by Man. To what an Age of Incredulity are we arrived at, where reolution, pleen, and injury, hall confirm a Mans oppoition to the very light of Reaon and Truth it elf? where we hall have Men bid defiance to His Majeties humility which he hews in this Operation; to his Piety and pious bounty which he liberally betows on his Dieaed Subjects, and to the Cures thus daily performed by his Sacred Hand, who
do daily tudy to ore-thwart, dipute, contradict, and peak ill of this Divine and mot Excellent Qualifications, rather than give Faith, Reverence, or a jut Acknowledgment thereto. And as a cloe to their black lips, I will preume to offer, That when the mot Learned have worthily, and with all reverence writ hereof, and have neither been ahamed nor afraid to proclaim to all the world the many miraculous Cures which have been thus performed by His Sacred Majeties Hand, and for many hundred of Years kept up by the Princely Line, their Incerdulity may well be called into quetion, not having validity enough in it to ballance thoe weighty and great Opinions which ever have, and till do maintain the ame: And where I have as a guard to my Opinion, the bet of Antiquity oppoing the greatet Scruples that can be made as to this matter, eeing ome o extraordinary hot for leening wholly any Virtue in the Gold or Silver, or the like, which hall be put about the Patients necks, and abominate the ue thereof with all their hearts, in any other but in
their own poeion: Where this yet hath been ued by the Kings Sacred Hand, we have found it of admirable ue and advantage.

Others as readily do cry out againt the Ceremonies,The ue of the ceremonies. being as little pleaed therewith as the former, when they hall pleae to vouchafe, allowing them of ome ue in diplaying a good and Religious Mans life, and yet are not willing to grant this of any efficacy in this Healing Faculty; whereas they may, or ought to know, that the Word of God is as great an Alexipharmick herein, in working this Curative Effect: The aying therefore of a certain Form of Word- at this Healing, is not to be condemned, unles we will blame the word of Faith by our Impiety: For Faith comes by hearing, and hearing by the Word of God, as Rom. 10. ver. 6. But the Righteounes which is of Faith peaketh in this wie: Faith cometh by hearing, and hearing by the word of God. Thus therefore the legitimate ue of the Divine Word, is to be joyn'd with a right Faith. But becaue I am ure I hall meet ome even oppoing the
thing it elf, knowing there be too many who cannot in their natures either peak well of any body, or of any thing, unles brought to their tet and approbation, and o depie all Virtues; peaking evil of Angels, Saints, and the Almighty himelf; laughing at his bleed People, evil treating his Anointed and their Dread Soveraign; mocking the Holy Spirit, and affronting his Gifts, Miracles, Scriptures, Sacraments, and all other Eccleiatical Ceremonies and Rights, which do not keep equal pace with their humor and fancy: A ort of which we read of in Phil. 3. cap. 18. who are there called, The enemies of the Cros of Chrit, whoe end is detruction, whoe God is their belly, and whoe glory their hame, who mind earthly things: Should we to thee bring the brightet Truth, fetch'd even from Heaven it elf; they are o naturally enclined to contradiction, that they will believe them to be in the dark: That you may with more eae bring an Atheit to believe there is a God, than thee to give Faith to the excellent works which are daily done by our
Saered Majety at this day by his Sacred Touch.

There are another ort of Creatures, who are inward enemies to this Sanative Gift, evermore doubting of its clearnes; and thee do hug themelves in oppoing and contradicting all uch as hall peak well thereof. Of which ort may Caper Peucerus be well reckoned one, of whom we have already given you an account, both as to his Religion, and unhappy Opinion. And I believe we have too many more of his Opinion at this day, who hould they ee our Soveraign heal, and exercie the ame Gift daily, yet this their cured Opinion and Humor ticks o cloe to them, that they will carce give it leave to breath, or gain any reputation amongt them: And although it may get footing into a more favorable Opinion amongt ome of them, that all this is done without any Inchantment, or ill and black methods ued, yet they do receive it with that tendernes, that it mut gain upon them by degrees, and takes ometime before
they can work them into any belief thereof. And ince it doth require no eaie task either to pleae or confute thee Adveraries as to the Fact it elf, who cannot aent to the manner of performing thereof, although having les reaon to dient from the ame: Thee following Reaons, I hope, may in ome meaure make the task neither o uneaie as may be expected. Thus therefore this Healing Faculty is not produced, ex emine, by an Ingenite Faculty which may be produced with the nature thereof, as many Phyical Virtues are thence derived, and by imilitude of Bodies and Manners taking their firt Idaea's thence, as one Body being productive out of another, but no Soul thus produced out of another, every Man generating his like in Specie, not in dividual Quality. Such therefore who would thus pres down with oppoition this Healing Faculty, have les need to doubt of that which the Learned hath o highly writ thereof, and maintained as in the Inaugurated Rights of the Kings of England and of France. Since God himelf is he that createth Kings, and Anoints their
Royal Hands with the Sacred Oyl, as with a Royal Balamick Virtue, by which doth arie other Gifts of Fortitude, Councel, Prudence, and Governance like Chritian Kings, as well as in this of Healing. Peucerus unkindly calls this, The admirable patimes of Events, at which I wonder more, than at his other odd Perwaion, whereas there is uch a ditance between them of Miracles, and the Divine Gifts of Healing (not only atteted by us, but by all our Neighboring Nations) that our Englih have that perfect abhorrence thereto, that we are as much purged and cleaned from the ame, as the Houe of God with Hezechia and Joias was purified from all its corruptions. But what need I bring Examples to confute this ridiculous Opinion of his, ince we find that he himelf doth fall to the ground, and acts in the dark? Let us therefore recede from this one extream, to prevent our falling into another, by keeping the middle way. Peucerus only fell from Augerius, even as the Meteologer doth from the Philoopher, and both from true Theology. Augerius Ferrerius de Gordonis
aith, That he and other Phyicians being much addicted to the Supertition of Charms, which were prevalent againt Bleeding, and other Chonical Ditempers, having in them the Faculty of curing intermitting Fevers, and many other Dieaes of that ort, thus proceeds therein. The event of which Cure is not to be taken from the Characters, nor from the Chatm only, but this working uch power in our minds, that we therewith complying, this gets fancy alo to joyn therewith, by which it gains ground of the Ditemper and overcomes it. Thus one Man acting by the power of Perwaion, he gains on the Man on which he thus acts, with which he does powerfully proceed in the ame; he joyning therewith, and giving a coadjutant Faith to the Operation thus performed, the intended deign does take a peedy effect; and thus working by Characters or Enchantment, or the like, for curing of Agues, and the Patients therewith o troubled, they believing they hall hereby be cured, the Dieae hath uddenly been een to vanih, and they acquitted from their Ditemper to
admiration. Confidence and Perwaion being two great Aitants in this Curative Method, epecially amongt the illiterate and unlearned, where Opinion having once got poeion amongt uch as to their Charms and Characters, there's no farther need of outward Applications, thee in themelves leaving atisfactory Arguments amongt thee ort of People to work their effects. But leaving thee dark and black methods thus generally ued amongt the ignorant, and les knowing: With his favor, known Miracles may be brought to light by the trength of the mind.

And let I may eem tedious in making good my reaon for the ame, as to this Healing Faculty: This is not a gift of Nature, but of Grace, neither does it live in Man but in his Maker; not in human confidence as thee Charms and Characters, but in the power of Faith derivative from the Almighty. Moreover, our Gracious Soveraign doth acquit all idle pretences whatoever hereto, by neither quetioning their Faith who come to be healed, nor asks their Belief about the ame; he only prays for them,
blees them with his Sacred Touch, gives them his Gold, and thus doth impart health unto them; from which clear conequence, uch as the Faith of them is who thus are touched by him, his Curative Effects does mot clearly evince and demontrate. Genebrard of Paris is very nice in allowing this Gift of Healing to the Kings of England, when he ays, Some of them have exercied this Healing Virtue: But he would have been much kinder, and a better Mater of Generoity, would he have been pleaed to hew the difference between thoe which had this, and thoe which wanted the ame. But I need not to travel far for an anwer ready minted for him, which partly falls in one of his own Country-men, which hapned about the midt of Queen Elizabeths Reign, after Pope Pius had let flown his Excommunication againt her: There was a tiff Roman Catholick (as they do delight to call themelves) who being cat into Prion,See Tooker and in a high meaure viited with the Kings Evil, and having with pain and expence long ued the advice of Phyicians without any ucces, at length
humbly addreed himelf to the Queens Majety, through whom, by Gods aitance, he was compleatly cured; and being demanded what news, I perceive, aith he, now at lat by plain experience, that the Excommunication denounced by the Pope againt Her Majety, is of none effect, eeing God hath bleed her with o great and miraculous a virtue, as Dr. Tooker hath it in Charimate, cap. 6. pag. 92. And as a econd atisfaction to this French-man, he tells us another Hitory of a Maid, when the Queen being in Glocesterhire, and many poor People afflicted with this Dieae, who in uncivil Crowds did o pres upon her Majety, that he let fall thee words, Alas poor People, I cannot, I cannot cure you, it is God alone who can do it. The which words ome ill affected perons did interpret, as her utter renouncing of this Divine Gift: whereas he only removed her Subjects Eyes from her elf, to deire their looking up to Heaven. Before he left the place, he was pleaed to admit a general Healing; amongt which, the afore-mentioned Maid being Touch'd by Her Sacred Hand,
went away immediatly recovered and healed from her Dieae. And whereas there is no need of Miracles, when the Truth of the Scriptures do hew the Dogmata Fidei, our Chritian Faith not being founded on demolihing of Churches, or dead Martyrs, nor in Murdering of Men, thee being accounted by us as no Faith, and if any to be allowed, but as an impious Faith: But by ours we do give honor to the memory of Martyrs who dyed for the ame; we do not worhip their Pictures with St. Augutine, but can look upon them with repect; we do not damn the Faith of Signs, for Signs do not much conduce to the confirmation of Errors, but rather to the glory of God and his worhip.

This Divine Function is performed without any educing Method: The King gives freely, not calling the Angels to witnes, nor inking o low as others do, to perform the ame by Black Art or Inchantment; he does it with a pure Heart, in the preence of the Almighty who knows all things, without Supertition, curing all that approach his Royal Touch. And this
I may frankly preume to aver, never any of his Predeceors have ever exercied it more, or more willingly and freely, whoe wonderful Effects and certainty of Cures, we mut and hall acknowledge as long as we can peak, and tell our Children thereof, that they may relate what wonders have been performed by his Sacred Hand to their ucceeding Generations.

div.head: CHAP. X. Several Examples of Miraculous Cures performed by His Majeties Sacred Touch.
div.p:
ANd that no Man may ay the Nut will not be worth cracking when he finds good Meat therein; as our Dicoure hath hitherto given you a tate of the truth of this Healing Faculty, o this comes like a happy Commander, bringing up the Reer; wherein hall be hewn part of thoe Gleanings which I have gathered up from the large and fertile Crop of Strumous Perons, and thee cured by the Majetick Power of the Kings Sacred Hands. And ince it cannot reaonably be expected that I hould gradually proceed from Edward the Confeor, even to the time of our Dread Soveraign, which would perhaps be a Task more troubleome than
deirous, o I am ure of greater bulk than I deigned or intended. And that I may not live altogether upon the uffering point, I would gladly know of any contrary Humour, which of our Kings of England did ever go without it, that lawfully arrived at the Crown? my preent Dicoure not reaching any Uurper, or Tyrannical Governour. But paing thee by, as we begin from Edward the Confeor, we ought to bear Record of ome of his Miraculous Methods aid to be done by him: And here, as ome ort of Men were not wanting to give too high a Character of his Deeds, o the meanet Act which was performed by him, was not let fall without an honourable Reverence. Amongt ome of which we read of a poor Man who chanced to come to him,Hitory. one who might have tockt an Hopital with Maladies, whoe ight made all Bytanders commierate his condition; the Sick Man had a trong Fancy and a bold Face, who deired the King himelf to carry him on his back to the Church, on aurance (as he aid) that he thereby hould be recovered. The good King grants his deire, and
this Royal Porter bears him into the Church, where o trange an alteration is aid to happen, that although he was carried in on all four, he departed thence treight, and upon two; and it is aid the Church into which he was thus carried was St. Peters in Wetminter, built by him on this occaion. Next to St. Peter he is aid to be much in favour with St. John the Apotle, who is reported to have appeared unto him in the hape of a begging Pilgrim; the King not having preent Money to upply his wants, did pluck off his Ring from his Finger, and betowed it upon him, by virtue of which Ring given he is aid to perform many and great Miracles. The ame Ring ome years after is aid to be ent him back again by two Pilgrims out of Paletine; and if any do doubt of the truth hereof, they are deired to repair to Havering, a Town in Eex, o called as they ay from this Ring, where, by the Inhabitants, atisfaction will be given.

This great and mot Pious Prince being dead, Harold the Son of Earl Goodwin next ucceeded him, who
aumed the Throne, and was Crowned King by Aldred, Archbihop of York, next to whom was William the Conquerour, from whom began the Computation of our Kings of England. I might after him name his Son William the Second, and o proceed to Henry the Firt, King Stephen, Henry the Second, Richard, John, the Edwards, and others, o to the time of Queen Mary and Queen Elizabeth; but ince I can find by no Authority that this Sanative Faculty have been ever wanting, or removed from the Princely Line, I hall preume to take leave, and begin with Queen Elizabeth, where amongt many other Cures done by her Sacred Hand, take thee following as they appear, the firt two whereof I have already decribed in the foregoing Chapter of the French-man, and the other of Gloceter, the which I do here forbear to mention to prevent Tautology.

Dr. Tooker alo tells us of one John Capel of Exon, the Son of an honet Citizen, and a Daughter of the ame Peron, both troubled with the Evil, and both quitted from their Ditempers by her Majeties gracious Touch.

Another of his is of a Maid, who was of the ancient Family of the Turbervils, who was for ten years troubled with this Evil Dieae, he being Toucht for the ame, alo recovered: he afterwards beholding her Gold gone from her Neck, demanded of her the reaon thereof? he tells him her neceity compell'd her to ell it, and yet he remained well, whence He, as other wie Men, have conjectured that the Gold given is only as the Kings Charitable Token, and no more, for he lived many years after very well, without any relape. Yet this does not always o ucceed, for I have een many upon the los of their Gold, their Evil has come afreh, and proved troubleome, as hall be made good by many Examples following. Many thouands are reported to have been cured of this Dieae in her happy Reign; King James ucceeded her, and continued the ame Sanative Power in his Life-time. After whom was Charles the Firt of ever bleed Memory, who performed thee Cures in a very trange and miraculous manner, with and without Gold, by his Prayer and Benediction only, by his
Sacred Touch, as alo by his Sacred and precious Blood. Of each of which in their Order, where for remark, bleing and cure, none ever of his Predeceors were able to be named in the hour with him. I begin with that wonderful and miraculous Cure done by him at Wincheter, only by his Prayer, related to our Dread Soveraign, and his Brother his Royal Highnes James Duke of York at Wincheter-Colledge, by Doctor John Nicholas, Warden of the Colledge this lat Summer, where I had the Honour not only to hear it, but afterwards aw the Bottle. This following Hitory I had from the aforeaid Doctor under his own Hand, ent me in a Letter from my very good Friend Mr. Shadrack Lyne, Apothecary of the ame place, and is as followeth.

p.q:
SInce my return from thoe Journies, which of late I have undertaken on my Colledge Affairs, Mr. Lyne hath minded me to end you a Relation of that mot eminent Cure of the Kings Evil in this City, by the Prayers of King Charles the Firt. The Peron that labored under that Infirmity, was Robert Cole, well known in Winton, being a publick Inn-keeper, firt of the Three Crowns, next of the Katherine Wheel, both Houes near the Colledge of that place: 'Twas evident to all perons that he was highly Dieaed, and great Scars remained as evidences of it after the Cure: His Throat was the place of his Soars, where there were great Wounds, and the encreae of them gave the Man daily and jut fears, that the paages for his Breath could not long continue whole and ueful, he ought for relief by a Medicinal Water, which he received from an Apothecary of Sarum (I think he told me his name was Handcock)
but as he, when alive, aured me, although the wahing with that Water did keep the Wounds clean, yet it did not top the increae nor the pains: He then in dipair of all other help but from His Majeties Touch, endeavored to procure that means of Gods mercy. But it being in the time when that Sacred Peron was removed from the Ile of Wight, and brought through Winton (where this object of Charity dwelt) in order to the lat of his Sufferings. There were Soldiers, Guards and Spies, ufficient for to prevent uch a gracious Act, and thoe had malice enough to have hindred that Martyrs doing good if they could. The poor ditreed Man, on bended knees, at that time in the preence made everal Exclamations, and preed nearer to the King that he might procure notice from him, praying till loudly, God ave the King: which provok'd thoe inhumane Attendants, to deal with the Petitioner as they did with their Soveraign, barbarouly: They trook him, removed him, and allowed him no opportunity to come within the good
Kings reach: The only effect was, that the importunate cries of him which was impatient to be denyed the lat hopes of eae and life, made the good Prince oberve him; and ince he could not be hindred from reaching him with his Prayers, he gave the weak and now dipairing Man his Bleing, in the like words to thee: Friend, I ee thou art not permitted to come near me, and I cannot tell what thou wouldet have, but God bles thee, and grant thy deire; after which, the dieaed Man without the Kings troaking, was forced to return to the Liquor that he had formerly waht his Soars with: But although the Bottle that he kept it in had been ecured in a Cup-board, and is to this day without any crack in it, yet the Water was much wated: The next day he found a greater decreae in the Liquor, and o daily until it was dryed up. At length, the Bottle became cabbed in its ides, and many Botches appeared in it, the glazing of the Bottle breaking off through the round bubbles or botches that aroe in the Earth: And
as thee effects appeared in the Earthen Veel, the Face and Throat of the Patient healed with equal peed. I my elf knew the Man o whole, that the Scars were the greatet tetimony that he ever uffered by that Dieae. He was ever after freed from any running iue, or pain, unles at one time, when (as he told me) a Gentlewoman that aw the Bottle, attempted to pick off ome of thoe Excrecences that budded out of its ides: After this, the places that had been affected in his Throat gave him new trouble and grief, but nothing was vented there, which being over, he lived above twenty years in eae, and in that Sicknes of which he died, the Kings Evil had no hare.

This practice of the Gentlewoman, and the fear of thoe times, made this R. Cole conceal the Bottle as much as he might do, let it hould be injured after he found his Face had a ympathy with it, or let the Powers then domineering hould demand it from him, he preerved it in a Woollen Bag, and although it might have been of great advantage
to his Profeion to have expoed it to his Cutomers, yet he regarded his Safety more than his Profit, and concealed it with all the Art he could; o that it was not een but when an intimate Acquaintance extorted that repect from him, with good aurance that it hould not be roughly handled; he being dead, the Bottle is until this day in the Hands of his Widow here in Winton, where there are many other Witnees of this which you receive now from

closer.signed: Your very faithful Servant, JO. NICHOLAS.

div.p: At the ame time I had this following at the Colledge of Winton, given me by a Peron of Quality: Of two men, both Father and Son, either of them being troubled with the Evil: The Father was touch'd by the late King and received Gold; the Son never was touch'd, neither did he ever receive any. The effect hereof was as followeth: The Father being ditempered and ill, keeps the Gold about his own neck, which kept him in health, and gave him peedy eae and relief: The Son falling ill, he borrows his Fathers Gold from his neck, and puts it about his own, which likewie gave him eae and relief. The Father after this by leaving his Gold, had his Ditemper eized him afreh, and then took the Gold again, and this made it as readily vanih. And thus by the intercoure or change of Gold from Father to Son, and from Son to Father, whoever of them kept the Gold, was defended againt any new approach or appearance of his Ditemper; and this was kept and maintained by them for many years together.

Another, not much unlike this, I had from John Hebden Eq whoe Mother being healed by King Charles the Firt, of bleed memory, did in a very hort time recover, and was healed of her Dieae. She after this going over into Ruia, where he afterwards dwelt, met there with one Mr. Heath, a Ruia Merchant, who was likewie o extraordinarily troubled with the Evil, that he was aid to be near eaten up with the ame: And although he made all the means he poibly could to get over to England, to come to be touch'd by His late Sacred Majety for the ame, yet the illnes of the Weather, and the badnes of the Seaon prevented his deigns. The great thing here remarkable is this, Madam Hebden lending this Merchant her Gold which he received from the King, and he for ome time wearing the ame about his neck, within a very mall time after the ue thereof, he found benefit, and upon his continuance of the ame in ue, he very peedily amended, and became o well, that he had no farther need of His Majeties Touch. The Lady her elf is now alive, and ready
to attet the truth hereof, as I had it from her Sons own hand.

Mr. Foter, now an Inhabitant in Windor, when he was about ix years of Age, and perfectly blind for about two years, o that he could neither ee Sun, Moon, Fire or Candle, who being perplexed alo with many Scrophulous or Evil Swellings about his Throat, and many others eizing his Face, Arm, Hands and Fingers; and after having pent much mony with Phyicians and Chirurgions, to little purpoe, was after all this brought to his late Sacred Majety to be Healed, by the benefit whereof, within fourteen days, he preently recovered his ight; and his Swellings which did frequently run into Suppuration and healed in everal parts of his Body, were as peedily dryed up, and he hath ever ince remained ound without any appearance of relape. This I had from himelf this lat Summer at Windor, who I am certain will be ever ready to maintain the Truth thereof to his dying minute.

There was a Woman Quaker which lived at Guilford in Surry, who being o perfectly blind, that he was rob'd of all light and ight: She coming to Hampton-Court, where our late King was then a Prioner, to be touch'd by His Sacred Majety; o oon as he received the ame, or within les than an hour after the reception thereof, he went down to the Kings kitchin, and did there tell the number of Spits which were turning upon the Range, and did there fall down upon her knees, praying to God to forgive her for thoe evil thoughts he formerly had of her good King, by whom he had receiv'd this great Bleing. Mr. John Stephens of the Kings Backtairs, was an eye-witnes of every part hereof, he being then at the Operation, and afterwards eeing her in the Kitchin: At this time the King did only put over her Neck a Silver Two pence, trung in a white Silk Ribband; and this may prove, that other Metal ued and imployed by the Sacred Hand, does the ame as Gold. All People which did here come to be touch'd had only Silver given to them, and yet mot of them
known to be cured; and uch as fail'd thereof, hapned chiefly from their unbelief and incredulity. Mr. Henry Ewer, four years of age, was brought by the former Mr. Stephens to be touch'd by His late Sacred Majety at Hampton-Court at the ame time; his Eyes being o ore and ill-affected, that he could not look upon any Fire, or behold the light of the Sun or Moon, they were o weak and troubleom to him: within a Month or ix Weeks after his being healed by the King, he was een perfectly dicharged from his pain, and recovered to admiration, and lived many years free from all trouble: Both thee Mr. Stephens is ready to maintain, if at any time he may be quetioned about the ame.

Mr. Halford, one of His Majeties Heralds, tells me this following of one Helena Payne of Windor, who having the Evil in that meaure as it made her Blind; this bred from a great Rhume and defluxion of her Eyes, with which he was perplexed for everal years together. King Charles the Firt being then a Prioner in Windor, and commanded thence by
the Regicides to London; this poor Woman pres'd to be touch'd by His Sacred Majety as he was paing over the Bridge, and preumed to take hold of his Coat, humbly upplicating His Majeties Sacred touch: The good King tells her he had no Gold; he till begs for Chrit Jeus ake, that he would grant her His gracious Touch; the which he having received, within three days after he grew well and recovered, and did after that retain her Sight to her dying day.

Another old Man came to my Lodgings at Windor this lat Summer, who told me, That he having been Lame for everal Years together, o that he could neither go or tand; he being brought to our late King, of Bleed Memory, to be touch'd at Windor, he thereupon oon amended, and recovered his trength to that capacity as I then aw him in, and hath had the ue of his Limbs ever ince to admiration.

Mr. Pregrave, one of His Majeties Serjeants at Arms, told me this
following remarkable Hitory of a Gentlewoman, who was troubled for everal years with the Evil, who alo had divers running Soars about her Arm, he being a Nonconformit and Dienter from our Church, and having very little Faith of His Majeties Touch; but at length, by very great perwaions of her Friends who had found benefit thereof, by their earnet perwaions did gain of her, if poible, to procure His Majeties Touch for the ame. This being in the time of our late King, of Bleed Memory, when he was at Hampton-Court; he goes thither and was healed by him, he having received His Majeties gracious Touch, and a piece of Silver about her Neck, immediatly grew better, and within a mall time afterwards perfectly recovered, o that her Soars dryed up, and he acquitted from all running Iues. But as a very trange Remark hereof, upon the day of our Bleed Soveraigns cruel Martyrdom, her Sores broke out afreh, he being in the Country and hearing nothing of the ame: But within a mall while after they healed up again, and he appeared very well without any appearance of Relape.

Mr. Seymour Bowman ent thee two remarkable Hitories in a Letter to me; the which, becaue I deign to Print nothing but Truth, I do here preent the Reader with a true Copy of the ame: The truth of which he is ever ready to jutifie.

p.q:
TO add to that great Treaure which I undertand you are Inriching the World with, give me leave to contribute two Mites, which may be thus far grateful to you, becaue they are upon my own knowledge. In the Year _____ when the great Treaty was between the late King and Parliament at the Ile of Wight (whether my occaions then called me) His Majety coming home one Evening from the Treaty-houe, a Daughter of one Mr. Stephens (I think his name was) a Citizen of Wincheter, was touch'd for the Evil in her Eye, which as oon as His Majety had done he went to Prayers, (Dr. Hinchman and Dr. Sanderon, ince Bihops of London and Lincoln, officiating) in which time her Eye flew open; at which he her elf being
urprized, told her Mother, who joyfully at the end of Prayers proclaimed it as a Miracle; upon hearing whereof, I asked the Girl about it, he told me he had been blind more than a Fortnight, and Mr. Serjeant Paynter, then chief Chirurgeon in Waiting, aur'd me he look'd upon her Eye to be in great danger. By this time it arriv'd at His Majeties Ear, who came to the Girl as I tood by her, and in my hearing ask'd her how long her Eye had been cloed; he anwered, above a Fortnight: Do you ee now, aid the King? to which he replyed (putting her hand on her other Eye) I ee your Majety; I ee any thing about the Room; at which His Majety pauing awhile, with a kind of Venerable admiration, took her by the hand and kis'd her.

At my return from the Iland, I lodged at Calhot-Catle (which is about the mid-way to Southampton) with my Friend Captain Peter Betteworth, then Governor, who hewed me a young Man, whom he told me had been infirm with the Evil in his Thigh for nine years, that it was very unpleaant to behold, the Fleh being
rotted away to the very bone, o that more than two pounds of fleh (by computation) could not equal one Thigh with the other, and for three years he went with Crutches; o that when he went to the Iland to be touched, it was very troubleom for him to go in or out of the Boat, as both himelf, his Father and Mother acquainted me. This very night after the King had Touched him, and put a hilling about his Neck which he brought with him, and hewed me, his Tents, which were of a very great bignes, fell out of his Wounds, and could not be kept in: In three days he quitted his Crutches, and made ue of a Staff only. In three Weeks he was able to play at Nine pins and run after his Bowl, and in les than a year he went to New-found-land as a Sea-man.
Sir, If you pleae to inert thee amongt the ret of your Miranda, I do aure you they are undoubtedly true, upon the knowledge of,

closer.signed: Your affectionate Friend and Servant, Seymour Bowman.

div.p:
From Mrs. Booky near Charing-Cros London, I had this following of one Mrs. Wet, the Daughter of Sir John Jacob, who being extraordinarily afflicted with the Evil, and perplexed with many running Sores when he was young, and having pent everal Hundreds of Pounds upon Phyitians, Chirurgeons, and the like, all which pretended to give her Cure, which never being effected, (her Mother being very willing to ue all means for her recovery, having no great Opinion of His Majeties Sacred Touch;) but Sir John her Father eeing all their Remedies failed, and mall hopes of amendment could be expected by their Methods, reolves to ue all imaginable means to procure His late Majeties Sacred Touch for her, by waiting on Him when He was at Holmby-Houe in order to the ame. The which he having obtained of His Sacred Majety, bringing with him his own Gold, which the good King was pleaed to put over her Neck; he leaving off her Plaiters he formerly made ue of, and keeping her Sores clean as he was directed by His Majeties Order, her Sores oon healed
of themelves, and he peedily grew trong and well, who for ome time had been o weak and infirm, that he could carce tand or go. Some years after, he leaving off her Gold, her Dieae eized her afreh, by gathering again in one of her Eyes, which proved both very painful and troubleome, her Head welling alo to a very vat bignes, and in few days he grew perfectly blind again. Her Father eeing this trange and frightful change, enquires the reaon thereof, and finding her not wearing the Gold about her Neck which had been given her, did attribute this new and freh appearance of pain and welling to her want of the ame. And although it was ome time before the Gold could be found, he not knowing at preent what was become thereof; yet by diligent earch afterwards finding it again, and he putting it over her Neck, and he wearing the ame, her Swellings uddainly vanihed, he recovered her ight, and has the ue of both her Eyes to this day, being in perfect health.
This following was ent me from a very good Friend of Mr. Bowmans.

p.q: HEaring you are Publihing a Book of the trange Cures done by His late and preent Majety concerning the Evil, give me leave to acquaint you with a remarkable Cure done upon my own Son, about three years of age, the Dieae being o in his Eyes and Face, that he appeared troubleome to the Beholders, and a very uneaie Object to himelf: But he being toucht with a Handkerchief dipt in the late Kings Blood, lent him by one Major Gouge, a Commander then in the Parliament Army, he was in 14 days perfectly cured of his Dieae. And this I aver under my Hand,

div.p: This Letter was brought me by a very good Friend, and a Peron of Quality, who deired my inerting of the ame.

I proceed now to ome of thoe marvellous Cures done by His late Majeties precious Blood, where at this day, as true Devoters to His Sacred Memory, there are many that have affirmed wonderful Cures performed by the ame. And one remark hereof, is that of a Woman at Deptford near London, who was cured of her blindnes, and many other Infirmities, he only being Toucht with a Handkerchief which had been ditained with His late Majeties precious Blood.

Dr. Francis Thompon, D. D. and Chaplain in Ordinary to His Majety, gives me this following Obervation under his own Hand where he writes, That being at Hadham with Mr. King, one of His Majeties Penioners, and going thither to Sir Richard Atkins his Houe, where he oberving a good Picture of a young Lady, Sir Richard told him it was one of his Daughters deceaed, of whom he had a very remarkable
Story to tell him, which was as follows: That a little before the Kings Retauration, his Daughter having a Swelling in her upper Lip, for which he had conulted everal of the mot eminent Phyicians of the City of London, who at lat concluded it to be the Evil, and advied him to go to the King then at Breda or Bruels, to be cured; whereupon preparing for his Voyage, he hapned to dicoure Sir Orlando Bridgeman's Lady, who intimated to him, that there were hopes of the Kings aving him his intended Journy; and that however in the mean time, he would accommodate him with a Handkerchief or Cloath dipt in His Sacred Majeties Blood, which had done everal Cures, which certainly could do his Daughter no hurt, and if he would promie to retore it, he would lend him it, to ee if it might ucceed accordingly with his Daughter as it had with others; upon which he received the ame, and his Daughter frequently tapping her Lip therewith about a week or ten days, or thereabouts, by Gods bleing, and the ue thereof, he was perfectly cured to admiration.

From Sir John Pettus I had this following of Madam Bowyar, who having for many years been troubled with the Evil, and finding no eae by any Medicine whatoever, he not having the happines to come at our late Sacred King, of Bleed Memory, to be Touch'd: and undertanding of his barbarous Martyrdom deigned, he ued all imaginable means, and applyed her bet Interet to gather or collect a little of his pretious Blood; the which he having obtained in a piece of Tiffany, did wear the ame about her Neck, and within a very mall time after her ue of the ame, he was perfectly dicharged from her Dieae, and hath ever ince continued well, and is till alive to confirm the truth thereof: And when he had found this great efficacy thereof on her elf, he lent everal pieces of the fame, which had been likewie ditained with this pretious Blood, and where ever they were applyed to Kings Evil Swellings, they were een uddenly to retreat; and uch as made ue thereof, were as peedily and ucceively cured to admiration.
Since my reception of the aforenamed Hitory from Dr. Thompon, I had this his Letter ent me, wherein as a farther vindication of the former, he gives me two others, as follows;

p.q:
ACcording to your deire, I end you in brief the Import of what we dicoured, abridg'd of ome Circumtances; viz. That I being with Mr. King, one of His Majeties Prioners at Sir Richard Atkins his Houe, when at Hadham: He told us, That one of His Daughters had a Swelling on her upper Lip, which the eminent Phyicians of London concluded was the Evil, and accordingly advied him to repair then to the King at Bruels (or Breda) for Cure. But while he was preparing for his Voyage, he hapned to receive a Cloth dipt in the late Kings Blood, from the Right Honorable the Lady Bridgman (being famous for many Cures) whereby his Daughters Swelling was perfectly abated within a Week or ten Days, by Gods Bleing, only upon her frequent tapping
the affected place with the aid Cloth. Since I told you this, I had it confirmed by my Lady Bridgman in Peron, and by another parallel intance; That in a few days it cured a young Lady near related to her Ladyhip (whoe name mut be uppret) of a Swelling alo on her upper Lip, by dabbing it only with the ame Sacred Gore, being a little wetted therewith.

To which I may add, what I lately heard from an honet Loyal Citizen, of very good reputation in St. Laurence Lane, that a peron went from his Houe o blinded with the Evil, that he could not dicern a Door-place in the Room, when he went out of it, and yet that very Afternoon walked without direction from White-Hall to his houe, after he had been touched by his preent Majety, whom God long preerve; and that he knew everal others touched, and every one cured.

body.closer:
This is all at preent from, Sir,
Your aured Friend and humble Servant, Francis Thompon. From my Houe in Silvertreet near Woodtreet, London, Dec. 21. 1682.

div.p:
There was a Scotch Merchant, who made it his buines every Spring and Fall to bring People from Scotland and Newcatle, troubled with the Evil, to the King where ever he was in his Troubles; as at Bruels, Breda, Bruges, Anwerp, and the like; and before his return from the King, he generally acquainted Serjeant Haynes of His Majeties Chappel (from whom I had this obervation) how thoe Perons were which he carryed back with him, after they had been Touch'd: Amongt the ret of which, he related this remarkable Story, of one amongt the ret that came who was refued a Ticket by the Chief Chirurgeon then in Waiting (where he aured him, that all uch who had obtained His Majeties Touch, received Cure therewith): But this poor Man being denyed the Touch of the King, by reaon of the Chirurgeons not giving him a Ticket, telling him, He had more need of an Hopital than of His Majeties Favor; affirming, That his Dieae had more of the Pox than of the Evil in it: And he making great complaint to Serjeant Haynes of his
hard meaure, with many protetations of his Innocency with all or any Woman-kind, and that he hould think himelf utterly undone if he might not receive the honor of his Majeties Touch with the ret of his Companions, deiring nothing more, they all bringing their own Gold with them. The Serjeant having more pity on him than the Chirurgion, made his application to Dr. Erles on his behalf, that he would pleae to move the King for his being Healed; the which having done, and the King granting his deire, The next time the Merchant came to the King with freh People, he acquainted the Serjeant, that this poor man was perfectly recovered; and although his face was o montrous to view, and accompanied with many deplorable and fetid Ulcers, that he was forced to cover them with green Silk, yet he received that great meaure of health by His Sacred Majety, as any one could expect to enjoy.

When the King was at Bruels, there was a Daughter or two of the Marques of Caraceens, who was Governor
of the Spanih Netherlands, which were brought to be healed by the King for their Evil; both which, within a very little pace of time after the reception thereof recovered to admiration: At the ame time Serjeant Haynes told me, That not only Scotch, Irih, Englih, but everal French, Spanih, Dutch, and Walloons, who were troubled with this Dieae, were all healed by his excellent Healing Faculty.

From Dr. William Payne of Winton, I had this following Narration ent me under his own hand: That he being to wait upon Dr. Erles, Lord Bihop of Sarum, and dicouring of the Evil, Dr. Erles told him, That when he was in Holland with the King, there was brought on a Bed a very infirm Woman, o weakned with that Dieae, that they were all unwilling to uffer her to be brought to His Majeties preence: The Chirurgeons were very much againt it alo, and Dr. Erles himelf did much diwade it, let he hould dye under His Majeties hand, as was very much feared. But upon the Womans earnet deire,
they did acquaint His Majety with her condition and with her requet: His Majety was pleaed to permit her to be brought in, and did touch her, none ever thinking to ee her alive again. Dr. Erles, a few days after walking in the treets, did meet this Woman with a large Basket of Fruit upon her head; he enquired of her the way to ome place whither he had occaion to go: The Woman knowing him becaue he did attend at her Healing, did preently et down her Basket of Fruit, and aid, M ‚Ä¢ yn Heer, Meyn Heer, God bles your good King, and God bles you, I am the Woman that was brought to your King to be Touch'd uch a day, naming the time, and ee how God hath blet me with ucces beyond all hopes, that I am o oon perfectly well and trong as you now ee me. This Dr. Payne had from Dr. Erles own mouth, and doth attet the Relation thereof to be true, as he hall anwer before God. And as a econd Vindication hereof, when I read the ame to the aforementioned Mr. Serjeant Haynes, he tells me he can jutifie the truth hereof, he
at the ame time waiting upon Dr. Erles beyond Sea.

A poor Man that came out of England to Bruges to be touch'd in Flanders for the Evil, by the King when he was there, having a neck as big as four or five necks, and his Head very montrous: He being touch'd by His Sacred Majety, and wahing himelf with the Water. By that time this Man reached Rotterdam, onwards on his Journy to his return for England, taying there two or three days, he ent a Letter thence to Mr. Serjeant Knight then in waiting, that he was dicharged from his Swellings, his Neck abated of his Tumor, and by the advantage of his Touch, he received perfect health and cure. Mr. Tho: Morley, Avenor to his Royal Highnes the Duke of York, gave me this Obervation, being both an Eyewitnes of this Touch, as alo of the Letter ent to Mr. Knight being then at Bruges.
I could mention many other Cures performed by His Sacred Majety in his Exile beyond Sea; but I now proceed to everal Cures acted by Him ince His happy Retauration.

After the Kings Return from abroad, and entring His Royal Throne, where there were frequent Healings at His firt coming, as ometimes three in a week, and thee in great multitudes, as ix hundred at a time, Mr. Serjeant Haynes tells me he hath oberved amongt the ret that many which have been brought perfectly blind to the King to be Toucht, who having received the ame, have been een uddainly cured, and freed from their Ditempers.

One Mr. Edwards, in the Parih of Curry-rivall in Somerethire, who being orely afflicted with the Evil, that both the ides of his Face were Scrophulated and Ulcerated, he being hereby not only made a ad pectacle to view, but his Eyes alo made blind therewith, o much that he could caree ee the Sun or Moon, he coming up to London at His Majeties happy Retauration, in order to be healed
by His Sacred Majety, within ix weeks after His reception of the ame, he was een o whole, that his Eyes regain'd a perfect ight, and his Face was covered with new Fleh like that of a young Child, and lived many years afterwards without any relape. This I had from Mr. Alford of His Majeties Chappel, who will always be ready to make good the ame.

Mr. Butler Miniter tells me of a Country-man, who having a Daughter very much troubled with the Evil, he being about twelve years of age, about the time of His Majeties firt coming into England, he being for ome time made blind therewith, this Country-man getting her Toucht by our Sacred King, he no ooner received the ame, but her Eyes immediately opened, he looked upon the King, and that very hour he was touched he received cure, and hath ever ince continued in perfect health. This he had from the Father of the Child who was thus miraculouly cured.

The ame Mr. Butler tells me, that within a mall time after our Kings coming into England, Elias Ahmole
Eq Comptroler of the Excie, acquainted him with this following Obervation, of one Arrice Evans, who then went generally by the name of Evans the Prophet, who being troubled with a very depicable and blated Face, o that it was not only naueous to view, but very fetid of mell, he coming to Mr. Ahmole to requet the favour of his getting him toucht by His Majety for the ame, he utterly refued it, not thinking him a fit peron to approach His Majeties Preence; and being tript of all hope or advantage from him, as alo from many others which he had endeavoured to procure: He being utterly denyed the attaining the favour of the Kings Preence by any interet of Friends, at lat reolves with himelf (with an aured Faith, that if His Majety did but touch him he hould peedily recover) to attend the Kings coming by him in the uual Walks he takes in St. James's Park; the King at length coming that way, his Face being covered with a Red Cloath, the which he lifted up till he aw the King near him, which he afterwards letting fall down, cries out, I am 'Rie Evans. The
King coming nearer him with his Attendants which waited on Him, ome of them told His Majety that he was His Majeties Prophet; the King coming at him, he kneels down, and cries, God bles Your Majety: The good King gives him His Hand to Kis, and he rubbing his ulcerated and cabbed Noe therewith, which was plentifully tockt with purulent and fetid matter: within two days after his reception of His Majeties acred favour, the aboveaid Mr. Ahmole aw this Evans cured, and his ulcered Noe dryed up and healed. This Mr. Butler tells me he had it from Mr. Ahmole's own mouth.

From Mrs. Waton in Kingtreet Wetminter, I received this of her own Daughter, who was o everely afflicted with the Evil, and her Swellings did arie to that bulk, that they very oft threatned her uffocation, by too cloe compreing the Windpipe, he uing everal means, and all fruitles, at length gets her toucht by our Sacred King; and when all other remedies fail'd her, at His firt touch her Swellings abated, he found peedy eae and relief, and within a hort time
perfectly was cured and dicharged from her Fears and Tumours.

From John Plummer Eq of Windor I had this, of his own Child, who being put to Nure to one Harnetts Wife of New-Windor, who was her elf troubled with the Evil, after his Child had for ome time uckt her Milk, he uckt her Ditemper therewith alo: The Child being Toucht the lat Summer by the King for its Ditemper, did immediately recover thereupon. The great remark hereof is this, That when the Child left the Nures Breat, he her elf fell ill, and grew weak, and for want of her being Toucht as well as the Child, he died of the ame Ditemper within a mall while after the Child had left her.

Mr. George Peryn, Gentleman-Harbinger to His Majety, gives me this Obervation of a Maid coming from Portmouth, the Kings Builders Daughter, who was o mierably afflicted with the Evil, and a Peron o deplorable to view, that he affrighted her Spectators; he coming to Windor to be Toucht, and getting to ee the King at Dinner, her Face being uncovered,
and he being taken notice of, was forc'd peedily to quit her place. This ad Object being within few days Toucht by our Sacred King, he uddainly amended after it, and her Face grew o whole, (which was furnihed with many Ulcers) that there were but very few marks left of her former mierable apect.

From the Earl of Starling I had this following, who told me his econd Son being much troubled with a Scrophulous Swelling in his upper lip, having had the bet advice he could procure from the mot eminent Phyicians and Chirurgeons to conult and advie about the ame, they not giving him any appearance of Cure, advied his Lordhip to get his Son Toucht by the King for the ame; the which ome mall while after he obtained: he no ooner received His Majeties Touch, but received immediate eae therewith, and he hath remained well ever ince.

From the Mayor of Wickham I had this, who having a Son about five years of age very much troubled with the Evil, that he was blind, and could not ee, with a hard Swelling on his
upper Lip, and finding no good by all other means he ued, he brought his Son to Windor to be Touched; which o oon as he had received, his Eyes amended, the Swelling of his Lip abated, and he in a very hort time retored to health, the which he hath ever ince enjoyed without any relape.

Sir Roger Hanet, eldet Serjeant at Arms to His Majety, tells me of a Child of ix years of age, who having everal Evil Swellings about her Neck and Throat, and o perfectly blind that he could neither ee the light of the Candle, Fire, or Sun, he coming to Whitehal to be Toucht, he having been formerly Touched and lot her Gold, her Ditemper eiing her again, upon her econd Healing by His Majety, and new Gold given, her Swellings peedily vanihed, and within two hours were een to leave her, and in fourteen days he was perfectly retored to her former health. Sir Roger undertook her econd Touch, and aw the effects thereof, and will atisfie any man which may quetion the truth thereof.

Mr. Thomas, Clerk of His Majeties Kitchin, acquainted me with this following remarkable Obervation, which was of a poor Girl which came out of the North mierably afflicted with the Evil, to be Toucht by His Sacred Majety; he was o perfectly blind that he was lead to Whitehal, having no ight at all: he having been healed by the King, the Film which covered and obtructed her ight did immediately break: after her Touching, he askt her Mother, Whether he were her Mother? telling her he could ee her. After this he went without any help out of the Banquetting-Houe at Whitehal, and within a little while after the Healing, he aw this Child play with other Children before the moving Wardrobe at Whitehal; and this he is ready to confirm as well as affirm.

John Hebden Eq tells me his Lady, who after a long time having made ue of Phyicians and Chirurgeons to little purpoe, and being by their methods brought o low, that he was not able to go or tand for two or three months together, he being brought in a Chair to the Banquetting-Houe
at Whitehal to be healed by His Sacred Majety for the Evil, he no ooner received the ame, but immediately found a very great change in her elf, and with the reception thereof he likewie received a new trength therewith, o that he walked without any help to the Banquetting-Houe Door, which could not tir or go for two or three months before, and amended peedily upon it, and he in a very hort time arrived at that degree of health, that he grew every day tronger, and is now as well as ever he was in her whole life.

He likewie at the ame time acquainted me of a Neighbouring Fanatick of his at Batterey, who having five Children, and all of them troubled with the Evil at once, the Parents uing everal means, but all proving ineffectual, one of thee Children being got Toucht by His Sacred Majety, by His means did immediately recover of her ditemper: all the other for want of the ame bleing and benefit, died of the like Dieae.

Sir Lionel Waldens Son tells me of one Markham, who having everal Running Sores under his Arm, whence iued out much tinking matter, and a very large Swelling on his Face, he being everal years o weak that he could neither go or ride, he being Touched by the King at Windor, in les than fourteen days he was dicharged from his Swellings, his running Sores dried up, and he hath ever ince continued well and ound.

From Mr. Robert Muryell of Cambridge I had this following, concerning his Brother who there lived, who having for everal years been troubled with Strumous Swellings along his Neck and Throat, he being healed by the King at Newmarket, his Swellings peedily vanihed, and hath ever ince continued in health, and that this Ditemper hath for many years gone along in the Family: he told me of fifteen of his Relations which were afflicted with the Evil, and every one cured by His Majeties gracious Touch; and amongt the ret he likewie aured me that one of his Brethren, who was a Student
in Trinity-Colledge Cambridge, who leaving off his Gold, his Swellings did peedily hew themelves; but no ooner was his Gold put on again, but they were likewie found as readily to vanih.

Mr. Thomas Dunckly, belonging to His Majeties Cloet, aures me that one Mrs. Dorothy Philips, who was mierably vexed with the Evil for many years, and had a very large Strumous Swelling in her left Breat, which afterwards turned to a Scrophulous Ulcer, o large, that he told me he could put his hand thereinto, he being in a very weak and deplorable condition, not able for above ix months together to bring her Watcoat together; and when he had tired all the Phyitians and Chirurgeons he made ue of about her Dieae, he by Dr. Barwick was advied to go to be healed by the King; Mr. Dunckly gets her Toucht, which hapned on a Friday; the Munday following he went down to Loughburrow in Leicesthire, and returned back in a month very well and cured, without any outward application, or inward Phyick, and is at this day
very well, living at the Old Change in London.

Dr. Johnon of Brantry, Rural Dean of Bocking, ending another poor Woman to Mr. Dunckly, in order to his getting her Touch'd by the King for the Evil, which Woman was perfectly blind therewith for above four Months before, o as he was led up and down about the Houe by her Mother; and whenever he went to Church, her Mother was forc'd to lead her thither: This Woman, within a Month after he had been healed by His Majety, he regain'd her Sight, and was in that happy condition, that he evermore led her Mother afterwards to Church.

Mr. John Stephens of His Majeties Back-tairs, acquaints me of a Gun-Smith in Wincheter, who being a Quaker, and very much troubled with the Evil in his Neck, he coming to him to deire the procuring him a Ticket, in order to his being healed by the King: No ooner had this Quaker this Ticket given him, but he tells Mr. Stephens his Faith was o
mall, that he did not believe the Kings Touch could much help him, or that there was any Power or Virtue therein, but reolved notwithtanding to make ue of his Favor. This Quaker no ooner ees the King, but his Spirits immediately raied to a higher degree of Faith, and begot a greater belief in him, telling Mr. Stephens that his mind was quite altered, and he was certain His Majety would heal him. This Quaker, within les than 48 hours after his being Touch'd, was very much amended, and before he could get home, was wholly dicharged from his Swellings in his Neck: and as a publick acknowledgment to Almighty God for his great Cure, he went to the Cathedral Church at Wincheter the firt Sunday following, to pay his publick Thanks: And when he heard the King prayed for, he was taken notice of being more concern'd than at any other part of the Prayers, by lifting up his Hands as a greater and more incere acknowledgment of the extraordinary Bleing he lately received, and is and hath ever ince remained a true Son of the Church.

Marmaduke Ling, in the Parih of North-Petherton in Somerethire, being a School-fellow of the ame Mr. John Stephens, did likewie deire him to procure a Ticket (from Mr. Serjeant Paynter then chief Chirurgeon in waiting) for him, he having o large a Scrophulous Swelling in his Face, being very hard, and montruouly extended, that he cared knew him; he being touched by his Sacred Majety, within 14 days after his Swelling grew oft, and every day became more and more pliable, o that in ix Weeks time it was like the other ide of his Face: And in two years after Mr. Stephens aw him in Somerethire there perfectly well. This and the former, he is ready to make good, when ever asked thereof.

A Servant-maid of my Mother-in-laws living at Enfield, who having a very ill contitution of Body, accompanyed with many Scrophulated Swellings, and Evil Ulcers, and running Sores in both her Legs, being both very noyom and foetid; he having made ue of many Chirurgions
and others, but without any relief; asking my advice, I ordered her to come up to London to be Touch'd by the King for the ame; the which he no ooner received, but found immediate eae, her running Soars oon dryed up, and in a mall while her Swellings abated; he leaving off her Gold, her Swellings began to appear again, as alo a new vent of running, and he her elf became diordered: She craving my advice the econd time, I ordred her evermore to keep her Gold about her Neck, and ever ince he followed my advice, he has had no further appearance of running Iue, Relape, or Trouble.

A Nonconformits Wife, having more Faith in her than her unbelieving Husband, being very much troubled with the Evil, was brought to the King, in my waiting this lat Summer at Windor, to be Touch'd; who although he daily deired her Huband he might come before, he was evermore denyed the ame, he telling her it was a piece of Supertition, and that there was no more Virtue in the Kings Touch than in another
Mans: Her Husbands occaions calling him to take a Journy, he reolves, if poible, to be healed by the King, and was brought into the Preence, he not being able to walk up. I have it for certain, That as her Faith was tronger than her Husbands, o the Effects thereof were as prevalent, whereupon he preently amended, and received great help and comfort. I hould be evermore of this Womans belief, had I been in her condition, and hould always deire with Dr. Fuller, that I might gain the favor of His Majeties Sacred Touch, and the happines of being Healed by him; where I ought alo to joyn gratitude to God the Author, and all humble thanks to His Sacred Majety the Intrument of my recovery.

I having the great Honor of firt waiting on His Sacred Majety at his Chappel Royal at Windor on my Knee, at which time was above forty mierable and charitable objects of Charity, as both Scotch, Welh, Irih, and Englih, which were troubled with the Evil; many or mot of which did find preent eae and cure:
